description:
New York style pizza. It's quick, it's fast, it's delicious.

I added mushrooms for a dollar and they piled on the sliced button mushrooms, pretty generous.

The only gripe I have is that I wish they served it on plates instead of wax paper because it was kinda hard to pick up without all the mushrooms falling off. But then again maybe I wasn't eating it right and should've folded it over...
author: Mimi T.

description:
It was ok. The guy working was rude. Sure, I get it. Drunk people come through, I'm sure they are annoying but you don't to rudely point out that there is a line behind someone when they weren't even being rude/obnoxious themselves. Let them take their time.

Pizza was kinda burnt and was pretty average tasting.
author: Kelly G.

description:
According to multiple sources, Arinell's is *the* place to get *real* NY pizza. It only took me 8 years to make it here, but better late than never.

I have to say, being a NY pizza snob, I was not impressed. It's not the right shape (pie isn't round, so slices aren't properly triangular), the crust doesn't have the right texture, wrong cheese, not enough grease, etc.

That being said, it was fine pizza. It's just not NY pizza.
author: Sherry L.

description:
Came here for a late dinner bc it opens until 2am. Got a slice of their cheese pizza with mushrooms which I believe were an extra dollar. Total was $4. They heated it up in the oven and it was ready in a few minutes. 

The mushrooms were definitely worth the extra dollar because the pizza was loaded up with mushrooms. Every bite I took there was mushroom. Loved it. The pizza was thin and crunchy but not too hard where your jaw will pop out. Crust was still very chewy and crunchy at the same time. It was very delicious affordable meal. If I were in the area, I'd definitely be back.  

would also like to point out that we came on the last day before prices changed~
author: Cecilia Y.

description:
AYYY I'M WALKIN HEAAHHHH

you'll feel like you're in New York getting a fresh slice from the street. It's super cheap, the slices are bigger than my head (and I have a giant head). One downside is that it's cash only. Delicious, wonderful pizza. If I was younger and went out more in the mission, this would be my spot.
author: Samir K.

description:
This place is fire.  That is all. Oh also this spot is CASH ONLY. 
Located in the mission district which every Uber driver said was safe but it felt a little sketch. Haha but it was no problem Pizza was so good. Great late night slice as I believe they are open until 3 or so. I was there pretty late.
author: Gabriel C.

description:
So freaking good. Hole in the wall, you duck in, order what you want and wait. The only reason why this place didn't get 5 stars is because of how they wrap the to go slices. My husband ordered a NY slice and I got the Sicilian with mushrooms. I was honestly expecting those slice boxes or at least a paper plate. Unfortunately we were walking about 6 blocks back to our place and we had one piece of wax paper each to hold our pizzas. Ours hands were burning, grease was dripping, and by the time we had gotten to our place the pizza was cold. 

However! the NY slice was very good, thin, crust crispy the way it should be. The Sicilian was thicker and square, the mushrooms were well seasoned and overall I enjoyed it immensely. 

The guys are no-nonsense, no BS, order and get the F out types, be prepared for what you're going to order and quick about it. 

Parking is horrible, try to walk. Also cash only!!
author: Amy K.

description:
Bottom Line: Wow this place is pretty good for "NY Style Pizza!" 3.25 for a slice- a little pricey. Very small sit down area- take slice to go. Cash Only.

Pizza: The pizza itself was one of the closer I've had to NY style pizza since being in California- ayeeee! The crust is a little bland though, but I got past that quickly taking a taste of back home. The slice isn't huge for the 3+ dollars, but it's cheaper than spending $20 for a meal in the area, amirighttttt.

Atmosphere: Very hipsterish. I mean, rock music, grungy atmosphere. It's not bad, I just didn't want to stay I there given the mood I was in at the time.

Come here for a slice or a quick eat before bar hopping!
author: Tristina B.

description: Classic east coast style pizza place that you would find on the boardwalk in New Jersey.  The pizza is good, basic but not greasy like back east.  6 stools for seating; 9 toppings; Regular and Sicilian ( sort of); a dive.
author: Steve L.

description:
CASH ONLY.

Best thin crust pizza in SF, according to my friend. We were going to a show nearby and wanted to grab something quick on our way, so we stopped by Arinell as it's conveniently located close to the 16th St BART station.

Ordering is very straightforward; you start with a basic slice of cheese pizza and can add additional ingredients for a cost. Then they'll stick it in the oven so that the pizza slice gets nice and toasty.

Food-wise, I was impressed with how the crust of the pizza had a nice crunch to it despite its thinness. I wasn't a huge fan of the sausage which tasted bland and hadn't warmed up completely in the oven since it was cut very thick, but overall the slice of pizza hit the spot and was exactly what we wanted before our show.
author: Dianna H.

description: I'm originally from NYC and this is probably the closest you can get to a decent NYC-style slice joint in SF.  If there's another place that comes closer, I haven't come across it.  I've searched high and low for decent pizza in the Bay Area, coming up short time and time again.  This is the one place that has come closest to what I might find at a slice shop back in NYC.  That being said, if this place were actually in NYC, it probably would change my take on it entirely.  It's also not the most consistent; sometimes it's good and other times it's not as good.  I suppose it depends on who's making the pies.
author: Sel C.

description:
Really good pizza for the price.  Very quick, fast, and easy.  I had the pepperoni and cheese slices and they were more than enough.  Very big slices but thin crust of course.

There were 2 guys that were working who looked like they hated their jobs.  I wish they had left my slices in the oven for like 30 seconds longer but it was still pretty good.
author: Jane C.

description:
This is definitely one of the better NY slices in town IMO.  $3.25 for a cheese slice is a bit steep even though they give you a big slice.

I had a slice of cheese and it was pretty good.  It couldve stayed in the oven for an extra 20 - 30 seconds bc it was luke warm.  Also, they could have used a tad more marinara sauce.

Their pepperoni was also pretty good.  The pepperoni tasted a bit more processed and not very authentic.  This also couldve stayed in the oven for an extra 20 - 30 seconds bc it was luke warm.  They also could have used a tad more marinara sauce on this as well.

I would definitely be back!
author: Jang N.

description: This is a place to get slices and not to camp out and have a dinning experience. It's in and out place. This spot is a spot to get slices after drinking .They have delicious Sicilian pizza slices and cheese and pepperoni thin New York slices . The service is not for everyone. The may be vacant. What do you expect from a place which had punk rock culture since the 80's in San Francisco.
author: Juan V.

description:
This was the first place I ate at when I came to San Francisco from NJ in 1994. I've been coming ever since. Its as good as the best places on the NJ - NY area. 

Now if only, with all this technology, someone can figure out how to get Arinells delivered. None of these services can pick up food for you unless the place is already in their system. Except for maybe task rabbit but thats kind of a pain. Whatever happened to waiters on wheels, weren't they filling this void? Anyway kudos to Arinells I guess for out smarting tech. Its appropriate with all the death metal and hate music those guys are always blasting in there.
author: H K.

description:
I'll update with a picture of my slice the next time because I come here fairly often. I can't believe I haven't written a review here yet, I even already bought an Arinell t-shirt last year.

Arinell's is dope. Tonight's thin cheese slice was especially on point.

This is my favorite slicery in the mission. I just grab a slice of the thin cheese, they heat it up, and I take a seat, and enjoy. They have oregano, garlic powder, crushed red chilies, salt, pepper, all the seasonings, but you don't really need it because the pizza is so good. But I always put crushed red chili on pizza. 

I haven't tried the fat pizza yet, as I only always get the NY style thin.
author: Shruti D.

description: Is there a better slice of NY pizza in SF? I would say no.  Sure the service is slow and surley- cash only and no delivery but one bite of the pizza and all other negatives melt away.  I spent 10 years looking for better in SF and have come to the conclusion that the search always ends at 17th and Valencia
author: Matthew S.

description: Good pizzaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa!!!! I loved it. Thank you for being open late and feeding me pizza! It's so good. Mmmmmm. You guys rock!
author: Bryce Y.

description:
The guy who claims to own the place came out of the store and told me, while I was playing guitar, that I should "f*** off" using profanity right in front of customers. Most decent business owners know to handle a situation in a more professional manner and simply ask if I could play a bit further away and I always comply gladly. I hope more people see this mans true colors.
(Update: I did some personal investigation and found that the guy who told me to f*** off lied about owning the place. The rude guys name is Henry and is new. The owners name is Ron.)
author: Cory H.

description:
Cousin Syd's favorite Pizza Joint that he always goes out of the way for. 

There is no delivery. 

It's New York Style. It's thin slices, (but they have deep dish too). 

No sugar & No Msg. Only Salt in the leavening process.

His tip is to let the cheese cool for about half an hour 
(Idk why.. I just want my pizza hot, there is an explanation though).

Not bad. They do take awhile to make.
author: Lilian L.

description:
Simple and unpretentious while also authentic and delicous. Possibly the best slice in the city and easily the best NY style. I used to live in NYC and its better then most of the slices there as well. Its a small pizza counter on the outskirts of the mission with a cook and cashier both of which were friendly. 

NY Slices are paper thin, foldable, crisp, a bit greasy and taste amazing. I didnt try the heavier Sicilian this time. I ordered a slice of cheese and after loving it went back for a 2nd of pepperoni. Your pretty much limited to cheese and pepperoni no huge menu of Hawaiian, cali styles, and other bs but what they do they do right. 

Thin golden crunchy and great cheese and sauce. Didnt have the blackened clay char I usually look for but didnt need it crust was good with a crisp but not brick hard outside. Plenty of oregano, parm, and toppings as well. Highly recommended!
author: Sean G.

description:
I'm on a search to find the best New York style pizza in the San Francisco Bay Area 
This is the second place I've been to and when I walked in they had regular slices and they had some yummy looking Sicilian pizza. Had to try the Sicilian pizza! And I'm going to tell you it was the best damn Sicilian pizza I've had so far. I will be back to try the regular slice and if it pleases me they will get that extra star
author: Erin L.

description:
The hubby loves pizza places like this one. You go in, point to the pizza you want (thick or thin crust), they heat it up for you, and soon you are eating your pie rather than waiting 20-30 minutes for it. You can choose from a variety of toppings or just have their cheese pizza as my husband did. I prefer their thin crust, and I like mine simple with just pepperoni. We've been here twice now and I'm sure we'll be returning at some point. 

This is a cash only place so make sure to have a few bills with you. It's also tiny with only a few high stools against the wall and little standing room for people waiting to order or waiting for their pizza. You may have to take your pizza with you if you happen to catch this place when it's busy.
author: Hazel C.

description:
I've been passing by here for literal decades and Friday was the first time I recall coming here. I hit up their Berkeley spot every once in a while but for some reason I never really stopped into this spot. Hell, I didn't even know it was related to the one in Berkeley until I actually looked up at the sign.

Anyway, I knew that I'd be having some drinks before getting on the Bart and I wanted to get something cheap and quick to help soak up the suds so I stopped in here. 

I just ordered a cheese slice and when it came out of the oven, it was super hot and the thin crust was crispy - just like I remembered in college. I sat and ate it in the inside counter. The slice was a pretty decent sized and it was exactly what I needed.

I think I'll stop here more often, especially if I'm coming out of Casanova.
author: Art O.

description: This place is straight fire. The slices are so big that my boyfriend has trouble fitting all three on the counter. Sometimes he just has to get two before he goes back for a third.
author: Ryce S.

description:
Mouthwatering thin crust fat slice pizza. It basically melts in your mouth. Kind of on the greasy side but that's good right? Definitely a hang over cure and preferably fresh out of the oven. 
Limited selection of toppings but excellent customer service to make up for it. Thanks guys!
author: Sahar N.

description:
This pizza was mediocre at best. Despite receiving a slice from a fresh pie out of the oven, the crust was like a cracker - when I attempted to fold the pizza it would break apart and thus was not foldable. Ended up having an oddly shaped chunk of pizza broken off from my slice.

I think the only thing going for it is that it's a decent value relative to a Slice House $5 slice.
author: Brendan Edwin C.

description: I just moved to SF into the mission district from St. Louis, not even knowing what the mission was. Being a pizza snob, and not having found any good pizza in STL, I've been craving GOOD pizza. On today's run, I chose a new route and ran past the aroma of delicious cheese and red sauce! After my run, I walked over a mile to find the aroma. Finally seeing a pizza place I walked in, but the smell wasn't right. I kept walking and saw Arinell. Upon waking in, I knew I found it. OMG, this is REAL NY pizza. Sooo good! This is now my go-to pizza spot! The guys inside are totally cool. So glad I went for that run. Lol.
author: Larry G.

description: GREAT NY Style Pizza ! Not To Mention A Genuinely Colorful Crew And Atmosphere . Funky Cut Slices , Pepperoni, Cheese , Sicilian ...
author: Gregory P.

description: Been coming here since it opened in the 80's. Still da best pizza and you can get slices while you wait for your entire pie of deliciousness. Real east coast style!
author: Ida Slapter D.

description:
If you like thin-crust NY style pizza, this is your place. Seriously, I didn't think anyone in this city knew how to make east coast style pizza until I had a slice here. No frills, pretty cheap, and very yummy. $2.25 for a big plain cheese NY slice. 

The pizza is worth 5 stars, but taking off 1 star because they don't deliver. Parking is terrible there, so who would drive there to pick up a pizza. The pizza would get cold if I walked to get it. I've only ever gotten it by the slice but would order a pie probably every other week if they delivered.
author: Mike C.

description: Got served cold pizza. Asked to warm it up. Were pointed out at how many people are in line behind us and had to wait. Meanwhile a friend slipped and fell and spilled lots of water. We cleaned, no help or questions if our friend is OK. Next we got asked to leave. You are welcomed for the excellent tip for 6 people.
author: Axel E.

description: Came here at 11:20 on a Thursday (closes at 12) and they said they ran out of pizza .... UGHHH make more?!?!
author: Carrie L.

description: Be prepared for rude, indifferent service and to be served from people with poor hygiene. I stood there waiting for at least a minute while two workers chit chatted behind the counter. A third employee came in and went behind the counter. Of course, since this is a dive joint, he didn't wash his hands before asking me what I want. I asked for a corner slice of Sicilian from a fresh pie. He said that he couldn't cut that piece because I t would ruin the pie. Doesn't pizza by the slice get cut up anyway? I used to come to this place because it's the closest to New York style pizza that I've been able to find.  Never again.
author: WINNIE B.

description: Awesome pizza. Overly obnoxious and terrible service. Our cashier was wasted, really wasted. I'm just getting a slice. I don't need to remember the interaction. But seriously.
author: Sarim T.

description: Yum! Great for a late night slice. Fast and easy. Inexpensive. Fun and friendly woman working the counter.
author: Vicki L.

description:
Closest thing to NY style pizza in san francisco !! It will not be the greatest pizza you ever ate, but for what its price, availability, It is pretty darn good! 
Crispy paper thin airy crust.                                       Checked
creamy goey mozarella                                              Checked
ny style tomato sauce                                                Checked
Slightly sweet dough crust from long fermentation   Checked
3$ something for a big slice of pizza                         Checked
Standing in stool for quick grab and go                     Checked

sounds like NY pizza to me....
author: Dan A.

description:
I can't explain the emotions when I get near this place. It's like a mix of nostalgia and excitement all wrapped in one. 

THIS PLACE IS THE BOMB.COM!!!!!!!!!! 

It's crazy how hole-in-the-wall this place is! I really didn't know it was even here! I thought Golden Boy pizza took the cake, but DAAAAAAAMN first bite I took of a Sicilian ("deep dish") and its like a dance in my mouth and brain all over. The pizza comes in 2 categories, sicilian and neopolitan ("thin crust"), and only is made as classic cheese. When you come up to order you can then ask for extra toppings (at an additional charge) which will be added to your "X" number of slices. Love the fact that it's get in - get out atmosphere so people grab their stuff and go. Usually exceptionally popular at all times of day I've been.

Pretty cool OG concept, AMAZING classic taste, and great people! Will be a fan for LYYYYFE~
author: Daniel O.

description: Came here last night at 1 am for some late night drunchies and man the pizza was delicious!! I ordered a slice of the pepperoni pizza and was pleased to try their famous NY style pizza. Would DEFINITELY go back to try some more.
author: Prasiddha H.

description:
Might have been just what was on offer at the moment but, looking for their usual delicious thin crust NY-style pie, ended up with a doughy if decent slice of pepperoni.  
Bonus:  got a nice slice of pesto thrown at me by a young woman who didn't want to share the lone shakers of pepper and parmesan for two seconds.  It landed nicely on the bench, and a homeless guy was happy to see it out the door.
author: Warren J.

description:
The onions, garlic, and bell pepper toppings are served raw on the pizza (wtf???). Pizza itself (the cheese and bread) is mediocre at best; it's no better than Domino's and maybe worse. For 3 slices with 3 toppings each was over $15 (???). 

Also, the customer service was awful. The dude was rude and extremely sassy. As in, worse than +90% of cashiers and servers.

This place sucks, honestly.

These 2 employees that served these raw toppings and awful service were working at 5PM on 09/30/17. Please fire them.
author: Jared G.

description:
Cash only
Above average NY pizza for SF. 
Interior is small to nonexistent and very dirty. 
The guy who ussually manages the front and takes your order and wears a green hat is a prick.
I'll probably still end up coming back since there isn't much better around the mission
author: Alex R.

description:
Went in at 6pm when it was not busy at all. Asked how many pizzas I should order for a lunch for 12 employees. One person said 3-4 large pies, but his coworker decided he should sarcastically step in and tell me to order lots of pies, "like I should probably order 500 no 600 pies right now". He continued talking and laughing and I walked out. Nice way to treat potential business. 

There is no food so delicious that it's worth poor treatment. Definitely left an impression I'll share with business people  and locals.
author: Christina D.

description:
We ordered pizza by the slice, which was a base cheese pizza with each additional topping at a hefty $.50. The fact that they simplify sprinkled on raw garlic and onions made this decent pizza far worse; I'm really not sure if that's actually how the pizza is supposed to be made here or if the employees who made it prepared it incorrectly.
The employees were rude as well adding insult to injury.
author: Ariel W.

description:
Went in today (9/22) with my wife.  Got service from a overweight dude with a pony tail.  Asked for two slices of cheese. Normally they always heat the pizza up so I thought it might've just come out of the oven.  I took a bite and it was barely warm.  We returned and asked the guy to heat it up and he started giving us a hard time about it and threw our food around like it was trash.  While we were waiting there he started mocking me to his skinny coworker. It took every once of me not to retort since my wife is pregnant.  

Honestly, I love this place. I tell everyone its my favorite pizza joint in SF.  Pathetic POS like this ruins great businesses.  I'd say fire him but don't. I want to come back to see his smug face and hear what he has to say when my wife's not there.
author: David F.

description:
Yummiest pizza ever. Good price. Excellent customer service. We went at a slower time. Kids had the Sicilian as it was ready. They offered to put free toppings on it. 
We waited for a fresh pie. And had two slices and then two more. Kids had another slice of the Sicilian. And when we ordered our last slice to share he said it was on the house. Never got that kind of service in San Francisco where we've even paid for getting extra sauce. Wow!


April 2018
We love the pizza here. This time they said it will be 12 minutes for the next pie. We pre-paid and waited. The pie came out. He cut it in quarters. And then picked up the largest quarter to give to us and then put it down and picked up the smallest one and cut it in two to give to us. I watched the entire show and was curious and asked why. He said he was thinking if we left a tip or not. It is a cash only place. No service had been rendered yet and he wanted a tip when we paid. Wow??!! We tip AFTER the meal is over not before. My husband still left a tip despite my protests. We won't be going back for a while.
author: Su S.

description:
$3 a slice of NY-style pizza! Burning your fingers had never been so worth it! The crust is crunchy and the cheesy is gooey and the tomato sauce is delicious. I sprinkled on some red pepper flakes to give it a little kick! What more can you ask for?

Cash only!
author: Hoyan L.

description:
What the heck, this place ONLY serves cheese pizza and you have to pay for toppings? And it's just two kinds of crust, thin crust and Sicilian style??

Well, it's still ridiculously amazingly delicious and our stumbling upon this place was quite possibly the most amazing experience I have had on a slightly inebriated pizza run. 

First, it's cash only- however, that's usually a sign of a good joint for some reason. However, this pizza was super incredible. The dough was flavorful by itself, the crust was crispy and amazing (I had the thin version) and the cheese could have been a little more but it was super tasty and stretchy and ooey gooey. The sauce is something you can go home and dream about as well.

They have a good thing going and I hope they don't ever change! This place was a dream. Will be back for more.
author: David T.

description:
The closest thing to New York thin-crust pizza in the city. Don't be a shmuck and get toppings on your slice-o-happiness, stick with the plain cheese slice. $3.25 is a small price to pay for a light, airy, crispy, and at the same time fulfilling cheese slice that's a harmonious balance of crust, sauce, and mozzarella. 

Also, this is the only "restaurant" in the city that I will tolerate a cashier calling each slice of pizza coming out of the oven a "f*cker". No joke, Friday night 11pm with 2 guy friends. We walk in, order 3 slices and wait. As each slice comes out piping hot, the cashier with hipster tats, buzz cut, and piercings YELLS "Alright alright folks, we got ONE f*cker, now TWO f*ckers, and BA DA BING THREE f*ckers. Come grab these f*ckers." 

Sir, I'll be back for more f*ckers, guaranteed.
author: Thankie S.

description: It's not really great pizza I rather go to supreme pizza on 18 th. It's better the slices are huge this shit is crap
author: Iz F.

description: Best NY slice in Berkeley; this is a good replica. Needs to be folded, as it should be, and doesn't over complicate the menu. It's great, thin-crust pizza.
author: Sam G.

description: This is real east coast pizza! It's way to hard to find out here and I thought I wouldn't find it, but I did. I love this pizza.
author: G F.

description:
Super bare bones, "New York style" pizza place. ::Insert arrogant "I'm a NY'er so I would know" line here:: The Neapolitan holds up.

I'm choosing to view several things that would normally be negatives as positives in this case. When I went on a Thursday night, nobody said anything and I had to discern for myself that we were waiting for the Neapolitan to come out of the oven (there was a Sicilian in the window). The window has enough space basically for one regular and one Sicilian at a time, and that's it. People who ordered toppings had them just thrown on without re-heating.

So essentially your choice is "plain Neapolitan or plain Sicilian" and that's it. I'm okay with that, you might not be. I actually kinda like that your choices are so limited. If ordering a full pie of course, I'd assume the topping situation would be different. The pizza doesn't need toppings though. In fact, one of the guys said "bad choice" when somebody ordered toppings.
author: J.P. M.

description:
I can see why a lot of people like it here, super fast, relatively cheap, and a huge slice of cheese pizza and added toppings for extra 0.50 each. I guess I'm just not a personal fan of really thin pizza. I hope hoping the cheese would ooze but it didn't either. 
Very tiny joint, so don't expect seats. 
The guy working is extremely nice though, so there's that :)
author: Vence M.

description: The one star would be for the pizza it's ok something fast and cheap the guys that work here are complete trash. I run a service establishment and I would fire every single one of my employees if they acted like this!! I first walked in the guy said what's up?? What would you like? I asked him what you could put on the pizza he rolled his eyes and pointed to the menu. I ordered a slice of Pizza with pepperoni and he took off the pizza from the front put pepperoni on it and put it in the over to reheat it? Once ready threw it on the counter walked away. No gloves worn not washing hands after I handed him cash! They too worried about talking about the "chick that one picked up and if he had relations with her?!!" Don't care about customers at all save your money if you want at least ok service you can get better service at Burger King then here!!!
author: Brandee D.

description: I was born and raised in Brooklyn, and Arinell's has been the closest thing I've had to a true NY slice since moving to the Bay. The biggest difference was in the crust. Arinell's is more buttery and fluffy than a typical Brookyln slice, but that's not a bad thing. It's super tasty and the pizza still retains its shape when you fold it (an important sign of the real deal). The price ($3.25 for a slice and $0.50 or $1.00 for toppings, depending on what you pick) is incredibly reasonable. This place has been open for 42 years, apparently--and for good reason.
author: Jeremy Y.

description:
The best. Arinell is not only the best NY style pizza, but the best pizza I've ever had. I've tried finding a suitable Arinell replacement (outside of NYC!) for 8 years now with no success; nothing comes close to their recipe. Their slices are large, perfectly thin and gooey, with just the right amount of cheese. The sauce is not too tangy, not too sweet, just perfect.

I used to frequent the Arinell in Berkeley back when I lived a few blocks away, but now it is quite a commute to the Valencia branch. Although it's always worth the trip, I do wish there was more than one location in San Francisco!
author: J L.

description:
The thin crust pizza here is an awesome deal at $3 a slice (cash only)! Each slice is huge - practically 2 slices. 

Last time was 5 stars for me but it might have been because the pizza came right out of the oven. It's still super good and I'll definitely keep coming back when I'm looking for a cheap meal or craving pizza.
author: Linda X.

description:
I'm a transplant from NY. Best pizza in SF hands-down. No ham. No pineapples. No deep-dish. It's thin crust NY style pizza. Unfortunately, I don't live close by or else I'd be there every other day. 

The sauce is the best I've come across. It is authentic. The cheese melts the right way--not too thick, not burnt, not undercooked and chalky, not too thin and has that sexy elasticity when you bite and pull away from it (I don't know about the last pie of the day but I'm certain you'll be wise enough to know it might not be like the ones earlier in the day). That glorious orange oil that develops from the tomatoes and oil during the cooking process for the sauce which can pool in some areas is just right (don't mop that up with napkins--it's part of the love).

The crust is 99% right but I blame that on the Pacific air. I learned this because I have tried my tried and true NY crust recipes here and for some ungodly reason, it just doesn't work all the way and this is for most breads here as well. NY pizza crust shouldn't be bready, nor spongy, sweet, nor thick. It should be thin, hold up the pizza when fresh, crack just a bit so when you fold it it breaks at the seam, has a touch of salt, has some black spots underneath (unless when you use cornmeal under the pie in the oven) and when you get to the crust, it should look like a cross section of a toasted American English muffin. 

I know it's a long review but the hardest things to make are with the least ingredients. You can't get away with bad pizza unless you're going to load it up with all kinds of things to mask it. Even NY has meh pizza but I think they exist for people with no taste for the real deal. 

Hole-in-the-walls often are the hidden treasure for food establishments. So they don't have tablecloths, salad forks and fingerbowls--you knew that coming in. And if you didn't realize that, well...what can I say?
author: S Y.

description:
This is one of my two favorite NY style pizzas (Tony's in North Beach being the other) in SF. I have read and laughed at some of the reviews- this is not fine dining, there is no Maitre D'. 

This place is as real as it gets in SF- A couple of stools, pizza oven, and the product is great greasy pizza. Fold it in half, don't drip grease on your shoes, and enjoy!!!!
author: gary m.

description: Ordered a slice. Asked for a box and offered to pay for it. Was refused the option to pay for a box. Took my slice home and it was smashed and destroyed in the paper bag they gave. I was happy to pay for a box but it was literally refused. Snobbery to the max.
author: reza n.

description: After hearing how great this place was, and how so much like an East Coast Pizzeria it was, I was incredibly disappointed. The pizza is absolutely tasteless! It's a good thing they put out separate shakers of salt and pepper, garlic, oregano, and other seasonings. That should have been a hint!! The "service" was awful, if practically non-existent! Not only that, but it is not a sanitary place. The guy who handled my pizza, without gloves, was also shaking hands with someone who said he just had come down with the flu. Yuck! This was the first and the last visit for me.
author: Rob S.

description: Best NY style pizza in SF, hands down! Pepperoni is deliciously thin, floppy, and greasy just like back east! Pickup and cash-only (no delivery), but worth the trek. Walk-in slices also available. NOTE TO OWNER... Would be 5 star, but without fail (over 20 orders) phone customer service leaves a lot to be desired. Turn down the music and/or get a louder phone instead of asking your customers to speak up with a half-disgusted tone!
author: Brian G.

description: I was skeptical about this place as I've tried many places that claim to have New York style pizza outside of New York and have been disappointed many of times. But this pizza was is closest to New York pizza that I have found outside of New York so
author: O K.

description:
The pizza is cheap, but at what price? 
Rude hipster who play with his hair and after make a pizza? Giving change and topping pizza after? The worst was this guy with his long hair, instead of being polite he was bothered and I had to listen"give me a moment" for fix his hair while I had wait and listens to their bullshits. Hygiene 0 ..Surprised is still open...Dirty place, I agree!
author: Maria s.

description: I passed by one day for some pizza and it was pretty tasty. I ordered a slice of pepperoni and a soda and it was quite inexpensive. The place looks clean and the cashier was friendly. When I went there was no line. If you're in the area and want some pizza you should definitely pass by.
author: Manuela G.

description:
I read about this place being one of the cheapest place to eat. A cheese pizza for $3 is really cheap considering the high cost of living in the city.  With that in mind, I didn't have high expectations on the pizza.  The place is a hole in the wall.  The guys behind the counter were rocker dudes that gave me this impression "Whatever.  Take it or leave it".  I came for the pizza anyways.  Wasn't going there to make friends.  

I ordered a slice with mushrooms.  The slice is pretty big.  However, the pizza was okay.  The mushroom was still a bit cold after it was warmed up in the oven.  The taste was really nothing special.  It won't wow anyone.  It tasted similar to frozen pizza I get at Safeway.  However, I walk out still satisfied because of it size and it didn't break the bank.  

If you are looking for something to munch on or to fill your stomach up,  then this is the place for you.  If you are looking for fine dining that wows you, this is not the right place for you.
author: Paul C.

description:
Arinell Pizza is one of those places that looks like a random whole in the wall but guess what? It's by far my favorite pizza in SF! So so delicious. I have my memories living above the location in downtown Berkeley but the Mission location is just top notch. 

The cheese, sauce, and in my experience the pepperoni are soooooo good. Incredible and true New York style slice. Pro tip, ask for it well done. Highly highly recommend.
author: Diego A.

description:
A quick grab of a slice. 6 stools is all. Crankin' tunes & characters all the way !
Great pie & sauce. Thumbs up all the way !
author: Scotty L.

description: Good pizza but the dumb tattooed moron wouldn't let in our support dog with identification and the letter from a doctor. Clearly he doesn't understand much at all.  Hopefully they lose their lease soon. Truly an idiot
author: Amir S.

description: A little hole in the wall on Valencia,  I think the sign above the door is as big as the shop.  The Pizza slices are kind of small but they are a great no-frills snack.  The help sometimes looks like they have been imported from New York.  They are friendly enough but not perky which is good.  When you just want to grab a slice and go you don't want someone all perky so this is the place to go.
author: Kevin A.

description:
Drove across the city to get pick up one of these pizzas.  The pizza was great, but it was the service that really pushed this up to 5 stars.  

The cashier took the time for engage and interact with my daughter, who I was trying to get to speak up and figure out the change.  He was so positive and encouraging towards her that she was not afraid to interact.  Bravo!
author: Terence L.

description: Dude. The pepperoni slice totally hits the spot. It's perfect. Get it. You won't regret it. And you can't be the price and how fast you get your food.
author: Jenny E.

description: Want a slice of cheese or pepperoni pizza, this is your place.  Want a slice of pepperoni and sausage, or any combination of toppings? What kind of crazy person orders more than one topping, take your business elsewhere, buddy. I've ordered my share of pizza from Arinell, but twice now I've been told no more than one topping allowed.  This Saturday night, I dared to request two slices of pepperoni, sausage, and mushroom. I was told one topping only since there was a line waiting. I looked behind me and there was one person waiting to order.  It's crazy because the cashier's only job is to take your order and put toppings on your pizza. But apparently, he did not agree to more than one topping as a condition of his employment.  I don't care that he's high as hell, not friendly, and thinks we all suck, but at least let me order and pay the extra money for the pizza I want.  Or just rename the place, Arinell "home of imaginary lines and one topping only pizza."  I normally tip $4, but implemented my own "nothing extra" rule for this special occasion.
author: James L.

description:
I found myself in the Mission and craving some pizza, and quickly stumbled across Arinell's. 

It is small. It really isn't much to look at. I absolutely loved it. 

We walk in to the super small dining area and were greeted by punk music blasting, and the guy behind the counter nonchalantly saying "sup man, what do you need." It reminded me of what I loved about going to Telegraph Ave. in Berkeley before it was taken over by chain stores and fine dining. 

We ordered two pepperoni slices, which were promptly popped into the oven and were hot and ready in less than 5 minutes. They were uneven, asymmetrical and delicious.

This place tapped into a special place in my heart for angsty, young, me and though nothing about it is "spectacular" or "amazing," that is precisely who I enjoyed it so much. The only reason for not giving 5 stars is because it is a Cash Only establishment, and I never carry cash on me.
author: Michelle P.

description: This place has some amazing pizza. The guys working night are cool and friendly. Definitely recommend
author: Jacob M.

description:
The pizza is really good, but dudes who work there are constantly high super rude, dirty douchebags. There were several occasions that annoyed me at this place before, but was trying to simply ignore it. I gave up when one day we've ordered our slices and sat down to eat and the music is usually pretty loud at this place anyway, but this time they turned it super loud, to the point when it was unbearable and impossible to talk. I asked them politely to turn it down a little bit, but all I got was a sarcastic look, laugh and then being ignored. Now, I know it's not a restaurant and that dudes who work there are not the smartest on the planet, but...damn. It doesn't matter how good your pizza is, it's not worth it.
Just FYI I was a loyal costumer who was going to that place for 5 years and was always tipping, bringing people there and was nothing but kind. It used to be my favorite pizza place, but no more.
author: Kat M.

description:
We absolutely loved this pizza place! First of all, it was very inexpensive. It cost the both of us about $25  to eat, which is significantly cheaper than what we would have found at most other places. Second, the pizza itself was awesome. We loved it so much that after we ordered and ate our first individual slices, we went back to the counter and ordered a whole pizza for the two of us! 
The thin crust is great, and the cheese pizza was a winner. We'll definitely be back the next time we are in town!
author: Allison A.

description:
My group and I visiting SF had been looking for some good pizza for lunch and went to the fancy place across the street and hated the pizza. Since we were still hungry and had already dropped $24+ on a nasty pizza, we decided to check out Arinell's. The slices were cheap and I liked it, but I had a few concerns.
The guys there were super hot and helpful, but it seemed like they were lazy. Lazy with their service and manners. Then, I ordered my slice with extras. The guy who was taking the cash and working the register took my slice and added my extra veggies, but didn't bother to wear gloves or wash his hands for that matter. Then continued to touch money. 
The food was good for the price but I'm still annoyed that they didn't have a boss around to keep an eye on them.
author: Sara S.

description: solid thin N.Y. style pizza in SF. My friend is from the east coast and gave it her blessing. It's so think I wouldn't feel bad eating a large by myself. Lol will definitely be back.
author: Kat V.

description:
The simplicity of this pizza is what makes it so delicious. I find myself craving pizza from here 24/7.
- I prefer to get the sicillan slice without any toppings. The sauce and cheese are just so perfectly delicious together, its pretty amazing for how simple it is. 
-The pizza isnt soggy either, it has just the right bite to it.

-Deep dish is also great. Super cheezy and the crust is nice and crunchy.
-Both styles at affordable prices too and near BART.

Whenever we go to Dolores park we always stop on the way for a slice. Sometime on the way back too ...... (:
author: Xochitl T.

description:
Pizza was average, called New York style only because it's thin crust and there's no taste. Not the best but isn't the worst. The place is a bit dirty, the guy cuts the slices without wearing gloves which was a big turn off. Be sure to come before 9:30 otherwise if they sell out of pizza they won't make another. 

One of the guys there, has tattoos mostly covered on his arms, was very rude. I asked if he's going to make more pizza and he told me, "I'm not making you another one."

Place isn't worth the drive because the street they're located on, the parking is hard to find. There's better places than here.
author: Ken P.

description: The real deal for a floppy New York style slice. The crust is always the right balance of soft and crunch, and it's priced very fairly. Always good music on too. Either eat it there or out on the sidewalk immediately after ordering. It doesn't travel well.
author: Jack P.

description: Pizza was ok, service was not. Maybe being rude is their shtick, but I'm not game. Won't be back.
author: Katy K.

description:
This place is pretty bad. They serve pizza but that's about all they have going for them. The guys who work at this pizza shop work at a pizza shop for a reason I suppose. Their customer service is awful. Called to order in and was treated rudely over the phone. Was told to pick up the pizza 45 min later. That's a long wait but not unheard of. However, by the time I got it 45 min later it was already cold. It must have been done cooking a few minutes after the call. Wtf? Give me a call and I'll come in early.
Flavor wise the pizza was nothing special. The crust was like sawdust, and the slices were the farthest thing from equal triangles I've seen. I wouldn't come here again.
author: Mykolas M.

description:
I wish I could give this place 0 stars. I went on a Friday night and I asked for a a slice of cheese pizza. I specifically very nicely said I'm vegetarian. He continued to put pepperoni next to my cheese slice. Then when I asked the employee nicely to please separate, he gave me a disgusted look and threw my slice of cheese into the oven. 

Hey business owner, get better employees! 

Honestly if you like hiring rude employees, then don't change anything.

 

Quality of pizza- 2/5 
I gave it 2/5 because the size is big. Other than than, it's not worth it.
author: Ami J.

description:
Closest thing to NJ/NYC pizza I've found since moving to SF over 15 years ago. I'll order a plain pizza and drive from Bernal Heights to pick it up. Drives my wife crazy but I'll eat at least 2 slices on the way home.

One thing to be clear. You don't go to Arinells for a friendly smile and nice ambiance. You go there for a good simple thin crust pizza. I think the staff are pretty funny but can see how they might piss some people off. All I care about is a good slice of pizza. And they've got that down.
author: Jeff D.

description: Yummy pizza late night and inexpensive and neighbors are entertaining. Yelp says keep typing because note is too short.
author: Charles W.

description: Best NY-style pizza in SF. I'm originally from CT and this is the only place that gives me a taste of home.  I can't imagine living without it.
author: Tanya K.

description: Ordered 2 Regular slices of Pepperoni. The crust was nice and thin, not too much cheese. The Pizza was slightly oily but in a good way :). Perfect for pre or post bar hopping adventures lol. Will be going back for more
author: Sione M.

description: Seriously yelpers? This pizza is nothing to rave about. TBH it is shit. It has little flavor and is cardboardy. I have no idea why it is so popular. I've had lots of New York style pizza in New York and this is crap in comparison. I mean, it was edible, and $3, and open late. So an extra star for that, I guess. Not impressed.
author: Christine G.

description: Best slice in San Francisco. The most authentic NY slice I've had since my last trip to New York. Cheap and what I want out of the perfect slice--thin crust, perfectly foldable, cheap!
author: Alison M.

description:
Fresh out of the oven Sicilian style pizza = Amazing! 

Crust was crisp, cheesy was ooey gooey goodness, so hot you burn your mouth while eating but so worth it

Downside is all the homeless outside that come harass you while you eat 

Overall Thoughts

Can't beat fresh out of the oven or the price
author: Eddie W.

description:
Mission is more than just hipster boys and burritos galore, they have Arinell Pizza.

With a base price of $3 for a nice NY style slice and additional $.50 for each additional topping, this has a tasty yet dangerous recipe for leaving the door with just one slice.

I recommend this pizza shop and will definitely be coming back again.

This is the only location in the city. The next closest one is in Berkeley.
author: Alex G.

description: I cruise around the mission just for this pizza. Cheap. Delicious. No hassle. Just go in and buy your pizza. Kind of reminds me of the seinfeld episode about the soup Nazi. The pizzas are huge and thin.
author: Kaizer D.

description: Best NY style pizza in the Bay area, hands-down. I grew up in NY and have tried almost every Bay area pizza place over the course of 20 years. For a NY slice there's nowhere better than Arinell. It even has the NYC "hole in the wall" look and feel, which I love. I've eaten at Arinell probably 100+ times and will eat there 1,000 more in my lifetime. I cannot get enough! The best.
author: Marc E.

description: Stopped by this random pizza joint when I needed a quick bite to eat before heading out.  The pizza is New York style so it has a super thin crust.  I'm more of a pan crust pizza type of gal, but I don't mind NY style pizza too much.  They make up for the thickness by serving you bigger slices - all for the very affordable price of $3!  Can't complain there.  Arinells isn't a sit and chill place.  It's more of a grab and go spot.  It's also cash only!
author: Destynnie T.

description:
First and foremost I have to say I love the pizza here, and it is inexpensive. Most of the times I've gone I haven't had a problem. However, the last time I went was an exception. I brought a friend with me. She has lived in San Francisco for almost 20 years, but she has an office job and it was right after work, so she might have slightly looked like a yuppy (she is not one). We went in, got our pizza, and the rocker dude who works there was kind of rude to us. It didn't bother me, because I think that's just the spirit of the place- but I do think he was being especially disrespectful of my friend, because he thought she might have been a part of the wave of gentrification hitting that neighborhood. We got our pizza, it was as good as always, and then we went outside and chatted for a little bit. A drunk man from out of town came up to us and started asking us what dive bars were in the area. I don't drink, so we had to talk for a long time to get him the information he wanted. I felt self-conscious about this, because I suspected that the rockers working at Arinells were hearing and judging our ridiculous conversation with this drunk (somewhat douchey) out-of-towner. 

As we were talking to the drunk man, one of the rocker guys from Arinell came out and asked us if we were waiting for pizza, even though we had just sat in front of him for about 10 minutes eating pizza and then left, so I feel like he very well knew that we weren't waiting for pizza. My friend joked, "No, but I'll take it!" And the rocker said, "I bet you would." under his breath. This upset my friend, but I didn't actually hear it when it happened.

"They probably think they're the real deal," she said, "but I'm the realest deal. And the people that were here before me are even realer than that." I didn't totally understand what my friend was getting at, but I live in the East Bay, and I think the division between the tech yuppies and the people that have lived here for a long time, or the people that are here for other reasons is slightly less pronounced where I live than in the Mission- and especially on Valencia Street. 

Arinell has been around for forty years, and it is a dive in a neighborhood that is being transformed into techie douche places. Acknowledging that, I don't think we get anywhere judging people who are ultimately on your side. Maybe I'm totally wrong and the guy working there is just a jerk to everyone that comes in. Anyway, it was a gnarly experience for me and my friend, and it makes me hesitant to go back. I probably will, though, because it's my favorite pizza in San Francisco, which is why I am still giving 3 stars.
author: Kate R.

description:
Love this place! Been coming here everyday for 2 months now. I drive for Lyft in SF so it's fast easy and conveniently located. Love it. The employees are laid back pretty friendly for the most part. One of them with the long dark hair is hecka funny when a customer gives him attitude he gives it to them right back it's hilarious when I see it happen. 

The pizza is simple and tastes clean and basic but the crust is the best! Chewy and crunchy with the right amount of flour. Loving it!
author: Wyatt S.

description: Amazing NY style pizza. Perfect crust, cheese, and sauce. Where can you get Pizza that almost tastes even better when you reheat it at home in frying pan. Can you guys please open a shop in Portland, OR PLEASE!!!
author: Lindsay N.

description:
I don't know what I was expecting. Well, yeah, pizza; probably good pizza. I mean, 1000+ four-star reviews don't come easily.

I walked in and one guy's at the register and another one working the oven. There's half-baked cheese pizza on the counter: one's thin slice and the other's thick crust. I ask for a slice of the thin crust. The guy at the register pops it into the oven while I wait all of 2-3 minutes. It's handed to me on a piece of wax paper.

I take a bite. It's tomato-y, it's crunchy, it's cheesy, it's delicious. It's oily, sure, dripping even, but not unappetizingly so. There are jars of chili flakes, Parmesan cheese, and dried oregano, but I ignore them all. I don't want anything spoiling this perfect slice. I'm sure I can finish this and polish off another slice; no problem.

Problem.

I'm full. I can totally eat another, but why ruin it? It's a perfect portion. I'm good.

No, no, I'm great. I'll be back for that second slice soon enough.

CASH ONLY.
author: Adena B.

description: Walked into this place after craving a piece of pizza while walking in the Mission with my husband on our anniversary. Ordered a slice of Sicilian cheese and the guy at the counter hurriedly put the crappiest, burnt slice in the oven. When I asked for a different slice, he shook his head and said "I already put the other one in the oven". I put my money away and said "ok fine" to which he replied "later then". SO eff'n rude, I can't believe people treat others this way, especially paying customers. Do NOT waste your money here!
author: Marlene N.

description: Their slices feel half baked.  By design?  Not sure.  Ask a question and you're met with a dude still drawing "S" in a wire bound notebook.
author: ankur v.

description: Pizza was okay. The guy working there was rude, which seems to be the typical Mission style. Couldn't give a care that a paying customer was there. He cut me off when I started to order a soda to tell me he "wasn't doing soda today," whatever that means. The whole place had this overwhelming "rebel against authority" vibe. Not my thing... I refuse to give future business to places that act like they're entitled to my money by default and that I'm inconveniencing them by coming into their establishment.
author: Shannon P.

description:
Great slices, ready in minutes. A good, old style pizza shop. 

Don't expect a dining room - counter seating. It's a hole in the wall when what you care about is the food, not anything else. 

Probably, this place is good for after you've been drinking in the Mission. I'd expect lines pit the door on weekend nights.
author: Brent D.

description: As a native NYer who moved to Cal about 30 years ago, I gotta say people here in SF are such sissies! You want customer service, sanitary conditions, clean eating counters, someone concerned with your vegan needs( Ewww, a pepperoni touched my slice! )go somewhere else for pizza. Valencia Street has 6 or 7 other great pizza places to choose from. You want authentic NY style slices and Sicilians, you come here. Yeah at times they're sarcastic and rude, so what! All part of the dining experience.
author: LauraHerm M.

description:
Do you know who best taught the masses how to eat pizza?  

How you should first fold the slice lengthwise, making it compact so it's easier to handle & eat?  And also, so as not to burn the roof of your mouth?

It was none other than the magnificent Sophia Loren.

The movie was Houseboat.  1958.  Her costar was Cary Grant.

And it's gotta be plain thin crust pizza.  Real New York style pizza.  

Just try doing the fold thing w a thick crust or deep dish pizza.  It won't work.

This is the place for NY style pizza.

Is it a hole in the wall?  Most certainly.

Is it a little grimy?  You bet.

Can the service be impersonal?  Why, naturally.

If you're looking for any frills, you'll need to look elsewhere.

If you want a large, hot, cheesy, thin slice of NY, then come on in.

Just don't talk (or text) on your cell when they're ready to take your order.

And yes, the pizza can be greasier than it need be.  

But they still get props for having true grit, heart, & soul.

4 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: I don't get it. Maybe for sf standard it's ok? It does taste better than it looks (like plastic ). But if anyone has had a slice at Joe's pizza in NYC, this place is a disgrace. I don't understand why and how people are likening Arinell to a ny slice. NY pizza is way better than this, people !!!
author: M C.

description: A good friend of mine who happens to be a New Yorker highly recommended this spot and suffice to say I was most definitely thrilled! A slice is a few bucks and each additional topping is 75 cents. I literally drove all the way from Union City to San Francisco just to try this hole-in-the-wall first before sliding through the City. I was told this was the closest to an NYC slice one could come by in these parts and boy one sink into this slice of heaven had me dancing in my seat dreaming of New York with Alicia Keys singing in my head!
author: Aaron F.

description: 3.5 stars. After a night of drinking, who doesn't crave pizza?  You can't beat the price. Three dollars for a slice. I'm the Queen of junk food and I don't mind eating like crap all the time. But I found my slice to be very greasy. Definitely busted out the napkins and tried to pat it dry. I was that person. The flavor was good and I'm a huge fan of thin crust. Would I come back? Most likely because it is quick and convenient if you're drinking in the Mission. But I wouldn't go out of my way to grab pizza from here.
author: Grace V.

description: Anytime I'm in the bay I get calls from home telling me to bring pizzas back home. All Day pizza champs!
author: Ohya W.

description: There is nowhere better to go for a quick cheap ($3) slice in all of San Francisco. It's greasy. The triangles are asymmetrical. They won't indulge in small talk and it's all cash with nary a seat to sit at. But when you've had a few and don't want to go home and don't want to pay a fortune for food on Valencia and you're sick of tacos, go here. THEN stumble home.
author: David A R.

description: Delicious, timely, and a nice thin crust pie. Definitely optimized for takeout pies or a slice on the go. NY style, no frills, giant slices.
author: B C.

description:
I want to like Arinell. It's the only decent New York style slice in SF and the prices are great. 

However, in the 5 times I've been to Arinell, I've twice seen them treating disabled people like shit. First was a woman I didn't know in a wheelchair, and the second time it was someone in my party who had her ESA dog with her. Shockingly in violation of California and Federal law, one of the employees actually demanded she produce her paperwork on her support dog, and dramatically declared "I WASN'T FINISHED READING IT!" when we put her phone away after allowing him 30 seconds to read her documentation. Read the Americans with Disabilities Act, sir. I encourage the owners
 of this establishment to train their employees in proper treatment of disabled persons. 

My friend is very assertive and put this particular employee in his place and left with her pizza, but I can only imagine that this man has railroaded less confident person (like myself, if I'm honest!) in the past. We had just departed Giordano Bros, where they treated us fantastically, moments before, so the treatment that we received at Arinell was a slap in the face.

Even though I'm not personally disabled, a 40% rate of mistreatment of disabled persons is pretty absurd in my book. You won't catch me at Arinell ever again. If you like pizza and don't have a conscience, this is the place for you.
author: Taylor R.

description: Best thin slice pizza ever and so reasonably priced.  We get mushroom or pepperoni.  It's the best food after drinking.  And there is delivery with grubhub or bring me that. Have to try it. Yummm
author: Lei H.

description: Good pizza and good music always. Funny pizza makers and best prices in the mission. Nothing fancy just quality food in a great location!
author: Eric N.

description:
cheap, fast, delicious NY style.

Arinell doesn't front, it is what it is.  cheap, fast, delicious.

I've been known to slay a slice or twice at this joint, and it has become my go to.

Do I care that a pair of my favorite jeans is stained with pizza grease from Arinell? Maybe. But at least it was good pizza.
author: Susy C.

description:
A Latino and an African walk into a pizza joint. White people get served first. End of joke. Racist place with horrible service. (And when was the last time this place passed a health inspection?)
Update: I just checked their most current health review, which you can also access here on Yelp (from February 22, 2016). This place had 5 violations:
- Inadequately cleaned or sanitized food contact surfaces
- Unapproved or unmaintained equipment or utensils
- Moderate risk vermin infestation
- Improper food storage
- Moderate risk food holding temperature
author: Miguel A.

description: I've been up and down Valencia many times, and I've seen Arinell's Pizza Joint any number of times. Looking at the location from the outside, I was always a little suspicious, lol. However, for whatever reason, I tried it out today. I'm glad I did. The slice with pepperoni was only $3.50. For that price you get a pretty tasty pizza. I really liked the crust, while very thin, it was nice and crusty. At this price point, it's definitely worth the money.
author: Anthony W.

description: Excellent NY style pizza at a reasonable price. Crust was the perfect consistency, and the balance between cheese and sauce was pretty much ideal. Closest I've tasted to a traditional NY slice here in SF.
author: Michael S.

description: Straight ny style pizza and attitude I love it. Don't come in here thinking this is a full service spot if you're disappointed you're prolly one of the people that's ruining the mission district. Cheap delicious slices nothing more nothing less but it's just right.
author: Craig O.

description: Pizza is New York style  and its very tasty! Def coming back  it's cash only but the food is great!
author: Susan C.

description: I didn't realize that California made such crap pizza until I moved to NYC for 2.5 years. Upon my return, it was quite the shock to my system. Even worse, I brought my New York born and bred husband back with me, and pizza is his favorite of all the foods, and it's really been quite the disaster. But thanks to Arinell, he's probably willing to stay here! Jk (sort of. And not cause he wouldn't leave because of pizza, just because I won't let him). This is absolutely the closest thing to NYC thin crust pizza we've found in SF and as far as I can tell, California, and it's pretty f*&^ing delicious. All you little snobs turning your nose up at the wax paper, the service, the space, etc. etc., I am NOT here for you because Arinell is also obviously not here for you. It's greasy, it's the cheapest meal I've ever treated husband to, and it's DELISHUS. And if you disagree with me on that last point, it's cool, I didn't want to be your friend anyway.
author: Kelin B.

description: I have gone to Arinell's for years and have always appreciated that the folks there are individuals who efficiently serve up a slice. I have never expected to be coddled, or even verbally acknowledged beyond a thank you when I give a tip. My experience last night was not the same. There was a polite man who took my order and served it to me. I sat and ate, and watched him having a conversation with a young woman. At that point one of the guys running the ovens (a tiny white man) blasted the music, grabbed his joint and stood out front to smoke with another man who also worked in the back with the ovens. Because it was so loud in the restaurant, I left to eat my food on the street out front. When I was done, I took the paper wrapper and attempted to place it in the blue recycling bin. The tiny man slapped down the lid that I had opened, then went on a screaming (cussing and threatening) rant about how paper should go in the compost, and how this is not the east coast, and how paper should never be in a recycle bin, that it is to be composted................it continued until I crossed 16th street and couldn't hear him anymore. I really hope that owner is willing to address this behavior. I'm so sorry that I did not use my mace on Mr. Tiny. Abusive little men are so tiresome!
author: Mister L.

description:
The best Pizza in SF! Closest thing to NY style you'll find and very affordable too! One slice is enough as it's pretty big.

I haven't had luck finding good pizza otherwise here.

Remember to bring cash.
author: Narma G.

description: The slices are huge and are definitely NY style. Furthermore, you can get anchovies, which make this a cut above just by virtue of serving pizza the right away. It's not the kind of place I'd order a whole pizza at, and the interior definitely is a trip back to the grime and grit of 1970s NY, but it gets four stars for being reasonably priced and tasting good while being wolfed down.
author: Zeb L.

description:
If I was writing this review after ending a night of drinking in the mission with a slice of pizza, I would probably give it a four. Since I'm writing this review sober, it'll have to be a 3.

I appreciate a non-burrito option for late night eating and there are surprisingly few options for late night pizza in the Mission. This place certainly beats your closest options (pizza zone and escape from new york?). It's greasy, the hygiene is questionable and I'm not even sure they have plates but they do make a solid slice of NY style pizza.

Oh and you probably guessed this, but cash only.
author: Baron C.

description:
I really liked the pizza!
Service was fast, cash only, and out the door. We got fresh cheese pizza. So good. It was very flavorful and their tomato sauce was delicious. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone.
author: Kat S.

description:
Came here with my Australian friends after partying in Skylark. 

The pizza substandard even after being given the extra boost of being eaten while drunk. Usually that seasoning is enough to make anything and everything taste magically delicious but not in this case. 


If all you are going for is satiety, no matter how unhealthy or unfulfilling, then this place will definitely be a good choice- the pizza slices were ginormous and over ample
author: Joshua L.

description: hands down the best pizza in San Francisco! You heard it hear first. I take all my friend here and never have heard anyone say that this is subpar pizza. My greatest joy is when I catch a new pizza coming out of the over. If you're looking for fancy pizza with tons of toppings this isn't the place. They do pizza justice by keeping it simple. In Arinells Pizza I trust. Never has it disappointed me.
author: Nina H.

description:
It never fails...each time I return from a trip to the Big Apple, I come home craving a hearty NY style slice.

To satisfy those cravings, Arinell's hits the spot.  Not quite the same as the real NY experience, but it comes close.  Their pies are always fresh since people are constantly popping in for a slice or two so pies are in and out of the oven like no tomorrow.

Cash only and limited seating, but that's the whole concept.  Grab and go.  I'm no pizza connoisseur and I do love my artisan pizza joints in the city, but Arinell's is a great spot to grab a slice or get a whole pie to take over to a friend's place.
author: Janetto L.

description:
Having been to New York City and experienced their pizza, I had started to abandon all hope that I'd ever come across anything close to it back home on the west coast. Fortunately for me, my last year of college required a filler class just to satisfy unit requirements; I strategically chose a Humanities course about New York history, literature and culture, believing it would be an easy A to tack on to my transcript. 

One day, the professor walked in with the Annie Hall DVD and several boxes of pizza. I realized that morning that Woody Allen's directorial accomplishments have been overshadowed by his personal affairs. I was also properly taught how to fold a slice, to call it "take-away" instead of "take-out", but most importantly, I was introduced to Arinell Pizza. 

It's a small, no frills place on Valencia that you would easily walk past had you not been looking for it. It's not Delfina. I'm positive they don't use gluten-free, organic ingredients. There is enough grease on a single slice to scare the average health-conscious San Franciscan. But if it's authentic New York style pizza you're looking to try, Arinell is the place. Order the Neopolitan (only tomato sauce and cheese, DON'T ADD TOPPINGS) and grab a seat at one of the two booths. Enjoy!
author: Olivia V.

description:
I'm a fan of Arinell in Berkeley but this was my first visit to the Valencia branch.  After hitting up a film festival at the nearby Roxie, I didn't want to spend too much money especially since I was flying solo.  I saw the Arinell sign and suddenly the craving for New York style pizza hit.  I knew it would be cash only but I was pleased the SF prices mirror the Berkeley prices, $3/slice.  My Yelp Karma kicked in again and the notorious long-haired cashier was a prince to me. He told me the slice was already warm but that he could heat it up  more. I told him it was all good.  I chose a stool and settled in to enjoy my wonderful dinner. The cashier and the guy making pizza were listening to Merle Haggard; it was hard not to join the singalong with "Okie from Muskogee." 
Arinell isn't catering to hipsters or techies.  It's dimly lit and ancient-looking. I'm sure a new paint job would be great. But I'd like it to stay exactly as it is, a remnant of the San Francisco I love.
author: Julie C.

description: Classic NY slice. Never disappoints. Perfect ratio of sauce to cheese to thin crispy crust. Cash only, no bullshit. In a hyper gentrified 'hood, continues to offer a little slice of urban life with every slice of pizza.
author: Patsy H.

description: Handed the guy cash, he took of with his bare hands and then proceeded to grab a hand full of pepperoni and putting it on our pizza without even washing his hands first. Gross. We asked for a refund and the guy threw it back at us as on the counter as if we did something wrong.
author: Salvador R.

description: A very good NY style slice for $3 (I doubt we'll ever had the dollar slice wars here)  Now if someone in SF could learn how to make a decent bagel.....
author: hOWARD y.

description: Pretty good pizza (4.5/5 stars for the pizza) but I lost my appetite after noticing questionable food-handling practices, such as touching food with bare hands after dealing with money without washing hands.  I'm not sure how they got a 96 out of 100 health score on Yelp? I don't know about you but I definitely won't be eating anymore pizza from here!
author: Katherine Y.

description:
4.5 stars.

I was looking for a quick pizza dinner in the mission so I chose to try this place out instead of going to my usual Delfina Pizza. Why yes, I like Delfina a lot as well, but damn, this place really gives it a run for it's money. TBH I have to give this place cred for really knowing how to do their pizzas right. When I mean right I mean NY style, which I am quite partial to... Delfina is good, but different good and not classic NY style good, you get me?

So is this the closest thing in SF to a NY slice? Yes, yes it is. It has a CRISPY ultra-thin crust and it is drenched in delicious olive oil. Why is it not my favorite all-time pizza? Well, it's not from NY of course (jk). The only thing it could use more of is a bolder flavor for the sauce and some nicer cheese (and basil). If they offered a traditional margherita slice I may be won over to say this could rank right next to the best pizza I've ever had (Di Fara's in NY). But, c'est la vie, you can't really ask much of a casual joint. For the price point, no wait, and quality of pizza... you probably have yourself a steal compared to anywhere else for pizza in the city.

I didn't love the square Sicilian slices... I seek places that have this to compare to the best I've had so far (also Di Fara's in NY of course). I have had my share of good and bad ones and this one was just mediocre. Probably wouldn't order again, but definitely would go back for their thin slices. 

So did I make the right choice to go here instead of Delfina? Yes... yes I did.
author: Joanne Y.

description: I happened to walk by after going to a dessert shop and noticed a handful of people in the shop so I decided to stop by. The menu is basic, you start with a cheese pizza and add on toppings (meat, veggies, etc.). At first I was skeptical about it, but after taking a bite I was relieved. This place has good pizza! Would definitely come back again when I'm in town.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Bonus for late night food in SF.

Despite how oily the pizza, it was surprisingly tasty with a nice thin crisp to the crust (and I was not drunk!) and you get a really large slice. Some slices may have been sitting around for a bit, but they were still putting new pizzas in the oven at 1am.

pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/arinell-pizza-san-francisco?select=u9OvMCQQgjB58gAV_XQi9g#u9OvMCQQgjB58gAV_XQi9g
author: Ziyan C.

description: The most beautiful and delicious pizza in sf...don't just buy a slice...order a whole pie and enjoy it for days.
author: Chris G.

description:
Arinell is THE only acceptable pizza option in SF if you're from the Northeast. Nothing else even comes close. 

If you grew up around the bay or some other place in the country, you'll probably just think it's ok, since they don't offer the wide selection of toppings, sizes, crust styles etc that people seem to like for reasons I can't explain. 

Arinell does not disguise the quality of their pizza with these distractions. Their pizza speaks for itself, and has the quality of flavor rarely seen anywhere west of Trenton. 

Growing up eating pizza in Jersey and NY, I am extremely picky and pretentious when it comes to pizza now living away from home. 

Have tried dozens of places in numerous cities, and all offer the same disappointment. The burnt maroon colored flavorless sauce. Squishy weird dough resembling a smashed hoagie roll. Floating cheese. 

Arinell suffers none of these flaws. 

First time I had it I was walking down Valencia, not even looking for pizza (I had already eaten dinner 10 minutes earlier), when something caught my eye. 

It was some little kid attempting to eat a slice of pizza so big that it was spilling over his hands. Simultaneous to this an intoxicating smell shot up my nose - similar to how the smell of cologne shoots up your nose when walking by an Abercrombie store - except this wasn't cologne, it was pizza! The smell of melted mozzarella and sweet tomatoes in combination with that of a fresh bakery I hadn't smelled in over 5 years.

Upon this happening, I nearly broke my neck turning my head so fast to see what it was. After seeing it, even while being 15 feet away on the sidewalk, I knew immediately Arinell had the goods. 

So I sprinted to the ATM at the next block to get cash, ran inside and bought a slice. Ate it right at the counter and it was heavenly. Was so giddy afterwards, I had to go back 2 hours later to eat another, along with a branded trucker hat that I now wear with pride to show my support. 

Now, with that being said, drop everything you're doing right now and get a slice. Just do it.
author: Chris S.

description:
How many reviews have said, "this is the closest thing you'll find to a NY slice" Let me add one more. I've had some pretty shitty pizza around here. Each time I've shed a tear missing home and missing real pizza. 

As many of the experiences go, I was out late one night in the Mission and decided to grab a slice at Arinell's, of course, reminding me of my many drunken nights in NYC. So, I paid the $3 and was ready to be disappointed. 

BUT WAIT, I wasn't disappointed and I actually devoured it. It was hot and burned the roof of my mouth. Thin and crispy, but no crumbling all over. Salty enough for my liking. Each component not standing out, but working harmoniously together. 

Thank you for existing in this city, Arinell's. No it's not New York, but you're definitely putting a wide smile in the hearts of the east coasters.
author: Priti K.

description:
After going to New York over the summer, I've been craving pizza like a mad lady.

I ordered a slice of cheese, which came out to four bucks (or was it three?) The slice was pippin' hot and I got overly excited (because pizza!). 

One of my friends once told me that a pizza is not a pizza unless the cheese is stringy when you take a bite out of it (he got this from watching Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.) 

Arinell's pizza truly did have that string cheese moment once you take a bite. You know, the kind where it feels like there's a never-ending amount of cheese getting pulled from the pizza. The crust was thin but had a really nice crispy crunch to it.

Overall, the pizza here is fresh, cheap and delicious.
author: Anna H.

description:
I came across this list on Pinch-it that had SF's best NY-Style Pizza.  While the list had some good choices, someone contested that Arinell Pizza was mistakenly left out of that list.  So the curious pizza-eater in me made the trek out to the Mission and stopped over to see if this person was right.

Very thin pizza!  Exactly how NY-style pizza is supposed to be.  I ordered one plain cheese slice and one with mushrooms.
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/QjnmVuqVArA7d-syiUCiUw?select=GiyzatkB-N31pPfYCebNag#GiyzatkB-N31pPfYCebNag).
I figured that if they can't get a simple cheese slice right, then everything else can't be good, which I was glad that they got it down nicely.  Had the right amount of gooey-ness and oily-ness that you should expect from a NY-style cheese pizza.  I liked it very much.  The mushroom pizza was good too and they really piled on the mushrooms.  My only gripe about it is that they put the mushrooms on after the slice was already cooked and reheated it, but that's more of a personal preference for me.

If you're ever in the Mission and have that pizza craving, I'd recommend Arinell Pizza just as much as that person from Pinch-it.  It's not too fancy and is pretty much a no-frills pizza joint.  In the end it's all about the pizza and Arinell's makes a very good one!
author: Rodney H.

description:
Closest pizza to east coast pizza in this neighborhood? That's not saying much but it's probably the best of that genre of pizza. I still don't think the pizza is amazing but it's solid. 

Major pluses though: open really late sometimes which is a godsend if you're out the bars on valencia, everything is compostable which is very nice though I feel weird putting that in a review, and the attitude of the people that work there is hilarious. I would say it's super warm but it's exactly what it needs to be.

You can not bring dogs in here.
author: Geoff G.

description: Good vegan pie, they go super heavy on the toppings which is love so much. Super fast for lunch if you work or live close by, parking sucks in that area. This is my 2nd favorite quick and easy vegan pizza in Berkeley. The staff is super friendly, cash only but worth it for sure. Don't look for fancy pies here, this is the closest to a NY pizza spot that you can get in Berkeley.
author: Joi M.

description: Best slice of pizza in San Francisco.  Cash only, though!
author: D R.

description: How did I not know this was here after living nearby for so long? lol.
