It's a small pizza place that I guess is easy to pass, but it's a great place to grab a bite for lunch or after a night out :) Simple, customizable New York style pizza with thin, crispy crust. It gets busy sometimes depending on the time, so you may have to prepare for a wait, but the line goes by fairly quickly. There's a small counter area to sit at, or you can just grab and go of course. I'm sure I'll be back soon for more!
author: Bianca C.

description:
Arinell was my sole pizza salvation when I transplanted here over a decade ago.  For a town that prides itself on cuisine, I couldn't believe how lackluster its offerings were on the pizza front.  Fuck deep dish at Zachary's across the Bay, I just wanted a bomb East Coast slice at the time.

Arinell fit the bill. It's an authentic NYC-style slice.  And nothing has changed much over the years.  Place is still run by charming stoners who look like they were doubles from the Wayne's World sequel that never got made.  Prices are still cheap, slices are still delicious and the frills -well, there are none.  

This is old school Mission shit right here, son.  No Marina cascade effect here, come correct and don't be talkin' on your cell phone at the register, they will ask you to leave.

My standby is two slices of pepperoni with tons of jalapeños on it. Does the trick every time.
author: Saminda W.

description:
Is it fancy? No
Do they take cards? No
Do they have plates? No

But this is some damn delicious pizza by the slice. DAMN GOOD. And I love pizza, in all forms and fashions. For $3 you're out the door with a piping hot slice of cheese, 50-75 cents to add a limited selection of toppings. Slices come in either thin or Sicilian (deep dish). Prices include sales tax- great for that cash only, late night, possibly drunk lifestyle. The employees are funny with the perfect amount of grit and jokes alike to deal with the  eclectic line of pizza seekers that is usually out the door.
author: Lauren S.

description: Closest think to NY Pizza I've had so far in SF. Crunchy, crispy, and nice tasting sauce.
author: Deon R.

description: Nice little place to grab a quick slice of pizza. They have two styles of pizza: a regular thickness and a thicker one. They are constantly making cheese pizzas in these two styles. Cheese slices are ready at the counter. They add the topping on top of the already made cheese pizzas and put it back in the oven to get hot and crispy. I had a classic pepperoni pizza, which I would come back for. I love the crispy crust of the pizza. The slices range from about $3-5 based on what toppings you get. There are two countertops and about 5 stools inside that you can sit on. Arinell is located a couple blocks from the 16th and Mission BART station.
author: Nicole S.

description: Absolutely fantastic pizza. East coast style and the best sliced pizza I've had in San Francisco.
author: greg s.

description: I'm giving this place 5 stars even though the pan pizza was sorely lacking in flavor and cheese. Why still 5 stars? The thin New York style cheese pizza slices were delicious. Maybe the best I've ever had and I've had quite a few.
author: Stephanie P.

description: I would give better rating but it's not worth it. There health score is red 84. I didn't find out the score until after I ordered.  The guy handling the slices and cash doesn't was his hands between handling pizza and money. The pizza wasn't bad it had great foldabilty.
author: johnny W.

description: Pizza is ok, unsure if this is how New York Pizza is like, but I like my pie with a little more cheese. The deep dish was better, but I wasn't satisfied with my urge for a slice. I went next door to another pizza shop and satisfied my craving with a great combination slice.
author: Gehad B.

description: Such a good deal for great NY style pizza. I like to get the Neapolitan with olives and bell peppers. They put red, yellow, and green bell peppers on it. A medium is huge and costs $21 total. So worth it.
author: Kelly B.

description: Amazing slice, 3.25 and I ate my fill! Great service, fast (waited all of 3 minutes for my slice) and with a smile. Would have given 5 stars if they had washed their hands / worn gloves before handling my slice (after touching money). But otherwise no complaints.
author: Emily R.

description: This pizza parlour on Valencia Avenue in San Francisco is very dirty inside there was food all over the counters you would eat on from previous customers they never came out to wipe the counters down when we arrive to sit down to eat our food . And the floor was dirty with liter everywhere I guess the 2 young guys behind the counter don't no how to keep a Pizza parlor clean . This place is unsanitary and should be fined by the health department. I won't be going back ....
author: Prince P.

description:
I ordered a slice of pizza from the young white kid with a red and white cap on.  I asked him if I could buy a box, he said no, boxes are for whole pizzas only and if I wanted to buy a box to go to the other pizza shop down the street. This kid has the worse customer service skills I have ever encountered and should not be working in customer service. 

Dear restaurant owner, you should let this kid go or have a serious talk with him bc I am sure you do not want your business represented in this way. 

So pissed off I didn't even eat the pizza. 

Oh yeah and I saw him touching money and food without washing his hands.
author: Carter N.

description:
Born and bred New Yorker here.
Overall not good quality pizza.  I assume it's better than pizza hut, so that's why people here rate it so highly.

I tried the regular and Sicilian.  Both experiences wee similar.
    Cheese: tasteless and rubbery. The worst part of the experience
  
  Crust:  too thin on that regular, too mushy on the Sicilian

  Sauce:  Not bad. A little bland
author: JH K.

description:
Two smart ladies stumble in, all dressed in cocktail dresses, hair and makeup done, in high heels and in need of some good food. We know what's up and where to get a good slice of pizza while partying in the Mission. 

We giggle, chatting it up with other customers, having a good time with the late night hungry people in line. We aren't picky - we just want some pizza. Just in luck, we arrive as a fresh hot cheese pizza comes out of the oven. 

It's delicious, we devour our slices all lady like, touch up the lipstick and head out. Arinell is simply one of the best fast food pizza spots in this hood.
author: Rebekah T.

description: just look at my uploaded picture.  man i do like the pizza and I put up with the bad service all the time for a slice, but this time there was just too much attitude.  i will give the pizza a 4.5 stars but the fucking owner or manager and workers should have negative stars..  unfortunately they are just one of the business that regardless of their service you just keep going back.  guess i wont be welcome anymore.  poor me!
author: King L.

description:
I will never come here again. This place is run by trashy people who start unnecessary fights with their customers. luckily I was only a bystander/witness. If you're petty enough to want to start a brawl with your customers over nothing, maybe you shouldn't run a business that requires interacting with people. SMH 

oh and all of this happened AFTER the guy at the counter was super rude to me so I was not surprised by their behavior at all.
author: Melisa W.

description:
Food: B
Ambiance: lol
Service: B-
Service, another chance: C+
Service, one more time: "listen bro..."

There's a burrito place next door. They can probably make you a pizza.
author: Alex K.

description:
A big slice of NY-style pizza for a quick buck or two... I can't complain.  The pizza is definitely reminiscent of pizza from the Big Apple, and with a sign that proves it on the outside.  The workers inside remind me of SF folk though.  A little rough around the edges with a sense of hipster flair.  I'm sure there isn't a passable code with every health-code violation written in the book but the pizza is what everyone comes here for.

Check it out for yourself and don't be deterred.
author: Kevin J.

description: Good pizza, especially when you've been drinking! Sicilian slices melt in your mouth. :)
author: Lissette C.

description:
Best pizza around! 

No frills, nothing to complain about, just pure yumminess!
author: Bella B.

description: I wanted to like this place, I really did, but I will never go there again. I asked for a slice of cheese pizza with sausage and mushrooms on it and I got what looks like they took a huge dump of poop on a slice of cheese and grease. It was just clumped into a ball with WAY too much mushrooms for any person and such a waste of money for the place. No plastic silverware so I could even eat the thing, which was only because I was starving and didn't have time to throw it away and go elsewhere. It didn't even taste remotely good. I eat pizza almost every other day from everywhere and this is definitely the worst pizza I've ever had. Just a pile of poop meat, grease, bottom of the barrel sauce and barely passable cheese. My significant other is from NYC and is a pizza cook, and even he has also expressed his disgust with their "New York" pizza. The cooks don't give a crap about the food and on top of that, they were were hella rude and looked like they were homeless (not even in a hipster way). I hate to see places going out of business in SF, but that is actually one place that I'd love to see replaced by something not shitty.
author: Nikki L.

description:
Listed on a "best pizza in the Bay" list, I can say, without a doubt, it's pretty amazing! You get your choice of either deep dish or Neopolitan style and then pick any toppings you want added on. They put it together, toss it in an oven quick and out comes a pretty good sized slice for $3-5. We ordered two slices, one topping on each, and a drink and it came to under $10 for two of us. 

They also have the option to buy a whole pie although there is no delivery service. If you want to try this delicious pizza, stop in for a quick lunch (not a lot of seating) or pick up if you live nearby!
author: Cassandra J.

description: This NY Style pizza is everything. No frills, open just when you need it & fired up to gooey perfection within minutes. A slice of cheese is only a couple of dollars and hits the spot without fail. A little difficult to take to go since the slices are huge and floppy so feel free to hunker down with the eclectic Mission crowd before ambling on your way.
author: Faith Y.

description:
A friend who I totally trust food-wise brought me here.  He also lived in NYC for a few years, so when he tells me it's the closest you can get to NY style pizza in SF, I had to try it. 

Each slice is huge and only $3, and they heat it up for you.  You can customize it and ask them to add extra toppings for you for a bit extra.

The pizza fresh out of the oven has a very thin yet crisp crust, and there's plenty of cheese to leave those long strings as you pull the pizza away.   Of course, they have extra red pepper flakes, cheese, and oregano for you to top it off.  There's very little seating, but everything about the slice was spot on, and the guy behind the counter was really nice.

Cash only.
author: Marilyn T.

description: The appearance of this place definitely threw me off. It was a small pizzeria with fenced Windows and only a few seats to the side of the shop. None the less, my buddy and I ordered a medium pepperoni pie and went at it. Now, being a Brooklyn boy, there are certain expectation for pizza and this place certainly did it. The only difference was that the pizza crust and dough was not what I was used to but it's pretty close, however the sauce and cheese were spot on.
author: Kevin H.

description:
New York Pizza should be:
- Thin
- Big
- Not too greasy or crunchy

Arinell's got two of the three down -- their slices are pretty dang big and come out nice n' thin -- easily foldable. 

It's just a shame that they are super greasy and crunchy. It's such a weird combo, one that mops up a lot of grease while still being all crispy. It's ok.
author: Casey S.

description:
Ordered a whole pizza with my wife. This time they put extra oil on the pie and it was great. From now on, will always ask for extra oil. The taste was wonderful. Loved it. As good as the best in New York City, except for the bland crust. 

The crust is still bland. Wish they would improve it.

A whole pie costs the same as eight slices. Wish there was a discount as there is everywhere in New York for a whole pie.
author: Steven G.

description:
I dig this pizza. Quick for a slice, wait os obviously longer for full pies. 

If you're waiting after you order, head next door to Casanova and get a drink. Otherwise be prepared to get constantly squished while you wait and other patrons come in the door and squeeze you into the shallow corners. Your choice.

Tasty pizza, good ingredients, definitely going here again.

The good: good food, yes.
The bad: cash only.
author: Amanda B.

description:
Bottom line at the top: very basic pizza that tastes chalky but the guys are really sweet.
--
No frills cash only spot. Came in for a quick slice of cheese as a snack. Nothing special pizza wise, but the guys that work here are super great considering how they handle dealing with all the drunk nuts. 

Little star is definitely my favorite pizza in SF.
author: Dahlia S.

description: Delicious thin crust pizza! Got two mediums for 5 people and had only one slice leftover. Best pizza I've had in a long while, especially in SF.
author: K V.

description: Good lord, I had this yesterday and I'm still salivating from thinking about it. I moved here from NYC and I was really jonesin for a NY-style slice and man this is the place for that. It's even better than a lot of pizzerias in NYC! Their pies are not too thin or too thick, with a perfect ratio of  cheese to sauce to dough. Not too salty. The crust gives a delicious crunch when you bite into it but it's also a bit chewy (yes it can!) It's perfect for my taste, so incredibly satisfying.
author: Melissa C.

description:
This is just a good east coast slice in a classic divy spot. Generally some metal on the radio. 

I never get slices reheated. Its usually fresh enough and it keeps the dough from getting overcooked. Stays chewy instead of the occasional crackery 

The pan slices are awfully good as well.

I wish they were open later during the week.
author: Peter M.

description:
I grabbed a Napolitano slice and added mushrooms and sausage.  They grab a slice of cheese that's already made, throw the toppings on, and pop it in the oven to heat and bake the toppings on.

It's a huge slice with a nice, thin crust!!  Napolitano cheese slice was $2.75 plus mushrooms and sausage at $0.75 each (some toppings are $0.50) made it a $4.25 slice, but worth it.  They're pretty generous with toppings.

Arinell is a small place, so it's definitely grab and go.  It wasn't packed when I went, so I grabbed a bar stool and ate my slice there, but lots of people came and went even in time I was there.

It's close to the 16th and Mission BART stop, so I was ever in the area again, I'd head back for another slice!
author: Greg L.

description:
NEGATIVE STARS. 

TERRIBLE RUDE SERVICE. I thought I was the only one to have such a horrible and nasty experience here. 

I politely asked for a different slice (than the dried-up burnt one I was being given) and was kicked out-- WHAT?!?!!!? 
 Read it again--- I was kicked out because I -a polite customer - asked for something!!?! 

The staff are obnoxious, rude, mean, angry, ugly people. I'm so disgusted and angered with the whole place- the manager didn't even care when I called about this. 
 
I appreciate the three girls that left when they saw what happened to me. Good for you SFers! Don't put up with this bipolar-staffed, haughty, stuck-up racist restaurant. There pizza isn't even that good.
author: S R.

description:
In search of NY style pizza, we pull up our Yelp app that points us here. Been on 7x7's 100 things to eat list? Great, let's try it! 

My boyfriend called in our order, "large cheese Napoleon pizza" and I burst out laughing while he's still on the phone. I tell him it's not Napoleon pizza, so he tries explaining, "cheese with tomato" to the guy on the phone. I was still giggling; "he'll think tomato is a topping." He's British, and as a native East Coast girl, I found this pretty humorous. I guess ordering pizza not from a chain was new to him, but no clue why he thought the pizza would have anything to do with the historical figure! 

We drove to pick it up, but by the time we got home, the pie was only luke warm. It sure looked like a NY style pie, but the crust and dough just missed the mark just a bit. Overall, it was good, and I'd definitely order again from here when I am craving a taste from back home; it's as close as I've had in SF yet. However, they cut the pie into too small of slices, so you can't fold your slice. Not sure if the slices to go are different, but if I order a pie to go again, I'd definitely request them to make larger slices. It's not a NY slice if I can't fold it!
author: Rebecca G.

description: Came here looking for food because anywhere else we went were on the weird break between lunch/dinner. The concept is fast pizza. They've got premade cheese pizza slices for about $3. There is a list of toppings you can add for a small fee. They heat it up and viola. This would make great late night drunk food. As sober food, it was eh. Cash only.
author: Sarika S.

description:
Amazing pizza. The best I've had in the city. 

Wish they wouldn't be stubborn and would allow credit/debit and postmates. 

It's 2015 guys. Come on.
author: Adam S.

description: I'm pretty done with this place. Slices are large for $3, but the quality of the slice is just completely gone. It's not even a utility slice anymore. What it tastes and feels like is a really poor quality $1 slice in Manhattan, so I guess they can still say they're New York-style, but other than that, you've got a crust that's so hard you can't give it the Brooklyn fold without it cracking and snapping in half. The tomato sauce and cheese are mixed together on the slice to the point where you cannot differentiate either taste, and the service is just gruff. Later.
author: Danny C.

description: Great NY style pizza...small hole in the wall but so worth it!!! You can also order by the slice
author: Gina W.

description:
SF idk what your damage is but Jesus you guys have bad pizza. I guess you make up for it in truly orgasmic tacos but damn is your pizza game weak.

This is the closest to NY pizza the bay has to offer. And it's a damn good slice.
author: Ryley P.

description: Great thin crust pizza. Simple, delicious, and quick. Slightly greasy but would definitely go back. The slice was huge and filling enough. Next time I go to Dolores park I'll stop by!
author: Emily F.

description:
Hi Ron,

You're pizza is awesome and the price is great. However, one star is lost due to the jerk with the hair bun working the counter. He was rude and uncourteous. I don't want free stuff - please just correct this guy.
author: Khalid N.

description: Pizza is great, but the grimy servicemen who give death stares and attitude have to go. Check the numerous other reviews with the same complaint. $24 dollars for a pizza better come with a damn smile.
author: Gary M.

description: Who hires these assholes?  Honestly, you really have to *try* to find people this rude.  More than half of the time that I order anchovies they complain or talk to themselves in full volume that they think it's gross, etc.  When I (like a normal pleasant human being) say thanks and tip them I get a rude glare back.  The last time I went (and forever the last time) the guy went on a full on rant about my choice in toppings and then slammed the counter closed and left.  If you don't want to serve anchovies or don't like your job, THEN DON'T WORK THERE YOU MORONS.
author: Jacob A.

description:
This place is pretty awesome! I had read all the Yelp reviews saying that this was the closest thing to NY style pizza and had gotten some recommendations from friends so I had to try out this place. 

I love the concept of making a huge cheese pizza and then putting toppings based on peoples preferences for slices. It makes the whole process of ordering pizza by the slice so much more efficient. I got one slice of plain cheese and one with mushrooms. I would recommend the plain cheese over getting any toppings because the mushrooms were a little cold and the plain cheese was just so much more satisfying. 

This is cheap, fast, yummy and easy to pick up food in a great location! Definitely recommend it for a quick, yet tasty meal!
author: Malika R.

description: Arinell is my top choice for pizza in SF and Berkeley. They offer great NY-style pizza when they are 'on point.' Unfortunately, they can be really inconsistent (e.g., some pies perfect, others way over-baked). Unrelated to the food itself is my observation that the staff always appear annoyed by the presence of customers. It doesn't offend me personally, but come on. If I were the owner I'd be embarrassed to have these guys interface with my customers. That aside, when the pizza is on point it's tough to beat Arinell in the Bay Area.
author: Jeff B.

description:
Holy crap, this place is good. 

Rainy day calls for a hot warm slice without a side of 'non sense' 
You get pizza here folks. Yup, just good old NY style pizza without all the fancy stuff. 
You want meat? You have two choices, pepperoni or sausage. If you want the foofy artisan meat on your slice, not your place... 

This place gets it right, cheap, and fast. How they do it? Well, i wouldn't put on your best shoes to visit this joint. The best seat in the house is next to a garabge can or right by the garabage can
author: Youna K.

description:
I am from NY. So weight my pizza review accordlingly please.

BEST pizza in SF if you like thin NY style crispy crust pizza.

The staff is authentic hole in the wall style grunge rock playing tatted up masters
of the simple slice and soda. 

On rare occasion you can get a slightly undercooked pie.

I have eaten hundreds of slices of pizza from this place over a 10 year period and every bite is a sweet blissful taste of home yum home.

Thank you guys for being authentic at every level!
author: Foggy Daze D.

description:
Having been to NYC and eating a slice there, I would rate the cheese slice here as just okay for me. It didn't Wow me or make me say Mmm with my first initial bite like the slice of pizza I had in NYC. 

However, I did like the thinness of the pizza and how it just had the right amount of cheese and sauce on it. The slice was really huge and I probably didn't need to order a pepperoni slice too since I was quite satisfied already. This was evident by the people who just kept ordering a slice of cheese right after me.

The service was fast and efficient. Although, someone ordering a slice with toppings seemed out of the norm for them and disrupted their ebb and flow. The cashier took notice and had to separate the line between cheese only or ones with toppings - like someone choosing to order an android phone instead of an iphone. 
Disclaimer: I'm an iphone user.

Also, this place only takes CASH so have it ready or you'll definitely mess up the rotation. Overall, a good place to get a slice of cheese pizza and be on your way.
author: Anthony A.

description: It's simple, it's thin crust, it's as close as you'll get to somewhat NY pizza in the city. I never regret my decisions when I come here.
author: Eric A.

description:
It comes close to NY style pizza, but it's still not the same.  There is something about the elasticity of the dough and the flavor of the minerals of the water from the Catskills that make it taste not like a piece of cheeseboard.  The Sicilian slices are good too, but I'll settle for a slice of NY pizza any day.  You can dress up your pizza with a variety of toppings and seasonings.  However, the flavor comes from the oil of the cheese balanced by the crust.

There is limited seating inside this hole in the wall shop.  Service is fast and friendly even with lines.  Parking is tough on the street.
author: Jenny L.

description: My go to for a New York style pizza in the city. First off they have garlic salt which is like crack. Secondly, they got the pizza stuff down cold. Great flavor, perfect every time. The only problem is sometimes the folks behind the counter are a little too baked to keep up with demand. But at least they have a good time and are able to satiate the munchies whenever they want!
author: Sara G.

description: pizza ok but served by the rudest dudes ever, stay away if you don't want to get mad
author: G A C.

description: The closest thing to NY pizza I've had in California. This is not a fancy place!! Expect to eat standing. The pizza is great!
author: Hector D.

description:
All these complaints about grease and flimsiness, but hey grease is good. I might be overgeneralizing or maybe I was too hungry, but honestly this is my favorite pizza joint in SF. NY-style pizza is my favorite type of Pizza and I am the pizza queen. I literally crave pizza in my sleep and force myself to dream about it so I don't eat late at night. 

First off, for you fatties that care a lot about size. It's huge. end of story. It's definitely bigger than my head and yeah. But that's the thing about NY-style pizza. It's huge, but not filling, because it's thin af. But that's what I LOVE about it. The thinness allows the pizza to be crispy and not too bread-y and carb-aceous (I made up this word). Most pizza you'd eat have a larger ratio of bread to cheese and sauce, but I find NY-style pizza to be just perfection. I love how simple and crispy the pizza is. IT IS GREASY AS HELL THOUGH. IT is what it is but I rike it.

Let me say one thing though, service sucks! Sometimes I walk in and the guy's just on his phone and gives me NO attention. It embarrasses me. And they're most definitely on cloud 9 because they literally look like it and respond super slow. One time I asked for a plate and the guy was being so mean about how they don't use plate. ugh. annoying.
author: Joyce L.

description:
Yes yes yes yes yes yes yes.

OMG yes.

So good, so fast, cheap and convenient. I don't know what it is about these simple slices, but the amount of cheese, thinness of the crust, and perfect portion of tomato sauce make their cheese/pepperoni slices unbeatable. I'm glad this place isn't near where I live, or this would probably be dinner 3-4 times a week. However, I will still venture out of my way for the 10 minute experience it takes to scarf down one of these treasures. Make a point to stop at this place!
author: Sarah B.

description:
NY style pizza. Big slice. They cook the toppings after the fact and throw it back in the oven. The crust is disappointing.
For $3, decent drunk spot. Would not go back sober
author: Dave C.

description: Most authentic NY pizza and experience. Best when waiting for a fresh pie when getting slices.
author: Kay A.

description: Crispy, greasy, large and flat. They take a basic slice, top it with whatever you ask for, and heat it up again for you. Solid inexpensive food on the go. NY is not my fav style, but it is by far the firmest crispy thin crust I've had in SF I think!
author: Linus W.

description:
My wife and I came here on a Saturday night at 10 pm. Even though 10 seems late there was still quite a crowd. Luckily we managed to get seats a week before using open table. At first we weren't too impressed with the ambiance but apparently everything there is recycled. The waiter said all the chrome is recycled side mirrors from cars and all the veneers are recycled toothbrushes - awesome! 

We started with two slices of the artisanal thin crust. At first I was going to take away a star because no booze, but we already had a few at the hizzy. Plus, this place has an actual soda sommelier - take that abbots cellar! He helped us with the craft soda pairings my wife had a "sweet coca cola dark with pepperoni cheese tomato blend" and I had "lemon infused sprite cola with basil pine nut pesto slice".  The sommelier had a great sense of humor and was very helpful. We'll be back for more of his tidbits and life tips!

We've eaten at a lot of flatbread places in the area including beretta and Delfina but this is the first true Italian pizza place we've been to since moving here from Tokyo (and Paris before that). The maître'd wore the Italian style with his long hair and sports cap like we've seen on visits to Italy. 

The only complaint I had was some of the clientele looked, um, shall I say, "untoward"? This one overweight guy sat there on a stool in a t short and just stared into space like he was bored. There were other people there we felt uncomfortable around. Hopefully this place gets it's act together and those people who don't feel the need have a good attitude realize they aren't welcome in this neighborhood!
author: Saul C.

description: These guys at night are total ass*****  he was mad that I ordered 5 slices of pizza then demanded a tip. He was also mad that he had to make another pizza after wards total jerks. I hope there boss can see this and let them know. They both had long hair and big mustaches bad taste of music and ugly tattoos on there arms
author: Adam B.

description:
Greatest New York style pizza experience in the Bay Area.

My friends wanted to go to Delfina's but I really wanted to try a new place, something more rough around the edges and more laid back.  I was on the search for some great NY thin crust pizza and Arinell's has the reputation for being one of the best.  

For deep dish lovers they also offer Sicilian but I ordered the Neapolitan slice ($2.75) with pepperoni on top (extra $0.50 per topping).  The pizza is as thin, greasy, and as awesome as I can remember and the long haired pizza makers were just as loud and rambunctious.  If I lived nearby no doubt I'd frequent this place at least weekly.

Tips:  Slices are served on parchment paper and you're gonna eat everything by hand (there are no forks and spoons), so don't overpower the pizza with too many toppings.  Bring CASH as they don't take card.
author: David P.

description: The best bang for your buck food in the area. Super delicious pizza, huge slices, and you can add toppings if you want. I love the mushrooms but they often come out cold which is a weird contrast to the hot pizza which is why I'm knocking off a star. Also awesome for late night!
author: Amy Y.

description: Prefer thin crust, not so doughy, and fairly sauced. This place is one spot for my liking, also they don't serve your slice on a paper plate more like a deli paper, and placed inside a white paper bag for take out. The place is small and has limited seating. Over all it is not that bad, I like it.
author: Rick M.

description:
I love that crust, nice and thin.
Zesty sauce.
Big slices.
author: Ken B.

description: The New York-iest pizza I have found so far in the city. I'll happily grab a greasy slice here any time.
author: Kurt N.

description: Best thin crust pizza in the Bay Area.
author: Scott B.

description: Arinell Pizza never disappoints. Who cares if the staff is crabby? It's 1am on a Saturday night, Ozzie is blasting, and the pizza is fresh out of the oven. These dives are what make the Mission. Hopefully it will be around for another 40 years!
author: Christine E.

description: My husband is always on the hunt for the best pizza this place was good- but there are better. The pizza didn't live up to all the reviews.
author: Courtney M.

description: The pizza might be good but it feels like they're doing you a favor. No smiles, cut you off while talking... Really unpleasant service!
author: Arsema B.

description:
I love this place. Small enough to eat a slice and go, and there's always metal playing. I love those guys. 
I'm from Chicago and my boyfriend is from New York so we both know a good slice when we see it. 
This is my favorite spot in San Francisco for a NY style pizza, and don't forget to try the Sicilian at some point.
author: Amanda M.

description:
As close to NYC or Philly pizza as I have ever had east of the mississippi (or penn).  I am on the east coast at least a month of the year and this is it for NYC pizza in SF.

Killer and cheap.
author: Otto V.

description: Best slice of ny style pizza I've had in the city. It's a small shop with only a few places to sit and the guys running are usually dicks, but it's all part of the charm.
author: Logan T.

description: Best pizza in San Francisco, not just because it tastes exactly like what I want a cheese slice to taste like, but because it is $3 a slice, the people working there don't try to tell you how it was locally sourced and organic, and it reminds me to a cheaper city like NY with every bite.
author: Michael J.

description: Cool New York style pizza by the slice. They serve the NY pizza and the attitude. Quick spot with very little seating. I wouldn't go out of my way to visit.
author: Clive B.

description: Genuinely surprised to see how good of reviews this place gets.  They sell very plain pizza by the slice (just cheese), have very little toppings to add, and have some very rude workers. The pizza place on 24th street is the obvious choice to go for pizza in the mission!
author: Ray W.

description: Moved to the west coast from NYC & just miss NYC pizza? Then take your deprived butt down to this spot. Closest thing I've tasted on the west coast that even hits the same type of cheese. Drove from Los Angeles to San Francisco just to check this out. Well not entirely but you know what I mean! The Sicilian is the business!!!!
author: Erika F.

description:
Can't believe these last couple of reviews people have left. Yelp is not for constantly bashing a place, it's to give your opinion and that's it. No need for hatred and negativity towards the business. Pizza is yummy and the staff is extremely friend as well. To the idiots who said that the workers are racist: you are completely incorrect for the fact that I am not white what so ever & was treated extremely well.
Sorrrrrry douche bags.
author: Leeana B.

description: It's alright...I just need to go to the ny to have real pizza. It's not all the hype...
author: Sim T.

description: I last reviewed Arinell Pizza in 2009. Seven years later the pizza is still just as good. The best NYC style slice in San Francisco. Have cash, no cards accepted.
author: joe f.

description:
3.5 stars 

Good NY styled thin crust pizza.  Stick with the cheese or pepperoni, which they already have.  You can add extra toppings but it really doesn't add to it.  We had it with mushroom and sausage - the mushroom slices are too thick and not very flavorful.  The sausage is also in thick slices, not the ground ones you would expect.

Neopolitan is $2.75/slice.  Sicilian is $3/slice.  $0.50/topping:  pepperoni, olives onions or garlic.  $0.75/topping:  mushrooms, anchovies, sausage, green pepper or extra cheese.
author: Gloria H.

description:
Whether you live in San Francisco or you're just visiting for the day, this place is a must. They're pizzas are made New York style and they taste great! All toppings are fully customizable and made to order. At the same time, the pizzas only take a couple minutes to make, making this place the perfect place to grab a quick bite. The slices are very reasonably priced and are very generously sized.  At this pizza place, I'd stick to only one topping as toppings fall off quite easily. 

Overall, being located at the heart of the mission district, and the friendly, efficient working employees make this place an easy 5 star location for me.
author: Vishaal P.

description:
I grew up in new york.

For 10 years living in Ca, I used to long for authentic thin hot simple new york pizza by the slice. 

Now, when, I visit new york, I wish I was eating a slice from Arinell.
author: Evrett K.

description: I know this is going to be a controversial review, and this might be because I was born and raised in CA, but this is just OK. 5-stars for getting the low-key, cheap, and quick part of pizza by the slice down. But I think the flavor is super bland in both the Sicilian and the regular pizza. But that's just me, and it might be because I've been spoiled by Little Star (which I know is in its own category).
author: San D.

description:
I feel really bad about giving them a 3 star but I really think they deserve to be 3.75
I like the pizza but serving it on a wax paper is a problem because it gets a little greasy and the bar table is not always clean. 
A basic paper plate just makes it a little more appetizing and clean. 
With all of these stars, I can't imagine they can't afford paper plates? 

In terms of quality alone, this is a legit pizza and I'm still debating whether I should go back or try other pizza joints?
author: Chris L.

description:
New York style this is not. Just because a slice is thin-crust & so big that it requires folding before taking a bite doesn't make it ny style. There is nothing special about this crust (not chewy or flavorful enough) & they're skimpy of the tomato sauce, which needs a hint more tang. 

$3 for a cheese slice. Unless you're lucky enough to arrive as a pie's comin' fresh out the oven, you'll be getting a re-heated slice. They seem to do enough business that your chances should be good. Toppings ($.50 each) are added after the pizza's already been baked; I've never seen that "technique" before. 

Upside: I didn't experience the level of greasiness other reviewers have noted (& I hate excess grease.) 

Basically, don't believe the hype & definitely don't come here expecting real ny style pizza. Fly into LGA or JFK for that.
author: Fancypants X.

description: This is a good drunk pizza place, but not a good sober pizza place. The pizza is great in that extremely greasy type of way, but you really have to be in the mood for it or the grease will just overwhelm you.
author: Neha S.

description:
+5 stars for all that's mother-fu*king right about Arinell's.

Sketch corner with freaky people? Check. Tattoo parlor across street? Check. Skate kids busting moves right outside window? Check. Punk music playing in shop? Check? Daytime hookers? Check. Tech nerds with unfortunate haircuts? Check. Fender-bender almost resulting in fist-fight right out window? Check. Crazed homeless guys traversing foyer? Check!

NY Style pizza slices with the most authentic sauce / cheese / crust taste you're going to find west of The Village or Brooklyn? Checkity check check check. This is your fix right here, homie.
author: Mark S. I.

description:
Wow. This is it. This is THE spot in The Mission to get AUTHENTIC New York style pizza. Not one of those phony places with those thick ass slices. This is the real deal, thin slices, excellent crust. The atmosphere isn't everyone's favorite but who cares? They're quick and don't make you wait. 

As an east coast native, this is the only pizza place that I've found in SF that even comes CLOSE to the real deal. And it doesn't just come close, it matches it.
author: Brian F.

description: If you want a great NY style pizza, give this hole in the wall a second glance. I've been eating here for years, sometimes eating a reheated slice in the small counter areas, but mostly ordering a large to take away. And those are your options, there's no delivery. But piping hot just right pizza is worth questing 16th and Valencia.
author: Jamil M.

description: Best pizza west of the Mississippi. It's a little place. If I lived in San Francisco, I'd be a regular.
author: Paul W.

description: Hands down the best pizza I've ever had. The pizza is so thin and crispy. I haven't had any better pizza in SF. The slices are a pretty good size. I've been to this pizza joint many times and the employees are always nice
author: Elba A.

description:
This is redundant, because of my previous review for their site in Berkeley, but I'll just note that the Mission location suffers not a jot in comparison, and despite their lack of access to the Catskills watershed, they make outstanding NY style pizza.  All my Easty friends agree. This is the (stuff).

A couple of notes to add:  it's just pizza and drinks.  Cash only.  But what else do you need?
author: Bob K.

description: The wonderful thin crust reminds me of Secret Pizza at the Cosmo in Vegas. Crisp on the bottom edge but yet has a nice chew. However, the sauce and seasoning falls well sort of SP. Good NYC style stand-in.
author: John H.

description: My doctor friend told me that you guys kicked him out because he is Indian....tell your side of the story or I will never go to your place again and make sure everyone I know will never go to your place either
author: Payam S.

description:
The woman working at the Visitors Center praised Arinell Pizza and said it was like pizza in New York.  So I walked from Powell & Market to the Mission District for pizza.  

Arinell is a little hole in the wall place like I used to go in the East Village (in NYC).  And the pizza is okay.  But it ain't NY pizza.  No.  Sorry.  To stiff.  Too brittle.  Guess the woman at the Visitors Center has never been to NY.

But I am giving it three stars anyway.  It was an interesting walk, and hey, now I know what the tenderloin is like (having walked past it one the way to Arinell).
author: Mr. And Mrs. M.

description: For years, always the same two heavy metals dudes in here serving up simple yet excellent pizza. Not to get esoteric and compare to New York or a small village near Naples, but I gotta say, on any given night in the MIssion after a couple of cocktails, these slices are a welcome answer to my grumbling stomach and they seem to prevent hangovers too. These guys figured the trick isn't to import water, nor over-cheese and over-top, nor leverage a time-tested, passed-down secret. Instead, they just keep it simple, thin crust, not too much cheese, reheat in a hot pizza over and serve so it's a tad crispy, melted and tasty.  Congrats guys! Hope to see you soon.
author: Brian J.

description: Eating here just makes me so genuinely happy that I felt the need to give another 5 stars. When I put this stuff in my mouth it's like I'm back in high school at St. John's Pizzeria (RIP) near Union Turnpike and Utopia Pkwy, watching the Mets win the 1986 World Series while burning the roof of my mouth with slice after slice of awesome pizza. Thank you Arinell for not giving in to all the hipsters. If I ever heard the word "artisan" in the same sentence as "Arinell's Pizza", I can't be held responsible for what happens next. Geez, this pizza still rocks. Please, never change a thing.
author: Jason G.

description: Today is March 14, 2015 and after work around 430  I went to get a slice of pizza and I noticed the cashier was handling the money at the same time he was handling the pizzas so I asked him "if he can go wash his hands after dealing with the money before he touch my slice of pizza and of course he refused an he told me he won't be given me any service". I was so shocked and appalled I didn't know what to say but OK and turn  around and lefted.Now I am an  African American woman in my early thirties and I know it did not have anything to do with me asking him to wash his hands it was because of the color of my skin. It is people like this that will soon go out of business you cannot possibly think you can go around being racist and it will not catch up to you because initially  you reap what you sow
author: Comelia J.

description:
A slice of cheese pizza for three bucks.  It was tasty.  Only six stools in entire place.  Garlic, oregano, red peppers and parmesan cheese for free  toppings.

Stopped here after walking from Duboce Park.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
It is perfect pizza. It is cheap. I experience moments of bliss while eating it.

It is served by a bunch of young guys in bands who look like they party pretty hard.

I don't recommend toppings. They put the toppings on afterward, and they don't really get cooked into the pizza. Normally I love toppings on pizza, but here I only get the regular cheese, and it is incredible. 

There is absolutely nothing fancy about this place. It is just a hole in the wall pizza shop. But the end product is amazing.
author: Jimmy H.

description: Easily the best NYC style slice in SF. Extra thin with great sauce and just the right amount of cheese.
author: Jason S.

description:
your blood pressure is 120 / 80

your weight is perfect for your height

you're by nature patient with looking for parking

you only have $25 - 30 in your pocket (whole pizza) about $3 for a slice

this hole in the wall place will satisfy your craving for thin crust pizza
author: Martin C.

description:
#84 on the 2011 7x7 List: Cheese slice
#86 on the 2009 7x7 List: Cheese slice

-Tasty?  The cheese sure stretches with a generous amount of mozzarella.  The thin crust deserves a thumbs-up for not being limp.  There are so many other cheese slices out there that are so oily and drippy.   Not this slice.

-Service:  Two dudes working the joint to pay the bills - one takes your money and the other heats your pizza up.  That's about it and that's all you need anyway

-Ambiance: Two sides of against the wall -  counter space for eating; The place is a little dirty but you wouldn't expect less in this area

-Worth the trip/try?  For a quick, cheap lunch in the area - yes.  Otherwise, unless this is one of many stops on the food train, I will shrug at the question
author: Winnie L.

description: My favorite spot for a slice of cheese in SF. The cheese pizza by the slice has perfectly thin crust, the sauce is very fresh and the cheese is the ideal consistency.
author: H K.

description:
I LOVE the pizza here!! Mmmmmm......yum!
They've been closing super early lately which sucks and I wish the people who work there would be a little nicer but either way good/ fast/ cheap pizza a block from my house! Done deal!
author: Tumay A.

description: Not much choice (love that).  Cheap pizza.  Cash only.  Add your toppings (although cheeze str8 up is da bomb).  Fast service.  Friendly dudes.  Weekly customer.  That is all.
author: Adele Z.

description: if you want to be kicked out of a restaurant because of the color of your skin go here! Racist skinheads!
author: Sapna G.

description:
In NYC, this would be a mediocre pizza joint, nothing bad, nothing special. But here in SF, it's outstanding. It's the only place I know that makes real NY-style pizza.

I grew up in NJ, and to me, this was just standard pizza. You could get it anywhere. Then I moved out here. Lots of stores claimed they made NY-style pizza, but they were all alien to me. Until a friend sent me to Arinell's.

If you're looking for amazing gourmet pizza, go somewhere else. But if you're an NY-area transplant and feeling a little homesick, get some pizza here.

p.s. You can also buy pizza dough here to take home. It's good stuff. Add some gourmet toppings, and you could give Delfina a run for its money.
author: Elika E.

description: This is a great late night pizza place. It's super small but well worth the wait in line. The pepperoni pizza totally hit the spot for me last night and when I'm out in that area again I'll definitely be going back. There is another pizza place a few doors down and Arinells is much better by far!
author: Bhavisha P.

description: This pizza is delicious and very cheap for a huge slice! We had a late night out in a couple different districts and decided to grab a bite before heading home. Two slices of pepperoni for $6 can't beat that. Some of the best pizza I have had while in SF.
author: Matthew M.

description:
Not debatable if you know anything. Best NY style pizza in Northern California and probably California and I have been on a mission for years to find anything even close out here in the West. Pretty much nobody can make NY City thin crust pizza anywhere but NYC. Arinelli is as close as you can get to the real thing. It's even the type of joint you might see in NYC. No SF bullshit, foo foo black truffle organic blah blah blah here. Just the next best thing to good street pizza from the Big Apple. 

I hope this place never dies. 

And don't get any toppings!!! You will ruin it.
author: r k.

description: $3 for a plain slice, how can you beat that? Its a damn good slice, always hot and fresh and the crust is just thick (or thin enough) to hold the sauce and cheese.  By far one of my favorite pizza spots in the city.  If you're on a budget, this is the spot to go to.
author: Darren W.

description: This would have been a perfect slice had the sauce not been far too heavy on the oregano, giving it a frozen-like taste.
author: Rushil R.

description:
I'm only updating/downgrading my review in hopes the owner will see.  I don't want to call the shop and get anyone specific in trouble.
I've been eating slices at Arinell on Valencia for over 20 years.  It was always consistent and the closest to a real hole-in-the-wall NY slice available in the Bay Area.
Now I live overseas.  But, when I go home to the City to visit family, Arinell is always a much-anticipated stop... at least 3 times a week, in fact!  I just spent all of July home for my mom's 70th birthday,  I had slices at Arinell 5 or 6 times.  Each time the blond-ish guy who's worked there for at least 15 years was working, the slices were as expected.  But, 2 or 3 times it was other staff.  While the pizza looked almost correct, the balance and flavor were all off. The crust was slightly heavier and lacked the 'crack' when biting in.
Dear owner:  PLEASE crack the whip a bit and get these guys back on the right page!  I will miss you dearly!
author: Josh K.

description: Best thin-crust pizza in SF.  It's New York style, as long as you're not too strict about that...
author: Dan M.

description:
Cash only? Check.

Made quickly? Check.

Delicious? Check.

The staff is friendly and fast, the pizza tastes good. It's inexpensive and very filling. Oh, and I should probably mention I work right across the street from them.

I probably wouldn't go out of my way to come here, but many of my friends would beg to differ.
author: Richard K.

description:
The closest thing to the very best New York style pizza on the west coast can be found here in the heart of the mission district in San Francisco.
Close to the corner of 16th and Valencia, I was introduced to this place when I came into the Bay Area 11 years ago and I have to say it restored my faith in pizza. I'll drive from my home on the other side of the bay to this place at 1 in the morning to get a pizza. There cool dudes that work here. They recognize me and I don't have to wait in line to get my preordered pizza, kinda like the rock star treatment, plus a good tip helps! It's a hole in the wall. Good luck finding parking (but hey, it's San Francisco) I'm telling you, it's worth it!
author: troy m.

description: Had a poor experience with this place. Rang ahead and ordered a pizza, guy on the phone was very impatient and not helpful. Got there to pick it up and be accused me of cutting the line. But then he rudely demanded money for it. It was clear they hadn't even begun making the pizza at this stage. We then checked back in for it after the time he'd stated and he called us impatient. When the pizza arrived he announced it was for "the impatient nontippers" to the whole crowd. Just totally dreadful service. The pizza didn't even taste that good. Skimpy ingredients, the only delicious aspect was the sausage. Overall a one star experience.
author: Joe B.

description: It's a great place, and really a five star, but The Pizza Shop on 24th is better.
author: Girlie G.

description:
Erm, yeah, interesting hole-in-a-wall joint. I haven't eaten as much NY pizza as I would like to so I'm not going to compare.

I've really only cared for the cheese pies. It's a big thin greasy thin slice of cheesiness, with some tomato sauce on it. The crust is pretty good too. I can usually chow the whole piece down quickly without feeling greased out though, which has always been a mystery to me.

Definitely really good if you're drunk or have been looking for some food. I can see why people rate it so highly. I'm always a bit scared of walking into the place though because it looks sketchy even for a hole-in-a-wall joint...

P.S. I'm not really sure how this got onto the 7x7 big eat list...but judging by the Yelp reviews, it sure is popular.
author: Alice C.

description: Wow, pizza place on mission that sells by the slice :) All I was missing was a tall can. This was a great hidden gem with an amazing price for the BIG piece you get. I couldn't even finish it. The crust was thick and delic. A+
author: Jess C.

description:
Take it from an old Nyer, this place has true NY pizza. And I'm going to be specific now, since pizza in ny has gone way down hill: from 1960s to about 1980s pizza in Jamaica, in the 3 tris in Manhattan, half of brroklyn, and nearly all of jersey (who i begrudgingly admit had and still has the best pizza 'cuz real esate is cheaper there--duh). arinelle's is not wood or charcoal brick oven, which is very rare today in ny , but it's terrific thin slice ny style.

on the racist allegations abut this place: i was there the night of alleged incident. i am a man of color and i saw no racism--although staff was typically short-tempered, arbitrary, rude, and dismissive with customer and they did ask him to leave. its very NYer, btw. honestly no one in NY would EVER complain about the staff behavior lol, not that i'm saying it's totally acceptable. i was once thrown out of there long ago, lost my temper, and then just shrugged it off, went back later, figured out the personality of the place and then I figured out how to enjoy it. 

i know these guys can be very rude, curt, terse, d!cks but i think they are equal opportunity jerks, when they are jerks, which is not the majority of the time :) because

I have also seen them be very gracious, generous, capacious, giving, cool, funny, communal, and good neighbors on the street, so let's remember that, too. and if you don't like their personalities (i know a bunch of good restaurants whose owners are jerks so... I don't.
the pizza itself: best ny style in sf
staff attitude: an acquired taste: 
A) if you're from the midwest and call your mom "ma'am" this place likely is not for you and ny pizza is a meaningless abstraction anyway; however, if

B) you have spent time on a chain gang and think the idea of going after moby dick sounds kinda cool, then you'll love this place--may you be thrown out, enoy, and return:)
author: Jesus R.

description:
Very thin, cheesy pizza. 

Can probably seat 6 ppl in the whole place. 
More of a grab n go.

Better to get the whole pizza than a slice because it's fresher & slices are reheated.

Pretty fast to get whole pizza. But really fast to get a slice.
author: Gee H.

description:
I'm a huge fan of NY style pizza but this place ain't even close to a 99 cent pizza plase in NYC.  This place is completely overrated by typical SF people who base their opinions not on quality and service but on whether they think a place is hip or not.

If you like Zeitgeist you'll love this place because they have the same crap attitude towards customers and morons here eat that sh!t up and go back for more.  The staff here no doubt laugh at how you keep coming back and act subservient to them, who are a bunch of toothless heshers who are about as intelligent as a bucket of hair.

The pizza here is like cardboard and it's flavorless.  It's not terrible it just okay and it's no where near as great as people make it out to be.  But if it's late and you're trashed and you need something to soak up the booze, it's worthwhile.

This pizza is basically as good as Costco Pizza just with a better cheese to sauce ratio.

As overrated as By-Rite Ice Cream... oh wait I better review them next....
author: Deke R.

description: One of the best pizza joints in the bay area. Make sure you buy a whole pie as their reheated slices don't do this place justice.
author: James F.

description:
I'm prepared to say that this is the best slice of pizza I've eaten in San Francisco.  Foreals.  

For $2.75, you get a simple, thin slice of NY-style pizza.  I totally recommend just getting a simple slice of cheese pizza, no extra toppings.  Well, except for sprinkling some more parmesan and pepper.  The guy working there cuts you a fattyass slice, heats it up, and hands it to you all piping hot on top and crispy on the bottom.  It's super greasy, but that's what makes it excellent.  It's also super wide, so I think I now understand why some people fold their pizza.  

The place is really a hole in the wall, so I think it's better to just take your slice and walk and eat down Valencia.  Make sure to take lots of napkins, though, because the thing is extremely greasy, and the oil will not only get all over your mouth and face but also drip all over your hands.  

Oh, but it's so worth it.  I have a craving right now as I'm sitting at work.  I just might hit it up after work even though it's totally out of my way. . .it's THAT good.
author: Vivian C.

description: Walked in - the place is really small and there's only a few bar stool to sit at on the side.  There were only 2 pizzas - cheese and a deep dish cheese.  Lucky for me I like plain cheese pizza.  The thin crust was pretty good - crispy yet a little soft.  Not as cheesey as I would like it.  But not a bad place to grab a cheap, quick bite to eat on the go.  But bring cash...they're CASH ONLY.
author: Rose A.

description: The best pizza I've had outside of Nyc! Most def recommend! Fast service and good price! They even have garlic powder! So many pizza shops don't have garlic powder!
author: Hector T.

description:
Simple, affordable and the closest thing to NYC pizza you can get in the city period.  When I need my pizza slice or whole pie fix I trek on over to the Mission and satisfy that craving.   This is a simple pizza counter joint with a few stools if you want to eat on the spot.  

Great dough, sauce, cheese and your choice of topping ranging from .50 cents to .75 cents per topping for individual slices.  I usually go cheese or pepperoni as my go to pizza.  They are relatively quick, your pizza is topped and from the oven to you in about 4 minutes.  Hot every time, the slice is sizable with that hint of grease and the crust has a nice crunch but allows you to get your appropriate fold on for grubbing.
author: Grubnoisseur Y.

description:
I would say the best NY style pizza in Bay Area. People from the burbs may feel a little uneasy in this neighborhood at night. Well worth the trip out here.

Make sure use a little garlic powder on your slice.
author: David H.

description:
I actually crave a slice from this place about once a week. It's smart of Arinell to add the toppings made to order. I like the  thin crust, mushrooms and yellow pepper combo. Never mind that it is located right across the street from Blondie's  (home of the best martini you will ever have) and never mind the accolades posted on the front door.  It's worth a visit for a midday snack or a midnight slosh feast.

I rock this joint like my mom rocked polyester bell-bottoms in the seventies.
author: Hannah A.

description:
Probably my favorite slice of thin crust pizza in the city.
Mushroom slice is excellent - especially after drinks in the Mission.
author: Kent T.

description:
I grew up and raised a family in NY, and I ate my share of NY style pizza.  I loved them piping hot that burns my upper palate, oozing with olive oil and mozzarella that flowed like lava.  But most of all, I loved their full bodied flavor.

At Arinell, I found the crust to be thin, crispy and crunchy.  That was very NY styled.  But when I bit into the main part of the slice, I was disappointed that the sauce was flat and flavorless.  It tasted like DelMonte canned tomato sauce without any effort to flavor the sauce.  The cheese lacked the aroma and fresh taste of good mozzarella.  And the piece was dry without any indication they used olive oil at all.

The pizza is New York styled all right.  But it tasted like mediocre pizza from a run-of-the-mill pizza joint in NYC.  Nothing to get excited about.  I can't wait to visit my folks in NYC and gorge myself silly there.
author: Robert W.

description:
A ton of transplants below have already mentioned that this place is the closest thing to NY style pizza. I'm a huge fan because the sauce isn't to complex and the thin crispy dough/crust is a whole lot different from most other "by the slice" places in this city. The guys working the counter are always friendly and fast.
My only complaint is it's still Cash only.
author: Andrew Z.

description:
Arinell's is one of the best places in SF for pizza by the slice....ok, probably the best, and closest to New York you'll find here.....seconded by Marcello's on Castro. 

I think they put love in it, I believe these pizzamongers actually care and want you to enjoy their food. (but according to other reviewers they can sometimes be a bit cantankerous, tsk tsk)

Knocking off a star as they don't have a bathroom, at least not one they let patrons use, but instead direct you to the nearby Muddy Waters cafe.
author: Gwynnie P.

description: I only went to this pizza place because Nizaro's pizza  was closed . This pizza place honestly seems like it was created when the owner was high or something lol . The pizza slice was huge and they didn't serve on plates sadly . They served it on thin wax paper and the pizza was burning hot when they gave it to me that I almost dropped it . It was too hot to hold so my friend and I bought a big pizza box to hold it . Anyways , the pizza place is pretty small and like I said , I feel like this place was created when the owner was high or something
author: Katy W.

description:
This is my favorite pizza place in SF, hands down. I'm originally from NYC so I have opinions about how my pizza should be - thin, crispy crust, light sauce and cheese - and Arinell's lines up exactly with what I want. So good. I get a slice of mushroom sometimes, but really it's about the plain slice. The dudes that work there could give a damn about "customer service" but that's part of what I like. With pizza like this I don't care if you're nice to me. 

My only complaint is that they're not open late weeknights, and sometimes they close early when they say they'll be open late.
author: Greg N.

description: Simple. Good. Crispy. Tomatoey and cheesy without nonsense, fuss, or pretenses. Not enough really good thin crust in my life. This is pretty perfect.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Dedicated to Nobu K (aka Froyo Dude)....since I don't eat much pizza but you wanted my opinion, I went to Arinell's just for you.  This place gets the basics of New York pizza right, so it isn't fancy or gourmet.  It even has a bit of New York attitude with the cash only, no cell phones, and no jokers signs.  The counters are greasy.  One guy makes the pizzas and serves as the cashier too.

They had two huge pizzas, one was the Neopolitan (thin crust) and the other was Sicilian (thick crust).  You can add on toppings (50 or 75 cents each). They had 8 toppings to choose from.  The toppings are your basics - mushrooms, olives, pepperoni, etc.

I had a slice of the Neopolitan ($2.75) with mushrooms (75 cents).  The crust is perfection - if you like a thin, crisp crust that's still soft on top. The cheese stays on the pizza (hate when it slides off) and there isn't much of it.  The tomato sauce is good and simple.  I liked the textures and the fact that it wasn't super greasy - but it seemed a bit too plain. I miss those fancy gourmet toppings.
author: Lolia S.

description: Was about to order till the cook started being rude and thought we were soliciting and told us to hurry up and buy already.. So nah never again
author: Stephanie I.

description:
Arinell Pizza. SF's Big Eat 7x7 list has a slice of cheese pizza from here as a "must try" before you die. But why? What distinguishes this small pizzeria from the rest, so much that it even made a(ny) list.

Is it location? Well, it can't be. It lacks convenience because it's on busy Valencia Street. Parking is scarce. 

Is it price? Well, maybe. Two slices of cheese pizza only cost $5 and some change.

Is it choice? Well, there are only two available selections: 
*Neopolitan- thin crust 
*Sicilian- thick crust

Is it taste or quality? Well, their slice of cheese did taste good. However, the thin crust, light tomato sauce, & thin layer of cheese did not WOW me.  Regarding quality, a billboard claims no sugar or MSG is used in their pizza. Okay. Thanks.

Is it service or ambiance? Service was great. The cashier was very friendly & personable. However, the ambiance was casual...a place you would quickly be in and out of, not a place to hang out & relax in. Besides, the cashier WAS the cook/pizza guy. Ew! (That's disgusting on so many levels.)

So, WHAT is it then? Hm, I don't know. I really don't know HOW or WHY it's on that list. Meanwhile, you can catch me enjoying a slice of deep dish pizza, Classic style w/ hearty chunks of sausage & delightfully tasteful cornmeal crust, at Little Star...just a few blocks away!
author: Joy A.

description:
It's okay.  I have definitely have had better thin crust pizzas.  

I know pizza is greasy but it doesn't have to be that greasy and I definitely had to use napkins in order to wipe off the grease.  

I am on the quest to find the best thin sliced pizza in SF.
author: Vagabond V.

description:
Great thin crust and toppings. Quick service and friendly staff.
Best pizza I've had in California, I was starting to lose hope.
author: Sarah-Jane S.

description: Came by for a late night bite and I must say the service and the food is great.  Shared a Neapolitan and Sicilian with my mate and it was great!
author: Bianca D.

description: This pizza is overrated. I've definitely had MUCH better pizza (yes, I've had lots of pizza in NY). My slice seemed like it was dipped in grease :O I'm not going to be eating here again.
author: Jamie T.

description: I'm not from NYC, but I've been there a few times and had "the real deal." Whether this is it or not, I don't feel totally qualified to say, but I will say it reminded me of NYC. And even if it didn't, it's still really good, like the sauce is so delicious. Ratio of ingredients is ideal, I highly recommend. I'm rarely satisfied with just cheese on other styles of pizza (California style, or like Domino's), but just cheese is perfect here.
author: Amanda P.

description: I didn't feel this place lived up to the hype, honestly, but it didn't suck...not at all. The pizza wasn't terrible...and, given the cost, maybe thats the reason for high reviews.  It's cheap! 3 bucks nets you a very decent slice.  The vibe is fun!  I was given an assortment of (presumably) IPod driven Van Halen.  I can eat ANY pizza to Van Halen....especially early Dave stuff like "Mean Streat", "DOA", and "Hear About It Latter".   I digress about how I digest... The staff was fun and weird.  It felt nice being in there, and I wish I liked the slice better.  But no.  It's pretty average.  Crust, sauce, cheese, char...all are just...OK.  However.  The price (yep...I'm saying it again!) is killer!  I can't say I won't be back.  There is nothing wrong with this joint for a quick pop-in cure to starvation.
author: Evan M.

description: Delicious pizza! I got 2 slices to eat, without realizing how big a single slice is, and it was huge! The pizza was great though, perfectly cooked and great combination of cheese and sauce. I also loved the pizza crust. Compared to most other place, it wasn't made of cornbread (?), so wasn't super-crusty, but soft and tasty. I have tried other Pizza places in the area as well, and I like it more than Tony's pizza.
author: Ravish C.

description:
I love me some plain cheese pizza. Most of the ones I've encountered in SF have been the 'trying-to-outdo-others-with-lavisness' type of pizza, of which I'm not a fan.  (I'm looking at you, salad on top of pizza!) Cheese, sauce, and bread. Is it that hard? Apparently so. But not at Arinell's.

As a pizza lover (neopolitan, big slices style), this is a must. I don't eat sicilian style pizza so we'll skip that part. The big slices part is really appealing to me. It's the size of your head.

Pizza: $3/slice of plain cheese. $0.50 for toppings. You can get 2 slices and a small soda for under $10.  Did I mention the slices are huge? You can get away with just 1 slice as a meal!!  

Location: Right on 16th and Valencia. They are open late, so after a night of drinking and needing munches, this is the perfect place for that. 

Other deets: They play punk/rock music. Reminds me of the early 90s and growing up on the East Coast. The dudes who work there are totally chill. There's room to seat like 6 people total at their 2 countertops. Most of the time, it's just eat and go. They also have free jalapeno peppers on top of the pizza counter!  Apparently they don't put extra salt except for in the bread, and that may make a huge difference. 

Definitely go there if:
- you are in need for some 'real' pizza
- you only have a $5 or $10
- it's late night and you're drunk/stoned/any and need sustenance
author: R B.

description: I was born & raised in NYC and you can ask any NY'er the two things they always miss are pizza and bagels. There are so many places outside of NY that claim to be NY pizza but 99% of them FAIL!! This hole in the wall gem is truly NY pizza. I have to come to SF during midday every few months and make it a point to grab a slice for lunch every time I'm here (today was 2 LOL).  This place is a must go to if ur a real NY pizza afficianado. Check out the pic I posted as well ;)
author: Brian C.

description: Solid pizza! Thin crunchy goodness. I had a slice of sausage and a slice of pepperoni! The pepperoni was the better of the two. You can't go wrong with this place.
author: Goodguy M.

description:
Huge slices fresh out of the oven for ~$2.50 apiece. Consider me a fan! It's not the best pizza around, but it's quick and the thin crust is satisfyingly crispy.

If you're buying more than a slice for yourself, they charge $0.50 for boxes.
author: Nick S.

description:
So this is the same as the one in Berkeley so the same review I gave it for that one applies here. 

Awesome pizza. Simple and delicious- that's it. One of the best pizzas I've ever had.
author: Cesie A.

description:
I discovered this place a couple years ago and to this day, it's one of only a couple places I'll go to if I want a good slice. Thin crust, hot cheese, and greasy pepperoni, just the way it should be.

It's a classic hole in the wall, with a couple stools lining either side, walls adorned by fliers for shows at the Knockout and other places, a cheap stereo blasting metal and punk rock, and staff that look like they just came from a show.

What's not to like?
author: Ian F.

description:
What can I say, BEST slice of cheese pizza ever for $2.75! 

This place was listed on 7x7 Big Eats and my bf recommended it, so I definitely had to try it. I got a single slice of cheese and it was  love at first bite! The slice was pretty thin, but they give you a big slice. And they stick it into the oven at the perfect temperature for a perfect amount of time  and it comes out nice and crunchy. Oh and you HAVE to eat it immediately after you get it, or it won't taste the same after it cools down or no longer as crunchy. 

If I'm ever craving for a slice of pizza, this is my place to go!
author: Harriet W.

description:
Took my daughter to check out some schools in the area (she has her heart set on the East Coast). We looked at a few colleges, did some shopping in the city and decided to Yelp a spot for a good slice. I have to tell ya! I've had some delicious slices on the East end of things and... I'm sorry but, Arinell's was by far the most delicious pizza I've had on both ends of the U.S. (sorry NY/Catskills). I'm so glad we ordered a large to take back to the hotel with us! We ate that baby right out of the oven then snacked on a few slices late that night. SO delicious. I also have to say that the two down-to-earth pizza artisans were totally chill, not ALL BUSINESS like you'll get on the East. They know their pizza but they weren't just tossin' you out the door with your slice! They engaged with customers, enjoyed a few laughs, suggested a deep-dish-by-the-slice to a passerby... just real service with a smile! Like another Yelper mentions, there are no frills here (specialty pizza, crazy side dishes, etc.), but the pizza's outstanding and the service is awesome!  You won't need much else! Oh, napkins! :) You'll need napkins, for sure! Anyone who complains about pizza being too greasy needs to just STOP, now! That's just crazy-talk. Pizza=greasy! 

btw: I also have to disagree with the review of "bland bread"... here's the thing, they note that they do not use those additives that 'others' use... it's just good authentic pizza. The bread is BANGIN' because these guys know how to work it all together without the extra shortcuts people who've trained their taste-buds for the likes of pizza at their local Round Table or Dominos! 

*not tryin to send negativity out into the Yelp-world... just sharing my humble opinion and a bit of perspective (take it or leave it!). 
*but DO try Arinell's, and make your own informed decision!
author: Teresa C.

description:
As a Brooklynite I think my review should be taken seriously. I was taken to Arinell's in Berkeley in 1989 when I moved here from NY and instantly fell in love with the NY slice and the sicilian. This is by far, the closest thing you can get to NY pizza. 
Over the years, I have never had a bad slice there. Now if you want delicious gourmet type Pizza, Tony's in North Beach and Club Deluxe on Haight are spectacular. 
Now if Arinells sold sausage rolls and Italian Ices, I would feel like I am really in Brooklyn.
author: Michael A.

description: BEST ZA IN SF! i lived in New York for 8 years and had my jams of amazing slices... Arinell's comes closest to that delish new york slice. Good vibes! Good music! get your za on!
author: Colleen C.

description: Would you pay to see a yammering tech bro kicked out of a place just for being a d*bag? I sure would, but I don't have to at Arinell Pizza, because that's just how they roll. Arinell has proudly maintained its no-bullshit attitude, while serving up a classic New York pizza that blows away every other late night spot in the Mission. Can you find gluten free menu options? No. Can you call them and ask how much cab fare is from Fisherman's Wharf? No. Don't be a dumbass. Can you go for a real deal NY slice while listening to the Misfits or Slayer? YES.
author: Andy T.

description:
The Deep Dish Pan Pizza is super good and great for movie night.
They don't deliver but that is alright.  Get your cardio in and pick it up.

Taste is super good and it is the type of hole in the wall that is perfect for takeout.
author: Nico S.

description:
I'm back on my 7 x 7 magazine Big Eat SF list again!

I got a slice of the cheese pizza, which is #86 on the list. The boy had a slice of the mushroom and sausage pizza.

The $2.75 cheese pizza was just okay. Thin crust, cheesy, nice sauce, huge slice. (I'm definitely more of a deep dish pizza girl. GIVE ME CARBS!)  Arinell's is generous with their toppings, but it's literally put on top of an already made cheese pizza and reheated in their oven. Come on now, that's just $4.50 worth of laziness.

I don't think I'll be back anytime soon. Not even when I'm drunk.
author: Janice C.

description:
Put away those bon bons ladies and hold the leopard skin pants gay guys, because boy have I found the perfect match for all you Jake and Viennas out there.

Meet Arinell, Ari for short. It is SF after all so equal opportunity dating. Plus, he's Jewish! Exotic!!

For the Eva Mendeses (Mendeze?) and pretty much every girl, it's a thin crust (re: hits the gym aka lean and mean like Ryan Gosling) pizza that is "crazy" and "stupid" good. You'll "love" that it is an homage to the NY style that you don't have to "drive" all the way to NYC for. 

Or, if you're like Snooki and are into big juiceheads and gorillas, this Mammoth cheese slice is as big as the King Kong they have climbing up a skyscraper in their logo. Two hands are required unless of course you are fist pumping from delight between bites. 

It's cheap and cheesy like a bad first date. But it's also crispy and delicious so you needn't lift nary a finger to click into a dating website. 

Interests? Super good pizza and walks on the beach. 
Take this one home to mom already!

Fuhgeddaboudit!
author: Matthew T.

description:
You are here because you are hungry and want pizza right now.  You don't want to have to wait for pizza to be made, heated, or even sliced.  Fantastic.

Stand in line with a handful of money, and that hot, cheezy, and perhaps slightly drippy slices of pizza, either pepperoni or cheese, will be yours.  

Once you've obtained your pizza by the slice, you can take it to one of the side counters and eat here if you like.  There's room for approximately 6 people to do so if they're drawn by the eat-in amenities, which include red pepper flakes, grated parmesean, napkins, and a trash can.  

Enjoy!
author: Elaine S.

description: Best NY style pizza near 16th mission. Had their thin crust pizza twice, their lemonade was meh.
author: Rob G.

description:
Everybody say Cheeeeeese....slice.

The Cheese slice is usually the thing to get. Cheese isn't too melty or too solid. Crust has nice crunchy texture yet still slightly soft. Very cheap- $2. Don't be fooled, however. It's not all that bad. It may not be hot n' fresh sometimes. But with one quick toss into the oven for few minutes and it's ready to go. 

It's a small joint that doesn't attract a lot of attention. People come in n' out, as if they were loading/ unloading packages. Service is pretty quick. Very limited seating is offered. Nonetheless, it's a fine biz.

Simple pizza. Simple place. Simply ok.
author: Will S.

description:
UPDATE! I went to Arinell's today and they more than made up for last night, including sending me off with a slice for the road! Back to five stars!! Love this place and its closest to NY pizza. Thank you! Go Arinell's!!
--- --- ---
Arinell's you are losing a star for me, only because you broke my heart last night. I did a show at a nearby venue, and spent the entire day salivating because I knew I was going to have pizza when it was over. Since moving to Alameda, opportunities to visit Arinell's have decreased significantly, and I spent the whole day looking forward to the post show pizza, only to find that the hours have changed and they closed before the show was even over!!! 10pm?! My abject disappointment cost you a star. Still the best pizza in SF, but the hours are no bueno. We'll try to get there earlier tonight and see if we can fix this.
author: Ophelia C.

description:
I don't know much about NY-style pizza, so I won't weigh in on that debate. Who wants to be a pizza-judging poser? Not me! Instead, I'll just own the fact that I'm a midwestern girl who thinks Arinell is a good bet for a basic slice of pie. It has tomato sauce. It has cheese. On crust.
