It all blends well, in a totally uncomplicated manner, and can be folded up and eaten on the go. 

In contrast to some Yelpers' experiences, the guys who work here have always been very nice to me (even despite my lack of punk rock-ness).  As an added bonus, they're also super cute.
author: Janna M.

description:
Arinell is a solid pizza joint in the Mission. Conveniently located, tasty food, reasonably priced, with good hours.

I had a simple cheese slice, and was very happy.

A bit annoyed by cash only, but there is a BofA a couple blocks away, and an ATM right outside *shrug*.
author: Conrad B.

description:
When I walked in, I had big hopes that this would satisfy my cravings for NY pizza.  They had a pie that looked like NY pizza, they had sicilian and they called it a "pie."  

When I got home and opened up the box, i noticed that they didn't cut the pizza into 8 slices like you would expect.  Instead, I'd guess it was 16 or so slices.  Not that big of a deal, but how am I going to fold the slice if the piece is too small.

I picked up the slice and the tip drooped down, just like I'd expect.  This was looking good.  The taste was pretty good and I had really no complaints about the slice.  Until, I got to the crust.  It was was very thin and not the puffy doughy crust that I had expected.  so sad.

It's a good pizza and not a bad NY style pizza.  But the quest continues.
author: Larry L.

description:
Is it feasible that there's good pizza outside of NYC? Don't be so ignorant, you. I was pretty skeptical myself, but Arinell has a solid plain slice. Let's say...I had a few drinks prior to coming here and imagine...the pizza was piping hot, just the way I like it, and in conclusion, I ended up burning the roof of my mouth. This happened.

Albeit the facts I stated above, the sauce, cheese, bread and crunch made me feel like I was back in NYC. The establishment is small, has side counter tops with bar stool seats and is best for a quickie bite if you're hungry or drunk, or for pick up.

Another plus, it's close to Blondie's. Hayyyy. I'll be back for you.

Tip: Be careful the cap to the cracked red pepper container is screwed on all the way.  If not, the end result could be a hot mess.
author: J R.

description: Closest thing to New York style pizza this side of the continental divide!
author: Geri W.

description:
There are some good NY style pizza places in SF.  But Arinell's is the only place I get cravings for.   Thin crust and a little greasy, nothing hits the spot like a late night slice on a Saturday night.

Service is very fast, which is good, because you might have to double park, as the area is always congested.    And yes, the place is a hole in the wall, so plan to either at one of the few counter spots, or take your slices to go.   

Still at $3 for a generous slice.   On my short list for a quick, cheap and satisfying bite to eat.
author: Charles H.

description:
I felt accomplished enough after a grueling gym session to treat myself to a pizza dinner. This place is known for it's NY style pizza. Confession: I'm not too familiar with NY style pizza. All I know is that it's thin crust, but given that I've heard so much about it, I assumed it had to be mind-blowing. 

Except it wasn't. It was definitely really good (thin, crispy, not too greasy), but when a large majority of the yelp community and 7x7 magazine rates it as one of the 100 things to eat before you die in SF, I mayhaps had a bit more expectation than I experienced. 

The place is tiny and the service is quirky, which is nice as an outfit serving pizza by the slice to a largely on the go crowd doesn't really need fancy digs. Not to mention that's why I could probably have two cheese pizzas at $2.75 a pop. They were quickly heated up and as I hungrily stuffed one in my face and the other one in a to go bag, I also saw that they had a few other choices (usual suspects - pepporoni, sausage, few others). The price is definitely better than many other 'gourmet' pizza joints, but this certainly doesn't cater to that crowd. Instead it serves a simple thin crust pizza, which can be enjoyed at any point.

Just don't go in with sky-high expectations and you probably won't be disappointed. I liked it, but not enough to come back unless I'm in the neighborhood and craving pizza.
author: Aditi R.

description:
It looked so good.  It smelled so good.  It seemed to have all the qualities that a really good slice of New York-style pizza should possess...

Then I took a bite into what was quite possibly THE BLANDEST piece of pizza that I have ever tasted!!!!

Imagine my disappointment.  As I pondered how something that even had the physical consistency in my mouth of a really good slice of New York-style pizza could be such a flavorless imposter, my mind boggled.  I tried another bite.  And another.  Okay, let's face it, I was hungry and had just spent a lousy $23 on this cardboardy atrocity, so I ate my fill.   But I was beyond disappointed, especially after having elected to order from Arinell's after having read all of the over-the-moon reviews here on Yelp!  How could everyone have led me so astray??  Had none of these so-called pizza aficionados ever really had a good New York-style pizza pie?!  Or have they just lived out in SF too long and lost their East Coast taste buds from too many bland slices?

It remains a mystery to me.  But what I DO know is that I won't be ordering from here again.  I like my pizza to taste like something, preferably pizza, not cardboard.
author: Amy L.

description: this review is for their pizza dough! I make a lot of my own pizza due to my vegan needz- bought a dough ball last night... amazing and delicious - made great pizza cooked at 500F as recommended by the guys here. dough was $3 for med ball of $4 for a large ball... seriously I will be back, someone warn my thighs!
author: Coco J.

description:
According to several bay area magazines pizza lists and yelp, the cheese slices at Arinell is supposedly some of the best pie in the bay.  This just proves to me that so called "foodies" don't know shit about the food of the common man such as pizza and burgers.

Arinell's pizza is mediocre, that's it.

Dough and Crust:  Very good, i will give props on that, they have a delicious dough recipe here.

Cheese and Toppings: Decent, nothing special.

Sauce:  Bland and unremarkable.

I did want to like this place because the pizza is fairly cheap, they were blasting Black Sabbath inside the store, and they have free jalepenos to spice up your slices, but the pizza is just average.

In addition I was about 7 drinks deep when I came here, and let me explain something about the relationship between alcohol and pizza (since I happen to be a genius on both topics).  The more you drink, the better pizza tastes, so if it was just okay when I was rocking a buzz, then it's far from great pizza.
author: Brad R.

description:
The only place for post-bar noms on or around Valencia. It's really good. Slices are huge and there's plenty of shaking to be done of the parm, spices, and chile peppers strewn about the place.

Pro tip: Pros tip. Otherwise when you are at your moment of vulnerability, the staff WILL shout and sing "NONNNNN TIPERRRR" and bang on the pans. If you've had a few drinks and are just trying to get some balance, this could be quite startling and jarring to you. I recommend proactive tipping as a preemptive strike against your own disruption.
author: Megan G.

description:
The guy at the counter was so stoned... or just slow.  Maybe he was new, but whatever, he was a friendly dude and the pizza was great.

The slices come straight out of the oven so they are nuclear when you first get them.  Watch the grease, and give it a minute before you take your first bite or you will regret it.

I've never been to NYC but those who have say this pizza is the real deal, so come get your mouth around a big ol' thin crust slice of pie.
author: Stephen C.

description:
Closest to New York style around the area...at least from what little I know. Crowded during normal hours, insane during weekend nights when the Valencia partiers need something to soak up the beers. Wouldn't be such a problem except there's not an ounce of effective seating once a few people are in line and waiting for food. 

Price is damn cheap, pizza is fine. It will fill you up and that's about it.
author: Scott T.

description: Place looks dirty but they have huge slices of pizza. Surprisingly the food is good. Comes out fast and is a good price. They also stag open late if your out drinking in the area. No seating tho so be prepared to  grab and go
author: Alonzo T.

description:
This is a review by a vegetarian

It's growing on me.
Still a little greasy. $2.75 for a 1/8 20" slice. Good. Not pretentious. But then again, I've never eaten here when I wasn't afraid that there might be a stray hair from one of the guys working the paddles so it'd be hard for the place to carry off pretentiousness
author: Bob R.

description:
This is a refreshing flavor to get in this city filled with a million fine restaurants. It's sometimes hard to find a good pizza establishment and the only reason I believe this restaurant has such great reviews is because there is nothing else in the vicinity. 

The crust is amazing. Thin and crisp and there is just enough cheese to make me happy. This is a greasy slice but you'll know that before you walk in so don't be surprised. The high rating is only for the location.
author: Justin S.

description:
I went here after a drunk night with my friends. We stumbled into this place which was amazing! The pizza was good and I could even fold it. I'm really picky about pizza. The only thing is that the place is really small and don't take credit cards. But otherwise it's amazing. Big slices 

P.s they serve it on wax paper.
author: Liz R.

description:
The place is a dump, but the pizza rocks! Warm, crispy, and fresh out of the oven. Best NY-style cheese slices west of NYC. 

Recently part of an "adult film" was shot there (http://sanfrancisco.grubstreet.com/2010/08/arinell_pizza_used_as_porn_set.html). I'm sure (I hope!) the place has been sanitized since then, so I'll still be back for more 'za!!!
author: Dave L.

description:
The pizza itself deserves 5 stars. Its soooooo damn good. And ive had it SOBER. Of course when you are around at midnight (drunk) and craving a hot, cheesy, delicious slice of really good pizza, you should pop in here. I like to dip my pizza in ranch, and i dont think they have that here. But its ok, the slice of pizza (or 2) is amazing. 

-1 star because the dude at the register handles cash and pizza at the same time (which is actually gross)! And they dont take credit.
author: Boops D.

description:
"New York Style", meaning, perhaps one of the following:
 "real estate is too expensive to have a place to eat"
 "service with a smirk"
 "rat arb"
you decide.
author: sellMyFing n.

description:
When i think of cheese Pizza.... I am thinking " Ewwww" 

I have never been a big fan of cheese pizza but I had to come here to try their cheese slice because it is on the 7x7 100 to try in San Francisco list. Came here with two other friends and order a the cheese slice ($2.75), pizza was OK. after trying it, I am still not a fan of cheese pizza. I think I will stick with my pepperoni. 

Anyways, i would have given it 3 stars because it was one of the better cheese pizza I have ever tried. However, their service is horrible. My friend ordered a slice before my other friend but he never got his pizza. When he ask the employee about his slice, he said something like you never paid for you because when a person orders, I put the number of slices in the oven. I was like wow, are you serious, we watched him paid and he was giving us so much attitude. When my friend said he paid, the employee said "If you say so" with an attitude. Come on!! Is that how you treat your customers? That ruined my night, so I am so it ruined my friend's night. It so stupid because they do not give recipes to people, so they should not complain when someone did not get the pizza and you forgot that he paid. upgrade!!! 

In the end, he got his pizza but it come with a bitter taste because of the bad service...
author: Daniel L.

description: Perfect NY style thin cheese slices accompanied with headbanging death metal. Nobody does it better than Arinell, in fact I get disappointed when I have pizza in NYC, because it's just not as good.
author: Allen T.

description: Yum. I am a fan. Pizza made to order. The slices are HUGE. Pizza is thin and cheese melts off the bread. There are a few areas to stand/sit if you want to eat it right away. Cash only
author: Kristin M.

description:
I will never get pizza anywhere else.  Now that I have discovered this place, everywhere else is just sad in comparison.  Don't care that it looks dingy.  Don't care that it's a little more expensive than I'd like it to be.  The pizza.  Oh my god, the pizza.  IT'S DELICIOUS.  

Pure, perfect, yummy, greasy cheesy pizza which still tastes just as good the next day after it's been sitting in the box all night...I can eat 5 slices and not care because it's just that good.

It's always quick, the people are friendly, the pizza is hot, what more could you want?
author: Caitlin D.

description: Great thin-crust NY slices!  The cheese and sauce are just wonderful.
author: Jack L.

description: My go-to place in the neighborhood when I need to eat quickly! After a disastrous  night of ordering a pizza from Paxti's/Hayes Valley that never showed up (3 hour wait...WTF?!), I ran down to Arinell to pick up some slices. Thanks Arinell for saving my Friday. Delicious thin crust cheese pizza that is always perfect, perfect.
author: Rich S.

description:
Square.

Not the staff or the patrons. This is the Mission after all.

Referring to the shape of my Sicilian slice.

Never understood people who don't eat the crust. Often the best part. And this one was thick. More to love.

Our relationship didn't quite get to that level.

Crust and sauce were fine. Cheese texture suggested extended time in the warmer. Three bucks didn't break the bank.

A-OK slice in a far from square part of the world.
author: Jason B.

description:
I've been coming here since I was a little girl.

Understand that it is the CLOSEST you will get to NY pizza in the City by a long shot, possibly in the entire bay area. It is pretty damn good. Not life changing, but damn good considering you're in San Francisco.

New Yorkers won't like it, but they don't like anything.
author: Sara D.

description: I was refused service because I asked for a different slice before it even went in the oven. The pizza guy yelled at me to get out.  First truly insulting service I've received in the city. DO NOT go here. The workers refused to give me either the managers name or the owners contact. Patrons, be aware that if you ask for what you want, you may get not only seriously bad service,  but threatened.
author: Sanjay R.

description:
Anything less than 5 stars and you're smoking crack...  Best New York Style pizza in SF...  For Chicago Style go to Little Star...  Get pepperoni with jalapeno's and you'll never be let down...  

The staff could care less if you drop dead, but that's part of the places NYC charm.  :)
author: Will W.

description: Love this place. Love the pizza. Only giving four stars because they don't take debit cards and this location is small.
author: Isaac H.

description: As a NYC transplant, this has been the only fast slice joint I've found to be deem worthy of calling itself "New York City" pizza. Bravo Arinell
author: JJ D.

description:
Yeah dude wtf, not freaking bad. 

Super thin, greasy pizza. I wouldn't come here if wanted pizza but it's a great walk-by-bite.
author: Margaret S.

description: Extremely greasy pizza served out of a not-especially-tidy storefront by a guy who was super stoned. Perfect.
author: Jay S.

description: Fucking amazing pizza!!!!!! Perfect in every way! I love the service even though so of the google tech yuppies might Bitch, there straight foreword and no small talk. The closet to REAL New York style pizza you will find in SF, maybe even NorCal. Do yourself a favor and eat here!!
author: Jonny B.

description:
meh ... it's ok ... 3 stars for style

I got the scillian which was tiny. Added sausage for an additional $0.75 but otherwise it was hardly worth the effort. Definitely hole in the wall, will come back and try a regular slice soon. Dough was made fresh onsite.
author: Andy N.

description:
Touted as one of the best "NYC-style" pizzas in SF, I dropped by here for a slice of cheese pizza. The thin crust was definitely good, but the no frills, simple slice didn't wow me. 

Yet, another entry on the 7x7 list that was good, but not "you must go out of your way to try this" good.
author: Monelle A.

description:
I'm kind of an expert on pizza after having lived in Italy for five months. With that said I still prefer the American pie over the Italian stuff and Chicago deep-dish over New York thin-crust.

I gotta admit that Arinell makes a mean New York-style pizza, though. The cheese pizza slice is big, crunchy, juicy and a delicious, hot mess. I love that they're only $2.75 a slice and 50 cents per topping. And a topping doesn't mean four pepperoni slices--it translates to about 8! Bam!

After pizza, grab ice cream at Bi-Rite Creamery two blocks away. The perfect cheap and low-key date, right? Why do I always come up with all the good ideas?

By the way, can someone explain Boston-style pizza to me? I have yet to figure it out and I went to college there.
author: Liz T.

description: Came to SF from Brooklyn 10 years ago. I now make my own pizza having given up on the disgusting pig-slop that passes for pizza here. However, this is the real deal - a true NYC slice.
author: George S.

description: Awesome pizza!  Guy serving the pizza needs a shot of personality. Definitely recommend. .... worth the walk or drive.
author: Tony S.

description:
I like pizza.  All kinds.  (btw, it is not pizza if it has chicken on it, so I don't have to excluded chicken from "all kinds", because if it has chicken on it, it ain't pizza.  Period).

   But I digress.

   Sometimes you want simple pizza.  Easy pizza.  Fast pizza.  Cheese only pizza.  On a crisp, ultra thin New York style crust.  Served on waxed paper, with a Coke, by some some punk rock dude blasting Crass or something.

   And that is Arinell.  And it is the best.
author: Bad Y.

description: I always have to stop by and grab a slice when im in the neighborhood.  The pizza is the best I have had for a pizza by the slice. I just park out front hop out if the car and 5 minutes later im in pizza heaven!  Best deal for pizza and the crust is perfect! I love the cheese and pepperoni :)
author: Tabitha O.

description: If you don't like this place, chances are you've never been to the east coast for pizza.  Chances are you think you know NY style pizza but have no clue.  This is as close as I've had so far in SF, and the 'competitors' were amateur at best.  There's a reason NY is known for pizza, and this is a taste of that style.  Thank you thank you for giving me a late night slice that delivers.  BTW yes it's a dive, probably rat invested and a brothel during the day.
author: A A.

description: Seriously, this is the best pizza by the slices in the city!! The sicilian deep dish is so good!!!
author: Frank C.

description:
Ok, but not a destination place for pizza. The style is undoubtedly NY style. It is very thin, very wide pieces, and they are quite greasy. The establishment itself  looks pretty authentic with a gruff non-nonsense guy behind the counter, and they custom-bake you your slices.

Unfortunately the pizza was a little bland. I ordered 2 slices, one pepperoni and one plain, and the meat one was much better. Half of the plain slice was so soggy as to be unedible in the 10 min walk home from the place.

So...fine for a quick cheap slice, but nothing too special.
author: Jordan C.

description: Hands down, the absolute BEST pizza in San Francisco! And coming from me that says a lot! I am EXTREMELY picky about my pizza and as far as I'm concerned pizza sucks outside of New York and I really don't eat it in other states because it is so far from what pizza is supposed to be, most of the time. But this place is one of the few exceptions I'll make. So many places call themselves New York pizza and claim to be New York pizza, and many of them succeed fooling the tourists or locals who don't know any better. In fact there is a pizza place 2 doors down from here that sucks so bad, but it's always packed with drunk idiots. Granted, this place is tiny and there may be a wait, but it is so worth it. REAL New York pizza in a pizza parlor with New York attitude, the way it's supposed to be! And for pete's sake, by the slice the way it's supposed to be! When you want a quick lunch, who wants to wait around for a whole pizza to be cooked at "personal" small size which means more dry lousy crust and less good middle pizza? Everyone in NY learned that a century ago and somehow the rest of the country hasn't caught up? I love that the kids working there blast metal music and just don't care because they know they've got the best pizza and people will come regardless. Arinell's: Keep on keepin' on! I Love You. Don't ever close!
author: Peter K.

description:
Came here on a cheap, low-key date in the Mission.  Verdict... Guy- eh, trying to hard.. Pizza- delicious!  The cheese slice is a hot greasy mess of goodness.  It's a hole in the wall type place but pretty cheap and open late.  Go to Bi-Rite Creamery afterwards and you have yourself an obnoxiously trendy little outing.  

Only four stars because I was too sober to fully appreciate it.  Will be back.
author: Amanda G.

description:
I've never tried true NY pizza, but I hope it's comparable to Arinell's.

The place looks as greasy and gritty as the pizza is.  I place my order, and quickly turn around because I don't want to spoil my appetite watching how the pizza is actually cooked.

The crust is crispy, while the dough is soft and not over done-similar to the edges of an in n out burger bun.  

The toppings are very generous (more like: would you like a side of pizza with the 100 mushrooms we are about to put on the "pizza"?)

I'm not too much of a pizza girl, but I have been guilty of scarfing 4 slices in record time... sober.  Yes, it is just THAT good!
author: Clarissa P.

description: Oh! Try to add sausage on your pepperoni it's goooood
author: Jessca G.

description: Great place to get a quick, excellent slice of pizza. It is simple - two kinds of crust, a few different toppings - and quick. If you know what you're expecting, then it's as good as it gets. Very little seating and cash only.
author: Alex O.

description:
Walk in, look at the made pizza laid out behind the viewing glass, and you think wtf.. looks like some ghetto thin ass cheap pizza. The slices aren't even even or lined up, they just eyeball it and cut it as they go. 

But you have to get past that and get a slice to give it at least a fair chance. Once you do you will get to experience one of the best thin sliced pizzas in the city. The thin crust is soft but yet crispy, great taste and texture to it. The sauce is what I think really makes the pizza outstanding. It has the perfect taste of tomatoes and pepper and other spices to it, can't really explain it that well, just gotta try it .
author: Patrick L.

description:
3 bucks and change for a slice and soda at a spot that might very well be the closest thing to NY style pizza this side of the Mason-Dixon Line. 

Order at the counter and scarf your slice on one of the stools while you people watch along Valencia. Or even bring your slice into Casanova's and grab a drink as you eat. 

The pizza's generously sliced and while it's devoid of that delicious cornmeal crust (heavens to betsey, Paxtis), it's totally solid and East Coast friendly. After all, anyone from the east with direct access to NYC is going to be a true skeptic when it comes to finding comparable pizza out here. Arinell's passes the test.
author: Monica S.

description:
Hum...wasn't terribly impressed by the greasy texture and cardboard-y thin crust, but they're open late at night. Perhaps a slice fresh out of the oven would be more satisfying than the lukewarm one I had, so I'm willing to give this place another chance in the future. If you've had one too many to drink and are craving pizza, service is fast and the counter guys are pretty nice.

It's a tiny hole-in-the-wall pizza joint with maybe 6 stools total, so be prepared to grab and go. Also, cash only!
author: Christine H.

description: I'm from the east coast and this is the closest thing I've had to east coast pizza in SF. It's freaking delicious and if you don't like this place you are crazy! Simple and delicious. Top 5 best pizza places in SF and it's literally my favorite food so you can trust me. ;)
author: Heather W.

description:
Got two cheese slices (suckers are large; each slice is about a foot long).  Didn't see anything else but I figured maybe you're not supposed to order anything else. 

Nice light crust; a little chewy and a little crispy.  Maybe a little oily but OK.  One of the better NY styles I've had.  Wouldn't go out of my way to try it again but if you like NY style, get it here.
author: Neil Y.

description: Closest thing we got for a NYC slice.  Though, this is not a NY slice, you will probably be satisfied.
author: T. K.

description: The superlative best slice in SF. Granted, the bar is set pretty fcukin' low, but nevertheless, Arinell dishes out entirely decent slices. Occasionally, they're a little floppy, which is a bummer, but more often, the crust will stand up like it should. As an east coaster in exile, the intensely important role that Arinell plays in my SF eating life cannot be discounted. I need you, baby.
author: Brian M.

description:
Perhaps a couple of the defining elements of New York pizza are a filthy restaurant and really, really rude service.  Given that the pizza is pretty tasty, despite the filth in the place, I can't really know for sure.  In the past I've been able to look past the grime (which you can literally see in every crack in the place), the track marks, the cockroaches, staff handing food and money with the same hands without washing, etc.  Tonight they were just plain awful, well over and beyond the usual rude that I'm used to..  

So I took my pizza business a few doors down, to the other pizza place.  Happy hour, too!  $3 for a slice and a soda.  Not the same kind of slice as Arinell, but yummy enough, and the place is *quite* clean.
author: Rocky M.

description: Haven't been back for a few years, but it was DELICIOUS! Thin crust, mad crazy tomato sauce, and burning hot cheese. I'm ashamed to say I folded it up like an envelope, but dang, I was gonna lose the toppings!
author: Em L.

description: Loved the fresh mushrooms and fresh sausage that covered our large pizza last night!  We were commenting on how the toppings were distributed so evenly and plentifully that you got some in every bite.  The thin crust was also nice and crispy!  It's cash only, so plan ahead!
author: Julie C.

description:
Best Pizza in the city of San Francisco. Do not go in there expecting service, go in there, expecting flavor. I have gone in there over dozens of times and every single time, their slice of pizza has never failed my taste buds. I love it. 
Keep doing what you guys do. Love Arinell's Pizza. 
This is where I come for my Pizza fix and you should too :)
author: Falguni K.

description:
I lived in SF for 15 years, just up the hill in the Lower Haight actually, without ever making it to Arinell's. Now that I've moved to upstate New York but am back for a visit, I decided I had to try a slice today to understand why an upstate NY friend and fellow former Bay Arean can't stop talking about the stuff.

And I still don't know. To me there is absolutely nothing about this pizza that would move the needle above or below that solid three star rating for "A-OK" describing pizza with a nice thin crust, plenty of quality cheese, and a sure hand with the toppings. (Pepperoni is the value at 50 cents extra for a slice full of it. Pay 75 cents for anchovies like I did and you'll get 3 sorry fishies, but I had been warned by somebody down this thread). 

Definitely not skanky in any way but not up there with the Delfinas or even Cheeseboards of the world. The only really special thing is that the rectangular pizza is sliced into weird triangles which might get you going late at night, depending on what else was going on with you.

I am going to be the 800 pound gorilla here, and speculate that most of the comments in the Arinell legend are urban myths created in many cases perhaps by the myth-tellers themselves. The guys behind the counter were not spouting classical Greek yet they were tolerant of two very unhappy women with toddlers who communicated at the staff by yelling at them. Yes, if you just ask for it to go you'll get a paper bag but if you want to pay extra you can get a box. Yes, there are tattooed hipsters outside but this is the Mission. And so on.

The pizza and the experience, 3 stars.
author: Otis M.

description:
There are just some things that you don't do--one of them putting too much tequila in both margaritas you hand to Jaime. 

So around whatever the hell time it was, I stumbled outside with Matt for some much needed air and slurred "if we don't start walking, I'm going to puke".

So Matt did what any good guy who doesn't want to hold someone's hair back would, and took me to Arinell Pizza--it was quite a walk. Then again, I wasn't really walking, I was babbling about someone unimportant, and time just seems to fly when you can't see straight. 

OMG. SO FUCKING GOOD. Having to stand there to wait for the pizza made the room spinny spinny, but finally was able to make that stop when I put that piece of deliciousness in da mouth. I woke up in the morning with a burnt tongue, which also goes to show I can get pretty numb when I drink too much. 

Ok I'm going to update this part, it was a little mean. I have a guilty conscience. Either that, or I'm PMSing, hungover, and hungry as shit. 

So here you go--if you want NYC pizza, GO TO NYC DUH. If you want bomb-ass san francisco style NYC pizza, go here.
author: Jaime L.

description:
The best NYC thin crust cheese pizza in the city.  Hole in the wall, but fun to get a quick slice from the heavy metal rockers who work there.

Sausage slice is eh -- Delfina's salsiccia is much better.
author: marcie v.

description: Finally a good slice at a decent price in SF.  Had cheese and Sicilian cheese at $3.00 and $3.50 respectively.  Both very good.
author: Sam S.

description: DAMNNN this place has awesome slices. Thank God they only take cash because that it the reason I cant go everyday and charge up pies. Its as close to NY as you'll get. Crap now I'm craving one hard. Be right back...
author: Bri R.

description: This place gets rated on a monthly basis.  Showed up at 12:30 on a Friday night and they only have cheese thin and cheese foccacia and a lot of attitude.  Don't believe the hype.
author: l t.

description:
Oh.dear.god.yes!

This is pizza as it should be.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Good quality NY style pizza. Guess what this place almost matches NY prices as well (as in its cheap) instead of those trendy SF places that think a slice of pizza can go for $5.

Reasonable, and they do a great job reheating your slice!

Writing this makes me want another slice, even if it is just plain old cheese!
author: Caitlin H.

description: the music sucks and the employees are kind of weird, but the pizza, dollar for dollar, is the best in SF.
author: Bosie M.

description:
To all those haters - I like this place.  The pizza is thin, it's crunchy and it tastes pretty good and hits the spot when I'm in need of a late night snack in the Mission after doing some damage at the bars.  

I have had many different pizzas and this is by far one of my favorite thin crust places.  

Have yet to try their deep dish style, but I'm sure it's pretty good too.
author: Cherlyn M.

description: Best New York style pizza in SF!  I only wish they delivered...
author: Jill C.

description:
Perfectly servicable pizza by the slice, New York Style.  Traditional slices are $2.75 and Sicilian style (bready square things) are $3.  Toppings can be added for 50 cents each

The cheese is good, but the dough and sauce are only "ok."  If you're going to get it, it's worth getting fresh out of the oven; it's only a few minutes wait.

It may not be authentic, but I prefer Pizza My Heart or Victor's Pizza for thin crust pizza by the slice.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Update December 2012: Still enjoying good pizza, chill employees and sometimes some good music at Arinell.

I just hope I don't run into Ron (the a-hole owner) while I'm there, in which case, I'll probably be unable to keep my food down.
author: Josh B.

description:
This is a great pizza place. I would say it is NYC pizza the way I remembered it from my youth.  Cheap, hot and I can eat a whole pie by myself. 
I would give it 6 stars if they cleaned the place. This place is as filthy as the  public rest rooms in Penn Station, though I have eaten in worse places, I got to take away some points from them.
author: Bob b.

description: Straight and to the point Arinell is serves up cheap, large, NY style slices and pies. Pizza slices in San Francisco this large for $3.00 is something to praise itself. The place is cash only so don't be caught walking in without at least 3 bucks. I used to say that the employees appeared a little testy, however after frequenting this place and observing the people they have to deal with on a day-to-day basis I would say they are actually quite polite. For me, the real short comings of this place stem from its overall cleanliness. The pizza is served on wax paper which is messy and also confusing as paper plates cost almost nothing. I have also witnessed employees handle money and then work the dough without washing their hands. I have never gotten sick from this place so it can't be that bad but in the end there are a couple easy things that this place could do to certify it as the best cheap slice of pizza in S.F.
author: Nathan J.

description:
never understood it but do wonder why sf just can't seem to get the pizza quite right, east coast style.  somebody had told me its in the water but who knows.  these guys get braggin rights over tony's hyped coal fired in my opinion but 2nd to their neighbor in delfina

http://gothamist.com/2010/01/08/the_water_makes_the_pizza.php
author: Clark G.

description:
"I want pizza" 

Those were the only 3 words that I was able to mumble out with a drunken slur after a night out in the city.

Though I'm not too sure how we got there or who suggested it, I am 99.9% sure that this pizza was extraordinarily good, like, profess my love on top of a mountain kind-of-good. 

It was slightly crunchy, cheesy, and the pepperoni that adorned it was like nothing I have ever tried before. 

I suppose since people get beer goggles, it is possible to get beer buds. I'll have to come back and figure out if this was a pizza that will have me screaming in disgust or if it is truly...love at first bite.
author: Bianca L.

description:
Yum yum in my tum except the neighborhood scares me!  I know I know, call me a wuss.

I didn't have the NY slice... I had the thicker square shaped one... Sicilian.    At first I was a little confused.  I had heard that it was your typical "hole in wall" restaurant but there were really not many pizzas to choose from.  I looked up at the menu and I was thinking that maybe you can order a custom slice but no... they offer whatever is sitting out there.

Even though I heard so many good things, I was still hesistant because it seemed so dirty in there!  I was thinking, "how can it possibly be so good??"  Nonetheless, it exceeded my expectations.  Whew.  My slice of pizza was warm, had a crispy crust, adequate sauce & just the right amount of cheese.  I'll definitely visit again.... in the daytime.

My friends from NJ says this is the closest to east coast pizza it can get on this side of the country and in this part of the Bay Area.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Throughly mediocre pizza.  I got a medium mushroom and sausage pie and it was thick and soggy -- so much so the cheese and toppings would slide off of the slice when you picked it up.  I'm thinking it's because the mushrooms let out a lot of  moisture, but it's still a failure in construction and pizza-making technique.  They claim New York-style pizza and I was looking for something thinner and crisper than what they delivered.

The people there are awesomely nice.  It's cool to just sit there and talk with them.  It's kind of expensive and the pizza's just not there.  I loved sitting in the window and watching the world go by.  The medium pretty big pizza by itself.  The menu says 15-inches, but it felt larger.

Anyhow it's doubly disappointing because I really like the Arinell in Berkeley.
author: Eric W.

description: Incredibly cheap, solid pizza place. Great if you need something quick.
author: Heather R.

description:
Yummy thin slice pizza. But beware that it is dripping in grease ;)
I tried a slice of the plain cheese and I had to napkin dry it a few times to absorb some of the oil...
author: Helen Y.

description:
total dive spot in the Mission that serves up arguably the best pizza in SF.
the thin crust was super thin and I got my slice straight out of the oven.
wow! tasty stuff.
it did not remind me of NYC pizza though.
the crust here was thinner and crispier.
still awesomely good though.
it was more reminiscent of Rome. but not exactly.
i also tried the thick crust aka Sicilian. 
more cheese, more tomato sauce on a thicker crust.
it was tasty as well but not fresh out of the oven hot.
if you really enjoy pizza, you really must try the za here.
you'd be glad you did.
author: Jeff W.

description: Best New York slice in San Francisco. No frills.
author: Matt C.

description: Good Pizza - Thin crust - but can't sit down and enjoy - its just for no more than 6 people at a time.  The pizza taste really good!  New York style!  Prices has gone up $3.00 for just a cheese pizza.
author: Ramona L.

description: Late night pizza? That was an excellent decision! The pizza was amazing! I was confused, because first, there was no peppers, but then I saw jalapenos, and my extra delicious pizza became even more delicious.
author: Emily D.

description:
If you're been reading my reviews for a while, you'll know that I think pizza sucks in SF.  Sure, there's Zachary's, but that ain't no pizza (it is very good though!)

What you want, as an expatriate New Yorker, is that thin, crisp, hot, gooey slice.  The kind that you can still taste a half hour after you're done, courtesy of the grease around your mouth that you can't seem to wipe off with a napkin, no matter how you try.

Arinell comes close, damn close.  I'm giving it 5 stars because it's the best I've found in the city and East Bay.

However... there was something missing in my pizza.  I don't know what it was, but some bit of taste was lacking.  According to the sign, they don't use sugar or salt in their pizza.  Perhaps that was it?  I did try adding salt to my slice (a first for me) but it didn't help.  

The place is a little dive, so don't plan on going there for your next anniversary dinner.  Get your slice and get chowing.  It's good.

As with so many things in SF, I find the prices much higher than in NY, but sometimes a man needs some hot pie, no matter what the price!
author: dan s.

description:
Arinell - It's like being back in Queens in the early 80's without having to ever go back to Queens or the 80's. Flat, greasy plain cheese slices with the occasional crust bubble.

If only Harrington's Furniture down the street didn't sell off that free Ms. Pac Man they had going on in the back - my Valencia St. dream would still be alive.

The pizza is damn good and the staff they fetched straight out of Joey Ramones basement really knows how to make a pie.
author: Jack K.

description: It's not quite NY pizza though it is almost as tasty (sauce isn't as zesty/savory as a NY sauce) as the crust is crispy & cracks when folded as opposed to a real NY pizza.  Prices are cheap and tax is already included.  2 ginormous slices with 1 or 2 extra toppings plus a drink will run you under $10, that's awesome since it's in SF.  When I have a hankerin' this will be my spot.  I suggest taking it to go, then reheating it at home psst (in the microwave for 30 secs) then its almost just as foldable as a NY slice.
author: Joy-Lu B.

description: This review is based on the customer service I received. So I was looking on help for places to eat at while I was in San Francisco. So browsing and what not see this and I'm like wow this place looks really good I want to eat here. Fat forward the last day of the trip. We call to see if they are even open. Guy picks up and is like yeah yeah so I ask do you have  any idea the price of a can ride from fisherman's wharf to your place and his response was "why would you ask me? Do I look like a cab company?" So I guess what I am trying to get across is the fact that they aren't tourist friendly. I mean even a I don't know 20$ answer would have been so much better that what I received.
author: Jack W.

description:
The place is dirty, theres no room to sit down and the workers all look like their stoned and haven't showered in two weeks, but I continue to come back and risk food poisoning because I can't think of a better New York style pizza in the city.  

The crust is perfectly crisp, the sauce is in the right amounts and the cheese is melted and chewy, but not gummy. Until someone can fill me in on a better(and cleaner would be nice) pizza place i guess I just have to risk the unwanted bowel movements.
author: Domingo D.

description:
Meh.
Not impressed.  Stopped by on the way home from the city after a long long day.
I was not a part of the drunken party crowd meandering the streets of Mission at 1AM.  But every single other person there was.  The pizza looked awful when I saw it.  But I decided not to judge it until I tried it bc all the other pizzas you order by the slice in the city do not look as appetizing either.  
So all they had was cheese pizza.  The guy informed me you add your own toppings.  
Ok.  So I asked for pepperoni and mushroom.  
No.  No mushroom tonight.  Hmmmm.  Ok.  Just pepperoni then.
They throw on the pepperoni and put it in the oven.
I try it... 
???????
SOOOOOO not impressed!!!!!!
Then, this guy next to me puts down his extra large whole cheese pizza all hot and fresh out of the oven... and I'm like... Oh... Maybe that's what it's supposed to look like.
I don't think I will ever try this pizza again.
Gimme Nizarios, Blondies, Pizza Orgasmica, Escape from NY, North Beach pizza ANYTIME!!!!!!!
author: Reya H.

description:
I think I've said this before, but I'll say it again. I'm from New York. I grew up on pizza from that pizza place at the opening of Saturday Night Fever. Seriously. That place still has a picture of a very young John Travolta hanging up in it. I guess they don't realize that that movie was thirty years ago. I digress...

I love New York pizza. I don't eat Chicago pizza and after moving to San Francisco, I thought I'd never be able to indulge in the slice here and there, until I found Arinell's. Pretty damn good and very close to a good New York pizza. The only difference I can think of is the cheese isn't as salty as the pizza in NY. That's a plus. They don't deliver which sucks when we are in the middle of Halo and are hungry.

I cut out one star because it is a little more expensive than pizza in NY.

Oh, and I like my pizza plain: just sauce, cheese, dough and grease. Why do Californians like a salad on their pizza?
author: Bella T.

description:
This place is really a 2.5 but yanno.. whole stars only system. ;z

So Arinell Pizza is really good for a few specific things and absolutely nothing else.

1. Drunk, high or otherwise altered state of mind munching. Now I'm not saying that I take part in any of those activities.. that's just the word on the street. So I heard. From a little bird. Or something.

2. A slice of cheese pizza when you're in a hurry and want something that is kinda sorta similar to NY pizza.. but isn't.

That's it.

Do not add toppings, do not expect them to wash their hands inbetween touching your money and your food.. go directly to cheese slice. :0
author: Amber F.

description:
So thin and big you need to fold it to eat it - like you're supposed to... 
$2.75 for a cheese slice.  They would be higher on my list but some days are better than others there - not consistent.  This is a small place with neither the room or atmosphere to sit and eat.  Get in get out get happy.
author: Jeff J.

description: amazing late night thin crust pizza and really affordable for a slice. enough said haha
author: Kristin B.

description:
Walked in with my boyfriend who insisted on buying a slice of New York style pizza.

Walked out happy with a huge thin slice of pizza for only $2.75. =]
author: Jayne A.

description:
A little mission hipster grimey, but pretty much as close to real New York style pizza as you're going to get in the mission (not that there's much better in SF in general).  All the stars here are for the pizza...  There's not much to be said for the atmosphere, cleanliness, or service.  Get in, get out, and enjoy some thin crust.

If you've had a few drinks or you need some walking food then it's definitely worth the stop.  If you're looking for a sit-down experience then head for Pauline's or Little Star.
author: Kevin F.

description:
AWESOME!
FXXXIN' AWESOME KickAss New York Pizza in SF.
Everything here are so perfect. It got to be this way.
Dirty, small, ugly dude making, cheap, Flat big, thin, crisp-crust, moist top, juicy-hot, crunchy sound when i bite.
Man Oh Man, the slice of cheese pizza made me smile.
The Best Pizza in the city.
author: Nobu K.

description:
mmm favorite greasy cheese pizza in sf.
you don't come here to look for a gourmet crispy pizza. you come here to get a fat cheap slice of greasy, floppy, cheesy goodness. i wish they gave you a little more than the paper they give it to you on. a paper plate would be nice. i also wish you could request half slices because the are pretty damn big. i recommend sticking with plain and simply cheese(the pie kind not the deep dish) and not tryna get fancy with toppings.
author: Jess C.

description:
I was really excited about trying this place out after hearing about how good it was. Very disappointed.  Their pizza is really bland, it barely has any flavor.

I'll give them credit for the loud rock music charm and the "rawness" the place has.  I highly recommend Piccolo Italia for some awesome pizza by the slice.
author: Fawad M.

description:
Pretty buzzed at 2.30 am. I see a long line and a sign that says; "blah blah blah.... New york style pizza!"

I pull my boo from the arm and i start running torwards the sign. I'm in line waiting with people that think ''bay cities deli'' in Santa Monica is actually better than 'Ike's'. WTF? DOUCHE BAGS. 

Since all the places i had been to in SF were awesome, i didnt imagine that this pizza would suck butt. But it did. 

It sucks major butthole. 

ANNNDDD THEY ONLY TAKE CASH!!! WTF?
author: Aidan V.

description: Love love! Cheese pizza is the way to go, don't get any toppings! It tasted very close to the NYC pizza, 2 bros, which is yum! I love the sauce and cheese on Arinell, but I don't like the price, since 2 bros in NYC is only $1 a slice.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Went here right before watching a movie around the corner at the Roxie.

Very fast, convenient and cheap HUGE slices! 

They serve a thin neapolitan and a deep dish, but I am a fan of thin crispy pizza.

It's a very small location with 2 guys working. Kinda freaked out when I saw dude handling money then went back to touching pizzas without washing his hands but then again, what can I expect outta a small place like this in the Mission.
author: Charmaine P.

description:
I can't say anything bad about this place. The pizza is solid and all of the guys who work there remind me of Shannon Hoon.

Oh and the fact that Kink.com used it as a site to film a fisting scene? A little...offbeat maybe and yeah they didn't have to be the Shari Lewis to her Lamb Chop so close to the pizza display case, but it's not like they turned it into a daily lunch special.
author: Aubrey O.

description: Came here twice so far. First time I didn't get anything but my roomies got the NYstyle pizza and they both loved it. The 2nd time I came here with my roomie - i got the sicilian pizza which was really good. Small place with a few stools & a bar-style table against the two walls.
author: Amy C.

description:
when a giant floppy pie comes out of the oven and they only slice off 4 pieces... you can only guess how big those slices are going to be. My friend and I bought almost a whole pie for less than $15. We gobbled it up in less than 15 seconds it seemed like...

When I'm missing the East Coast - even tho this doesn't toootally compare...this is where I go to get "my fix"
author: Katy A.

description:
I just got off the plane and was hungry. I walked by this place and was like hmm... NYC pizza... pass. I kept walking and didnt find anything appetizing. 

So I walked back. Lets give this place a try and see how new york it is. 

So Arinell's decor will not get its picture in a fancy magazine and it looks like its violating a health code in some way but I made a decision and I was going to stick to it. 

I ordered a slice and it was presented to me on wax paper. Okay i'll go with it. I sit down next to the garbage and take my first bite. I had to look out their window to make sure I wasnt in NY because it really reminded me of home. Crispy, just enough sauce and cheese. My favorite. Now if they imported some NY water this pizza would be banging. 

Arinell when I'm back in SF and need a slice you will be the first place i visit.
author: Tassamai s.

description:
Fantastic thin crust pizza and pretty darn good thick crust pizza as well. Going back to childhood, their Berkeley location was my favorite pizza in the world. Something about the sauce and the mix of cheese they use just can't be equalled. Arinell rounds out my top 3 along with Zachary's and Cheeseboard. 

Sure, there are some other good pizza places around but Arinell is a true Bay Area institution. Definitely give it a try if you like pizza (is there anyone who doesn't?).
author: Aaron V.

description: Pretty decent for a thin crust slice of Pizza. $2.75 will get you a big Cheese slice. Cash only and they do not have bottled water.
author: Reen B.

description:
If this is what NY pizza tastes like, tear. I think it tastes exactly the same as when I get out of that new hole in the wall on Broadway and turn a corner in my drunken rage and enter a pizza place and order whatever they have left. Hipster or Paisa pizza it may be, but id rather trek down to Serranos or Arizmendi.
Oh and good luck finding parking without hitting a fixie! Better yet just walk there.
author: Jim L.

description: This pizza is bomb. It's fresh from the oven so it's nice and warm when you get it. There are also a good amount of toppings to choose from. They even have anchovies! I'm also a fan of thin crust and their thin crust is amazing. Their slices are pretty big...I'd say they're bigger than costco slices, but thinner. The best part is that it's cheap. Mmmm they also make Arnold Palmers. I was able to order two slices of pizza with some additional toppings and a medium drink all under $10. Cheap delicious food is the best.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
So fantastic greasy cheesy floppy deliciousness. 
Minus a star for being so tiny and only accepting cash.
author: Hillary L.

description:
After eating at Andalu, stopped here to top off. Only after a couple drinks is this place worth stopping at. It is cheap, everything starts out as cheese and then they add the topping when reheating your slice. Don't expect great pizza but it is nice a thin, hot out of the oven and made to order. 
Have a couple of drinks before coming here and you won't be disappointed.
author: Lawrence T.

description:
Is it wrong to want to be drunk all the time so you can live on Arinell's cheese slices (with extra peppers)?

DON'T JUDGE ME.
author: Jess F.

description:
Yeah it's NY style, but last night it was also sad, disappointing, drunk style. 

The crust on my slice was half raw.
author: Jenn W.

description: More about the experience than about the food. You're probably drunk or desperately hungry if you're eating this. New York-style pizza by the slice until 2am. If you want toppings they just pile it on the center of the slice. Watch out you don't get struck by the belt-loop keyrings on the hipster-punks.
author: Mandy H.

description: Very mediocre. If you are looking for NY style pizza this is it, but you this is 2 Bros quality or any of the other standard 99c pizza places littered across manhattan. Good enough to sate a late night booze induced craving, but no where near the slices you are really craving if you want that NY feel. I'll probably go back, but you shouldn't get your hopes up that this is going to be anywhere near a great pizza place in NY.
author: Scott C.

description:
Great, cheap NY style pizza.

Their slices are thin and fast...   "That's what she said"
author: Thömas F.

description:
This place has rad NY style pizza. Thinnnnn. Cheesy. Just a tad of grease. Cheap. Quick. 

No matter what time of the day I come into this place, metal and punk music is blasting...It feels reminiscent to all my trips to NY...

I appreciate it. 

Truth.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Ever been to NYC?

Ever eaten a slice at Ray's?

Do you like how that tastes? (I do I do!)

Then Arinell's is the place for you!  Best NYC style pizza I've had in SF (and you can trust me, I'm from the other side).  

My advice would be to stay away from the toppings-- they're nothing too exciting (pepperoni is good, I guess) but they're kind of expensive in my opinion (although my pizza brain still thinks its 1993 and I'm buying slices and playing the Simpsons arcade game with my allowance, so maybe don't listen to me).

I get a quick cheese slice here all the time.  The sicilian is excellent as well.  Love the guys behind the counter with their PBRs.
author: Kristin P.

description:
What a very nice place. I was drunk 2 weeks ago and stumbled onto this place during the bar crawl. My roomie was telling me about this place for a long time, but i only remember this because I looked at my bank statement the next morning and realized that the "really damn good pizza" I had that night was this place. 

I'd come again.
author: Seth W.

description: Haven't had pizza this good in decades. This is the pizza I knew as a kid growing up in Chicago (Never did I see thick crust "chicago pizza" til I came to California). Super thin, droopy, you have to fold it to eat it. Not too much sauce or cheese and plenty of fennel (the spice not the vegetable). Outer rim of crust is crispy. The sausage tastes great although it would be better in smaller bits than those big slices.
author: JJ H.

description:
My boyfriend and I were recommended this place while we were on the BART to Mission.

"Awesome pizza, but the place is run by a bunch of stoners," said the guy who recommended it to us. 

I saw it on a corner right after getting off the BART. Based on that recommendation, we decided that we had to try a slice.

This place epitomizes "hole in the wall." It's a small pizza place with hardly any seating. Most people just take the pizza to go. The interior is kind of dark and dingy. Our cashier had long hair and did indeed look like a stoner.

A slice of Neopolitan (thin crust) pizza is $2.50 while a slice of Sicilian (thick crust) pizza is $2.75. Adding toppings cost extra. A bit expensive for a slice of pizza with only sauce and cheese on top, but it's definitely worth it if you're in the specific mood for NY style pizza.

The crust was perfect: not doughy, slightly crisp. The sauce was very flavorful without being salty. The cheese was nothing to write home about, but I rank crust and sauce higher on pizza priorities than cheese anyway.

I'd definitely come in again for a slice.
author: Wendy S.

description:
Definitely reminds me of the new york style pizza, fold'em in half and eat as you go. 

It's simple and delicious. Not the place to go if you're looking for fancy toppings.
author: Jane K.

description:
Cheap, good, NY style pizza...perfect place to hit after barhopping with friends.  They have both Neopolitan and Sicilian style pizzas by the slice, both reasonably priced.  Had the Sicilian last night, although in retrospect the Neopolitan looked to be a better choice as the slice we had was overly sauced (soupy) and on this night, cut a little small, almost half the size of Golden Boy in North Beach.  Regardless, it fills a need and hey, it's only $3.00!  

Entertaining to see the cross-section of humanity that comes in here after drinking in the area.  There's a little of everything and generally, people are in good spirits or at least filled with them.
author: Roy N.

description:
I'm thrilled to be able to actually write a great review for a pizza joint in SF. As some of my readers may have noticed, I'm a frickin' stickler about pizza. Being a native Noo Yawka will do that.

So, appropriately, it was a fellow NYer who tipped me on this place. My buddy Franklin, who plays in local cover band TAINTED LOVE, and I were discussing the dearth of decent pizza in these parts, and he enthusiastically recommended Arinell's, which I had not been to or even heard about. My boy was adamant, knowing full well my intense passion about this sacred subject. 

So, I happened to be in the area the other day, when I recalled the tip as I walked by. So, I screwed up my courage, and stepped across the threshold.

Right away, the correct combo of scents greeted my nostrils, and I KNEW I was gonna love it. I immediately ordered 2 slices, which were served up promptly. Both were nice and oily, and at the perfect temp to eat.

I took a bite.

Bliss. Total, utter bliss, induced by near perfect cheeses and sauce. I was stoked. Another option for a slice!!!

I left and walked down to the bus stop at 16th and Mission, pleased that I had a few minutes to chomp down the rest of  the slice before the 33 came along to take me back to RCTV HQ. Keep in mind that I could easily grab a great slice at the end of my ride at Village Pizza on Clement, but I'm glad I snagged it at Arinell's.

Kudos to my NY comrade-in-pizza, whose opinion I can trust. Good call!
author: ACE A.

description:
Holy jumpin' taste buds on a pogo stick!  Arinell rocked my mouth!

Come hither o' thin-crusted, oily-orange pizza slice.  Burn my fingers with your intense fresh-from-the-oven heat, I do not mind.  For soon you and I shall be one!

Be you a plain cheese?  Fear not!  Arinell will add pepperoni and briefly return you to the firery hearth that brought you to life.  And when you reappear you shall still be crispy and loaded with such goodness as to silence all table conversation!  I for one thought I might not meet such a beauty to behold, but hold your flexible nature on a bed of wax paper I will.  Down to the last bite you remained true to the simple-yet-balanced flavors, even the crust a golden feast.

I will note to arrive at a non-busy time as to procure one of the only six seats in the store.  Chicago deep-dish style will always have a special place in my heart, and now I must make room for Arinell's NY-style delights!

Times visited: 1 (hopefully of many)
author: Amy L.

description: Stopped in for a couple slices recently - was very cheap, although no small to go boxes was annoying. Still tasty, worth a stop - although order a large pie for a box or eat it there.
author: Sam A.

description:
Pizza snob says:  GET IN MY BELLY.  I'm sorry... is this SoHo?  Am I on Bleeker St?

THE perfect NY-style slice I have found in SF, no questions asked: Perfect crust, perfect sauce, perfectly greasy, served up perfectly on a sheet of wax paper.

Hell mutha effin YES.
author: Laura F.

description: i dunno, of all the food choices on valencia i keep coming back, late night eat or smack dab in the middle of the day. nothing like a thin slice of cheese right out of the oven.
author: Henry Y.

description: Closet to the east coast pizza I have had in the city . Very big slices lots of add ons and super quick service. Once you pick the slice you want .. reg or sicilian, they put your toppings on throw it into the oven and in a couple min you got your piping hot pizza mmmmm ... The place is small so its really for a quick stop and eat.. Overall awesome pizza great service ... worth a try!
author: Anthony S.

description:
You'll read it over and over... probably the best NY-style pizza in SF. 

However, it comes at a price. 

Hugely inefficient staff/process (Sat night about 12:30... took over 30 mins to get a slice where there were only 13 people in front.) They don't have the space/organization to really have multiple pies ready, so that leads to the log jam. 

Round pizza... er... not exactly (I'm not talking about the thicker crust rectangular one)... so if symmetry is your thing, keep moving. 

Not the cleanest looking place... keep it off the counter if you plan on putting it in your mouth. -- message from the FDA (kinda) 

Having said that, there IS a reason this place always has a line (apart from the inefficient part), whereas the 3 other places within two blocks do not. 

Enjoy... and my advice when you go there. Keep it simple... no need for California toppings. Embrace the cheese slice.
author: Claudio d.

description:
Pizza!!!!

Went to this place because Little Star Pizza down the street was closed. I wished it was open.

Arinell was on the 100 things to eat in SF before you die. 

Ok, this place was just alright. They have a sign that claims their is no sugar or msg added in their pizza dough. They have both a thick pan square pizza and NY style pizza. Their toppings are limited. 

The Pizza was just okay for me its no SLICE OF NY! I can scratch that off my list now. 

Will not be back again.
author: Yung H.

description:
I don't know why everyone is saying this sh*t is NYC style b/c it aint, so stop playing yourselves. 
Anyone who actually lived in nyc and had multiple slices from different boroughs will know this is garbage. 

Just bc its big, greasy, thin and they have it displayed under a glass don't make it nyc. The thing is soggy and the cheese sits sadly on top of doughy nastiness. 

Pass on it. You're not missing a slice of nyc.
author: Mike Skinz Z.

description: Great for a quick late night snack.
author: Jeff D.

description: Their whole pie never tastes as good as their slices. Their pizza reminds me of this pizza I had when I was a kid on the boardwalk of Venice beach in the early 90s before the owner changed and the boardwalk only had shitty pizza. Anyway I keep searching for that taste, and this place emulates it the best...besides New York. Highly recommended. Parking sucks as to be expected.
author: Steve H.

description: With all my trips to SF over the years, I believe this was the first time I ate pizza in the bay?!!!  Anyhow, Arinell is a no frills joint with decent thin crust pizza for those on the run (literally because parking is slim).
author: J L.

description:
Yelp has categories for cheapest, most romantic, and open late.
There needs to be a new category for food eaten, and reviews written while stoned. Not that every review written at 2AM of a restaurant in the Mission is by someone whom just had multiple bong hits, but it appears many have been.  (see any Faralito review)
Dude. This pizza is fine if you like bread with tomato sauce. No flavor. Whatsoever. Cheese. Yes, but minimal. Toppings. Present.
24 bones for a one- topping large. Yes, New York 'style' pizza, but that's where any similarities begin, and end.
author: Mr. S.

description: As a native New Yorker living in the Bay Area, I'm quite judgmental about the pizza around here - ESPECIALLY when it's branded as New York style. Fortunately, Arinell meets the baseline qualifications for a real NY pizza. The crust is on point. The sauce and cheese could be better, but the CRUST is what makes a NY slice, period.
author: K S.

description:
The girly wanted to take me here when we first started 'hanging out,' since she knew what a pizza freak I am....We went, stood in line for a few minutes (I was extremely excited at this point, but I didn't really show it...I did not need her knowing what a fat a$$ I am when it comes to pizza that early on in the relationship...she's completely aware of it now) and to our dismay, the chick in front of us in line got the final 8 slices.  Needless to say, my girl was NOT happy. Actually, she was pretty damn angry. I figured the pizza couldn't be THAT good for her to be huffing and puffing the way she was..

A couple weeks later, she took me again, and I now see why she wanted me to try it so badly, and I realized why she was so angry!  This is one of the best NY Style pizza I've had in a while, without having to pay $24 for a whole pie. Haven't had such good "sliced" pizza since I visited NYC. I have, though, only been there once, so I have to try it a few more times (preferably sober) to up this to 5 stars.

I can't see myself bar hopping in the Mission without making a stop here.
author: Farbod D.

description: Good New York style pizza. Cash only. $3 for a slice. Was a little grimy and playing some weirdo heavy metal music, but the pizza was good, authentic NY style.
author: C C.

description:
I took the advice of SF Weekly's 2008 "Best Pizza" award to this pizzeria and stopped by today.  I got a cheese slice to go and carried it all the way home on the bus and the cable car ride home, but it was so worth it!  Best slice of pizza I had in a long, long time!

The saltiness and taste of the tomato sauce was just right, and the cheese and crust were baked to perfection!  I'll be back!
author: Maile N.

description:
One thing I noticed that New York has is cheap pizza places. Until today, I thought the closest thing you could get locally was Little Caesar's or Costco. Not anymore. 

$2.75 for a cheese slice - yes, I had very tasty $1 slices out in some cutty part of Manhattan. But still, it's a nice, simple slice but thin. I'd bet it'd taste even better after a night of drinking at the Elbo Room. 

And yes - this place is a gritty hole in the wall. This is the Mission, after all. If you want granite countertops with your pizza, go to the Marina or hop on BART to Walnut Creek.
author: Navi T.

description:
Hot Damn!  Their good greasy slice of NY Style Pizza just got better.  Last night I stumbled past their door after 1:30 a.m. and found them STILL OPEN.  Is San Francisco turning into a real city?!  With real food available after ten p.m.?!  Please, please, please say, yes!

Girl behind the counter says the new hours are until midnight most nights and until 2 a.m. on Fridays and Saturdays.  They're missing the post-bar-closing rush, and I don't understand why they'd want to do that, but their new hours still have me pleased as, uh, a-hem, pie.
author: Napoleon R.

description:
The next stop on my San Francisco pizza tour is Arinell. Let me cut to the chase...AWESOME pizza slices. Like seriously, awesomely good and simple. If you're not a crust eater, you will be...it's that good. 

BUT...after frequenting this place more than a few times, I still have two things burned into my brain forever. 1) a PORN was shot here. A raunchy raunchy porn (don't ask how I know the raunch factor). There's no way that entire place was scrubbed down, so do the math. 2) One night the guy serving slices had the absolute dirtiest hands and dirty black fingernails. And I watched in horror as he used those black fingernails to rip my slice away from the others and put it in the oven. Newsflash: wiping your hands on your dirty apron between taking money and serving my pizza is NOT killing the germs homie! 

Despite all of this...you see I gave them 4 stars...and I've been back since. Now THAT'S some good ass pizza.
author: Jole S.

description: Read the reviews and had to go try it. Its all true. Real authentic East Coast New York Style pie. Got one piece and a root beer. Had 3 bites and ordered another slice right away cause it was so good. Looking forward to my next visit. I want to turn my kids on to it so they know what pizza tastes like where I come from.
author: Jimmy G.

description:
Arinell's is a 7/10 when judged against New Jersey/York Pizza slices.  And just slices, not sit-down restaurants.  It's the one place I goto in the city for a slice.

However, the people who work there are sometimes borderline retarded.

My friends and I, all from Jersey (they were visiting) were out drinking right next door this past Saturday.  I knew Arinell's was open until 2am.  Just to be safe, we left the bar at 1:20am to get some slices.

Low and behold, the fence was up, and the guy was sweeping the floor.  

I asked, "Hey, what happened to 2am?"  

He responds, "We're sold out."  and kept sweeping.

Seriously?!?!  It's not a concert ticket, bro.  You don't sell out.  Worst case scenario you're left with ONE whole pie vs. selling pizza up until 2am and making another $100 for the store, AT LEAST.

The garbage pizza place a couple doors down was PACKED, and we were all discussing "sold out?  really?"

pull your "S" together, and operate a business like a business.  It ain't THAT good.  

So just know, while Arinell's claims to be open until 2am, the door may in fact be open, but they aren't serving pizza.  At least I know Escape from NY Pizza will be serving when they say they are.
author: David W.

description:
Hole-in-the-wall pizza at its best. Pretty much a quarter of this thin crispy crust adorned lovingly with hot gooey cheese is yours for only $2.75. If you want toppings, they basically throw your sausage or mushroom or whatever on top and throw your pizza slice back into the oven to get everything melty with each other. 
I managed to stuff a slice down my gullet even after hitting up Pancho Villa's happy hour cause it was SO GOOD! Wish there was seating though! Cash only also.
author: Rayna L.

description: Today I had the pleasure of ordering good ole pepperoni pizza!!! Sean was awesome gave us exactly what we wanted!!! Never had New York pizza but this place was great!!! Thanks Sean!!!
author: Keri S.

description: Quite possibly my favorite pizza place in the city. Never have I ever (take a shot) had a place give me mushrooms like theirs. This is a no bullshit establishment and a damn good slice is what you'll get.
author: Matthew C.

description:
This place has pizza that must be made with crack. I had a slice and have been craving for more ever since. Arinell's is a rather dingy little place in the Mission but their NY style pizza is fantastic. Comes with a perfectly thin and crisp yet chewy crust with really flavorful sauce. I had a pepperoni slice and the pepperoni added even more flavor. Yum.

They also give you a pretty nice sized slice. The young guy who was working the counter must have been on crack himself since he cut me such an odd-shaped slice (see picture) but after tasting this thing, he could cut it into any weird shape he wants and I'd still eat it. 

Tiny place that can probably fit 3-4 ppl snugly sitting on stools or standing up. 

Bottom line: Highly addictive NY style pizza.
author: Jim C.

description: Closest I have found in the bay area to NYC pizza. It's pretty close to the ubiquitous cheap slices on the east coast, at a good price. If phrases like "deep dish" and "stuffed crust" are things you associate with pizza, you might not fully appreciate why this pizza is special.
author: Dan T.

description:
I don't go here so often anymore, now that I live closer to 24th than 16th.  A random stop in last week reminded me just how great this pizza joint is.  A hole in the wall with character - stoner/hipster lookin' kids slinging your slices in a space that looks like when the lights go off at night, the rats and roaches come a runnin'.  Personally, I love it.  And the pizza.  Oh so good.  Definitely the closest thing to a NY slice in the mission; thin, foldable crust, great tomato sauce, grease...
And they're open late.  Perfection.

Note - I haven't tried the deep dish, and it doesn't seem like their speciality.  I stick with the original and rarely get toppings -- occasionally some garlic.
author: Jane F.

description:
Have you ever eaten pizza so good you lose your concentration? When everything goes blank and all you can focus on is that delicious slice of pizza in front of your face? That my friends is Arinell! 

Arinell makes your traditional thin crust pizza, but it's more than that. Their pies have the right amount of sauce, their cheese is never burnt, and the crust is cooked to perfection. So many transplants from the East Coast do not like SF pizza, because it's not like traditional East Coast pizza. This is until they try Arinell.

Another great thing about Arinell is they not only serve great pizza, but they play the best hair metal on their speakers. I recommend this pizza to anyone; keep on rocking boys!
author: Brent R.

description:
Awesome pizza. Not frou frou, but definitely tasty.

Doesn't deliver and parking can be tedious in that neighborhood...although found a cheap parking lot one block over.
author: S M.

description:
Ugh. How to Have a Successful Shitty Restaurant in San Francisco:

1. Find a niche that hasn't been filled (NY-style pizza).
2. Locate your restaurant in an area where people care more about how unique their food is than how it tastes (the Mission).
3. Hire workers who fit in in aforementioned area (PBR-drinking tight jean-wearing hipsters.
4. Produce bland food at a low cost that's still more expensive than its competitors.

Ta-da!

This is New York style maybe in size and appearance, but not in flavor. Bland, chewy, rubbery...ugh
author: Mark A.

description:
A person in my life used to call it Ugly Boy Pizza (sorry guys) and it just stuck.  I don't think any of the pizza dudes are trying to impress with superior hygiene or put together style and that's a-ok.  No frills aging punks giving you the slices you wanted.  It reminds me of my east coast roots to have straight forward interactions such as the ones you can have at Arinell's.  

I am not from NY and my standards are low, so lord knows how these slices compare for a New Haven pizza connoisseur, but I can say loud and proud that I like them.
I used to work a block away and I'd powerwalk back from Arinell's clutching a greasy delicious slice on a flimsy piece of wax paper.  Even though my hands were gross and guilt was written all over my pizza oiled face, ugly boy pizza is always worth it.
author: Bobby S.

description:
Best by the slice pizza I have ever had, in NYC or elsewhere. I just moved back to the Bay after living in NYC for 4 years. I loved thin crust before I moved there and I loved it even more by the time I left. Arinell's does thin crust right! So thin, so crispy...it's even crispy at the point! The sauce is delicious. The cheese is standard but good. The toppings are fresh. The price is right. Honestly, you cannot wrong at this hole in the wall, no matter what the time of the day (lunch, dinner, late night - I've done it all).

Bottom line: if you like thin crust NY style pizza, you will be hard pressed to find a better pie in SF.
author: Blond E.

description: Absolutley fantastic!! Last time I had pizza this good, was 6-7 yrs ago in NY. Place is a "hole in the wall" but as soon as you walk in, the amazing smell of old skool NY pizzeria hits you in the face. Had some slices at night. Took 2 pies back to LA the next day.
author: Farshi M.

description: death metal and cheap slices.  perfect.
author: Stephen B.

description: Nice crust on pre made pizzas that are refired with selected toppings.  The toppings don't get cooked as well since they are set on top of previously cooked pizzas but the crisp crust makes the pizzas good here!
author: L T.

description:
This pizza is reliable, tempting, and addicting . . .  all the things I must have in my life + mushrooms.

Does this review make sense? NO.  No worries, just go to Arinell, have a slice and you'll understand the nonsense that I am writing, because you will be that entranced.
author: Marty L.

description:
This place is pretty much a hole in the wall, yet it gets 5 stars from me. I hope that helps describe how good the pizza is here!

I usually get ~2 slices of thin-crust cheese pizza (no toppings necessary, trust me!), and I'm pretty stuffed once they're gone. 

I absolutely love this place because of the combination of good eats and great prices ($2.75/slice of cheese pizza). You won't be disappointed!
author: John C.

description: The best oily and scrumptious slice of cheese pizza in SF - whether you eat it hungover or after a workout.  Definitely deserves to be on the 100 things to eat before your die list.
author: Chad S.

description:
Great NY-style pizza. The only pizza in SF that compares to Joe's in Greenwich Village.

If you come hungry, it's best to just get the entire pie (really satifies for 2 people). It may look HUGE but remember that it's paper thin and you'll still be hungry after one slice (also because it's super good).

Be warned...they charge a box-fee for the pizza box - seriously, it's called a box fee!
author: Mike K.

description: This is NOT New York pizza. It's fine if you are looking for some over-cooked greasiness after an extended tour of the neighborhood bars, but should otherwise be avoided. At least they serve by the slice and are open late.
author: Kevin F.

description:
Straight up NY slice!  
if u want a taste of manhattan, Grab a cheese slice or two.  amazed every time how similar it is.
author: Josh C.

description:
One drunk evening in the Mission, I stumbled upon this relic of a pizza shop. 
With it's music blaring in the background, I ordered a slice of cheese as big as my face. 
As I bit in to my slice, my palettes went into a frenzy trying understand what was occurring. It only took moments to realize that this pizza is LEGENDARY! 
Go here, find it, search for it, stumble into it, do what ever you have to do... just get to Arinell's. 

And they also play a cameo in a very interesting movie...
author: Matthew L.

description:
The best cheese pizza I've tasted outside of New York.
I don't get to eat here often but I wish I could.

You know it's good pizza when you can just get a simple slice of cheese and it's good on it's own!
author: Mike N.

description:
I've been coming to this spot for over 15 years. Thankfully, it has been consistent for all these years. This place is the real deal... (FYI: they have another location on Shattuck in Berkeley, too, which is a little bigger, a little nicer, but pizza tastes just as good).
