What you want to get here are the thin pizza slices. What is it? Thin pizza with just the right amount of sauce and cheese. This is the type of pizza you can and should fold, then devour. Aww yeah... 

Complaints about cleanliness are based on fact. The guys that work here usually smell. Their hair is oily and their clothes are dirty. They look like they haven't showered for days. They will take your money, give you change, and use those same hands to put your toppings on your pizza slice before popping it into the oven.

If that grosses you out, your best bet is to just order cheese. That way, the guy does not touch any toppings, and does not touch your pizza. (Warning though, even when you order cheese, some of the less skillful guys might touch the pizza with one hand while transferring the pizza to the oven with the pizza peel in the other hand)

When you order cheese, the only potential contact between the guy and your slice is when he grabs the piece of wax paper and your pizza lands on the wax paper. 

Just try not to think about it and bite in.
author: Ken L.

description:
YUM.  Best New York style ever.  And IMHO that's the best kind of pizza.  

Nuff said.
author: Misha F.

description: For the closest thing to a NY style ultra-thin crust pizza. this is the place.  I always get a cheese slice which they re-crisp in the over upon order.  This place is no frills.  There are couple of small counters with stools.  They have basic soda fountain.  They have a thick crust pizza too but I always get the thin crust.
author: Shane C.

description: Best thin crust pizza ever. This place is so so so delicious. A huge slice for $2.75. The only problem I had is that it's a small hole int he wall and we had to eat this out in the street in the mission.  Definitely a place where I can honestly say I can eat the whole pizza because it's SO good!
author: Christine B.

description:
To be clear, I'm too old for "4th meal". 

But, finally, A's has decided to stay open late on the weekends (3am I think?). 

So, yay for young people!!!
author: Shal J.

description: The real deal.  Better than a lot of pizza places in NYC.  If you don't love this, than you don't like New York style slices.  The simpler, the better.  It is truly one of the best eats in SF.
author: Wilson B.

description:
I have found there to be three kinds of pizza. 

1. Yuppie-tastic.
2. Bastardized American Greasy Deliciousness.
3. Ellio's.

If you want the first don't come in to the mission. If you want the third go to the grocery store and make it yourself to eat while watching the latest episode of heroes. If you want the second, and want it done right then move to New York. If you don't want to move to New York (and why would you SF is waaaaay nicer and slightly cheaper) then check this place out. It's cheap(ish) thin, greasy, and delicious. True, that this is for a specific demographic, but having a steady diet of New York pizza for 4 years certainly makes me part of that demographic. Even if the pbr and tight jeans didn't.

I like bastardized american greasy deliciousness when it comes to pizza. Don't hate.
author: Kevin O.

description:
Absolutely the best pizza in SF I've had. I have my germaphobic issues but I didn't really notice the whole "server-using-dirty-hands" scenario as other Yelpers have (but maybe I continuously choose not to notice because their pizza is that damn good!) I always go for their thin cheese slice w/ pepperoni. The cheese, sauce, crust & pepperoni are perfect. The closest to foldable, greasily delicious NY-style pizza you'll get in SF.

Love that they're open late. Perfect 2 AM snack after a night of dancing. And it's 2 blocks away from our house. And cheap! Hmmmm...no wonder I've noticed more cellulite on my thighs since we moved to this neighborhood. Ah well. Won't stop me from going back to Arinell. You only live once.
author: Agatha S.

description: I got a huge slice of New York style pizza for cheap.  The service is friendly and quick- this is great for what it is- a hole in the wall pizza place.
author: Christy L.

description:
The best New York-style slice in SF. Their thin crust cheese slice is a must. Their sauce is amazing--on the sweeter side, not too tomato-y.  

I usually don't order toppings here because they sort of just pile them on pre-cooked slices rather than make a fresh pie.
author: Bradley T.

description:
I like my pizza the same way I like my men-- hot, quick, and dirty.

.....haha, just kidding (kind of).  

Seriously though, I was torn whether I wanted to try this place or not because so many people talked smack about it.  Well, Arinell must've done a serious business overhaul or I'm just lucky, because when I walked in, the guy behind the counter actually half-smiled and said "Hey, what's up."  I looked down at his hands for a quick inspection of his fingernails: they were clean.  The metal music was loud but not blasting.  The counter was (gasp!) not greasy at all.

And most importantly, the pizza was fabulous.  I got it to go in a bag so I could walk over and eat in Dolores Park, and in the short time it took me to get to the park, the pizza grease had practically obliterated the bag.  That's how you know you're eating real NY style pizza!!  All the west coast low-cal junk is nice, but every once in a while, a girl needs some real food, and this is where it's at!
author: Christy L.

description:
Dangerously close to NY-style pizza. And in SF!!!!!!! Crust is a bit thin but this slice definitey fits the bill. Much better than that escape-from-the-planet-of-the-apes-or-whatever-place. :) 

Would I order from there again? Sure: it's Friday night, the guys are over for poker and we've got beers.
author: Sandeep C.

description: This is a really good New York Style pizza. I came here not expecting anything grand but let me tell you this place is really delicious. Just wanted to recommend this to anyone in the area.
author: Nicholas A.

description:
YUM-O!! 

I was headed to my first Yelp Elite Event at Morak Lounge which was just half a block away, and I realized HMM WOW HEIDI C. IS HUNGRY! I remembered the event stating that Arinell Pizza was right around the corner so I decided to scope it out. Let me tell you, stepping foot into Arinell Pizza at 7pm on a Tuesday evening was the best decision I made that night.

Let me give you the run down. I came in here, hoping to get a slice of a sausage pizza. I stared at the counter and they only had out a huge cheese pizza. Then next to it, there was a thicker deep dish-esque cheese pizza. I stared at that, stared at the menu to find slices listed as mushroom, sausage, pepperoni, etc. I was so confused. 

Heidi C.: Hi do you have anything else besides cheese?
Worker: We have everything.
Heidi C.: (looking dumbfounded) Oh...? Then can I get 2 slices of sausage?
Worker: Yup! 
(Worker proceeds to pick up two slices of cheese, moves the two over to his topping counter, puts on a few slices of sausage, then reheats the pizza in a huge oven)
At this point in time, that's when it clicked to me. You order whatever topping you want, and they put it on the cheese pizza for you! That's pretty clever since they only have to make 1 kind of pizza. Cuts down on manual labor. Very very very smart....

Slice of cheese: $2.75
Toppings: $0.75

OHHHHHHH and if you're a pizza oil dabber, get ready to dab your pizza here b/c it's pretty oily!
author: Heidi C.

description: The best NY style pizza in SF.  Great thin crust, greasy ( in the best way possible)
author: Ashish M.

description:
Massive slices with massive prices (for what it is) I might even be able to stretch my financial sensibilities and say this would be a great buy at $2.25 a slice, but if NYC can do it and still pay rent for $1.50-$2 a slice, then so should the mission.

Everything about this pizza is spot on except for the price.
author: Ben L.

description:
As fate would have it, we happened to arrive here at the end of the night when just the last four slices remained.  Had we been further back in line, I probably would have bit the person in front of me to have at their pizza.

The NY pizza is pretty much as good as it gets in Cali.  It's not QUITE there; the crust is a little blander than I care for, but it is really burn-the-roof-of-your-mouth fantastic.

Arinell in the Mission is nearly a carbon copy of the Berkeley digs.  Complete with the dickhead-ish hippies running the counter.

But for this level of quality, I'm willing to put up with a little attitude.
author: Rocco B.

description: My bf and I ordered a medium pizza (8 slices) with pepperoni, mushrooms, and olives for $21. Pizza was okay with a good, crispy, thin crust, but it wasn't deserving of a spot on the 2010 Big Eat SF list.
author: Sophia B.

description:
It was what it is. You eat it when you've been drinking for a while, but you wouldn't think to eat there sober. The slices at Marcello's in The Castro are much, much better.

Props for finally staying open past bar time, and also for always playing bad-ass metal.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Why is it so hard to find a pizza in SF that's as a good as a NY pizza? It seems like a simple formula...thin, crispy crust, not too much sauce, and topping (I'm not too picky on that last point, I never met a pepperoni I didn't like), and still no one does it right.

Arinell's pizza is the closest thing I've had to the real deal and it's quite satisfying. A medium with 2 toppings will stuff 2 hungry people, teh crust is thin and the cheese/ topping combo is great. They don't deliver and it's really best to eat the pizza on the spot to avoid a softer crust. Also, cash only. 

My pizza go-to!
author: Aristocles P.

description: I find it hard to believe that Arinell made it onto 7x7's list. The pizza is not remarkable, and I'll remember it more for the copious amounts of grease dripping off the slice. Aside from that, it is a decent tasting pizza with good flavors and a crispy crust. Perfect place to drop by before, during, or after a Mission bar crawl.
author: Brittany L.

description:
hey guess what?  arinell's is in san francisco, not new york.

can any pizza NOT in new york really be called "new york pizza"?  probably not, which is why people call it "new york STYLE pizza"... emphasis on the STYLE, which implies that it is similar to that of the pizza new york is known for as opposed to say, chicago style pizza which everyone knows is deep dish.

now that i got that off my chest...

arinell's reminded me of my most favoritestestest pizza place in boston, Pino's... and Pino's is so my favorite that i would slap my mama for a slice.

anyways, arinell's... it's good.  it's thin, and cheesy, and pizza'y and i like it.  there's only a few stools to sit and i think they only take cash but i'm not totally sure.

additionally, fair warning when you go towards the end of the night... even though arinell's say they are open until either midnight or 3:00a depending on the day, they shut their doors when the pizza runs out.  i went recently and some dude got all heated about this fact and threatened to yelp about it.  listen bro, sometimes restaurants run out of ingredients.  next time: plan a little better.

i like pizza.
author: Lauren P.

description: HALLELUJAH!!  Finally a NY style slice in SF that doesn't suck the big one!  This is the closest thing I've found yet to authentic east coast style 'za, and it's decently cheap to boot.  Woo-hoo!
author: Monica R.

description:
One of the advantages of working from home is the ability to get an early lunch.  It was with that in mind that I went to grab a slice, well, TWO slices, at Arinell's.  Generally I get my New York Style fix at Speederia down in San Carlos, so I was curious how this compares. 

It is now two slices later, and I'm quite pleased.  The pizza was greasy, but then, what New York Style isn't, and isn't that what napkins are for?  The cheese and sauce itself was quite good, perhaps some of the best I've had, but like the other reviewers, I agree that the toppings were less impressive.  The pepperoni was ok, while the sausage was kind of dry and basically felt like the regular Costco sausages cut up in overly thick slices and thrown on my pizza.  I definitely prefer the sausage from Speederia.  But perhaps my greatest pet peeve here was the crispiness... I expect my NY Style to have that EXTRA crispiness, and Arinell's just didn't shine on this front as much as I would have liked.  

Still, if you're going to be getting pizza slices in the Mission, Arinell's is by far the best of your options, and, for myself, I know I'll be back again!
author: Leon K.

description:
EDIT: i've gone here twice in the past couple months and both times it was... okay. five stars down to three? damn, maybe i was drunk the first time.

wow, i think those were real mushrooms.
author: Ronny K.

description:
Great thin-crust pizza served by dudes so surly they are entertaining.  

I'd give it five stars, but a friend showed me evidence that Kink.com just filmed a porn video there for their "Public Disgrace" website.  Yup, group sex filmed right where I stand when I order my slices.  That kind of makes the pizza a little less appetizing.  Hope they scrubbed the place down good after that.  But I'm sure I'll get drunk and forget about it.
author: Paul S.

description:
If you are from the east coast and are feeling homesick for a NY/NJ cheese slice - don't waste your time looking elsewhere.  I've had lots of other pizza out here and nothing else comes anywhere near Arinell. 

If you know what I'm talking about, you know I don't need to say any more than that.
author: Katie W.

description: This place has surprisingly tasty pizza for not that much $$ - reminded me a lot of a classic hole-in-the-wall New York pie shop - not QUITE as good, but definitely a good stand-in for the real thing.  Super thin crust too, my fave.  Plus, as a bonus, the slices were HUGE.
author: Jenna L.

description: Alright for a quick bite for lunch. They definitely do a good New York slice. Last time I went, I wanted to place an order for take out, and they wouldn't let me bring my bike inside even for the 30 seconds it would have taken me to place my order and go back outside.
author: Johnny W.

description: My go to for a quick bite or some pizza in the Mission.  Cash only.  Quick, friendly service.  Delicious NY style pizza.  Can't go wrong!
author: Katrina V.

description:
oh its so bomb. best NY slice i've had in the bay. if you are driving to pick up, bring a friend to run inside while you circle because parking is boo-boo. walking works too.

i think it's the crust. super thin, crispy enough to hold the toppings. it cracks when you fold it. 

it could be the cheese that strings along just the right amount. 

nah, it's the sauce. perfect amount and balance of tangy, sweet, savory. 

whatever it is, it works so get in mah belly!
author: Stacy C.

description:
5 star thin crust pizza with 1 star attitude. 

Seriously, the kid (the skinny one with the really short hair) at the register literally picks fights with anyone who walks through the doors who looks even remotely mainstream and female. He started screaming this degrading stuff at this girl in front of me who was very clean cut. I was shocked and then when I ordered and requested one simple thing he totally went off on me. After insulting me he said "Welcome to Arinells" and smirked at me. It was so ridiculous. I felt like I was across the counter from a petulant child. He's this angry kid with a huge chip on his shoulder wielding his cash register power like he's Napoleon. It's actually a bit pathetic. 

I love their pizza and used to come here ALL the time. I basically grew up in the Mission, and since I moved out of the city I make a point to swing by whenever I'm in town to grab a slice, but maybe I am too old and mainstream for this place. I have reached a point in my life where even if the pizza is good I don't believe in supporting places that are, quite literally, abusive.
author: Natasha Anna A.

description:
People tell me the East Bay is the place to go for pizza, but I've found my home slice at Arinell in the Mission.  For 5 years I've lived in the Peninsula/SF and have never been truly satisfied by a pizza joint until now.

The California pizza philosophy goes something like this:  "Throw as much crazy, weird crap on top of the slice as possible, and hope it tastes good".  CPK, Pizza Orgasmica, Pizza Delfino all subscribe to this school of thought.  The true test for pizza is how a plain cheese slice tastes.  No gourmet prosciutto with aged provolone.  None of that pear/goat cheese/spinach BS.  Just crust, tomato sauce, and mozzarella.  Would I ever eat a plain CPK cheese pizza?  Hell no!  ... but I would die for a cheese slice from Arinell.
author: Carlin E.

description:
I would say this is a really freakin' good slice of pie... and I lurve my pie. Having lived in NYC and crammed my face full of pizza for months, I need to tell you that this is pretty close to the real thing. I would say it's better than a few of the places I went in the city.

It's a small little joint perfect for when you need a slice on the go. There's a small spot for you to sit and read a paper while you chow down, but it's not a place to take a group from the office. The crust is super thin and super crunchy. The sauce is sweet and tangy, the cheese is nice and melty and the pepperoni tastes fresh. If you like deep dish like my man friend does then you'll be happy to know that they serve Sicilian deep dish as well.

Order a Neopolitan slice for 2.75 or get a 16" for $16.50 and an 18" for $22. Some toppings are .50 and some are .75. They include pepperoni, black olives, onion, fresh garlic, mushrooms, anchovies, sausage, green pepper, and extra cheese. Super sweet ass drinks include Diet Coke, Sprite, Root Beer, Coke, Lemonade, and Fruit Punch. Hit this place up next time you're shopping for vintage duds in the area. Cash only and NO cellphones!
author: Melody L.

description: I wouldn't want your hipster status to get in the way of actual hygiene. Guess what? Handling the food, taking cash and making the dough do not actually belong in the same sentence when unpunctuated by a hand wash.
author: Chris S.

description:
For once, I don't understand how yelpers can rate this place so highly..  It was the dirtiest place I've been to.. and the pizza tasted gross even if you close your eyes and not looking at the person who served you with long and dirty fingernails.  

Service was bad, the guy who handled the cash also made my pizza... He looked as if I annoyed him.  And then he sliced the already made cheese pizza that was sitting outside for a while, put the additional toppings I requested, and threw it back in the oven for a few minutes.  Is that what they call the famous NY style pizza? And while the portion was huge, all the toppings (including sausages, bell pepper and mushrooms) were still cold.  ARRRR.... it totally gross me out.  I'm still puzzled by the raves of this place.. Please enlighten me!  Am I missing something?
author: Carina N.

description:
To start off, I would like to disclose that I have a rule to only leave reviews after patronizing a business at least 5 times so my reviews aren't made willy-nilly. 

Probably the best pizza-by-the-slice in the Mission.  Always a favorite when I'm down on 16th.
author: L W.

description: Great NY style Cheese Pizza!!! Had to try it cause it was on the 7X7 top 100 list.  This is a small little shaddy pizza shop. No need to get dolled up here ladies.  But great pizza.  Made very similar to the NY style thin slice pizza.  Huge slices! Great cheap eats :)
author: Ying F.

description: Great pizza, I would give it 5 stars but I have had better pizza... just not at this price or by the slice.  So happy I live near by.  Just wish they were open later during week nights.
author: Nicole W.

description:
I'm more of a thick crust pizza type myself (Chicago-styled deep dish is a fave), but Arinell makes a decent thin crust cheese pizza.  The crust is nice and crispy, and the sauce and cheese are pretty good, too.  However, I can't say that the cheese slice really warrants a high position on the 7x7 List-- but I do think it'd be a great stop after drinking a few beers or so and a night on the town with friends.

This was the first on a 7x7-The-List marathon that my friends (Alea G. and S.K. included) and I embarked on in the Mission.  It was quite an epic quest, and we hit up eight places before waddling home (we tried to make it to nine, but I think my stomach might have up and murdered me at that point).  So this was stop one (see pictures here: http://pineapplebread.wordpress.com/2010/05/25/the-list-an-8-restaurant-marathon-through-the-mission/ ).  Our next stop was The Monk's Kettle . . .
author: Jeanne Y.

description:
This place is sooo freakishly delish... This is not your sit down w/ your family and let's listen to some italian music restaurant.. It's small-easy to miss, grunge-rock-why-did-kirk-cobain-have-to-die-so-early type of joint that gives you big bang for your buck.

thin crust, extra cheesy, slightly oily

And after your slice, go down a block, grab Bi-rite ice cream and head over to the park for the best sunday afternoon ever.
author: Milee M.

description:
It's definitely NY-style, and it's damn good.  Not as good as an actual NY place, but it's infinitely better than any other pizza-by-the-slice joint I've been to in SF.

The guy who was working here wasn't very friendly, he clearly expected everyone to understand how he would prefer that they order, but oh well.  Maybe people think it's more authentic NY if the guy's an ass.  Or maybe all these Mission hipsters think that kind of attitude is cool.

The lamest and most un-NYC aspect of Arinell is the hours.  Closing at 10 pm on weeknights and at midnight on Fridays and Saturdays = weak.

But hey, it's a cheap, good slice of pizza.
author: Joseph N.

description:
After a long stint on the other side, one of my roommates is now single. This is really awesome, and not because the ex is a jerk (he's not), but because I am pretty selfish, and I like having a mutual wingwoman around. 

The last few weeks have been full of educative experiences on what not to do for her as we navigate the treacherous waters of SF single life together: 

- Hitting on a guy by telling him he looks like your ex will not work. Trust me. 

- Just because you and your female friend are out dancing in the FiDi and two guys come up to ask you both to dance, does not mean they are straight. They are probably gay, and will tell you that your haircut is fabulous. 

- If you let a dude buy you a drink, do not be surprised if he tries to grope you over frings at Mel's at 2 AM the same evening. And don't be surprised if you kinda let him. Frings are amazing! 

- It's 11 PM. You've been drinking for ages and you pop into Arinell for some stomach-coating goodness before you are on to the next bar. What kind of pizza do you get? Tough decision. Do you go for the plain cheese, the cheese with peppers to seem like a healthy drunk, or do you ask for pepperoni and sausage and throw up the middle finger to all those smushed into the small little shop? 

If you're my roommate, you order ANCHOVIES. Smelly little fish? Even the guy behind the counter (who was totally chill and didn't have an attitude like I expected) was disgusted. The pizza is great for those late evening visits, but let's be a bit more discretionary with the topping choices in the future and remember that smelly fish = smelly breath. 

Hey roomie: You have much to learn, young grasshoppa.
author: Devon S.

description:
As a REAL New Yorker, this is the only pizza that comes close.  

It seems like most Pizza in California is about the toppings.  I only order plain slices at Arinells and it is still a MILLION times better than anything else I've had in SF including GoldenBoy.
author: Tom L.

description:
#86 on the 7by7 Top 100 things to Eat in San Francisco

Was good, but I'm sure it could've been better. They gave me the last slice which was probably the reason it was dry and rubbery.  Although I do need to give the thin crust props.  It was nice and crispy.  

Cost- around 3 bucks.  

Place- hole in the wall, 1-2 dudes working.  They grab a slice that's on display, toss it in the oven, and in less then 5 minutes, bam!! you got pizza.  

Parking-  Decent during the weekdays.  Standard Mission style parking.

I'll roll by again in the near future and order a fresher slice and re rate this joint.
author: Chase F.

description:
How the hell can a plain cheese pizza taste so damn good?!?!?!?

No idea, but the razor thin crust and the cheese and tomato sauce and tasty crust and the semi-stretchy cheese and the hotness hit the spot 10 times in a row with every single bite. Oh. my. god. We even got the last two slices of the old batch and it was tasty as hell.

BTW, one slice is about $2.75. Definitely a disgusting looking hole in the wall place, but soooooo worth going to. There's a legitimate reason why this place always has a line.

Not worth 5 stars only because this is the first time I've had this style of pizza. I'll have to try other places to compare. But still. Definitely has become a place that I will go to several times and crave.

Cheeeeseee pizzaaaaa. YUMMMMMMMM.
author: Angela H.

description:
This is the best tasting pizza I have had in SF.

So why am  I only giving it 1 star?

1)  I have never been to a more dirty place to get food.  Ever.
2)  How the hell did the staff get hired?  
The guy who "helped" me looked like he hadn't showered in weeks - long, greasy, unkempt hair AND hands with fingernails which appeared to have dirt? or some sort of black substance embedded in them!  Super unfriendly, had this attitude like customers bothered him from talking to other staff.  This dude touched my cash with bare hands, then scratched his nasty oily head with same hands, then pulled out a new pizza and cut it with same bare hands, touching the pizza all over.  eeew
3)  I got sick from eating here - and i've never gotten sick from eating out.

How do you check health inspection ratings?

Oh, I forgot to mention if you want any toppings on your pizza, they literally just put them on top of their already cooked cheese pizza.  Wtf?  They may as well just not even offer toppings if they aren't going to make it right.  What bullshit!
author: Ali G.

description:
it's great pizza. Our favorite in the mission district. 
Two slices is usually good for each person.
author: j d.

description: I love the pizza here.  Thin crust, tasty sauce, enough toppings.  Open late too!
author: Peter N.

description:
I am reminded of my youth in Philadelphia when I sit down for a cheese slice and a coke. 
I have not had a bad slice here. 4 stars for pizza slices. I love that it is cash only. Keep the line moving. They have a no cell phone rule. Shut up and eat your damn slice, yo. The zen of not hearing anyone on their phones is not to be discounted. 
Why don't I ever get an entire pie from this place? 
Come on!!!
author: Jason S.

description: Easily the best NY-style cheese slice I've had in SF.  A bit sacrilegious to say but it is similar to Joe's pizza in the village.
author: aaron h.

description: The pizza was great.  However, according to Yelp, they should be open until 3 am. Their sign read 2 am outside their building.  I came in with a group of about 8 at 1:30 am late Friday night on Aug 19 after hitting the bars. There was only four slices left and the guy refused to make more because they were "closed." I informed him of the error on Yelp and the sign outside.  He refused to acknowledge the frustration of only having half your party get food in the middle of the night. I hope the owner reads this and deals with his lazy ass employee because they could have gotten a ton of more money had they remained opened another half hour.
author: Rylan A.

description:
There are a few spots i love in SF to get a slice:

Escape from NY (all over SF)
Za Spot (Russian Hill)
Chico's (SOMA)
Golden Boy (N. Beach)
Pizzelle Di North Beach  (N. Beach) 
Little Star (doesnt sell slices but worth getting the whole pie)

and... Arinell when i'm in the Mission. 

This is about as close as we get to real NY pizza in SF. Its not Jonhs in the Village, but its thin and crisp and really, really good. If you dont like it, go somewhere else (i would say something rude but hey, I'm not a New Yorker).
author: Adam X.

description:
THE ONLY PLACE IN SF WITH NYC-STYLE PIZZA. 

Anyone with any shred of dignity for decent "street" pizza (we seem to be an endangered species out here) needs to eat here. And repeat.
author: who k.

description:
ANATOMY OF A POPULAR YELP REVIEW

Humorous one-liner opening the review.

So, I came here last night with a drunk friend/mom/cheap hooker and it was great. Eating here resembles intercourse, not because it actually does but rather because I just really like saying "intercourse." And now, I present some crazy, poopy-filled dialog between me and some people you will never know...

(standing in line)

Keane: What toppings do you want?
Mom: Why am I in this scene? I was never here before.
Keane: Bluetooth headset - no service. Isn't that funny?
Monkey: Sheep plural is still sheep.
ScarlettJohansson: Keane, I want to intercourse your brains out know.
Keane: Great idea, but you spelled "now" wrong.

Arinell serves the most NYey take-out slice in town, and would take place as my favorite if not for Victor's superior crust flavor/texture and much-reduced grease levels. But too much of any pizza will still make you a fatty and life's not fair and OMG CAPS MEANS I'M INTERCOURSE SHOUTING!!

Outro bathed in finality.
author: Keane L.

description:
If I can't go here, I might as well slap a little Hunt's tomato sauce and a Kraft Single on a Thomas' English muffin because that's about as right as anyone else in this area can seem to get pizza.

Seriously. 

And to all you Cali bitches dab-dab-dabing the grease off your pie with napkins, GROW A PAIR!  This is New York Pizza--live a little, damnit!  Life is fucking short!  SHORT, I say! Yeah, that's right, I AM A REAL WOMAN!!!  I fucking EAT my pizza, grease and all. That's right, bitches. And when I'm done I stick out my tongue and lick the orange sheen off the wax paper.  What?  Thought I WOULDN'T? As a matter of fact, you know what?  Leave that greasy napkin your narcissistic pussy ass used for blotting and I'll SUCK on that mutha, too.  WATCH ME. 

I hardly miss New York at all.
author: Tsada K.

description:
Yeah, I mooed at the counter guy.  I admit it.  And, y'know what?  I'd do it again!  I don't care about their NO MOOING sign.

When you're drunk and hungry, and all they have is cheese pizza, you sometimes get a little rowdy.  And seeing as I come from simple farm folk, what did they expect?

The irony was just too much for me to take.  I'll moo if I feel like mooing.  I'd Oink, too, if they only had slices of ham and pineapple.  In fact, last week I got kicked out of McDonalds for neighing at my Quarter Pounder.

Anyway, the pizza here is pretty good, but they need to work on their anti-agrarian policies before someone goes 4-H on their ass.
author: Adam W.

description:
You'll go for the long haired, disgruntled metal heads serving greasy pizza that has just the perfect combination of mozzarella and a sweet tomato sauce, but you'll stay for the endless collection of mix tapes blaring Iron Maiden out of a boom-box that looks and sounds like it's been in continuous use since the early Reagan administration.

Arinell Pizza is a magical, wonderful place.  It's the kind of place they write about in fairytale books and those awful "Remember When?" programs on cable...and don't even THINK about getting a napkin and dabbing off those little pools of grease forming at the top of your pizza.  That's not just grease, that's credibility!
author: Kevin H.

description: This is no-frills, New York style pizza. The kind of pizza that has thin crust that's crispy on the outside, doughy on the inside. This is the kind of place where they give you attitude if you try to act like you even own a cell phone when you're ordering. And the kind of place you eat and leave, so someone else can take the one of 4 stools you're occupying. Or you just take your slice with you if there isn't any space for you. In short, the kind of place that makes damn good pizza and the kind of place I would frequent fairly often when I found myself in need of a slice if I lived in the neighborhood.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
#86. A cheese slice (2009 & 2010) Big eat SF list

good, but why on the list? ....really really really thin (but not soggy, actually semi crispy) if you like it that way!
author: S V.

description:
Damn you yelp...you've finally let me down.

Being NYC born and "Sopranos Country" Essex County, New Jersey raised I have spent the last 15 or so years looking for decent  New York pizza further than 20 miles from the Lincoln Tunnel.

Reading the reviews got me intrigued and then excited and ultimately devastated.  I was hoping that  the reviews like "godsend," "best NY-style," "authentic," "slice of New York heaven" would be right on and the whiny negative ones about grease would be from Chicagoans or people from Portland.

I could say close but no cigar, but in reality it isn't even that close.  The crust was the proper thickness but way too crispy.  Authentic NY pizza crust isn't so thin that you could fold it if you so chose,  you HAVE to fold it in order to pick up the slice.

As previously stated the sauce was bland.  The toppings were complete shit.  Sausage  should be sliced so thin you can see through it...not piled on in huge chunks.  The cheese and the grease were on target though...coulda sucked it up with a straw.

Now the Sicilian looked intriguing so perhaps I'll give that a try...

I guess it's back to Amici's for me, but they have a whole other set of issues.

At least I got another entry for my "Jane, You Ignorant Slut" list of places everybody is just plain wrong about.

UPDATE:  I was hoping it would be better cold the next day as good 'za often is...unfortunately no.  Though Sonny seemed to enjoy the 7 slices I gave him for breakfast.
author: Jay W.

description: Cheap, quick, delicious, open late. Everything you could ask for in a pizza place in the mission.  The perfect stop after last call, or to take in for a bite into one of the neighboring bars.  I only wish they served to-go slices on a more substantial wrapper, I always end up dripping grease all over myself.
author: Heidi M.

description:
This is NOT authentic NY-style pizza.  The crust is all wrong, it's too thin and not chewy enough.  The sauce and cheese are correct and in the correct proportion, but the bad crust makes it not good.

This place is REALLY dirty and they leave the pizzas out behind the front counter for God-knows how long.  

I do not recommend at all.
author: Kathleen B.

description:
I think Arinell is by far the best by-the-slice pizza you can get in San Francisco. I understand what one of the past reviewers said about it occasionally being bland, but considering all the junk people pour into their sauces these days I appreciate the really clean taste of the slices--that is what East Coast pizza is about.

I also love how they put *just* the right amount of cheese on. Californians love their cheese a bit too much for my taste.

Yeah, I know the guys can be a bit rude but in a way its refreshing; it really is about the food. Also, I love the music they play from 70s stoner rock to thrash metal.
author: Paul C.

description: I lived in NY for over ten years and even lived above a pizzeria for a while--so I know my NY slice. (I used to eat a slice a day at various locations) This is an ALMOST authentic NY slice, a bit too much sauce and not quite crisp enough when reheated, I will certainly try again as I may just have been a "off" slice.  I frequent Village pizzeria (both locations) a lot and really feel they DO have an authentic NY slice, but they too can have an "off" slice now and again...
author: Amy W.

description: Thank God. NYC pizza amidst a million wannabes and California pizzas with avocados and nettles. This is the real deal and I can't believe it took so long to find. Also have a location on Shattuck in Berkeley. Cash only so beware. 3 counter seats on either side of this tiny place, so best to carry out or better yet, eat your slice our front folded...
author: J E.

description: Probably the best attempt at NY-style pizza in San Francisco!  The slices are huge.  The pizza is cooked fresh and then reheated by the slice on demand: essential to get the bottom crunchy.  The sauce and cheese are thinly smeared on.  No reason for any toppings except from the free shakers: red pepper flaks, oregano, garlic salt and parmesan.  The main issue is that they're not open after the bars close... because that's really then time when you get pizza in NY!
author: Adam B.

description:
Decent size slice, pretty good taste, but nothing compared to Serrano's up the street.

On top of that, a guy who works there (I haven't been back in a while so he may not anymore) is a complete and utter douchebag.

... naturally this made my desire to want to eat there diminish....

But 3 stars rather than 2 for low price and fast good pizza slices.
author: Kai S.

description:
Looking for a slice served with a side of attitude?  Arinell's is the place for you!
I don't know, I just don't get it...my slice was ok but nothing earth shattering.  If this is good, NY style pizza then I'm content eating non NY pizza any day.
author: phil h.

description:
It's a shit hole dive with grundgy servers and drunk dirty ass customers, BUT gotdamn the pizza slices in here are good!  Maybe they're lacing it w/ a little nose candy in or something.  Crust is crispy and sauce is just right w/ fresh toppings.  

Can't lose on the combo of good taste and reasonably priced slices especially after rolling out of one of the bars with your wig peeled back.
author: Himelick M.

description:
Guy in front of me as the pizza-man puts a piping hot fresh pie on the counter, "Can I get a slice from that pizza?"
Pizza-man, "No."  Proceeds to give him the last slice of a now completely cold pie that he re-heated.

You gotta love it.  They know there pizza is the real-deal-Holyfield and they don't take any shit from the customers.  Talking on the phone?  No pizza.  Not ready to order?  Next guy gets his slice.  

But when its all said and done, its all about the pizza.  And this place serves it up proper.  The closest things to New York City pizza you can find in San Francisco.  Stick with plain cheese; the true pizza connoisseur's slice.
author: Justin B.

description:
This place rocks, literally. You get a piping hot slice of thin-crust
with a generous side of chunky metal riffs & rock complexity a la Iron Maiden.

I wish they stayed open later during the weeknights; that could really
facilitate increasingly self-destructive behavior on Wednesdays.

I guess this pizza is to me like cocaine was to Paul Di'Anno. But my
pizza is only $2.50 a slice & Bruce Dickinson is nowhere to be
seen...yet.

12/20 update: The have Sicilian too!
author: Adam W.

description:
Good pizza if right. But if you think this is NY style pizza, you must have never been to NY. This pizza is nothing like NY pizza. And it sure costs a lot more than NY pizza. 

Large pie with xtra cheese, pepperoni, sausage, onion and garlic. $32. 
THIRTY-TWO EFFIN DOLLARS!! 

NY style pizza my ass..... But it is good. ;)
author: Jen D.

description:
So good the homeless people prefer digging through Arinell's trash can than any other pizza restaurant in San Francisco! You may have to step over a few bodies before walking through the door, but don't let that stop you from experiencing the best NY style pizza by the slice (and the whole pie) in the city!

Thin, crispy, tasty, perfect! After living in Manhattan for six years I really missed good, thin crust pizza and had givien up trying to find it here. I tried "Escape From NY" but it just isn't that great. I most likely would have never ventured inside Arinell's because of its appearance....small, dingy, cramped, bad lighting, etc....but after a friend's insistence and one bite into a delicious slice I was hooked.

 I give it five yums.  Yum, yum, yum, yum, yum.
author: gary c.

description:
Best NY Pie I've had in the city so far... but that's not saying too much.

YES the pizza was quite good, but I don't hasten to return because I was really turned off by the hipster scowls of the staff.  What a bunch of dicks!  Maybe they were having a bad day, but I felt like I was interrupting their doing nothing, by ordering a slice.

Maybe I'll stop in again if I'm around there, but I'll think twice about it first, it's a shame too because they pizza IS good, just not good enough for me to see past the staff's attitude.
author: Christian H.

description:
Last week, I got a chance to stroll along the seedy streets in the Mission district. Aside from having strong Hispanic representation, various cultures are high lighted especially by a wide range of cuisines. After a grub tip from Thanh, I had to try Arinell, a hole in the wall pizza joint famous for their New York style pizza. I ordered the Sicilian slice ($2.50) and one bite transported me to comfort food heaven. The slice is all about texture. 

The thin slice is chewy married with the nutty taste of slightly burned cheese. Simply delicious. An overuse of powered parmesan cheese, oregano, and chilli flakes would simply be a sin overpowering the goodness of the main ingredients.
author: Rayfil W.

description:
This is really about as close as you'll get to a New York slice in San Francisco. 

If you are lucky enough to get there when a newly made pie just came out, enjoy. The crust has that fluffy doughy freshness, that slightly crispy thinness. Unorthodox by East Coast standards, I know, but I'll throw a pile of jalapens on that thing and devour. Nice.

Look into their Sicilian slices, too. They make a juicy, satisfying thick square.

Years back the staff there were young cheerful, hard-substance abusers. They'd pretend to get into fist-fights over who would serve you first, it was a kick. The scene behind the counter seems to have mellowed, though you still get a feeling that these guys are in rock bands and doing illicit things. I always come away from there a little heartened. "Wow. There's still a scene like this in the city? People in their 20s in San Francisco don't all just work in offices downtown, drive cars and eat at Ramblas? How cool is that?"

And they listen to great music. I've heard Can, Faust, Man is the Bastard, Arthur Brown, Rudimentary Penii, Amboy Dukes-era Ted Nugent and all kinds of other stuff in there. An eclectic mix of good meat & potatoes Rock. 

If I had a complaint, it'd be that there's not enough seating, and folks like to camp in there. But no problem, I'll just take my slice down the street to Muddy Waters.

If Arinells were to open late, the terrible-lowly Cable Car Pizza down the street would not last a month longer.
author: David M.

description:
Great thin slices at a fair price...

And I love how the help can give a shit.  I think that is part of the charm...
author: Nathan W.

description: Ordered a large pizza with some toppings to go.  Walked in to pick it up, wanted to cancel my order after seeing the greasy dirty looking guy behind the counter, paid for it anyway, ate it with some friends, felt a little dissapointed with it after reading so many good reviews, slightly burnt taste, dough a little too tough, finished off the pie anyway, proceeded to gossip with friends, then head out to movie, movie was let down, returned home, zonked out on bed,
author: C A.

description:
For some people, the rude nasty attitudes of the guys who work here might be part of its charm...but it wasn't charming to me.  I went there late night on Wednesday, so maybe it's not that way during the day.  I was uncomfortable, and I wasn't really sure what was going on...and the guys behind the counter were in  no hurry to help me.

It's tiny, oddly decorated, and they were playing the weirdest music known to man...and SUPER greasy pizza.
author: PrincessPeac H.

description: NO DEAL!! not good at all. Watery sauce, tasteless dough. I disliked it so much I don't want to talk about it anymore.
author: Ruben A.

description: I have to say that Arinell slices are extremely inconsistent. The last two times I've stopped by for slices, they were given to me without having been heated properly, and they must have been prepared a long time ago -- the dough had a consistency that reminded me of hard styrofoam. The staff can be rude sometimes, and if you don't tip them they can be snotty about it.  Sorry, but if you're rude and don't heat up the pizza properly, don't expect a tip. Deja Vu, a block up 16th, has much better slices and is friendlier.
author: David C.

description:
This is the first time I've really been misled by the Yelp crowd and I'm REALLY disappointed.

One star for Arinell's and one star for the morons in San Francisco who don't know what the fuck NYC style pizza is.  

This is NOT NOT NOT NOT NOT NYC pizza.  Yes, the pizza is thin, but so is a piece of cardboard and I wouldn't call cardboard with cheese NYC pizza - but you guys might.  My jaw literally ached after two slices because the crust was so tough.  The cheese was ok but the sauce was virtually nonexistent. 

I guess I'll be getting used to smoked salmon and tofu pizza.
author: Will H.

description: Have to say its been awhile since I had a piece of Arinell's pizza so I went for it again....Basic cheese was calling me. It's OK....not great, little greasy.
author: P G.

description:
I am a New Yorker who doesn't bitch about places that advertise themselves as NY-style pizza when they don't match up in every possible way to this.

There is no strict code as to what defines "New York Pizza" except big, foldable, greasy slices. Then again, sometimes I've eaten NY-style pizza in NY & the slices were so loaded up with ingredients that they couldn't possibly fold over. Does that mean it's not NY-style pizza? No.

If you're going to bitch about places not being NY-style, then the defining factor should be this: Are there big, sweaty, ill-tempered Italian men in grease-stained wife-beaters serving you your pizza? No? Then shut up & stop splitting hairs. 

Us New Yorkers love to kavetch about everything. We complain about our favorite restaurants as much as we do about our favorite people. But when it comes down to it, good pizza is good pizza, period.
author: Pete J.

description: My mom grew up in New York and, for the most part, only allowed us to order from Arinell's my entire childhood. They don't deliver, so we would call, pre-heat the oven and then take the 5 min drive to pick up our hot, fresh delicious NY style pie. I have now lived in New York for three years and still think Arinell's is a solid slice of pizza, if not one of the best in San Francisco. If you're going in just for a slice, get the cheese. They put the toppings on the cheese slice after you order it, so unless you're ordering a pie this may be a turn-off for you. I always get cheese, slice or pie, as it is the sauce to cheese ratio as well as crust that makes this an awesome pizza. The restaurant itself is a very divey spot with just a counter and a couple of stools, so if you want to sit down and enjoy the ambiance, its probably not what you're looking for. However, if you enjoy the "ambiance" of standing outside on Valencia at 1:30 am after they force you out of the bars a half hour early, this is the perfect spot for you. I wouldn't say its as great as some of the fantastic pizza parlors in New York, especially since I live in a neighborhood full of them, but for a late night slice or a NY style pie in in SF, I haven't found better.
author: Marie S.

description:
Oh how I love me some Arinell!

Stopped off last night to grab a slice before heading home and mmm mmm I am still jonesin' for another.
 
However, I have 2 problems with Arinell-

1- The big ass, foldable plain cheese slice is plenty, however, I always find that I want more out of pure gluttony.
2- I get super nostalgic and miss my old "digs" in the East Village :(
author: Anna S.

description:
I've been an Arinell regular for many years, mainly because i lived in the mission for most of my San Francisco life and i'm originally from Philly...and let's face it folks... good pizza is hard to find in California.  Rumor has it it's the water; bagels, same dilemma.  I have to believe there is truth to this.

Arniell is the absolute easiest place to grab a cheese slice for a quick bite whilst walking down Valencia street.  The're also a few bar stools in the joint so you can chow down while people watching (the walls are lined with mirrors and i always get confused about which direction people are walking outside when people watching).  Order ahead if you want a whole pie.  

Now there's nothing fancy here, just good old dough, sauce and cheese.  No artichoke hearts, peppers or pineapples (pretty sure they do have pepperoni though). But if you're feeling daring and wanna host a make-your-own pizza party at home, they sell their dough ready to be flattened, tossed and splattered with ALL the sauce and toppings your little heart desires!
author: Isabel C.

description: Excellent! Well, that about covers it. 3 bucks a slice and worth every penny.
author: Brian K.

description:
Cheese Pizza

Super thin crust, oodles of cheese, sprinkled with red pepper flakes, oregano and parmesan cheese makes it the best damn pizza on the West coast. (you have to sprinkle it yourself with the oregano, etc.)

Ok, so not technically NY. My fellow new yawkas get a grip ( we are 3000 freaking miles away from  NYC!). Go for the cheese slice. Ditch the slices with toppings. The toppings are mediocre. 

Makes me nostalgic for my old Cal days when I would go 3 x week. 

Since it's in the Mission I don't get there often enough. But, when I do I am never disappointed.
author: L P.

description:
I'm a native New Yorker and I love my pizza. After moving to SF I was sorely disappointed at the low quality of pizza served out here. Some people claimed it was the water, but Arinell proves those people wrong. Pizza in San Francisco is bad because the people making the pizza don't know what they are doing NOT because the water or the bread is different. Arinell's pizza could pass a blind taste test for NYC style pizza. It gives me hope that I can live here and not feel soo homesick all the time for NYC pizza.

A few days ago my boyfriend and I ordered a large pizza pie from Arinell (it was HUGE), and we consumed the whole thing in one sitting (I usually eat 2-3 slices when I order pizza, this time I ate about 6-7). That's how good Arinell's pizza is. If you ever want to know what real pizza tastes like... go to Arinell. If you've only ever had California pizza, then you've been missing out and you need to go to Arinell to learn what real pizza tastes like.

All of my five stars go towards the pizza. As for the decor/ambiance.. it's a f-king pizza place... what do you expect? If anything I think that it looks exactly like any random NYC pizza place which adds to the authenticity of this place. I don't care if I can't sit in there or if the guy on the street corner is asking me for change. I go to Arinell for the pizza.

Oh and it's cash only folks so don't forget to stop by the ATM before you go!
author: Teebs C.

description:
If I could have given 0 stars I would have. 

***Seriously, FUCK this place.***

I wanted some pizza right after I moved here from NYC and saw the reviews touting this crap to be close to NYC pizza. So I took a chance. First, finding a place to pull over to hop out and get the pizza was a nightmare and the price was high, but I wasn't too phased as I was used to this sort of thing...especially if the taste justifies it. 

Once I set foot in the place is when things got bad. The employees are the biggest wastes of skin I've ever encountered. I can understand a little contempt for your job when you're in your 30's, working at a shit pizza shop for pennies in the bowels of hipster hell, but these guys just took it too far. OK, so the staff deserves to be shot, but lets get on to what I came for....the pizza. 

The pizza is typical CA pizza: uncrisp flavorless dough, sauce tastes like red colored water and total overkill on the overpriced toppings. Buying a Tombstone frozen pizza from Safeway is more appealing than this garbage. 

The only thing this place is good for is to relive high school by ordering a bunch of pizzas for pickup, stop in, 'forget' your wallet in the car, call the guy an asshole and never come back in.
author: AnonE M.

description:
Scratches the itch for NY pizza but nothing special. The hours are weak and it is a little gross.

Yeah yeah, I lived in NYC too. Yeah I miss the pizza and Arnell scores points for being the only place in town for anything close to NYC pizza that I've found. Also, there's something satisfying about buying greasy thin crust pizza from stoners listening to (and signing) heavy metal but the pizza isn't spectacular, it's just pretty good. Generally tasty but lopsided and slimy. 

Others have commented on the fact that the place isn't the cleanest, but it isn't the worst. Since I usually go here when I've been drinking, my major complaint is the hours. The hours are lame. I can't count the times I've been out on 16th and needed, I mean really needed a slice of pie only to find that Arnell is closed and it is barely (or not even) midnight. Really? A place where stoners sell the perfect drunk food closes long before bar-time? To the owner: You're employees are high already, they don't need to leave before the bars close and you could give the bacon-wrapped hotdog carts a run for their money.
author: Rob I.

description:
Closest you can come to the good NY pizza in SF. Thin crust. Big slice. Tasty.

Why don't they stay open past 11? It kills me to have to go Cable Car on a late weekend night.
author: David K.

description:
The only reason why I'm taking a star away was the emaciated, pasty lad who was making my pizza had Rupunzal-like greasy hair; changed his Def Leppard tape above the refrigerator as he was adding olives onto my pizza; and man handled a pile of dollar bills before serving the slice of cheezy goodness to moi... not to mention the amount of grease slathered on the countertops, which was also peppered with spilt parmesan, dried chilis, and used napkins.

But hot damn... this pizza is phenomenal. Phe-no-me-nal.
author: I Love Beef C.

description:
There are two things I have to say about Arinell.

1. This is the only place in Northern California where you can get a proper slice of pizza. This is more to do with the abject lack of pizza outside of NY, than it does the quality of food at Arinell's. 

No fuckhead, pizza isn't supposed to have a gallon of sauce on it. And no, this isn't "thin crust"; this is pizza. There IS only one kind. You see, on it's way over from NY, pizza stopped off in Chicago, and whaddaknow, fat as all hell Midwesterners looked at it and said "lets make that into a thick doughy pile of crap, and I bet we can shit all sorts of wrong toppings on it, so that my ass will get even bigger." Yet despite its corpulence, pizza managed to struggle its way to the west coast where like most transplants from the heartland, it lost a good amount of weight, but not nearly enough. And, like most everything else in California, people put sprouts on it. This is the story of pizza.


2. This place is truly staffed with dicks of the highest caliber. I want to punch every single person who's ever worked here, and slap their parents. In 2004 I had words with one prick in particular, who was working the register. It's not important what it was about, only that my beef was honorable. For about 8 months afterwards I had to skulk back in there only after having cased out the joint from across the street to make sure His Highness Dickwad the First wasn't working that night. The pizza is that good. Or rather, I was that desperate. After 8 months, I decided enough was enough and henceforth every time I have a pizza craving, I get on a plane and go to NY.
author: Daniel K.

description:
So, this guy, who doesn't look like he's supposed to have both eyes, gives me this puddle of grease with just enough pizza underneath it to protect the paper plate.

Can I get some napkins?

He grudgingly reaches under the counter and gives me a napkin.

Can I get another napkin?

What're you eatin, ribs?

-- Kyle Baker, "Why I Hate Saturn"

In these five sentences, Kyle Baker summarized the New York pizza experience, which is faithfully recreated at Arinell. 

You won't find any fru-fru California crap here - just a perfect thin slice, heated up until the melted cheese on top releases this nuclear-orange oil that, like the color should warn you, is just waiting to slide off into your mouth, or onto your shirt, scorching everything it touches.

It's a beautiful thing. No tofu, ginseng, pesto or chicken. No sir! Only good New York toppings like bell peppers, sausage and pepperoni. Get a slice, throw on some oregano, parmasan, garlic salt and hot pepper flakes and hope to hell that the piece of waxed paper they use instead of a plate doesn't dissolve before you finish. Then go back, get another slice and start the process once again. If you're a New Yorker, you'll swear you're almost back home for a moment. 

Arinell is a definite 5 out of 5 - the only thing that could make it better is an egg cream or a Dr. Browns Black Cherry to wash it down.

And remember: "Can I get a fork and a napkin? If I give you a fork, whatta you need a napkin for?"
author: Avery G.

description:
Everything you've heard is true. Unless, of course, you heard this place has crappy pizza in which case everything you've heard is false.

I find myself subconsciously calculating these "errands" on 16th street that all happen to fall around lunch time or when my stomach speaks at 3pm. Yeah, I need um... stamps... oh look! there's Arinells. Well jeez, I mean it's RIGHT THERE and a single slice won't kill me!

btw - I have never seen so many references to 'pasty white guys' in a single listing on yelp in my limited tenure here... I guess I should continue the trend.



pasty white guy.

that is all.
author: Miroslav W.

description: Arinell's is great whenever I have a craving for a quick fix of thin crust pizza that I can fold and take on the go. It's not quite as good as thin crust pizza from NYC, and they just pile toppings on top and throw it in the oven. I thought they were joking the first time I saw them do it. you can see it in some of the other user pictures. It's the one thing that stopped me from giving 4 stars.  If you're close to home, just head back and throw your own toppings on and pop it in the oven. The staff is edgy and you're not sure what mood they'll be in, but it seems to fit. Generally nice crew working there.
author: D S.

description:
Best NY pizza in SF hands down, from a Connecticut Yankee who went to NYC at least once a month for 8 years.
crust:  ultra thin
sauce:  perfect
cheese:  just enough
And yes, you have to fold it AND use your second hand to guide it.  It's just that good.
author: Fong L.

description:
I really don't know if it gets any better than strolling around SF on a beautiful Saturday, happening upon a New York pizza by the slice joint and being from LA. It's like the three cities of cool colliding together with cheese and marinara sauce and making you realize that life is really pretty awesome sometimes! 

Oh yeah and the pizza was great too. :)
author: Stephy S.

description:
Very close to NY-style.  Thin, almost crispy crust, grabbable crust around the edge, easily foldable, plenty of grease to drip out after you fold it.
I wish they'd sometimes put a bit more sauce on, and the fact that they pretty much only make cheese slices and then put stuff on & recook it for extra toppings by-the-slice is annoying, but it is quite tasty.
author: Don H.

description: CHEESE SLICE and a  coke....reminds me of my little girl,we both love it!......what else can I say
author: Curt M.

description: Overrated...too crispy, the crust tasted a bit stale and wasn't fluffy enough, not much cheese on the pizza and overall not a ton of flavor. Oh, did I mention I'm a pizza snob? :) I don't know how this made the 7x7 list.
author: Elaine S.

description:
if this is considered ny pizza, i hope you get mugged on the subway.

this pizza sucks donkey balls.
author: Kathy H.

description:
Okay so obviously this is nothing new but Arinell's makes some darn good cheese pizza.  I come from living in the east for almost a decade so I was dying to find some good NYC pizza.  This is pretty freaking close!  

The thing I don't like about it (but is exactly how many NYC places do it) is that they put the toppings on after the cheese pizza has been cooked and warm it up.  This is not a big issue for me since I'm a pizza purist who almost always gets the cheese or margherita pizza.  

Another great option is pizza by the slice.  Perfect for singles or people on the go.  Hubby and I are lardies though and can eat an extra large pie (only $24!) between the two of us.  One warning though, if you are ordering for take out, call at least 30 minutes in advance!  This is no dominos!  You'll end up circling the area with the "Mission" impossible task of finding parking.  The least amount of time it's taken them to bake a pie from beginning to end is half an hour!  

Also, for those spice lovers, don't forget to dump on the free jalapenos before you go!  And don't forget to tip the pizza dudes.
author: Susan L.

description:
The BEST pizza in SF - being that I'm a Jersey native this means something.

If you can get past the 'interesting' neighborhood it's amazing. Since there is no delivery the best recommendation one can give you is to call in advance, bring someone with you in the car, drop the passenger off to pick it up, drive around the block, then pick up your passenger and the pizza. Don't even attempt the parking. 

The pizza is to die for!!!
author: Teresa J.

description:
I give this place 5 stars for their pizza but 3 stars for hygiene - the staff handles food and money without washing their hands - hence, the 4 stars on average. The only time this place ever disappoints me is when they run out of pizza and close early. 

And if you ever feel like making your own pizza but don't want to make your own dough, buy the dough from them! It's so worth it.
author: Patty G.

description:
So, I finally got around to trying Arinell's after hearing friends rave about it...the wild thing is that I had walked by this place on many an evening spent in the Mission and had no idea that I was missing out on this gem!

Overall, their pizza was very good, but not quite as good as Giovanni's in Sunnyvale (which is still my favorite New York-style pizza). I had a plain slice because I didn't want to mess around with toppings the first time around...

The only reasons that this place doesn't get five stars are the sparse seating and the fact that the crust was more crispy than I would expect (my slice "broke" when I folded it, which was a bummer).

This just means that I have to try it out again and give it a chance to get bumped up to five stars!
author: Art D.

description:
The guys behind the counter are so grungy, and the pizza is so greasy...

I love it!
author: Marsha Z.

description:
I love Arinell pizza ... right out of the oven. It has to be hot.

Several times I have taken a few Arinell pizza pies to work for everyone. The people from the east coast love it! The people from the west coast don't understand why we love it so much. It is very similar to NY pizza ... and you can get a slice anytime.  

I agree with other reviews that the sauce could be better.  But when it just comes out of the oven ... it is very close to perfection.
author: Lee R.

description:
Growing up in NY, I've always been a big fan of NY style pizza.  Big greasy slices that you load up with cheese, pepper, some oregano then fold and eat.  

SF area has scant choices when it comes to NY style pizza.  So many places try and fail miserably.  Arinell makes a worthy effort.  A large pie costs about $17 and will feed 3 people.  The slices are large, cheesy and has the right amount of sauce.
author: Hui C.

description: Great slice of pizza that gets tastier the later it gets (and the more alcohol you've consumed).  Paradoxically, this is the only pizza I've ever had that is better with just cheese than when you add meat to it!  The sicilian slices are good, but the classic, thin NY-style slice is definitely what you want to get when you have drunk cravings.
author: Pilan C.

description:
There are two things in life that I love to have folded:

1. Money inside my wallet or in a Chinese red envelope (lei see)
2. Arinell NY-slice pizza

Yee!
NCM
author: Chiu Man N.

description:
Once I got over the feeling that I wasn't wearing enough black and didn't have long enough hair to buy pizza there, I really started to enjoy Arinell's.  I've never had pizza in New York, but if it's any better than this I better get myself out there ASAP.

The subtlety of flavor in the crust--you can somehow taste that they use really good water--is what really does it for me.  Plain cheese, folded in half, good to go.

Also I love the drawing of the guy on a Bluetooth by the counter that says Bluetooth = No Pizza.  One time after closing the bars down I stumbled into Arinell's and made the mistake of answering my cell while I was ordering.  I'm never that guy, I hate that guy, and I was dumb (drunk) enough to be that guy in Arinell's of all places.  But they still let me have my slice anyway, cause I was all drunk and apologetic and self flagellating.  Never underestimate the power of a good self-flagellation.
author: Kevin H.

description:
The place is dirty and looks thoroughly unsanitary.  Perfect.
The staff is usually on something, often heroin.  Perfect.
The pizza is the best in the city.

If you need a slice or a gram, this is the spot.
author: Jesse H.

description:
Arinell = yummy NY style pizza.  That's the bottom line.

Great for late night cravings.  I just wish I lived a little closer so my pizza wouldn't get cold before I got home.  It's only a 5-10 minute drive, but there's not much on a thin crust pizza to keep the heat in.  Arinell is  definitely worth 5 stars if there was a more of a place to sit and eat or if there was a location within walking distance of where I am.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Thanks yelpers for the best slice of pizza in town... Mozzarella  piping hot like melting fondue layered on tomato sauce with hints of oregano and thyme then cooked to a crisp with each bite worthy of any  discerning palate -- the words heard is still- YUM YUM YUM :-) ...Hmmm i like proses
PS- Fresh mushroom sauteed in butter and garlic or is it evoo
author: Arissa C.

description:
Alright, so I'm obsessed with pizza. My belief is that San Francisco's pizza scene is generally sub-par, however I'm not very easily disappointed. When it comes down to it, I'm eating melted cheese and I'm happy about that.

My cousin's husband LOVES Arinell and has been asking me weekly for months now whether I've had one of their slices yet. No, no, not yet. That is mainly because Arinell closes early. Bad business strategy in my opinion, as the post-bar-closing drunken pizza slice is a crucial way to end the night. I keep having to go to the (lesser - now I know) Cable Car pizza next door. Who even knows when that place closes... 

Well, I finally decided to eat pizza before 2am for once in my life, and I gave Arinell a shot. Upon walking in, I could not help but notice the clientele of tweakers that were hanging out there. I also could not help but notice the strung out employees (jamming to the Smiths or some equivalent grimy London band). Years of drug abuse have rendered them 80-pound skeletons and left them with dirty fingernails that they use to handle slices without gloves. Some may think, yuck, walk away. I prefer to ignore these telltale signs of health code violations. 

And thank god I do. Their pizza was hands down the best pizza I've had in San Francisco. I value crust above all other aspects of a pizza and their crust was perfect. Flawless. Crunchy, crispy, wonderful. And cheap. I only wish they would stay open a smidge later so I could really grub when the time is right (late-night). 

And seriously, despite the mild dirty yuck factor, everyone that worked there was really nice. Fast service, good pizza, good stuff.
author: C P.

description:
My wife and I are both from New York. We never considered ourselves particularly fussy about pizza until we moved here. We were just about ready to move back east when we found Arinell, and now we have a reason to stay in SF.

Our theory is that they must sprinkle a small amount of crack on the crust, because it's that addictive. And the dudes who work there are definitely on *something*. It seems like the grumpier they are, and the worse the service is, the better the pizza ends up being. After I call to place an order, my wife always asks, "Were they surly?" and I say "Yup" and she says "Perfect!"

Seriously though, you need to be prepared for potentially abusive service. One time they got my order mixed up with someone else's and ended up not making his pie. I was paying and about to walk out when they figured that out. The guy said "Where my pizza?" and the Arinell guy says, "He has it" and points at me. Yeah, thanks for shifting the blame to the customer.

I keep going back though, and the pizza keeps getting better. Must be the crack.
author: Scott K.

description:
This place made me feel sick.... Seriously, it gave me acid reflux for 6 hours. I don't know what happened, I ate the last piece of cheese pizza on the counter and ended up in my current miserable state.  Interestingly this doesn't seem to have happened to any other reviewers so I'll move on to the pizza itself.

Slice of cheese was grease laden (this of course has been mentioned by many others). The lubed up pizza basicly slides down your throat. As for taste, I tasted grease. The pizza wasn't warm (he only reheated it for half a minute?) but it wasn't the most unsatisfactory  pizza I've ever tasted. Probably won't be back because I never want to feel like this again.  OOOOwwwww.....
author: Jennifer M.

description: Seriously, the pizza is delicious.  However the customer service is really really sour.  It was raining out and we asked for a box because we were taking the pizza to go and the guy serving the pizza told us "well, that's wasteful".  JUST GIVE US THE BOX DUMBASS.  We would have recycled it anyway.
author: Eric D.

description: OK.. for a new york style pizza that's not in new york, this place ROCKS. thin crispy crust with just enough of everything else on top. i always add a little pepperoni. but damn, it's a good pizza. YAYY!
author: Yui K.

description: It's grundgy here and they are always blasting some kind of metal music. The guys here are kind of aloof and look like they are on drugs. They do serve up damn good pizza though. There is barely anywhere to sit and stand and good luck if you are trying to park in the Mission. One of the better places to grab pizza by the slice if you are a fan of NY pizza. I'm constantly skepical of this place but Arinells does deliver. I believe the thing to do is stick with the cheese pizza.
author: Annie Y.

description: Decent New York style pizza. Nothing to get too excited about. Also they messed up my order.
author: Jeremy S.

description: There's a spiral telephone cord tied to the tip jar so "customers" won't run off with the cash.  That gives you some idea of the ambience of this lil' pizza shop.  You really don't go for the scenery.  It's basically a counter where you grab a nice slice to go.  And this easterner loves the thin crust (it's not all chewy like most west coast "pizzas").  They've got basics, nothing fancy.  But when you're in the mood for that (after hitting the bars, something to soak up the quesy feeling in your stomach), Arinell's makes just what you're looking for.
author: Cassidy P.

description:
holy krimolies! Good pizza that's not deep dish Zachary's or some crazy gourmet, free range, organic, fair trade, no cage, sustainable, dry farmed, cruelty free and biodynamic nettle and ramp concoction? The answer: HELLS TO THE YES!

I did the unthinkable last night- pass up Pancho villa for a quick slice at Arinell- and damn was I happy.  Greasy, but oh, so so tasty! The thin crust NY style REALLY is NY style. Want Organic Free range duck on your pizza? Tough luck, take peperoni or sit and spint. But who the hell cares? This shizzle is good! Their "deep dish" napolese pizza is more like french bread pizza but its also crazy good.

Damn, i feel all the greasier and dirtier for eating it but damn, thats the kind of classy guy i am.
author: Tim V.

description:
Chicago/NY'ers are natural born pizza critics and we have a common quest to find good pizza on the west coast ... which, more times than not, is ridiculously disappointing. 

Recently had my first Arinell experience and it was seriously fantastic ... easily better than any slice I've had in either San Fran or San Diego.      

two very enthusiastic pizza-loving thumbs up.
author: Sarah K.

description:
Best NY style pizza in SF.  
Sometimes, I close my eyes while biting into a slice and feel like I'm back in the Jerz.  But then I quickly realize that my friends Tony and Vinnie aren't standing behind me, talking about their landscaping jobs.
author: Paul B.

description:
I loved this pizza! Granted it was late night, and I'd had a few beers...but DAMN it was so good. The crust is thin, the cheese is perfectly melted, and not too much sauce. I got mine with mushrooms on it...and they are sliced thinly and then baked onto the pizza. (Victor's could learn a thing or too from Arinell's).

And an extra bonus...the guys serving up the pizza are yummy in a.."I totally want to do you but don't want to know your last name" sort of way.
author: Leesa P.

description:
Meh. I haven't found better yet, but I'm sure I will.  If you're hard up for a slice and you happen to be in the area, then stop by. They create a servicable slice of pizza.  I wouldn't go out of my way for it. The sauce is bland and the crust is just a bit too crispy.  It does get the job done though. It certainly doesn't suck.

I was lucky enough to be there to eavesdrop on a new employee talk about how they should wash things from time to time so that bacteria doesn't build up. It was spoken as a mild suggestion rather than a mandate.  Hopefully  these guys wash the kitchen more than they wash themselves.... Also, I enjoyed watching a crack addict buy a slice and empty almost an entire cheese shaker onto it before he left.
author: Gabe M.

description:
Look no further for the perfect slice. 

I see some talk of 'authenticity' with former New Yorkers puffing up their own cred by talking this place down. 'Authentic' or not, the pizza here is the best in town -- and definitely of 'New York Style' -- as opposed to the majority of the other marginal pizza places you're liable to find around these parts. 

Arinell's offers a perfectly cooked thin crust drowned in cheese, grease and a light coating of tomato sauce. For my money all the proportions and ingredients are just right. The burned out counter help has this down to a science. 

It is all about the pizza. Nothing is finer than a sloppy slice of pepperoni, a coke and a healthy stack of napkins. If only they stayed open later.
author: Dan M.

description: great pizza by the slice .. I go here for the deep dish w pepperoni .. havent tried the thin crust yet... reminds me of midwestern pizza !!
author: Micah W.

description:
Cheap, quick, thin slightly greasy NY style slices... usually perfect every time...

Hey i only give it three stars because atmosphere is a guy begging for change outside & service consists of two burnouts cranking heavy metal or punk on an old boombox while you wait at a counter... and i friggin love it !!

Never see the owner anymore, but he's a rare east coast Italian fella that's actually in the pizza biz... 

Sadly, this somewhat lowly establishment is an oasis in a city full of sub par west coast pizza slice abominations...

I'm so bummed when I get the drunken munchies after 11 and Arinell's are closed & then i stupidly start thinking i should go to the lousy Cable Car Pizza joint just a few steps up the block...

Of course that crap is a rank sloppy gloppy pizza imitation with undercooked wet dough made according to some ancient Brazilian recipe... and as an Arinell's loyalist forced to fraternize with the enemy, i truly regret it everytime.

Please stay open later Arinell's... I need you!
...
author: Donny N.

description:
It wasn't bad pizza but I guess when you're hungry anything tastes good.  

What sucked:  parking, but of course it's on Valencia so good luck anyway.

What was good: The slice I had was HUGE, it wasn't OVERLY cheesy.  

I've had better but overall it was decent...would I go back..yah, if I've had too much to drink and was starving for a slice of pie.
author: Karen B.

description: The only ny style pizza I've had outside of NYC that was any good. And it's great! And they're always playing great music. A San Francisco gem.
author: Alec B.

description:
The last time I was in here, this bum came in and bear hugged an unsuspecting fellow customer for approximately 42 seconds.  A very long 42 seconds... It was uncomfortable for everyone except the bum.  He seemed happy.  

Anyway, the pizza was still solid as usual.  This is the kind of place that does exactly one thing - and it does it pretty well.
author: Mike K.

description:
The pizza gets 3 stars. But the staff add an extra one!

The night I went there, the secret ingredient was being smoked in back. The cashier was SUPER loaded, moving in ssllooww motion. The guy making the pizzas was cutting whole sausages in half and throwing them on the pizza (each slice was guaranteed a whole sausage). Apparently he'd gone through the weekend supply in 2 pies. And the oven dude was pissed that someone threw mushrooms down the drain in the fountain drink dispenser and couldn't get them out. "Sucking" them out was offered as a suggestion by sausageman. "Heh heh," said the cashier. Until they figured something out, water was the only available beverage.

The pizza was great (with the second slice free because the cashier moved on to the next customer before I could pay), and the staff more entertaining than animatronic Cheech & Chong puppets at Chuck E. Cheese!
author: Tres S.

description:
SF Food Inspection Score: 92

I am not sure if this is the spot that gave me mud butt last night but it was hella good.

I didn't know that the neopolitan slices were bigger than my face and I ordered two. That probably explains the mud butt....

ANYWAY.

The pizza was thin, therefore all the grease just leaks through but not as much as I would expect. I just got their cheese but the next time I go, I will def ask for more cheese and garlic. The pizza is plain but that's a good thing. 

There's also a jar of jalapenos you can pile on.
