I just hated sitting at their counters and I don't know about you but I don't watch myself eat like a pig. But I'm probably just self-conscious. So I turned toward the window and people watched. Probably because I'm self-conscious.

Oh! And they give those that appear less fortunate cups of ice. That was mighty nice.
author: Kristina C.

description: Arinell is the place for pizza,every month,i get a craving to drive an hour just to get a couple of slices,then top it off with ice cream at Mitchell's.Their crust,chesse sauce ratio is just perfect,the dough is soo crispy.def #1
author: Soupnazi B.

description:
Second stop on the pizza crawl...

First though: Dear Man at the Counter, Please smile. Thanks, Sara.

This drop in New York style joint was incredibly convenient. But to say it was New York style is a stretch. I could not fold my pizza!!!! This was because of two reasons: 1. the crust was too hard and 2. the slices were cut in very awkward shapes.  And one of my crawl companions actually had a hole in the bottom of his slice... yes just cheese and sauce... no crust.

I would also like to note there was not enough grease.

The cheese however was very tasty.
author: Sara K.

description:
YES please!

Super thin crust huge by the slice, simple and amazing.

When I first came there was a line out the door. The slices don't look like much, but when they can make a slice of cheese pizza make you seriously consider waiting in line again to get more... you know it's good.

Stinks it's not in a more convenient area, but I'd trek out. 
Good luck parking depending on the time.
author: Angel L.

description:
If I judged this place just because of the quality of its pizzas, it would actually earn 5 stars.  I penalize them by one star because the cashiers add toppings to their pizzas with the same hands they handle money without washing them.

However, most people's immune systems can handle that, so if you are willing to overlook this, I highly recommend this place.  The slices are large, thin, crisp, and delicious.  They use just the right amount of cheese and sauce on them.

The fact that the employees don't seem to care about anything and play rock CDs all the time adds to the charm.  

The place does not have a lot of seating space, so it's basically just good to grab a slice or two, eat it, and go.  But that also adds to its charm.  

If you want to minimize the chances of infection, just order a slice of cheese.  That's what I do.  I love their pizza so much that sometimes I go all the way to the Mission to eat one slice.
author: Francisco J. R.

description: Maybe I'm spoiled by pizza on the east coast (and no, not just NYC--you can get good cheap by the slice pizza pretty much anywhere these days) and I found this to be good but not "every other reviewer gives it 5 stars" good. That said, in a city where good pizza hole in the walls are hard to come by, Arinell is the mission's king
author: Bill H.

description:
A $3 slice of easy goodness.  Small, dirty and fast...I love it.  

Don't plan on eating inside, there are only a few barstools.  A no brainer when you don't have time for a long involved meal.
author: jennifer j.

description:
Best non-yuppie pizza in San Francisco!

A slice of the thick and a slice of the thin, a perfect balance of pizza bliss.  I was kinda bummed that ya'll didn't give a free slice to my friend when he was dressed up as a slice of pizza for Halloween.  But, money talks, so you, know, I ain't gonna let his costumic muscle get in the way of your hustle and bustle.

And MAJOR BONUS; that guy from that really awesome band At The Altar Of The Cosmic Unicorn works there.  Bro, I love running into amazing musicians at my local pizza shop, it's what makes SF so r-a-d.

If only they would get the band back together... ahhh, babies!
author: Ben V.

description:
Good pizza, doesn't quite pass my fold-over test as little pools of grease do form. The last time I stopped for lunch, a note was posted to wish one of the pizza guys a "Happy Birthday". Conversation overhead:

Customer:  Whose birthday is it?
Pizza Guy:   It's mine!!
Customer: Happy Birthday! I bet you can't  wait to get off of work to party!
Pizza Guy:  Heh heh, I've been drinking all morning long!

Can always expect something to chuckle at while enjoying a slice.
author: Theda E.

description:
Arinell comes pretty close to real NY pizza.  For some reason, though, it doesn't last--no pizza for breakfast on the west coast I gues.. But when it's fresh out of the oven, Arinell satisfies my desperate cravings for something from home.

I don't get the attitude, though.  Yes, New Yorkers can be rude, but generally pizza brings out the best in us tough guys.  (Speederia Pizza has the attitude down, btw--they'll tease you relentlessly, but it's all in good fun).  Arinell seems to require its cashiers to be bitchy-ass punk rock looking whiners who refuse to hand over your pie if you don't tip. 

And they don't even deliver.

Well, mister bitchy pants, I'll buy pizza from you, but only because i have no other option.
author: Nikki S.

description:
The best New York (thin) pizza in SF. The dough, the sauce..it just melts in your mouth. Buy the single slice, it's bigger than the "whole pizza" slices! My buddy from Manhattan turned me onto it and he initially joked they were bringing water from NY over, because he couldn't believe how great it was.

I've been trying to find a better slice for the last 6 years without success.
author: jasen i.

description:
Definitely dig this place for some NYC-style pizza.  Being from the east, I have been missing good pizza that actually has a flavorful crust.  I don't throw away the crust...ever.  So if I need ranch dressing to get it down my pie-hole, I'll do it, but won't like it.  Arinell's has the easily consumable crust with the "foldability" down to a tee.

As the other reviewers say, don't expect clean conditions or nice staff.  If you crave good pizza by the slice ($2.50 for cheese), go here.  Otherwise, I'm sure Mr. Pizza Man is still open.  No serious...he is.  Call and he'll deliver to your lazy ass.
author: Chris M.

description:
Eh. That's what I think about Arinell Pizza. If it really is the best pizza in the Bay Area then I think I might cry. I'm also a Jersey native... and I wasn't too impressed.

That said, it definitely satisfied my after-hours appetite, when most of the other options were burritos and tacos in the area. There really isn't much of a seating area here either, it's fine to grab a slice and sit for a minute but don't expect a sit-down dinner with friends. Will I go back? Yea, probably, if I'm really hungry and want pizza. But I might check out the other options in the area first if it's during the hours they're open.

The thing about the pizza here is that it so wants to be NY pizza. But it's missing something. It needs a bit more grease. And a lot more cheese just oozing from the top, that drips off the second you lift the pizza up. And the crust needs more bubbles. Otherwise, it's ok.
author: Adena D.

description:
Pretty. fucking. overrated.

Would you like some attitude with your pizza?

Seriously, tasteless pizza with mediocre toppings. A huge hipster following. 



To be fair: I thought this place was GREAT the first time I had it...after about three fill pitchers....
author: Danyell K.

description:
Oh Arinell! I want to love you. I mean I'm dying for an excuse to take you home and make you mine. 

You've got the right ideas: the hipsters guys and girls serving for you -- pumping the bomb mix tapes (emphasis on 'tapes') and shuffling around with just right disrespect for urgency. I love your willingness to oblige my late-night food fantasies. I love how your shabby chic-ness keeps the other dorks who've reviewed you of late away... 

But you're soggy girl. There's just no other way to put it. Every time I try to fold you in half -- to put my mouth on your hot late-night goodness, you just can't manage to sustain the rigidity that I need to get full satisfaction. 

I think it's the time in our relationship where it's important for me to level with you -- to suggest that maybe you ought to see someone about this problem. I only want what's best for both of us...
author: Brian S.

description:
This is the first spot I've gone to based on Yelp ratings.

Nope, I didn't want to settle for one slice since I've read all these reviews on how good the pizza is, so my friend and I ordered a whole medium pizza and shared it. Mmm. Sooo good. I was on my 3rd slice and as I counted the remaining slices, something caught my eye! 

A piece of short, thick, curly hair perfectly positioned on top of a pepperoni! That pretty much ended the party for me. So much for secret ingredients...
author: Zell C.

description:
When I first moved to SF in '75 a pizza counter person ACTUALLY layed a paper towel on top of my slice to take up the oil!   God, I thought .  No wonder NY and Philly pizza is so good.  Next thing you know they'll put sprouts on a slice!  Travesty.  Arinell is exceptional IMHO.  I stop at both their SF and Berkeley sites.  It's supposed to be greasy even if it's not 
(God forbid!!) CA healthy!  Wonderful NY style pizza.  If they ever change it I'm outta' there.  MMmmmmm....  Nearly a match for Gioia, another fantastic slice.  Never mind the wood fired pies at Pizzaiolo... No, NOT Pizzaiola...  All great pizza...
author: Joshua C.

description:
Did I mind the homeless person eating on the stool across from me? Did I mind that the floor probably hadn't been cleaned in a long time? Was I scared that the pizza looked like it had been sitting out for a long time and that the rock music blaring in the background was a bit annoying?

Not at all. Stopped by here to grab a quick slice and a Coke, and I must say I was quite surprised the pizza was so good. A very large slice of cheese pizza, thank you. Big slice, sauce was fine, and the crust was crispy and delicious. If you like chewy, go somewhere else. The coke was ice cold. The guys working behind the counter were quite nice, despite their rock concert attire. Overall, not a bad place to go, but does need a cleaning.
author: David G.

description:
So far this is the closest thing I've found to real NYC pizza since I moved here.  It's not totally right (the sauce is a little bland), but it is a pretty good thin slice.

But the place itself is seriously lacking.  First of all -- it should stay open until the bars close.  You walk out of a bar at 1:30 or 2:00am, you want a slice.  You can't get one.  And the counter is run by damn hipsters -- which makes everything freaking slow.  If this were a real NYC pizza joint, it would be open until 2:30am (at least Thu-Sat), and it would be Italians and Dominicans behind the counter moving at a fast clip, making pies and filling orders in the blink of an eye.  These people need to visit Joe's Pizza at 3:00am on a Sat night to see how it's done.

But, I still go there.  It's the best single slice I've found so far.....
author: Laine F.

description:
From a New Yorker, Queens and Brooklyn to be specific:

5 stars for fuckin effort!

The BEST ATTEMPT at NY pizza to date. Not quite there with the variety but the plain cheese slice... it's aight it's aight!

I would not go so far to say they are like representing.

All you have to do now is include the sicilian and the white slice and the beef patties and garlic knots. Just fuckin do it so you could lay all other places to rest. How good will it feel to shut down all the other pizzarias in the city.

And why don't ya'll fuckin deliver?
author: Jay N.

description:
Gotta agree with Dan S., there is something missing. Not enough sauce? Not enough grease? 

Whatever it was, this transplanted NY-er is thrilled to have found this place. My fellow NY-ers: remember that time you were drunk and waiting in Penn Station at 3am and grabbed a slice while waiting for a train? Now imagine something 83% as good as that. That's Arinell's.

It gets 7 stars based on SF standards. If this place were in NY, I probably wouldn't indulge. 83% just isn't enough in NY. But we're not in NY.

Anybody know of a place to get a real bagel?

Here's my Bay Area NY-style pizza breakdown thus far:

Tier 1
Marcello's (SF) & Gioia (Berkeley) are real-deal NY pizza places. Even in NY we have our favorite places which will probably determine which one of these you choose over the other. The difference here is subjective. I feel Gioia wins out on taste. The sauce is phenomenal. Marcello's wins on crust (specifically the outer rim). Both places are winners.

Tier 2
Arinell's (SF & Berkeley) & Lanesplitter (Berkeley & Albany) are quite good and rate about 70-80% NY quality. Pretty good. Laneplitter 19" pie is $10 to pick-up from the Albany location. That's a great f'n deal.
author: Robert V.

description:
I seem to give a lot of 5 star ratings, but I guess I'm an optimist.

Anyway, Arinells is THE spot to get some good, greasy, big ass slices of  thin crust pizza after hitting the bars around Valencia. The dudes are really nice and are usually on something. 
It's pretty cheap, around $2.50 a slice I believe plus a few cents for extra toppings. I don't know what New York style pizza is supposed to taste like, so I can't approve the validity of that, but I can say it competes with Escape From New York pizza and is almost winning on atmosphere alone.
Their Berkeley spot is just as good, too.
author: Meghan K.

description: Pretty good slice of pizza, but I'm not sure if I'd drive all the way to the Mission and try to find parking to eat at this place. If I'm in the area and want a good, fast pizza, then I'll def come here. I got the sicilian deep dish slice with pepperoni - YUM. Highly recommend it if you're in the area.
author: Rosie W.

description:
Arinell's makes the best NY style slice in the city of San Francisco.  Hands down.  The shop is very reminiscent of the small 'slice shops' all over New York.  There are two small counters where you can sit down to eat your slice.  However, there aren't any tables.

Arinell's also makes a sicilian style pizza too.  It's pretty good, but it's the NY style slices that keep people coming back.

At first glance the crew at Arinell's seem like some of the most apathetic people in the food service industry.  The ones I've talked to are very cool guys though.  

They don't stay open that late and it's not the cleanest place, but I'll gladly overlook these two things because their pizza is so damn good.
author: Dheeraj I.

description:
As part of our SF pizza crawl, Arinell was the most convenient.  There really just aren't that many places in the city that you can get a good slice.  We walked in, paid a few bucks, and got a slice.  The other stops on the crawl were far less efficient.

New York Style?  Um maybe, but it doesn't really hold a candle to pizza I've actually eaten in New York.

The crust was nice and thin, but the taste was a tad sweet and floury for me.  The sauce was sweetish too... but there was not enough of it to be offensice (this was a good thing).  The cheese was perfect... stringy and salty and greasy.  Yum!

Overall, a great value and a satisfying eating experience.
author: Linda L.

description:
Mooooooooo.

Damn good pizza late night. Cheese pizza no toppings.
author: Eric T.

description: I don't care what anyone says--This is some slammin late-night pizza!  It's thin crusted and all about the topping.  Hole-in-the-wall style for sure, but when you're just getting out of the bar on the late tip, what more do you need?
author: Angella S.

description:
Imagine that you work at a pizza place where 90% of your customers are drunk dickholes that treat you like shit. 

Now imagine that there is no apparent management of the place, so you can do whatever you want. For example: 

-Blast metal SUPER loud over the stereo
-Have a newspaper clipping on the tip jar about a man getting murdered outside of a pizza restaurant with "..FOR NOT TIPPING" scrawled on it in ball-point marker
-Have long hair that doesn't even pretend to be under some kind of net
-Have signs indicating that assholes using their cellphones will be asked to leave and will not be served pizza

The pizza here is mediocre. In fact, the pizza is like two star pizza. But I'm giving them an extra two stars because the idea of Arinell is so awesome. I can't come here when I'm feeling grumpy and craving good pizza, but if you're in a good mood and looking for some entertainment that's so good it makes up for the very so-so pizza, this is your place.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I love this place!  One of the best places for NY style pizza, which means thin crust and not too much cheese (for me, eating regular pizza is not that enjoyable now with the thick crust and too much cheese).  

If you like garlic, try the garlic slize, they put lots of garlic on it, mainly raw, it's so delicious!  You'll have garlic breath for the rest of the day, but it's worth it!  For a mid-day snack this place is hard to beat.
author: Ramon C.

description:
So close to a perfect pizza it will amaze you. Crispy, moist crust covered in well spiced marinara sauce and topped with good old fashioned plain mozzarella--this pizza is to die for. Also, if you are poorer than the sidewalk in the Mission District, you are at the right place. One giant slice of heaven for only $2.50, I'm drooling just writing this review. Check it out, you won't be sorry. 

***Don't be surprised or put off by the interior or the location. While it is small, and not necessarily perfectly clean, it is rather clean, and you can see every part of the place. It's just one room with two counters along the side walls as you walk in, only six stools, a place to order, and a few pizza ovens on the back wall. Simple and near perfect. =]
author: Shannon F.

description: Fucking bomb. A little crisp, a little chewy, a little cheesy. No MSGeezy.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I didn't Moo.

I didn't request ice. I am not a crackhead. I only play one in my own mind.

And I didn't confuse it with Cable Car, which apparently has closed and since been shot up. Or vice versa.

So okay. I was in a kind of shitty mood. Parking in the Mission does that to you. Went to get Spike & Mike tickets, went to get food.

Arinell does me well for pizza. It's East Coast style, which I like, greasy as hell, and folds decently -- though what's up with the shape.

Then there's the ambiance. Very conducive to digestion. The speed metal rushing through my colon could've made me barf right there. Or do something else disgusting. This being the Mission, anything goes. Right?

So the summary: Good food, lousy atmosphere. Get it to go if you have a clean place to sit. And don't call the Mission a third world country if you're walking around with my boyfriend. Otherwise he may call you Kramer.
author: Allison L.

description: Arinell's is great. People that don't like it are wrong and were born in a place that doesn't understand what good is.
author: Sergi A.

description: Pizza by the slice, reminiscent of NY. Slices are big, toppings are reasonably priced and they come out of the oven quickly - quicker than NY.
author: Lefty R.

description:
OMG, $2.50 or so for an EXCELLENT slice of thin-crusted pizza.  This is DEE BEST NY style pizza in SF (for the price).  Hands-down!

You MUST eat the pizza once it's presented to you - no take-outs please!!  unless you can heat it up in a oven (NOT microwave) when you get home.  

It's so good, I can scream (yes, orgasmic)!
author: Bessie T.

description:
After working in corporate America all day, since 5:54 a.m this morning I was stuck at my desk on conference calls, fixing problems, researching issues, and then noticed that I missed my lunch. The calls grew longer and I was getting more stressed on what was supposed to be a happy friday. Whatever, I digress. 

At 3pm I wanted something quick and something I could get to go. I decided to take my mom for a quick bite to eat and I ended up going to Arinell's.

This place is located on 16th and Valencia. It's next door to an ATM machine, and they only except cash so BRING CASH.

This place serves up huge slices of thin crispy crust New York style pizza. For plain cheese, it's 2.50 a slice, they charge you for extra cheese and extra toppings. We wanted to take some home for other people so we bought 4 slices, 2 with extra cheese and 2 with extra cheese and mushrooms and onions. The 4 slices cost 16.50.
Mind you these had to go into two large boxes they were so big.

Also there are alot of signs that say "No cellphones".
So please don't bother talking in their with your cell phone cause they don't want to hear your business.

This pizza was crispy, thin crust and pretty good. Stop buy and bring your own beer! 

This place just serves pizza and soda, and thats it. 

There is maybe 4 places to sit, and that's all. You'll really be eating this while you're walking.
author: Charlene C.

description:
I love pizza.

I have been searching for great NY style pizza in the bay for...years.

Unfortunately, I wasn't too impressed. It was good. Good enough for me to come back. But nothing to write home about.

The search continues!
author: Rasi A.

description:
OVER-RATED.

are you people serious?  this place does NOT live up to the hype at all.  i gave it so many chances to prove me wrong, but it only proved me right.  please rethink your reviews when you've actually tasted it sober.  please.

cliff notes:  if you want good pizza don't come here.
author: Jung L.

description: Probably the best pizza by the slice in the city. Prices are fair, wait is never too long, and there's plenty of bars in the neighborhood to hit up after. I'd give this place a 5 if they'd get some Frank's or Crystal.
author: Alfredo A.

description:
Buy a slice here. Not a pizza. The New York style doesn't lend itself to making it all the way to the apartment without getting soggy. -which, I'm not a fan of. The slight crispiness of the bottom has to be enjoyed before the grease invades. 

The atmosphere is not to be missed. Very similar to a hole in the wall NYC pizza place. Metal-punk screamed from little speakers and was only good cause I hadn't heard of the band. They have a cheesy Brooklyn bridge mural painted on the front of the counter in faded and matted colors of night. It was like a 'Dead Boys, before the punk band made it' documentary. The guy that took my order was wearing a cut off shirt held together over his bony body with a safety pin on the side. He looked like he got hit hard with the Holy Fu*%ing Sh!t stick. He was sweating, his skin was red; he looked like he was about to collapse, combust., do something offensively brilliant. 

I ordered pepperoni and mushroom, which consisted of taking a cheese slice adding pepperoni and mushroom and putting it back in the oven. Of course I burnt my tongue, what a pizza douche of me. 

I'll be back for more. You all should go, too.
author: Jake H.

description:
GREAT PIZZA!   Great thin crust, NY style pizza.  Sometimes, less is better and in this case, less is definitely better.  No frills, nothing fancy, just pizza at its finest.  

There's also one in Berkeley on Shattuck, near the BART station.
author: Jaymee C.

description: Awesome thin crust pizza.  A slice of cheese pizza w/ jalapenos and crushed red peppers sure hits the spot.
author: Helen T.

description: This is just cheap pizza. It tasted alright, but nothing write home about.
author: Anton S.

description:
Arinell's is a bastion of NY style thin crust pizza!  It's clear the restaurant owner has been to NYC and tasted the cuisine because I think just about every other pizzeria in the bay area is clueless.  It's about $2.50 for a slice of cheese.

Just to qualify the specific qualities of the pizza I enjoyed...there was ample tomato sauce between the bread and crust, the crust was crispy and hot, and the cheese was neither runny nor congealing.

The decor is lacking and there's not much seating.  Great for grabbing a quick bite to eat or soaking up the spirits at the end of a quality evening in the mission.

Hooray for good pizza and thank goodness for Arinell's.
author: Eric M.

description:
I'm normally a "thick, gooey pizza" girl but this was good for being thin crust. The guy working there was interesting, and I loved his "you talk first" system. Dude just gave me a blank stare!

Oh and I didn't like their sausage. I wasn't expecting it to be the "round kind", I quickly took it off and regretted not getting pepperoni!
author: Valerie A.

description:
HA HA HA HA HA!  I laugh to keep from crying for once again choosing a lousy place to eat.  Just bought two slice of sausage/cheese pizza from Arinell Pizza and have no idea why people are giving this place such 'rave' reviews.  I may have well just ordered a slice of cardboard ( dough) with cheese (rubber), and a set of tires (sausage) on top.  It was hor-ri-ble - hey, I know it's HALLOWEEN - but what a graveyard!  I can't figure out exactly what is so good about dump of a place with the worst pizza I've ever had in my life...and I've been eating pizza for over 30 years.  What?  Did you pay those people to give good comments about your business?  Must have - you know what my opinion is about this place...
PI-TI-FUL.  Go back to whatever planet you're on cause it sure ain't New York, New York - yuck!
author: Angela C.

description:
I like pizza.  I like em wood fired and I like em Chicago deep-dish, but most of all, my heart I give to crisp NY style, fold-in-half slices.

Is it better than a corner joint in Queens or New Haven? Maybe not, but what can beat our childhood memories anyway? It's just as good though, and that's more than enuf when you've been without.

If you've been on a search for NY slices, make your first stop here.  The sauce can be underseasoned, so take advantage of the shakers.

p.s. if people think the guys working here are hipsters, your jeans might be cutting off circulation to your head.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
I love Arinells because the guys there are very nice. 
I love Arinells because they make funny drawings about No Blue Toothing and post them.
I love Arinells for the Pizza because they only use like 5 ingredients and its just what pizza is supposed to be. 
Thank you.
author: Janel M.

description: A true dive! in every sense of the word! I love it!!! good Pizza on the cheap!  Loud rock music,but in that place I do not mind!!!! It seems to fit with the sleazy and I do mean sleazy guys that work there,but they are always cool with the customers.One thing that may freak you is that they put the additional toppings on with no gloves and this after being outside smoking or whatever,Yes I saw it for myself!!!! All that said it is a great place to stop for a fast cheap slice or two!!!!
author: Bill J.

description:
Yes we all know its not NY pizza but for SF please don't complain.   Its really good enough.  Yes we all know the guys working there aren't going to win any grooming or beauty contests.  Neither will the guys working at Famous Original Rays ...      

One thing I'll bring up that people fail to mention:  their sicilian slices.  Grab a sicilian slice next time you're there - they are better than the plain thin crust.  And take a few extra Vitamin C's before you go to sleep and chances are you'll live ...
author: Juje B.

description:
Terrific dive pizza joint.  They serve by-the-slice or by-the-pie, thin or napoleon style pizza.  The slices are great tasting and cheap.  Not a whole lot of space, 6 ppl can easily take up all the seats (two counters with 3 seats each on either side of the entrance).

If you stop in for a slice, get some free jalepeño slices!
author: James B.

description: Best stop on the way too and from Bart! Awesome ny style gigantic slices. Can't go wrong. Cash only.
author: Greta M.

description:
I'm totally shameless when it comes to Arinell's pizza.

The people who work there look like they haven't washed in weeks, the music is too bangy and loud, and parking near 16th and Valencia is terrible.

But I have mastered the art of leaving my car in the median with my emergency lights blinking so that I can dash in to get a slice (or two) of Arinell's.  It's perfection - perfectly thin crust, perfect ratio of sauce to cheese.
author: Tara M.

description:
While i was eating here the health inspector came in, usually a bad sign, so i naturally listened in.  Started out mundane enough, someone filed a complaint, he had to check it out.  It wasn't until he started to explain the complaint that it got good.  Someone had complained that a costumer had brought his bicycle into the store, his dog feces covered bicycle.  Looking around and i saw that this hole in the wall isn't big enough for a bicycle, let alone such a crapulent one.  The Health inspector whipped out his clipboard and asked, just to make sure, 'this is 508, isn't it?' 

No, it was next store.

and the pizza is great also
author: Herbert S.

description:
When I left Brooklyn in my youth (or 'yout' as my family would say), I said (and I quote) "Goodbye greenpoint! Goodbye williamsburg! Goodbye middle village! And goodbye wonderful new york style pizza, with a thin crust, a perfect amount of cheese and slightly sweet but salty sauce, prepared by a hairy, sweaty man with dubious hand washing practices in a place that you really don't want to spend more than five minutes in or more than five dollars on!

But now I live within four blocks of Arinell Pizza and I know that that last goodbye was unnecessary.
author: Gabe S.

description:
Cheap and delicious, the best combo for food.

I got a pepperoni slice. I am a raving fan of the crispy crust but didn't like the pepperoni. I don't quite know how to describe the taste of the bad pepperoni, maybe almost too thick and undercooked? I love the kind of pepperoni that is super-thin and has crispy edges...

Next time I'll just get a cheese slice and I'll be set.
author: Ava C.

description:
The absolute best pizza in San Francisco. Thin-crust, NYC style pizza that keeps me coming back for more.  I am a transplant from the east coast for over 11 years and pizza is my favorite food on the planet  - it has been highly challenging to find someplace (and I believe I've tried them all!!) that even comes close to NY style-but this place captures it all - counter delivery keeps it real...I mean if I want ambiance in a slice place, I'll just bring a pie back to my house!
The other thing I like is that they ALWAYs have a pie ready to go under the counter...hardly any wait time.  My only complaint would be that I wish they were open later since more than a few times my drunken monkey munchies forced me to go to cable car pizza place next store *YUCK".

Arinell's can you please open a shop on the Haight? Escape from NY doesn't hold a candle to you....
author: Melyss S.

description:
I am rating this place four stars and must explain the following theory about yelp. Ratings, for me, are region relative. I'm not going to rate SF joints against something in New York or Paris, because I think that's just not helpful. 

Based on the above premise, because Arinell's is in CA, it gets 4 stars.  It is pizza that  approximates NY-style. Being in CA, I've had to train myself not to think pizza is a viable food option.  It has been hard. When I can't take it anymore . . . I go to Arinell's. 

Most of the criticisms about sauce, crust issues, etc. are pretty accurate but really guys, let's not kid ourselves, we live in California . . .and  like the fat ugly chick at the end of the bar, we just can't afford to be that picky.

(I have not yet done the Amici's thing, but unless they're fed ex-ing that shit directly from Brooklyn - it shouldn't cost that much. And the place fucking looks like The Cheesecake Factory . . . wack.)
author: Jen A.

description: I'm biased to any place that has a heavy metal attitude but this place IS great.  Small, small place in a great location that make rocking pizza that's always fresh and affordable.   What else do I really need to say?
author: Sin F.

description: A legitimate New York slice, with thick-crust Sicilian as an option. A welcome sight for a visiting New Yorker. Don't be put off by general dinginess of the place or the hipstery staff, it's pretty good stuff.
author: Joe M.

description: Pauly from the KNBR morning show has talked these guys up in the past, so I decided to give them a shot. Place is definitely grimy in that 1970s Charles Bronson "Death Wish" NYC kind of way. I ordered a cheese pizza and did like the crunchiness to it, but I was not blown away.  It's similar to NY pizza being that it's thin crust, but it doesn't compare to the best I've had from NYC.  But if you're feeling nostalgic for La Gran Manzana, check this place out.
author: Jeronimo L.

description:
Just because a slice of pizza is big, can be folded in half, greasy, thin crusted.... does NOT make it a New York slice!!!

My search continues. Oh Yelp, you've forsaken me with your recommendation of Arinell. Who are you other Yelpers claiming to be east coasters?

All that being said, I'd probably come back, just because SF pizza is so bad that it makes Arinell seem OK. Even still, it's not right to compare this to a good/real NY slice.
author: kathy c.

description:
Does anyone remember Woolworth's pizza in downtown SF?  For some reason, this pizza reminds me of it.  Thin and crispy.  Of course, what's missing are the wigs and make up products @ the old Worthworth counters...

It's a hole in the wall but delicious.  Afterwards, if your stomach can handle it, treat yourself to some Indian ice cream across the street @ Bombay's.  Yummy!
author: Jen L.

description: This pizza is dope. Big thin crust pizza. Lil greasy but its good stuff. Sauce is sweet. Nice staff but not too nice cuz they're cool, ya know?
author: Carly W.

description:
This pizza is just like how I like my women.  Hot and not too thin. 

One star off for making me want to  say that.
author: John L.

description:
Arinell is to NY Style Pizza what Zachary's is to Chicago style. About 90% authentic, and worth every bite if you love thin crust pizza. Now, it's very true they can be inconsistent so YMMV but please, don't just go once thinking you got ripped off. I got your back, so let me break it down for ya on the good and not-good of Arinell's NY Style:

Yay! What they do right:
- As a previous posters remarked, the best balance of cheese, sauce, and grease you'll find on an authentic NY style pizza slice made in San Fran. The sauce is spiced perfectly - slightly sweet, but with enough of the right savory spices to make it best enjoyed WITHOUT TOPPINGS. 8/10 on the sauce.

[Digression about pizza sauce - go on and skip this unless you're really bored because I spew about pizza sauce for my own, therapeutic need. And I need to talk about pizza sauce or I'll go mad!
The difference in pizza sauce is foretold by the tomatoes or tomato product that goes into it. Most pizza places in San Francisco use plain tomato sauce for the base or even worse, mix water with thick tomato paste. But if you walk into any decent pizza place in the greater New York or New Jersey area, look far behind the counter. You will see in the dingy back room, massive cans stacked upon cans of whole tomatoes. GASP! That's right, they start with whole, canned tomatoes and make the pizza sauce fresh - and that my friends, makes all the difference between schwag and great-tasting pizza. 
Ahem. Now, back to your regularly scheduled review.]

- The slices are large, and can be folded length-wise as is commonly done on the East coast.
- They crust is wafer-thin! Slightly crispy, just enough so that you can hold it up without it flopping over and scorching your wrist.

Mkay, so what DON'T they do right?
- Um, what's up with the 1 1/2" edges of  crust surrounding the pizza? Sure, a good thin crust pizza must have a substantial edge of crust to grip but much like the less-authentic Escape From NY Pizza, there's too much crust around the pie and you gotta wonder whether or not they really wanted to make you a large pizza or, were making a medium with extra crust on the edges. If you love crust, ignore my nit-picking.
- They will often over-cook their pizzas - and you'll know right away when you see the cheese is brown-orange or when you can hold a slice by the very edge of the crust and the body of the slice defies gravity. 
- The pizza guys are total slackers and it takes a little faith to believe that you're gonna get a good pizza.

Suggestions:
*** To those reviewers who said from their experience, the pizza had no taste, or tasted like cardboard or was too crispy. **** 
I don't doubt your experience. But the nature of running a pizzeria that sells slices is, they must make a whole pie and then re-heat the slices as they're ordered. Therein lies the fault! Re-heated pizza loses about half it's flavor and even more tragic, there's no way to keep the crust from turning into a cracker-like consistency. So! To avoid the deleterious effect of re-heating, a few things I recommend:
1. simply order your slice as-is. Meaning, warm. 
2. wait for them to put a fresh pie up on the counter.
3. Order a whole pie for $22. Take them about 20 minutes to make it fresh - but make sure they make it fresh and don't re-heat one of the pies below the counter!

Another consideration is that the pizza cannot be delivered so if you're thinking of transporting the pie, be practical. It's gonna loose heat when it travels - even on a hot day. I bought a pie the other day and drove it from Valencia to the Inner Richmond. Even though it was 80 degrees on the thermometer, the pizza was still room temp when I got home. 

Now, don't think that stopped me from binging - GF and I ate the whole damn pie and it was yum and I'm not whining about it being warm not hot. But, it was over-cooked. The inconstancy of their preparation, the fact that the product - even re-heated in their own pizza oven - loses alot of flavor and texture, and the fact that seating and eating at Arinell is only fine if it's you and maybe one other (and if you dont let your hand touch the under-side of the countertop)? I feel I have to warn you that YMMV at Arinell.

Still, 4 stars for making the bestest NY style pizza in San Francisco. Alot of pretenders out there *cough cough Amici's cough* but this is the one place that actually knows what a NY style pizza should taste like and despite inconsistency, I'll keep coming back for my fix.
author: Ben S.

description:
I would put Arinell side by side with Blondie's on Powell. Not bad, not great..just pizza. I guess when people rave about New York pizza, they are correct to. I had seen pizza like this when I was there. However, does New York pizza automatically mean good pizza? I think the starrier reviews are either nostalgia-driven or these people are sick of schmancy California pizza. I wouldn't blame them. The sauce, I think, needs to be more tangy.

Here are the ups and downs:

UPS:
 - Pizza hits the spot when you're hungry for a pie.
 - No nonsense ordering.
 - Quick to get a whole pizza even during dinner. 20 minutes from ordering to eating.
 - Close to parking structure.
 - May escape with life from Mission bums.

DOWNS:
 - No maitre 'd.
 - Greasy pizza good. Greasy cashier touching pizza, bad.
 - Barstool seating is too...grungetastic.
 - Cash only.

Would I come back for the ambiance of loud guitar riffs, toothless greasy grins and pay parking? I think I'll keep the NY style pizza treasure hunt going...
author: Rey T.

description:
So everyone has their own idea of what pizza should taste like. Most of the time you like what you liked when you were a child or when you had your first taste of any flour based pie w/ tomato sauce & mozzarella cheese. Fine. You grew up with thick; she grew up with thin; he grew up with chewy; over there, they grew up with crispy. Whatevs.

I grew up with thin NY style slices served in Italian family owned & operated hole in the walls. Most of them had counters with some seats. Some of them had benches with seats. They all served pizza by the slice. Capiche?

Arinell is like those pizza parlors of my youth. Except, that they throw in the punk rock soundtrack that I wished those parlors had played back then. It transports me back to my friends in the 80s riding around town on our bikes and skateboards, causing all sorts of trouble, refueling with a slice or two, and then getting into mischief again. Thanks Arinell!

DISCLAIMER: As for the pizza itself, I'm biased because I love this sort of thing. If you're looking for crispy/crunchy, try Amici's.
author: G Z.

description:
Best Pizza west of the Mississippi.  Period.  Start with a slice of regular cheese and work yourself up from there.  Gotta fold those slices people!

Now for the only con.  You will need a pair of nunchucks and a steel bo staff to stay alive while eating outside in that area.  If you are there from 7am - 5pm you MIGHT be safe.  If after 7pm, forget about it, it's like Night of the Living Dead out there.  C.H.U.D. will get you, lace up those running shoes tight  - like a tiger.
author: David C.

description:
A quick guide to digesting this review:

1) I loves me my holes in the walls --- the dirtier, the more delicious it seems. 
2) I'm a picky eater.
3) New York pizza spells pure joy.

Arinell knows how to bring me back to Mulberry St with its this crust and its intoxicating balance of sauce and mozz.  The pizzaman slices a very generous wedge out of a rectangular pie (but not sicilian), on which a douse a healthy helping of more mozz, garlic and oregano.  I sit on the tiny mirrored bar ledge on the right and I savor the symphony of flavors.  You, too, can do this.  And only at Arinell.
author: Katie T.

description:
You can't work here if you're not into metal.  Seriously, every guy who works here is in a band, gets laid more than you, and is about as smart as a pile of laundry.

The pizza is super thin NY-style.  Only order slices of cheese, the toppings suck (they're raw), and don't bite into the crust without any stuff on it, it tastes kind of like matza bread, but more boring.  Despite all of these caveats, their cheese slices and really good. And unlike almost everyone else in San Francisco, metalheads don't currently get subsidies, so help a brother out.
author: Mike H.

description:
Decor: 2 
Service: 3.5 
Food: 5 

My favorite pizza. Hands down. I really do love this place. It's the closest thing you can get to New York Style Pizza. I grew up on the east coast and spent much time in NYC and I always crave the pizza. This craving led me to Arinell and I frequently find myself thinking about this place. The punk rock music is always banging in this place which gives it a unique atmosphere. The only problem is that a lot of derelicts come here and sometimes act like douche bags. But that's part of what makes this place so appealing. What this place lacks is made up by the incredible pizza. I always get the same thing. Cheese. I'll be back... soon.
author: Roger H.

description:
As NYC as you can get without going to NYC imho. Delicious thin crispy crust -- was never into the fold thing but that's okay.  Before Arinell, Amicis and Escape f/NY was actually top NY-like out here, but this is way better.

For me it's initially about the crust. Then everything else and that -- sauce and cheese were just right by me.

$12 got us 3 slices with stuff and 2 sodas.  A gr8 deal.
author: Me V.

description: Solid slices of greasy pizza. Good for those homesick from the East Coast.
author: Brian C.

description:
It's kind of a pizza gloryhole. You don't look anyone in the eye, you don't think about why your shoes are sticking to the floor, you're totally grossed out in so many ways... and still you leave satisfied.

Most of their business seems to come from drunk people who didn't bother with dinner a few hours earlier.
author: Paul B.

description: Hands down the best pizza in the Mission.  Maybe in SF.  Thin crust NY style at its best.
author: Katharine B.

description:
Everyone says this is the closest to NY pizza, including New Yorkers, but I don't think it comes very close!  

It's decent pizza, and it's conveniently located for a late night snack.  And it's pretty good, too.  I love thin crust style.

But I can't say it comes anywhere near the same flavor as an NY pizza.  I was kind of disappointed since a New yorker told me it was close..and then I discovered it wasn't.

I don't usually stop by this place just because there is so much yummy Mexican food (and MORE) in that area, and I'd rather eat that than an OKAY slice of pizza for the same price.
author: Liz C.

description:
Pizza by the slice or 2! okay it was good when your hungry. No waiting.
Ordered cheese pizza and it was flat and crispy. They even reheated in the oven in the back and in seconds we were devouring the greasy, cheesy, carb/fat loaded pizza. Yum-o!
author: Mauling W.

description: Best place to get a slice in the Bay.  I think I seen one of the cats who work there in the clink when I got arrested that one time, but I can't be sure...  They're mad nice though.  I always get a slice of cheese, unheated, with mad parmesan on it.  Arinell gets love.  EAT HERE NOW, ya punks.
author: J K.

description: Decent pizza for the city, though unfortunately that doesn't say much. When it's fresh and crispy it's top notch.
author: Andrew K.

description: This is a damn good slice of pizza. The closest to my loved and dearly missed slice of NYC pizza. A no frills joint and I like it that way.  Slice is super thin and a bit oily and SUPER cheesy.  How can you go wrong?
author: Kamael S.

description: I'm from Philly.  I grew up on pizza.  If you like East Coast pizza, you'll like Arinell.  Capisce?  Nuf said.
author: Sondra H.

description: Best NY pizza I've had in SF.  Definitely the real thing.  Go check it out.....you'll be back
author: Zach T.

description: My #1 pizza in SF!  Nothing better than grabbing a slice and taking it next door to Casanova to enjoy it with a cold one.  Or, nothing better than reversing that order, and drinking in the neighborhood, and then grabbing a slice to enjoy while wasted....
author: Sarah E.

description: Love this place, the pizza is simple, thin crust, sharp cheese, everything I want in life for $2.50
author: Jaemes H.

description: Best single slice pizza on 16th and Valencia open late hands down.
author: Alex H.

description: Best. Pizza. Ever. I love Arinell's pizza - thin but solid crust, amazingly flavorful & mild tomato sauce, perfect amount of cheese that's baked long enough to be a bit gooey and a bit solid, and plentiful toppings. By plentiful I mean you will mostly only see your toppings, however rest assured this is a lot of cheese waiting underneath. This pizza is so good it's worth it to demolish an entire pie on your own & have a stomache later.
author: Jasmine A.

description:
best pizza in sf so far, i love new york style pizza, also loving standing and eating them, nyc style yo... they add the toppings you want to the pre-baked plain pizza and re-bake to order, so it's always super fresh. First bite is always the fucking best, the cheese melts in your mouth... as good as bad sex... diam... I need some Arinell's right now...

parking is a big bitch in mission though (see my review on the mission)...
author: Andrew N.

description:
Yes, finally, pizza that I can really rave about....oh arinell, I blame you for my current "fat" feeling
The Scene:
Yes, it's in the Mission, yes it is a hole in the wall....but wow! Call ahead and order so you can double park, make the death defying scramble across the street, and quickly swoop up the best pizza in san francisco...BEST!....cash only kids, so dont carry around only plastic like I used to

The Food
Thin crust, crispy, bubbling cheese......need I say more? Add whatever toppings you like, this pizza is AMAZING! Personally, I opt for mushrooms, artichoke hearts and pepperoni. The sauce is just tangy enough, that it is perfectly balanced with the combination of cheeses....my mouth is watering as I type.....I now need pizza, arinell, I'm eating you tomorrow
author: Bianca L.

description:
Folks love to bandy around phrases like "New York Style" or "The Closest thing to NYC pizza in SF" when talking about Arinell's. I remain unconvinced. Having moved back to SF from the Big Apple this year I feel I'm standing on good footing to compare and contrast. 

I grew up in SF and lived for years in the Mission. I have always loved Arinell's. However, I know New York Slices and Arinell's does not have New York Slices. 

Eating a good New York slice is a voyage into cheese. A world of dense, savory, greasy mozzarella cheese that marches inexorably through your system nourishing you while at the same time potentially choking you if you eat too quickly sans lubricating beverage. 

Arinell's pizza is an interesting simulacrum of a NY slice. Like one of those crafty water bugs that can appear to be a poisonous spider but is far more benign. This is not a bad thing. Arinell's is not overladen with cheese, nor is it burdened with too much of anything (sauce, cornmeal dusting, flavor). A marvel of crispy consistency. Arinell's regular slice (I never touch that Sicilian stuff), especially sans toppings, is a benchmark for dependability. A cold San Francisco day is lightened (much like the tender-firm crisp goodness of the crust) by the consumption of a slice whilst on the move. Take just the wax paper, douse to taste with oregano, red pepper flakes, garlic salt, or that despicable fake Parmesan cheese and then power your stride with crunchy munches. 

The staff, however, have the NYC thing down cold. This is not a bonus.
author: Milk N.

description:
Great stuff.

Thin crust pizza that delivers on flavor.  Not the friendlist bunch of fellows working there, but the Chris Kittan look a-like can sure bake a good f-ing pie.
author: shaun l.

description:
Hey metal head dudes, you make a pretty bland pizza.  I've had saltines that had more flavor.  I would also need to buy three slices just to fill me up, and I'm a pretty small guy.  Is this some kind of Valencia and 16th curse that you and Cable Car Pizza share?  Well, at least Cable Car is filling.  Though, I wouldn't want to fill up on it.

The thought of a slice in the Mission would be pretty bleak if it weren't for Deja Vu.

edit: the sicilian slice isn't bad if you don't mind grease.
author: Paul W.

description: Delicious New York-style pizza, and open late! Order the thin-crust slice, and any toppings you want are added by hand before heating. There are a few stools, or you can do take-out. It's probably not the healthiest dinner, but it's really tasty. Something about the cheese reminds me of Papa Gino's, if anyone else has been there (around new england and Florida). Maybe there's a little cheddar in there?
author: Mary-Ann E.

description: Big re-baked slices served by stinky hipsters to drunk Missionites at 12am.
author: Eric S.

description: I'm  not a big fan of NY style pizza.  Only ate here because it was on the 100 things to eat in SF.  I had a slice of pepperoni, I thought it was ok.
author: Matthew P.

description:
I miss being drunk in the Mission.  I rarely am these days.  In the Mission, that is.

Arineli's has been a saving grace on several occassions.

It IS NY thin crust at its best (for the West Coast).  I don't care if I see the greasy rockers behind the counter manhandling my slice with their tattoed fingers.  I'm all over that shit.  

I never fail to burn the roof of my mouth with this place.  I never can wait.
author: Jen I.

description: Favorite pizza in the city hands down. Its the only pizza I've eaten that tastes anywhere near the pizza back in N.Y. As far as service, I'm not going to tell you that your going to get sunshine and rainbows. But will say their somewhat friendly. Def not dix :-). If your in the mission This is a place to try
author: Timmy Z.

description:
I had Arinell's for the first time in a long while, and it really is simply the best thin-crust/new york style pizza around. I agree with other posters, cheese-only is the best way to appreciate this kind of slice.
Can't give 'em 5 stars though because they don't deliver! Bummer!
author: Wendy G.

description:
Best New York style outside of the Big Apple

If you're in SF and craving a slice of New York style pizza, then head over to Arinell. You won't be disappointed! Just watch out for the crazy crack head bums that hang out on the corner. Brings back memories of NYC!
author: Sun-Kai P.

description:
I actually went around the block three times to find a space near Arinell's because I was in the 'hood picking up these incredible handmade earrings made for my daughter by my friend Shana - that's another story though. I was hungry. I needed something fast. And then it hit me, and it felt like Arinell's pizza. 

I wonder if I was there the same day Sarah was there and darn, I missed her - oh, back to the review - I get distracted easily.

I've been there 3 times before. And one thing I know I know. Excellent NYC pizza. I've eaten a ton of it (and am still so svelte what IS my secret?) There is a place on Gilman in Berkeley that almost has it nailed - I always forget the name because one of my divorce counselors was just down the block - and the pizza made it all worthwhile!)

Fact is that there are FIFTY different types of NYC pizza. Brick oven, Coal oven. What we're talkin' here is the stuff where the grease runs out of the slice even if you just tilt it 10 degrees.

Arinells has the grease down to a science. It's like they add it purposely. The crust ain't bad. The sauce is fine. It's the atmosphere that gets the 5 stars for me. Parking on Mission in front of some of the funkiest homeless encampments in the city.  

And yes, it's been said - but my experience might have been the best:
GUY 1: (In a hoodie) "My welfare check is a week late, how much ya got.
GUY 2: "Three."
GUY 1: "I got .75, I think we're there."
GUY 2: "HEY, TURN THAT SONG UP"

PIZZA GUY TURNS UP THE SONG ON THE TINNY BOOMBOX REALLY LOUD. INDETERMINABLE ROCK AND ROLL, NOT TOO METAL, NOT BAD ACTUALLY, EVEN TO THE WRITER OF THIS REVIEW WHO IS MORE INTO BRIT POP BY FAR.

GUY 1 LEAVES WITH THE SLICE. GUY 2 STAYS TO HEAR THE MUSIC, PAYS MORE THAN GUY 1 AND GETS NOTHING BUT THE MUSIC.

Lunch that day was a slice of Arinell's and a Apple Turnover from the Mission Beach Cafe. Yes, I had healthier food for dinner, thank you.

So, is Arinells AUTHENTIC New York pizza? No way. Is it risking your life for? Go during the day, the corner is dicey. Not as dicey as some of the places you go for pizza at night in NYC. 

You should go though, as I guarantee you will have a story to post here too :) Yes, you can eat atmosphere and it does make the food taste better.
author: Dennis S.

description:
One slice for less than $3. What more do you need to know.

And their pizzas are huge.
author: elaine m.

description: My exposure to the various pizza joints in the Bay Area continues...this time, I decided to give Arinell a shot (based on previous Yelp reviews).  I gotta say, it was a pretty decent pie.  I picked up a large pepperoni and mushroom.  The crust was NY thin and the overall flavor was decent.  The quality of the pie reminds me a lot of what you would find at a Ray's or Famous Ray's in Midtown Manhattan...in fact, it is almost spot on.   If I was in the neighborhood, I might order another slice or two...but there are others I need to experience first.
author: Rodney B.

description: OMFG.  This is the best freaking thin slice pizza I have ever had!!!
author: Stacy S.

description: The pizza is very thin crust, very crisp, but the toppings could be better.  The mushroom topping was TERRIBLE.  The peperoni is okay.  Probably plain cheese is the way to go.
author: Piggy S.

description:
The attendant at this shop had long, unkempt fingernails with plenty of dark mystery-matter lodged underneath. 

When I asked for a pizza with three toppings, he explained that their pizza can't usually accomodate such requests. I told him I'd risk it, as I was really craving a mushroom, pepperoni, and olive slice. When it came out, it was soggy and literally dripping olive juice all over my cheap paper plate. 

I explained that this was so unappetizing and soggy that I couldn't eat it, and politely requested a refund. Not only was there no manager on duty, mr. pizza-serving-meth-head told me to 'suck it up." 

Disgusting food, unacceptable service. I highly suggest checking out Deja Vu pizza up the block, on 16th and Guerrero, instead.
author: julia k.

description: What is there to say other than Arinell's rules for what it is. Not a place to take your mom on mother's day but excellent pizza.
author: Armand C.

description: I do not remember if I already rated Arinell Pizza or not but I can tell you that they have deep dish pizza and I was very pleased with their pizza and prices. I can say a lot better than Escape from New York Pizza on 22nd street or whatever they are called. At least their CASH ONLY sign is located at the window where you see the available slices comparing to the other place is hidden at their register area in which is really stupid and a good loss of customers.
author: C G.

description:
They get thin-crust pizza right. The crust is the key to Arinell's pizza. That and it's sold by the cheap slice in a funky little joint. 

Now, in New Haven or New York, where thin-crust discussions approach theological complexity, Arinell's would just be an ordinary corner pizza place. But in San Francisco, they're a standout. Among Bay Area thin-crust pizzarias, Arinell's has one of the best crusts (the other contender being the Cheese Board in Berkeley, surprisingly).

No fancy toppings, just a basic, well executed thin-crust experience. Great value, and the slices are served hot right out of the oven.
author: Pat T.

description:
Back story.  I will eat pizza any time and any place and I am a certified pizza snob.   So I'm returning from Marin after eating a sizable lunch (at the Dipsea for those interested) and I decided that I needed to give Arinell's a shot at the title of best Pizza in the city.  Well I'm here to say that they currently hold the title.  Pizza was cooked almost to perfection, and when I say perfection I will be more specific.

Pizza perfection - thin crust, but not too thin.  Cheese actually sits on the slice and does not slide all over the place and lastly but probably the most important "easy on the sauce".  Oh yeah, you can also hold the slice without it flopping all over the place.
author: Tom C.

description:
So I'm from New Jersey. Pizza is the equvalent to burritos here. Fast, cheap, and good. I figured once I left the east coast, I would be hard pressed to find anything similar. But then I found Arinell's. 

All of you who complain that it's not NY pizza.....you're right. It's not NY. You are in California. Once you deal with that fact, you'll realize that this is probably the closest you'll get. Now I haven't tried their Sicilian, or really many with toppings, because often that just ruins the purity of a slice. Their plain cheese pizza is great. Nice crust, big slices, decently greasy. The sauce could use some help, but all in all...I'll take it.
author: Emily L.

description:
It's prolly some of the best NY style pizza you can find in SF.

Thin slices and inexpensive.  Gotta love it.

I just wished it had later hours and a few more chairs to possibly sit and eat.

Great place though, especially in the Mission District.
author: Mike V.

description:
Update:
The more pizzas I taste in NYC, the more I am convinced that Arinell's is the best pizza in the West Coast.  If you like Joe's Pizza in the East Coast, I felt this one was comparable or even better.

Old posting:
5 stars - Taste overrules everything else.  Don't care if the place dirty, don't care if they take cash only, don't care if I have to circle around the freakin' block for 1 hour trying to find parking and I DON'T CARE IF THEIR PIZZA IS UGLY... I simply love Arinell's!!!  

When I was a student at UC Berkeley and the one in Downtown closed down for renovation for a year or so, I took BART to Valencia for 2 slices...and it was so worth it.

Put some extra cheese and you're in heaven.  This place has one of the most amazing thin crust pizzas I've had in SF / Bay Area and even around the world.  This place has a very unique taste that is a bit different from NY or Rome (I'd say their crust thickness is in between NY and Rome - NY being thicker and Rome being thinner).  

Don't expect something creative.  Don't expect service.  This place is for a gooooood cheese pizza.
author: Min K.

description:
To all us New Yorkers out there, this is what you've been looking for.  

Well, it's as close as you're going to get.  Which is pretty much the highest compliment that can be paid to a pizza place 2900 miles from the city where you're supposed to get pizza.

Bluetooth=No Pizza.  Love it.
author: John L.

description:
at 730pm all i saw was cheese pizza which the worker had to heat up.  $2.50/slice.  Tara M. connected nail to head when she wrote: "the people who work there look like they haven't washed in weeks".

i can't believe there's almost 300 reviews for this place, probably because yelp started in SF and everyone here wants to have hole-in-the-wall places under their yelp belt. this place qualifies.

transport this place to LA and it'll have 3 reviews.
author: Ameer N.

description:
Um, dudes, the slices are tiny and when you try to fold it in half (can you say essential?) it cracks.  Every time.  So not cool.  So not NY style.  

Cheese to sauce ratio is good, though.
author: Nora B.

description: I had high hopes given the reviews of this place, but it was only ok to me.  It is NY style, but I thought it was a little dry and the pepperoni needed to be crispier. I think the base cheese pizzas were over cooked.
author: Kelly M.

description: Excellent NY big slice thin crust pie. 2 pepporoni slices will do the job.
author: Nick H.

description: Thin crust pizza at a great price.  This is as close to New York pizza as it gets in California.  This place could have a little more selection, but I guess that's the beauty of being a hole in the wall.  Go for the cheese slice no matter what...and if you're really hungry, then you can try to other stuff.
author: Julie C.

description: Taste in pizza style is such a personal thing, but if you like the super thin New York style pizza, this is the place for you! I happen to love this style, and Arinell does it right. It's not just the thin crust but also the cheese they use, it's the best!
author: Susan C.

description:
sometimes the perfect NY slice 
and sometimes not
always a bad attitude
its too bad because i love it when its good but you never know 
i gues there are a couple of different people making the pies
author: robet r.

description: Damn, now that's what I call thin crust pizza! Not too greasy, satisfying, and the price is right--CHEAP!
author: Donna M.

description: Ok thin crusted pizza, but I'm I was more disgusted because the cashier was also the same person who handled my food.  You don't have to be a health inspector to figure that one out.
author: Ricky M.

description: Great thin, eat-on-the-run pizza.  I like it either plain or with pepperoni.  It's $3.25 for a slice with one topping.  Cash only.  It's not at good if you keep it in the box and eat it at home - you gotta eat it right from the oven.
author: H G.

description:
OK - while I agree with christian, the hipsters working there can be hit or miss, but are usually pretty chill.

Go for the pizza which is the best NYC think crust around in my opinion.

The crowd surfing on the Valencia sidewalk are bonus points!
author: chris s.

description:
As I enter Arinell, I note the aging food equipment in the kitchen. Certainly, the place does not look clean. I quickly glance at my food options. I place my order.

The man who took my order was surly. Nonetheless, after my pizza was heated, I took a bite.

Excellent pizza. How a plain, cheese pizza could taste so great is a mystery to me.

This restaurant is a rare exception. Normally, I am not too endearing of poor service. However, the pizza at this restaurant certainly makes up for it.

Additional Notes:

- I have tried Arinell's takeout/call ahead service. I have not found takeout/call ahead to be reliable -- as the employees do not take phone orders seriously.
author: A B.

description: This is some of the best pizza in the area. If you like thin crust, definitely check it out. It's nothing fancy, but the plain cheese pizza is fantastic. Nothing boring about it! Or if you want some toppings, those are always good too. Their ingredients are high-quality. And it's an easy location to get to from anywhere in The City. By the way, who the hell drives to the Mission anyway? Just saying.
author: Sam R.

description:
Best cheap slice in SF (that I've found).

And the place does have that "just feels right" quality about it.

If you order mushrooms on your pizza they come sauteed with garlic, not just raw mushrooms put on top to wilt, as in many other joints. 

I wish they used better cheese though...
author: Jacob L.

description:
Extremely good pizza. 

Do as I say and not as I do. Wait for it to cool. They hand it over lava hot!
author: Angela K.

description:
THE RUMORS ABOUT THIS PLACE ARE TRUE.

this is great pizza.  they pop it in the oven for a few seconds and it's just perfect...
author: KL S.

description:
The best-  'nuff said.

But they lose a star because what hole in the wall makes pizza like that with no delivery or late hours-- what the hell?

I dig the crotchety boys that work there- they remind me of guys I went to high school with.
author: SaraMitra P.

description:
Ooooh Baby... 

Nothing like that first drip of oily seasoned grease of a Arinell slice. 
Take the grease and thin slices with a shoebox eat-in and life is pretty sweet. Throw some garlic powder on that and you got a party since Arinell is open late enough. 

My favorite in-between rushing from work to BART. Arinell is also equipped with a viable entertainment system as the high end riff-raft sway back, forth, in, out and well, all around the surrounding streets! 

Arinell = S.F. experience fo sho.
author: Camille B.

description:
Desperate times call for desperate measures.

My bf was one serious hungry hippo after dirt jumping in Pleasanton and if we didn't grab something asap, he was about to get Micky D's...wtf?!?!?  I can't have that.  

The neon sign pointed out NY style pizza...alright let's get it.  It was on the way to my pad.  CASH ONLY. 

Ordered 2 slices of the Sicilian and 1 regular and I asked for pepperoni but I think the dudes that worked there don't give a crap. So all I got was cheese. 

It was O.K.  I wasn't impressed by any means and doubt I will ever go back.
author: Inga B.

description:
So being another typical East Coast pizza snob, I gotta give cred to Arinell's for keeping it real.   A formidable, thin crispy slice with just the right amount of grease, sauce and cheese to fold and chow.
It seems like such a harmless, simple formula to pull off but damn, ever so elusive.  This spot is the ONLY one in the city that hits close to home.
Sure, the smarmy, greasy haired rocker kids making the pies can have you thinking twice and sure, who knows what Mission dreg was sitting at the counter stool just a minute ago but fuck it, I'll take their dripping cheese slice over some gourmet cardboard any day.
author: Stephan J.

description: Yeah dousche bags work here but who cares.  The pizza here is true nyc.  It reminded me a Bleecker's pizza on Bleecker street.  The crust is thin and light.  Haven't ate anything like it in SF.  Its def worth eating after eating a burrito at La Cumbre.
author: Fatty A.

description:
Best pizzs in SF!! We moved here from NYC, and this is the closest pizza in SF to NY pizza.
The only issue is, that sometimes when you order a pie, they burn or over cook the crust.  They need to get that right.
author: Debra J.

description:
This is the only good pizza in the bay area.  if you want the whole experience, the perfect drink to accompany your slice(s) is the suicide/earthquake/whatever-you-call-some-of-each-from-the-soda-dispenser
(but skip the lemonade)
author: Plug N.

description:
I wanted to love this.  I wanted this to be the link with my NYC past.  The slice of pizza which would transport me back in time via my taste buds.

The sauce and cheese were roughly comparable with the very generic Ray's pizzas that exist in New York, but the crust was not right.  It had the right thickness, and it even had the bubbles in the crust, but it was too hard to fold in half.  This is just wrong.  NYC pizza is meant to be folded in half, and the orange grease is supposed to leak out the back onto your plate.  Every slice I tried to fold in half broke.  Crusts are meant to be chewy, but not so chewy that fear of hurting your jaw becomes an issue.

Arinell's is not very good value for money.  For not too much more we are able to get three meals out of a pizza at Little Star.  I would not compare them on pizza, because the style of pizzas are so different, but it seems fair to compare them on price.  Especially when you consider that they are in the same neighbourhood.  That being said Little Star's thin crust pizzas are nothing to scoff at.
author: Toy W.

description:
It's pretty tough to find a good slice of pizza.  But on my trip to SF, I found a great one.  Everything I heard about this place was true.

Food - Great.  It's not overpowering, but nicely balanced.  I had a plain pepperoni pizza and while it's not my favorite topping, it was one of the best slices I've had in a long time.
Price - Average.
Service - Nonexistent.
Environment - In the mission and like the mission.  Little hole in the wall.

Everyone has their own perference in taste.  However, if you think it tastes like cardboard, you might want to stop eating the box.

Suggestion - A nice pepperoni pizza is worth it here.
author: Ricky C.

description:
From the east coast, i would say Arinells is one of the best places in the city to have pizza.  Why only 3 stars you ask??
Well not only is this pizza place dirty, i've seen one of the pizza makers playing with his hair, putting it in a pony tail and then start working on a new pizza without washing his hangs.  Gross!!!  Arinell is definitely a guilty pleasure but i have stopped going ( unless i'm really desperate for pizza) because of the greasy hair pizza problem.
author: Michelle A.

description:
This place would be tolerable if it was in ~The City~.... but this is SF, and I take what I can get.

That being said, I had avoided this place like I would avoid  a tap-dancing pubic louse for years because, well, fuck west coast pizza. 

Then I finally ate here.  I think I was fucked up.  But let me say, I have since eaten there sober and the pizza ain't half fucking bad.

It is even better when I am ordering a whole pie, because then I have control and can order it done right.  By that I mean, put some extra sauce of that muthertrucker and for the love of Mary, the Baby Jesus in the manger and Shiva, take it out before the god-damned crust edges are burnt.

Then it is good pizza.

If you disagree with me, you are wrong and deserve a swift one from a steel-toed DM worn by an angry single lesbian right in the grapes, or to slide down a banister and slam your cootchie into a nice solid teak newel post.
author: Mollena W.

description:
Yummerz.  I've had so much bad pizza in this town before coming to this joint.  

Sure you may have to make a venture to hipsterville to get a slice but it's the only decent slice being served in this city.

The pizza at Arinell's is the typical slice you'd find on any street corner in NYC --- which is eons better than any other place you'd find in SF.

Thank you sweet Yelpers for guiding me to this place.
author: Guava C.

description:
Arinells.......Two reasons I have ever eaten here...

1. Wasted and it smelled aight
2. My boyfriend lives at the place. Seriously. Loves the pizza and swears by it.

I personally suffer through Arinells for the sake of not starting an arguement, but really anyone who thinks this is great pizza I question your intelligence.

Two stars for the staff however, punk rock lives.

Thanks Arinells for the drunken stomach aches and the smile on my BF face.
author: Charlie B.

description:
Okay, I've been to NYC recently and I went to Grimaldi's Pizza in Brooklyn. I was like DAYUM! California pizza has nothing on this. So now, I've been searching for pizza similar to that in my hometown of SF. This place... not even close. I've had delivery better than this. Yes the crust was thin, straight forward, and simple. 

BUT!... The cheese slices are pretty much premade, then reheated again with the topping you want. I don't care if it's hole in the wall, just make me some good NY pizza if you can. This was a decent attempt, but not good enough. Greasy as hell too. I would only come back hear if I was drunk and extremely hungry.
author: Carl D.

description: Fine pizza, pretty ordinary. Very greasy. Plan to order to go, you won't want to hang around in the hot and stinky "dining room."
author: Adam B.

description:
They have NY Style Pizza (or as close as you're gonna get in SF), but I think I like Serrano's a little better.  Even though Arinell's is closer to NY style, I think the pizza at Serrano's is just better.  That said, if you're itchin' for a taste of the Big Apple, Arinell's will tide you over!

3.5 Stars!
author: Garrett C.

description: The best place for New York pizza in San Francisco. Yum.
author: arin f.

description: yum, so good and they sell by the slice.  also have one in berkeley.
author: Angie C.

description: Hands down, my favorite pizza spot in San Francisco. All I ever order is the thin crust cheese pizza, and it's the greasiest, most satisfying slice of New York I've had here. The staff even remind of New York - a little grimy & super direct.
author: Amber K.

description:
Blondies and Escape from New York pale in comparison to the authenticity of this place. The sauce may not be the best in the city, but they got the crust PERFECT.

The only drawback here is that sometimes the guys behind the counter are so wasted that it's slightly frightening (I mean those are pizza ovens behind them).
author: Andrew L.

description:
When me (born and raised in northern new jersey) and my girlfriend ( a queens native) walked into Arinells for the first time, before we even got close to the pizza, we  looked at each other and said "nailed it!".

From our vantage point we saw the thin film of orange oil indicative of there being a perfect sauce to cheese ratio that allows the cheese to actually melt into the sauce. Basically, the opposite of every California pizza place with the inch thick cheese barrier.

And the taste/texture more than surpassed our hopes. It was like being in a time warp back to 1980 to the pizza party my little league team had at Kay's Pizza on Maple Ave.

Everything about Arinells is purposeful and perfect, from the slightly grungy interior (Most places take time to develop that vibe but they had it on grand opening day). To serving the slices on wax paper. To the slices with the occasional bubble in the dough.To the slightly aloof, but actually cool people who I truly believe take pride in the pizza they serve.

My pizza boycott (except free pizza at work etc) of California pizza is officially over thanks to Arinells.
author: midas r.

description:
Best new york pizza west of the bay bridge. (I still prefer the Berkeley Arinell, for reasons I cannot hope to explain in a review.)

The pizza, the ambiance, the clogged parmasean dispenser, the napkins dispensers that are either totally empty or so full you can't get a napkin out without destroying like 50 napkins in the process, the disgusting condition of the counters, everything approximates a pizza joint in the city (not this city, that other one).  

Note to fellow Californians on how not to be pizza ignorant.  If you want a slice without any toppings ask for "a slice," not "a plain slice" or "a cheese slice." Cuz then you'll be cool. Pizza cool.
author: Noah R.

description:
I will not compare this to NY pizza just because I've only been to NYC once and never actually got to try the real deal. 

I will say that this is damn good pizza, whether its close to the real thing I just don't know. I've had the peperroni and the regular cheese, but out of the two I would say the plain cheese is better. It's thin, greasy, flavorful, and slides right down. The place is a dive, but you don't go here to sample the ambience. If you're craving some good pizza  and are in the area then I would highly recommend this place.
author: Alson L.

description:
This is the third review of only reviewing a CHEESE SLICE.

This place rocks. It literally does, they always seem to be playing MOTORHEAD and SLAYER. S'cool with me, I can hang as long as the slice doesn't taste of metal, because that would be not so good.
They call this New York style, and it comes pretty damn close. The thin slice is excellent, and they also have a thick crust (square) style, which i have not tried. The place is pretty busy during peak hours, so get it to go, i do because  I AM A MAN ON THE GO.
author: wayne s.

description:
Hands down the BEST pizza in San Francisco. The sauce rules, and its not sweet like so many sauces.  And they use real awesome cheese.  Thank you for making a great pizza.

The only wierd thing- if you ask for a pizza slice to go and you ask for a box, they look at you like you are crazy. They want to give you your pizza in a paper bag.  Gross.  What is up with that? if you fold the pizza it ruins it. All the cheese sticks together.
My advice, pay the $.50 extra and get a damn box.
author: Ivanna C.

description: Love this place, long time... I think it's like 2.75 a slice. Real NY style slices.  I've never been to NY, trust me though.   I'm a good judge of characteristics.
author: Marvella W.

description:
the NY style pizza here was always on the very decent scale, as far as san francisco pizza goes.

the last time we came, the tall thin guy with the ponytail was so obnoxious. there was a slice of cold stale pizza - it was obviously been sitting around for decades and should not have been served to anyone - and a whole NEW hot one that just came out. he refused to sell us a slice from the NEW one and instead told us to take the cold one or leave.

we left and will never come back, thanks to this obnoxious jerk.
author: huong n.

description: This place kicked off a trip around the Mission trying to knock off as many items from the 7x7 list as we could.  I'd been here once before and thought the pizza tasted better the last time.  The crust here is pretty fabulous, but the rest of the pizza was only so-so.
author: Alea G.

description: Quality thin-crust cheese pizza, you are quite tasty after an exhausting Bay to Breakers run today. My parents thank you.
author: Randy M.

description:
Mmmmm good. nice crispy crust.

No nonsense staff.

top off with mushrooms and live jalapenos and you have a quick meal or a nice topping to the drunkenness from Dalva, Casanova or any of numerous local dives...

Cheese does linger for a while.
author: el b.

description:
Hands down the best pizza in the city.
