Sure, everyone that works there is practiced in the art of being a zombified asshole, and yes, it's pretty dirty in there, and right, the incessantly bad punk rock (played out of a "My First Sony" boombox) makes me want to murder myself, but it's all worth it.

Fuck a topping--the cheese pizza is straight up delicious. A perfect crust (screw you, Defina's pizza, for that wide band of inedible crust around the outside of your pizzas), THE perfect sauce (not sweet, and just the right amount of kick), and high-quality cheese. Sublime. We stopped ordering a whole pie cause we can't stop ourselves from eating the whole fucking thing.

Oh, and about their practice of folding the pizza and putting it in a bag? RETARDED. You destroy the integrity of the cheese and wind up with a chewy mouthful of shit. Spring for the extra quarter, people, and just buy a box. Sure, they'll give you (one more) dirty look, but it's worth it to get your pizza home in pristine shape. You wouldn't  fold a photo of Angelina's face, would ya?
author: Cody V.

description: great great casual cheap pizza.  Fun vibe.  Quick in-and-out lunch or dinner.  The pizza crust is amazing and the pepperoni is thick and spicy!  My boyfriend even brings this home for me sometimes!
author: Kat D.

description:
I am a native New Yorker, and I thought this place made a very respectable NY style slice a lot more than other establishments in the Bay Area. I would be kidding you if this place could compete with a NYC establishment like DiFaras, but its a very good slice, equal to an above average NY pizza shop. Definitely better than most other Bay Area pizza establishments I sampled during a recent trip.
Update, I give this place four stars, I just returned to New York and had some slices at local joints, Arinell is better than many NYC pizza shops.
author: Gino S.

description: My favorite thin crust, cheapo pizza in the city!
author: Dave H.

description: This place has gone down the tubes.. They have a filthy white guy with a backwards cap a bushy ass bead working there.  Was handleing money with his hands, then walks over after I tell him what pizza I wated & without washing his hands starts putting sausage on my pizza with his filthy scum money hands & puts it in the oven..  Major health code violation.  Then after spendng $8 bucks + a dollar tip even after his health code violation, I asked him 4 a to go box & he rudely tells me "No the boxes are huge"... Yet I ordered 2 slices & the crust measured 18" in length.. He then said he'd have 2 charge me 50 cents.. I said no then burned my hands on the thin ass wax paper he put it on... Won't b back again
author: Liz G.

description: California doesn't know how to make a decent slice of pizza to save its life! Enter Arinell's as close to NYC thin crust as you can get, I have only had there cheese as I am a little terrified of getting a pie with toppings and realizing they messed up the best representation of edible pizza this city has offered me since moving. Just as a side note my first visit a homeless women decided to drop her knickers and take a piss right in front of the shop in between 2 cars, the guy behind me lost his appetite and luckily I was not phased or else I would not have eaten the wonderful thing that is Arinells pizza
author: Brian S.

description: I prefer thin crust pizza and Arinell does the trick. It's kind of like the sloppy joes of pizzas... have a llotttt of napkins on deck.
author: Annie L.

description:
YES! 

The closest thing to NYC thin crust pizza around...a staff that looks like they just walked off the set of "Dazed and Confused" and very loud metal (played on tapes I think!). Sooooo good.
author: Matt S.

description:
First things first- If you want a slice of pepperoni, and all you see is cheese, relax. They put the pepperoni on then slide it into the oven. I can't tell you how many times I've had to see the unwashed counter guy explain that. 

Anyway, as far as this place's reputation of being as close to NY pizza as you'll get in SF, that's fairly true. The crust is thin, but usually a bit too thin so it ends up cracking when you try to fold it. They've got the grease level about right. (NYC pizza should have enough grease so that it rolls down your arm and off your elbow. Shut up health nuts.) the sauce is generally lacking, but the cheese almost makes up for it. 

As for the sanitation, well, you do risk getting hepatitis from the counter guy taking the money from the crackhead, then putting pepperoni on your slice without any thought of hand washing. I've also seen them sitting down on the bags of flour in between orders. No big deal though. Looking at the building should alert you that sanitation is not the greatest of concerns here. Think of it as a workout for your immune system and enjoy. 

All in all, it isn't John's, but it really isn't bad. I have no problem going in and grabbing a slice.
author: Tom W.

description:
This place is bitchin... at first I was worried that I'd have to stand and eat on account of the sparse seating arrangement, but thankfully a crackhead wandered in and started dancing..  the hipster crowd cleared out very quickly. Bitches.

Anyhoo the pizza is great but I'm subtracting a star because it isn't really sensible to add toppings, since they don't really get cooked. But if you're in the Mission,  got three bucks burnin in your pocket, and hankering for a cheesy slice shoved at you on a paper towel, look no further. Also if your gut response to surly metalheads and Cannibal Corpse on a ghetto blaster is "fuck yeah."
author: Jim K.

description:
Being a New Jersey native, I've had my fair share of pizza in NJ/NY and was deeply saddened to find California just doesn't serve a decent slice. For someone who loves pizza as much as I do--and only gets home about twice a year--this is a pretty big disappointment (though I can't say I wasn't warned before I moved here).

Thankfully there's Arinell to curb my pizza cravings--it's as good as it gets from what I've sampled out here in the past three years. No frills pizza that's just like home--I'll eat this drunk AND sober!
author: Alissa C.

description:
arinell's is the best this crust ny style pizza in the bay area!
i started eating it while at berkeley for school, and was so happy to find it in sf when i moved here.
it is simple: cheap, fast, and delicious. the best is if you get a freshly made slice but they always heat up the pizza so it is the perfect temperature.  
i usually like toppings, but for arinell's i recommend sticking with the cheese pizza.
you can also order a pie to go and have it every night for a week!
it is my favorite pizza in sf!
author: Yummy E.

description: this place is just OKAY now. something changed in their crust/sauce recipe, maybe they cleaned or something? It's not the same, oh well. All things must go the way of the dial tone.
author: J R.

description: Wowww! I was here on a Friday night at about 11:30pm and I had no idea that they were open until 3am.... 3am!! when did this happen??? This is what I was waiting for all along!!  I had to tell everyone I know and if you don't know already Arinell Pizza is open until 3am Fridays and Saturdays! pretty awesome right?? I thought so! Not to mention if you're totally wasted or just craving some pizza, its sooo comforting to know that they're still open. Especially when you're in a time of need! I LOVE YOU ARINELL PIZZA!
author: Katie D.

description: Borned and raised in New York.....this is DEFINITELY New York Style Pizza....no other pizza joint can compare to this lilttle place of heaven!!!
author: Jannie L.

description: This place would get 5 stars for their pizza but I ordered a whole Pie from here a while ago and found a ball point pen in the box all melted down. The pizza was still good but I couldn't eat the slice that had pen on it : ( But I still come back and the pen was I'm sure due to the stoner dropping it in the box and throwing the pizza in there.
author: Michael K.

description: The best and only legitimate NY style pizza in San Francisco and as far as I have tasted, in all of California. I've lived in Northern and Southern California and I have yet to find pizza as good as Arinell. I live in DC now and with it's proximity to NY one would think that the recipe for great NY pizza would have somehow migrated this far. But I have yet to find any place that does it right here either. Arinell is to pizza what The Ramones were to Rock and Roll, it makes one want to open their own pizza joint.
author: David S.

description: I had a slice of cheese here and the crust is definitely NYC thin. But the sauce was lacking, and they didn't bake it hot enough either so it was so so for me. I like A Slice of New York in Santa Clara better.
author: Derrick V.

description: The best truly authentic slice of East Coast pizza in town.  Anyone who says otherwise is an ignorant fool.
author: Doctor L.

description: One of my favorite post-drinking-on-16th-street food stops.  Now THIS is cheap, greasy, New York-style pizza.  The slices are cheap and enormous, and are fantastic for soaking up booze.  Sadly, there's not much space for eating inside - just a few bar stools.  However, there is the added advantage of being able to watch yourself eating pizza drunk in the enormous mirrors.
author: Angela B.

description: I would easily come back--the crust has a nice crackle, colored caramel with a slight charring which tastes oh-so carb-ilicious. Super hot and dripping with cheese, it's a fine example of New York style pizza, and for the right price, too. Still, it's just a fine example. It's not even a stellar example, and am surprised a little by the amount of hype for an Arinell slice. I would easily come back for the convenience but can tell you... I was not blown away.
author: Jessica L.

description: I've done it drunk, I've done it sober... Arinell is solid. Just don't get toppings - they fall right the hell off since they're not baked in with the cheese. A great simple slice of cheese pizza is all you need here.
author: margot b.

description: Eh, Arinell's is good but not great. I have to say I prefer Escape from NY on Haight and Za's on Hyde for the New York-style. No, I'm not a native New Yorker, but I have been there and it is my favorite style of pizza, but I thought Arinell's was a little too thick to fold and the cheese was a little rubbery. Don't get me wrong, it tasted fan-fucking-tastic, but I would stop far from saying its among the best.
author: Brandon B.

description: I had their cheese and pepperoni slices and I'm drooling right now just thinking about them.  They make a mean slice of pie!  This is the closest you can get to New York Style pizza in Nor.Cal. Nice thin slices, fold it up and you're good to go! Also try their fountain drinks, I usually get the "red" flavor...I think it's suppose to be some kind of tropical fruit punch. A couples slices of pie + red drink= happy tummy.
author: Abby A.

description:
sometimes i have mixed feelings about this place, yet i still find myself coming back.  if you just need a slice or two without any trendy overpriced BS (yes i'm talking to you, Little Star) then come here.  some of the employees aren't the brightest crayons, but, eh.

i say mixed feelings because sometimes you get a slice that's been sitting there for a while.  most the time it's still pretty good though, at least not stale enough to care.  however sometimes it seems like pizza gets better with age anyways, like when its been in your fridge for 5 days and you wake up one morning remembering it's there. like finding a dollar in your pocket after doing laundry.

thats what Arinell's is.  it's finding that dollar in your pocket.  not a 5 or 10 dollar bill, but just a good ol mr. washington.

PS free jalapenos on the counter is a HUGE plus in my book.
PSS standing room only, or the curb outside.
author: eric f.

description: As a transplanted New Yorker (from Brooklyn, no less) you can imagine my JOY when I finally went to Arinell's. It was almost like being back in NY, except with punk rock instead of hot 97 or z100 blaring and with skinny boys instead of morbidly obese italian men.
author: Maria D.

description:
I entered Arinell's hoping to witness an exchange like the one mentioned in Willy M's review: an irate, tattooed Iron Maiden devotee behind the counter snatching pizza away from a hapless customer.  It was not to be. 

The scene was set (Iron Maiden blasting), and the guy behind the counter had the requisite tattoos.  But he wore the beatific expression of the well and truly stoned, and instead of yelling at customers he peaceably enlisted the help of the cash register to add two whole numbers together.  

The tip jar has a few cutout headlines saying things like "TWO MEN MURDERED OUTSIDE PIZZA PLACE...for not tipping."  There's even a plant in the corner adorned with a trio of DEATH symbols: a little plastic skeleton, a perched miniature crow, and...an orange plastic spider ring.   It's all very charming, but can I get a little confrontation?  Can someone get a pizza slice or a cell phone confiscated?

But in the end it's my fault, because I didn't dare to ask who was playing or to whip out my cell phone.  I did, however, enjoy two slices of truly excellent pizza.
author: S P.

description: arinell's is the one of the only place in sf that has decent pizza.  everywhere else sucks pretty much and you'd think with all the great food options, pizza being that it seems easy enough to make sucks balls here.  Anyway, the pizza here is good and one of the guys that works there reminds me of jay from jay and silent bob.
author: christopher h.

description: A slice from Arinell's produces a harmony in your mouth. Each ingredient unique and delicious. Each ingredient combining for a seamless slice. Unlike most pizza slices, there is no one ingredient that overshadows the other in a slice from Arniell's. The crust is the perfect amount of thinness, crispness and flavor. The sauce is flavorful without being too acidic. Cheese is gooey. The perfect NY slice without being in NYC.
author: Sara J.

description: New York-style folding pizza. Fold it over! Delicious. Wash down with a root beer or lemonade. Five stars for pizza alone. Bless this place, I've never seen an Arinell employee who wasn't in need of a shower and a bowl of hot soup. Or at least a sheep dip and a hair net. But the "ambiance" more than makes up for the grooming. Who doesn't want to hear screeching metal blasting from an old tape deck while pushing hot slices down your standing frame? It's heaven. Oregano dusted crust. Cheese and sauce merging as one. I love this place.
author: Jeremy W.

description: You may notice that this place closes relatively early considering it's in a prime spot to supply tasty food to missionite drunkards . . . They're so good, they don't need to pander to the late-night alkies such as myself!  Cable-Car Pizza (next door) on the other hand is conspicuously bare during the day, but packs in the patrons following last-call.  I can only imagine the drunkards place of refuge this place would be if they stayed open late as well!!
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
this my go to fast slice when i can't wait for dinner or need a fast lunch. nice thin and crisp crust. maybe a bit lite on the sauce. it's best just to order a cheese slice. i got sausage once and they just slice some mini disks from a link of sausage and lay them on the slice.  then when you eat it they fall off. 

so i have learned from other reviewers and do it the new yorker way. cheese only. i haven't been to new york so i can't say how original the slice is but i'm liking it fine. 

must be the youth of the employees on being lanky bony 95 pounders or they don't eat much pizza. feed those boys some pizza with sausage that sticks to the slice. i'll still take the cheese that i've come to like.
author: roger b.

description: As a kid in a small town, I saw lots of hippies: ex-hippies, survivalist hippies, deadhead hippies, and wanna-be hippies.  I have wandered fields of pot.  I have hitchhiked with children of the Rainbow festival.  The Country Fair knows me, and I can smell patchouli for miles.  My hippie-dar knows no bounds for I am a connoisseur of disestablishmentarianism.  So let me tell you this: the hippies at Arinell make some fine pizza: crisp, thin, soft, and foldable.  But they are lazy hippies, and they are dirty, like a freshly showered Tara Reid.  Minus one star for one bout of food poisoning.
author: Nom D.

description: I love their pizza. The closest you can get to real NY Pizza with that thin crust they got goin' on.
author: Aiden D.

description: This is the only place I've found in all of the Bay Area that serves even a pale replica of New York pizza.  And yes, the place is a pit.  Both locations.  We all have our crosses to bear, and this is one of them.
author: Gabriel D.

description: Super greasy, super thin, super goooood.  Again, SF continues to starve for decent pizza (as opposed to the slices of cardboard covered in cheese that most places tend to serve) and Arinell works relentlessly to counter that statement. I appreciate a good pizza (good meaning gross, not gourmet) as well as hot dudes, so Arinell suffices in both departments. Of course I like dudes that look like the botched abortions of meth-addict moms, but hey, we live in a diverse rainbow of pleasures and ideas, so shut the fuck up.
author: Chloe S.

description: x-large thin slice o' thick square sicilian....$two point five zero (plus)...stiff large surface area thin slices....crunchy browned toasted crust....drippin' on the greasy side....light on the cheese top....small indoor pizza "stand"....few stools 'n' dark counter to dine.....plain cheese por the $2.50....anything more adds on $ and more....
author: Hen A.

description: Yes!  Yes!  Yes!  I prefer to call it New Jersey style -- represent, yo! -- but whatever.  This is the best slice in all of San Francisco.
author: Telstar L.

description:
easily the best ny pizza in sf.  sometimes they reheat slices in the oven for a bit too long causing the crust to be too crunchy and burnt in some areas.  as you should know, this makes folding the pizza hard to do since it just cracks in the wrong places.

other than that, if you've been craving that ny slice, this is really the closest thing you'll get in sf.  try it!

go plain cheese or maybe cheese + mushroom.  i walked in once on a girl adding bell peppers and all this other junk on it.  i almost covered my ears.
author: Daniels L.

description: My review is WAY overdue for an update! I don't know what the hell I was thinking with my 4-star review. Arinell's is hands down the best thin crust pizza joint in the city. At first glance, you feel like you walked into some generic eatery where the pizza has been sitting out for hours. As soon as that slice hits the oven, though, it comes alive. There's something magical about the blend of crust, sauce and cheese. No matter where you live in the city, get your ass to the Mission and grab a slice of this ungodly goodness.
author: Susan L.

description: Arinell I love you. You make the all time best New York style pizza in the city, but why are your employees perpetually gross? Dirt under the finger nails? That's a little nasty. Luckily this is unconditional love
author: claire b.

description: Nice thin crust and greasy cheese, BUT not enough sauce!  This is not NY pizza!!  It's too dry.  It doesn't even come close to tasting as good as Marcello's on the Castro (which is the best pizza in SF in my opinion!)  Plus, I wonder how clean and safe this place is.  They're smoking pot in the back.  Seriously, we smelled some heavy pot smoke as we tried to eat our pizza.  At first I thought it was the oregano but my husband confirmed it and we quickly got our little boy out of there!  Gross.
author: Lalu B.

description: I think they have an employee policy here: All employees must: 1. have conspicuously manicured facial hair in the form of mustaches, mutton chops or goatees. 2. Must be a thin pasty white male in his early 20's to early 30's. 3. Must play rock and roll while working. Metal and southern rock preferred like Skynnard or Motley Crue 4. Must be unnaturally sexually appealing despite seeming lack of hygiene. 5. Baseball jerseys prefered while working. 6. Mumbling while taking orders is promoted.   So yeah,  the boys are hot, and the pizza's fucking GREAT.
author: Netty L.

description: I like to stop here on my way home from work when starving and grab something to munch on.  The pizza is alright, nothing spectacular as noted below - but still pretty alright - and cheap which is awesome when you are broke.  The thin is good but I also enjoy the thick.  Convenience factor is way up there.  Stumbling in is great if I remember to have cash on me.  I think the ambiance is what brings me back.  The staff is always cordial, and most likely drinking a PBR or 5.  The boom box is probably playing Metallica and rattling from the bass.  There are probably some interesting characters having an interesting conversation that you can eavesdrop on - since it is a pretty small place of course.  I would never intentionally eavesdrop...
author: Kristina K.

description: Will you marry me Arinell's? Can we make cheese slice babies and raise them on punk rock and pepper flakes?
author: Jennifer G.

description: Ordered a slice.  It looked thin enough.  I asked for it to be hot and extra crispy, so it was put in the oven.  It was warm, but not scortching hot and not crispy.  The sauce was bland and the cheese gooey, but in a rubbery way.  Not the best yet not the worst.  Sadly it gave me a bellyache that stuck around for quite a while so I have to knock it down a star.
author: Heather S.

description: I love cheesey, greasy, thin style pizza that can't stand up by itself and needs to be folded to eat it.  Arinell just happens to serve it, and right in a major drinking corridor.  Thank you, Arinell, for being so cheap, delicious, and always satisfying my cravings!
author: Denise G.

description: This place gets the ol' Svendle seal of approval. You can finally get a slice of N.Y at this place. The display window is always empty which is a good thing because ther pies get eaten faster than they can cook em'. The crust is thin like a cracker, and the cheese just melts in your mouth you'll be satisfied after a good night of swillin with yer mates in tha mishun dist...!!! And the people that work there always have killer 70's doom rock on there blaster too which helps me digest a good meal..!!!! You won't go home with a stomach ache either from too much cheese...!!! A definite 10 for these cats..!!!
author: Sven S.

description: Ah jeeze... here we go again.  People go out, get drunk, have a slice... and somehow think they've magically stumbled on the greatest thing in the world of food.  Please... try this place sober before you give it a 5-star rating.  The sauce is sugary sweet... it just ain't that great.  That being said, I don't really like very many pizzerias in SF at all... I have just a few favorites.
author: Matt W.

description: It's not the easiest thing to find a decent slice of pizza in San Francisco. However, Arinell makes some of the best NY-style slices this side of the Mississippi. There's not a lot of eating room, so this makes the place a good stop pre- or post- visiting the bars.
author: Nish N.

description:
it looks really dirty and the staff is pretty rude and unaccomodating, but daaaaaaaaaaamn is the pizza good.

thin-sliced and VERY new york......it's the stuff dreams are made of. (at least mine.)
author: Sid D.

description: Authentic, gritty, cheesy NYC street slices in San Francisco.  This is the real deal.  I challenge any other NYC transplant to tell me there's a better slice in the city.  I stop here every time I get up to the city, if only for a single slice of east coast memories.
author: David M.

description: Closest I've come to NYC pizza in SF (and I've been looking for years) and go to NYC at least twice a year and always eat my beloved pizza first.  Arinell's is not as good as the real thing but it's as good as you'll get in SF.
author: S. C.

description: Hey, I grew up near New York and this is real pizza... with real New York style service ;-)
author: Kjell B.

description: Best pie in town. You'll get a slice of 'tude if you come on the wrong way so be nice. Most authentic tasting I've had on the West Side.
author: Njon W.

description: flat-out, the best new york thin-slice in SF. thin enough to fold, but still crusty on the bottom. tasty sauce. a perfect amount of cheese. and you get a huge slice for only $2.75. they also have sicilian, but i would never be able to pass up the thin slice here. plus i cant imaging the sicilian being better than golden boy. this is the place to be.
author: Andrew T.

description:
The selection of condiments here does please the Andie. Nothing can bring a smile to my face and cause my nose to wiggle involuntarily  like some salt, pepper, garlic salt, oregano, crushed red pepper flakes and parm cheese all shakin' on the top of my thin crust NY style pizza (And on occasion some other things!) . All of these fabulous condiments are available to you when you get a delicious slice of Arinell Pie!!! Dang! I appreciated the "no frills here is da' deals" kind a attitude here at Arinells. Order it and they will serve it up- maybe with a smile- perhaps not! But you will be smiling either way.
 I grabbed a slice before heading over to the Double "D" for some Hangar One cocktails. Heck- I inhaled two- count um'  two fantastic slices of pie and then I proceeded to swagger on down the road- my belly was full and my mind, still registering the orgasmic experience that I had just endured, (I mean that of course in a good way) was in a state of shock! Can pizza really do this to a person! Why yes...it can!
author: Andie F.

description:
Look, I like my pizza simple, ok? A thin, greasy slice of cheese or  pepperoni in a paper bag (Arinell keeps it classy, y'all) is all I require. I don't need variety, or seating, or longhairs who DON'T wear random metal shirts, or actual sound systems vs. the retro boombox. Just gimme my slice (or 4) and let me go on my way, skipping happily down Valencia, past the bums, past the hipsters, scalding hot cheese dangling from my chin, the wind in my hair and a song in my heart.

Never, ever change, Arinell. I love you just the way you are.
author: Ya R.

description: I love their pizza so much! It just makes me so happy to come here and stare at myself in the mirror and talk to myself. No but on a serious tip it's PRETTY GOOD!
author: fuck you p.

description: Everyone knows how hard I crush on the Arinell boys.  Especially that really tall really skinny one with the longish greasy hair.  I would have been so in love with him in high school.  In fact, this place is totally nostalgic for me.  It reminds me of the pizza kiosk in the shitty mall that we spent our nights at.  Pizza's yummy enough, and the price is right.  I love the huge misshapen pies.  Arinell's makes me happy.
author: Coco D.

description: I effen LOVE Arinell's, , , like nobody's business!! I usually grab a slice when I'm in downtown Berkeley, but I have had it in The Mission too, and they're the same. Nice, huge slices of New York style thin slices! Bring it!! Unfortunately I don't get it as often as I used to, so I get a little crazy when I do. Rather than doing the typical "fold", I've been know to get two slices, slap one on top of the other and have my way with it! No mercy baby!
author: alexa c.

description: They slices are very thin, and had a pretty decent overall flavor.  Its not in the best of neighborhoods, and I'm searching for better, but its one of the best SF slices I've found.
author: J E L.

description: Not only is the pizza fucking incredible, the staff at the Valencia store is the most entertaining, rag-tag group of punk-rock metal misfits that have ever laid waste to throngs of bitchy late night customers. If you've ever seen a movie from the eighties or nineties, and that movie had a pizza place in it, it's probably pretty similar to Arinell. It constantly reeks of weed, and I'm pretty sure they only own two tapes: Iron Maiden, and Iron Maiden. I don't know about you guys, but I get kick out of watching people get 86'd from the dining establishments I frequent. One dude made the mistake of asking what was playing on the stereo. The cashier responded by looking REALLY pissed, grabbing the slice out of dude's hands and saying, "MAIDEN!" whilst placing the dude's money back on the counter. Awesome!
author: Willy M.

description: As a New Yorker, I've been completely critical of the pizza here in California. After being constantly disappointed and vanquished to a diet of endless burritos, Arinell's totes "NY Style Pizza" on their sign, and they exactly deliver that. This, by and large, had me bending the thin, crispy slice to have the oil drip off the cheese. It burned the roof of my mouth and was delivered to me the minute it came out of the oven. A little skimped on the sauce, but the cheese and the crust were dead on the money. And here I thought that you'd only get that crust if the water was piped in from the Adirondacks.
author: G B.

description: Brooklyn pizza, in my mind, should be served by dudes who don't care if you live or die.  You wanna slice with wilted flowers and capers? Go take a long walk off a short pier.   Arinell, an unassuming (read boring and unadorned) store front in the mission,  is my favorite joint in this city of pizza pretenders.  Simple sauce, good cheese ratio, and a crust that gets crispy and a little black around the edges.  Simplicity, folks.
author: Ryan D.

description:
Seems almost a waste of my time to write another good comment on this place because so many have said so many positive things before, but this really is an awesome place to grab a slice in the Mission. Very tasty, very authentic. 

The guy that usually works there is real friendly as well.
author: John S.

description: I completely agree with Rocco, the pizza here is a pretty close match to NY pizza but the crust is a bit bland. Even so, it's delicious, thin, cheesy and the sauce is perfect. Great late night food!
author: Sara W.

description: Too good!  A few years back I bought a large pie (Neapolitan) with onions & olives, took it home and ate the ENTIRE thing that evening.  Granted, it's not quite as good as the pizza I used to get growing up in Jersey, but it's the best New York-style pizza I've had in the Bay Area.
author: Christian H.

description: Holy cow! FINALLY, I've experienced a NY style pizza in California. I can hardly believe it. Thank you fellow Yelpers for your reviews! If Arinell's was closer to home then I'd eat there every week. They have cheese pizza by the slice. If you want something in addition to cheese, they'll add it on and toss it in the oven. They have about 6 stools and no tables. It's within walking distance of the 16th street BART station.
author: Kevin K.

description: Cheap, simple pizza from a dirty, run-down parlor. That's San Francisco. Great place to stop by before/after watching a flick at the Roxie just across the street.
author: Ryo M.

description: I have to say that this Queens-born boy has been frustrated with the pizza out here on the west side.  Thick crust, thin crust, and all that fancy stuff they slap on top.  None of it compares with a nice thin cheesy slice of New York style pizza like John's in the Village.  The $300 plane tickets to JFK are worth getting a slice of heaven, but now I feel like if I'm short on cash, at least I can go to this hole in the wall in the Mission to tide me over until my next trip back East.  If you're homesick for New York, head to Arinell's for a quick fix.
author: Dave L.

description: Thin, crispy crusts. Gooey, hot cheese. Large, generous slices. Good, great, and even better. Been going for years and it consistently proves itself as one of my favorite pizza places. The place is not the cleanest, I'm not sure how it remains open because it never looks like its passing health codes. Nevertheless, its cheap and tasty.
author: Esther S.

description: Arinells simply put, has the best pizza in the Bay Area. The slices are thin, greasy and give me perma-grin like the morning after sex which incidentally only happens once every four years. Sort of like the World Cup without the charm. Don't order a pie to go, it loses something. The place is perfect, it's even dirty. The last slice I had, I could almost smell the Hudson River.
author: Jason W.

description: Good street food pizza; this ain't Delfina or Little Star and it's not trying to be.  Just go for the cheese, no toppings, fold it in half, and put it in your mouth.
author: Mercutio k.

description: I think all the rave reviews might coincide with the fact that this place is stumbling distance from some popular bars.  The place is pretty dumpy, the pizza was just ok; points for being near Dolores park and a lot of bars, minus points for not sufficiently heating my slice.
author: Alex K.

description: Love Neapolitan style pizza. Tried the cheese and it was thin, crispy, large and lots of cheese. Great slice for only about $3.
author: Juju F.

description: Love Love Love. Once they told me they ran out out of sauce and thus they were closed. I still love 'em.
author: Damsel N. D.

description: Cheap no frills counter, surly pizza boys, but still, maybe the most authentic NY style slice in the city. An excellent place for a delicious snack before a night of Mission bar hopping.
author: Stellah D.

description: Pretty DAMN delicious! So good that I ate a slice and an hour later I went back for another one. I'm just a pig - what can I say! Thanks to the buds at Elixir who showed me the light when they told me where to go for a little slice of heaven :o) MMMMmmm!
author: Aim E.

description: How these metal kids make such an amazing slice of authentic NY style cheese pizza is beyond me. It is a hole in the wall, no joke. All the crazy crack heads on 16th st. crawl in and get in line too. My only qualm with them is that they always seem to close early. A place as good as this needs to be open til 1 or 2am at least. Perhaps, they are leaving early to go smoke some weed and make more metal mix tapes. Whatever they need to do to make that pizza, keep doing, it's working.
author: Kristy H.

description: Great place to grab a slice.  Accurate documentation of phone-in orders is hit-or-miss.  Too many distractions between hanging up phone and putting pizza in oven:  Classic Dead Kennedys tune on the boom box requires full attention.  Need to smoke this joint - pronto.  Now let's see, I could have sworn someone called about something earlier....
author: Cully W.

description: duhhhh, is that what NY pizza is supposed to taste like (forgive me for tho ist not fromst there)  or at least closely resemble? Ok, fine with me. I've worked and lived within walking distance of the Berkeley and SF Arinell's and this place has served me well at $2.50 a slice. A little greasy, but two thin slices of cheese or pepperoni goes a long way. I must say that the SF employees are wee bit more surly than their counterparts across the bay, but who cares. Since when is a NY style Pizza slice joint supposed to be like the cheesecake factory with an over-smiley hostess and paid to smile staff
author: Lindonesia S.

description: In grammer school I used to go to the corner pizza parlor a lot for lunch.  This was in Jersey City, NJ.  These pizzas were made there, tossed in the air, ladeled with sauce all in front of you. It was 50 cents a slice in second grade and by the time I was in seventh grade it was a dollar - ok, the preface was kinda long.  IT WAS GOOD NY PIZZA!!! And, Arinell Pizza is just that - like it used to be - thin, humongous slice of good 'ole cheese pizza!  If you are from the east coast, grew up in the tri-state area treat yourself to a slice at Arinell's - it'll bring ya back.
author: Tiberius A.

description:
I didn't know what to expect from this skeevy looking little shitbox of a pizza joint but I know that if there's a line where it looks like there shouldn't be one, you should peep that shit out.  Man, this is pretty damn close to my ideal slice.  Thin; light on the sauce; dense, rich mozzarella. But it's the crust that got me.  No fucking around with sugary sweetness you get all yeast, flour and salt.  I can deal with surly, assholish customer service no problem.  However it does suck when you feel like you can't make special requests (well done for example) without risking a hidden boog in your food.  The dudes that work there do not want to hear your bullshit.  Trust me.  Oh well, just rock out to whatever they're blasting on the boombox while you wait.  Now sit down, eat your slice of pizza and be quiet.  
Shameful admission:  I dropped a slice crust down on the 22 once.  For a hot second I considered picking it back up.  I came that close to Hep A - Z.
author: beltrand a.

description: I have to say I was majorly let down by the pizza here.  I cannot believe that people have given this place good ratings.  My weakness is pizza so I definitely know great pizza when I taste it and this was far from great!  I wuold have been happier with pizza hut or something.  My pizza was tasteless.  Nuff said!
author: karla k.

description:
Tiny hole in wall
Best slice this side of New York
Thin crust perfection
author: HaikuReview X.

description: I'm from NYC, and so when I saw all these "this is real NYC pizza" reviews I figured I'd give it a try...well, it ain't.  Thin crust is good, crust that is so thin it might as well be a soggy tasteless cracker is not.  I guess you got to be on a drunk Mission walkabout to like this one.
author: Todd K.

description: This pizza is hit or miss. But when it hits, it' so worth it.  I think it's the closest to NY pizza in SF. Thin crust, toasty, not chewy, and a layer of nice fresh mozz. and sauce.  I can't stand other pizza joints that basically serve bread with a pound of cheese. I think Arinell'sv inconsistency is caused by their "green" friendly staff.
author: Mike A.

description: I don't even like pizza. They're not being rude, guys, they're just soooooo stoneddddddddddddd. If there weren't any customers I can imagine this being the ideal job. Cut em a goddamned break! The pizza here isnt bad either, I don't hate it.
author: katharine s.

description:
i grew up in new york, and this is the closest thing i can find to actual pizza on the west coast.  even the crust is good, and that is unheard of out here.

that said, the east coast vibe includes the lack of seating, dirty counters, and ill mannered staff who often demand tips before giving you your food.

well, you wanted east coast, thats what you got
author: Steve S.

description: Gooey, melt in your mouth thin crust cheese pizza at $2.25 per slice. A bit too greasy for me to enjoy on a regular basis but when craving cheese and fat, I head over to Arinell's!
author: Trinh T.

description: Good NY style pizza. Thin, greasy, tasty. Fold it up and eat it up. Yum yum.
author: Milk and Cheese ..

description: I love the no-bull-shit pizza that these guys make. One of the best cheese pizzas I've ever had, here or in NY.
author: Reza E.

description: i totally agree with kevin H's review.  long hairs servin' up delicious, thin, greasy NY style pizza by the slice to some metal blarin' out of a boombox.  Mmm, Mmm, Mmmmmm.  Thanks to my friend lis, this place has become one of my favorite pizza joints in town.  always hits the spot.
author: Beccie F.

description: Quick, cheap and good. They've got the slice that is almost as good as a slice from NYC...
author: Nicolas H.

description: I wish I could remember more about the pizza here, but sadly I've been sloshed both times I've been here.  What I do remember is that this slice hit the spot perfectly!  It is the closest to a New York slice I've found in the Bay Area.  Also it was reasonably priced.
author: Jeff A.

description: This is such a classy place; I would recommend anyone to go there. Every time I'm in there, I hear someone go to the counter and say something like "You guys have the best damn slices in San Francisco!" And it's true. They're simple and delicious. Nothing fancy here. It's a true neighborhood experience and great pizza, fast.
author: Karl N.

description: It's close, but it's not New York as they claim.  But it beats Amicis.  Wish they'd think about delivery.
author: abdullah s.

description: I don't get the hype. The pizza is flat - so was my expression after consumption.
author: haley d.

description: Thin slice with garlic, that's all. Not bad, but not amazing either. Great for a quickie.
author: Maximillian M.

description: I am Brooklyn, NY-born and raised and Arinell's is where I go when I am homesick and craving a NYC-style slice. Let's get one thing clear though: West Coast pizza cannot hold a flame to a real NYC pie. However, Arinell's efforts are the best I've seen in the city.  Super-thin crust, delicious sauce, and the occasional crusty bubble - what's not to like? I also like that they always have some crazy music blaring like death metal or punk and The Ramones-rejects-staff serves the pies up delicious and without any fake "see ya next time" smiles. Loves it.
author: Clarissa S.

description:
cheese slice. fold in half.
new yorkers, find your solace.
crust, crispy yet moist.
author: yutai l.

description:
Certainly reminds me of NY Pizza. Nice, hot, basic, foldable, thin crust, big slice of yummy pizza. We have been here 2 times, and the pizza has been delicious. The guys working there are friendly yet quirky, and they have all sorts of music being played :).

The neighbourhood does not seem all that great. The place is a hole in wall kinda place, with stools. Order, pay cash and get ready for a slice of NY. Definitely worth a visit.
author: Tarak P.

description: It says something when you order a pizza and by the time you get home, it is pretty cold, but it is still better than 90% of the pizza you've had. Arinell's was worth the drive to the Mission, going around the block a dozen times looking for a parking space and eventually the need to double park (sorry bikers!). We had the cheese and it is a fine NY-style pizza.
author: Jordan M.

description: love it! In fact, I love their thin-crust Neopolitan pizza slices so much, I have never even tried the Sicilian. For a by-the-slice joint, the pies are suprisingly crisp and fresh, and I love how they pre-cook the mushrooms so that they don't come out dry and nasty.
author: anita c.

description:
Now they have a sign that says "No cell phones at counter" or something.  Which is fine, if I didn't have to listen to their frickin' noise at full volume while I'm at the counter.  

Still gets my 4 stars for the best slices!
author: Ritch G.

description: Thin crust pizza here really hits the spot, but you have to eat it in-house. Otherwise it gets soggy. But fresh out of the oven... I could eat it every day. In fact, I probably do.
author: P C.

description: Closest thing to NY pizza you'll find out here. My only complaint is only plain slices. If you want toppings, they just throw them on top and reheat. Not the same as "baked in goodness." Order a whole pie if you want them. Otherwise, still damn good.
author: Sig N.

description: Arinell's is the best (only?) place for a great NY slice in the middle of SF.  No frills, barely any seating, but huge slices with crispy, chewy crust, gooey cheese, and sweetly balanced sauce.  *droooool*  Just get the cheese - no need to get fancy here, trust me.
author: Lynn L.

description: They definitely have the thinnest crust around.  A little too thin in the middle, and it gets a bit greasy and soggy.  BUT after you get that first bite out of the way, the rest of the pizza is great!  If they are closed head to Cable Car Pizza - they stay open later.
author: Amme P.

description: The crust was great and so crispy but the topping were kinda weird. You custom order the topping and they add to the existing cheese pizza and reheat. Ordered two slices, the pepperoni turned out decent but the mushroom and sausage toppings were somewhat cold/room temperature. I saw another girl's order with sausage and onions and the onions were completely raw.....poor thing, maybe that's how she likes it...?
author: Yan M.

description: about as close to a real New York/New Jersey style pizza as I've found in the city.  For quick, cheap and good thin crust, they hit the mark.  (But  maybe not the place to go for a date; they seat about four people on stools at the counter. . . )
author: Mark N.

description:
i so wanted to give this place 5 stars.  a first bite it seemed worthy of being called NY pizza. the cheese and sauce are perfect.

but then i had a second slice without the parmesan, oregano, red pepper flakes--and i realized its problem.

the crust.  it's tasteless.  and too dry.

too bad.

if you don't eat the crust-edge it's one of the closest "NY" style pizza places around.
author: Judgey Von Judge O.

description: Real thin-crust, NY-style pizza served out of a hole by disgruntled hipsters. Delicious sauce, great gooey cheese. Sometimes the dough gets a little soggy, but I wouldn't fault them for that. This is the perfect place to grab a cheap slice on the way to the bars on Valencia.
author: Andrew K.

description: Coming from a former Brooklynite, this is the closest to NYC pizza in SF.  You'd think they proprietors were from a mom and pop shop in NYC with their style of pizza.  It's a must eat after drinking/dancing in the Mission.  Just wish they'd open later...
author: Christopher C.

description:
I know it's cliche'....but I am all up in the whole east coast vs west coast pizza debate...
I grew up on NY pizza South FL style (because the half of the population down there  that isn't from Canada is from New York)  (case in point- I spent part of my childhood living in Canada, my husband grew up in Long Island)
With the exception of Brothers pizza I don't get California pizza
Whatever...I just don't
The plus side of this is that we are getting really good at making our own pizza at home
The bad of this is that sometimes you just want to go out and 
get a slice (or two)
I love Arinelles pizza
It's delicious, and cheesy, and greasy, and 
so full of flavor...
The crust is super thin, and the perfect balance between
 crispy and not so crispy (that does so make sense!!!)
Allowing the cheese and sauce to really shine through
Maybe I have just been lucky, but I haven't gotten a bad slice there
And I like the atmosphere...I have yet to notice any attitude... maybe because my husband is a total metal head  (he doesn't really look like one, but maybe somehow they know) or maybe  because we are fat and so not hipster looking? I don't know.  
My only issue is that neither location takes Visa, so going there requires hitting up the ATM first, and that is so not cool.
author: Maxine M.

description: ginormous slice of pizza with mushrooms, needed a bit of spicing up with pepper flakes and even salt, crust was perfectly crisp but lacked a bit in flavor, all in all a delightful slice of pizza that completely satiated my craving.  The service is what one would expect at a place like Arinell's-to the point, no frills and I don't think it needs to change.
author: Frankie S.

description: It may not be true New York - whatever that really means - but as far as I'm concerned it's the closest thing in SF. It's cheap, open late, fast as heck, and it has character. What else do you want?
author: Saren S.

description: I lived in NYC for 6 years, and Arinell doesn't taste like any of the pizza I had while living there.  However, I think their pizza is wonderful anyway.  The sauce has a nice, clean flavor; the slices have a good cheese to sauce ratio, and the crust has a good texture (crispy and thin but not so thin that it's soggy).  Yes, the place is a dive and the cashier is surly, but whatever.
author: ML P.

description:
This is one of the best thin-crust new york style pizza places in SF. I would definitely recommend ordering a whole pie instead of the slices.

Probably the best thin crust pizza if you cut out all those gourmet fancy schmancy pizzas places with the organic farm fresh ingredients that they grow in their backyards and cheese from cows they milked that morning...
author: Dirk Diggle R.

description: If you're hankering for REALLY good, thin crust, NY-style pizza in SF, this is it.  I grew up in Boston and lived in NY, and this is the best east-coast style pizza that I've found in the Bay Area.  Be warned that this is a no-frills, hole-in-the wall place--bar-style seating only for about 8 people.  And yes, it helps if you like loud speed metal, especially if you plan to dine in.  Arinell's pizza is the quintessential, "very quick, absolutely delicious, on-the-go-in-the-Mission-but-not-a-burrito" food.  Tip: ask for extra sauce, which makes it perfect.
author: Ethan C.

description: walk in, walk out, greasy, delicious thin crust, east coast slice of pie.
author: B B.

description: Whenever I move to a new town, I have to do a sampling of the local pizza joints. So far, Arinell Pizza has to be the closest I've found to a true, old school NYC slice. Plain [cheese] slice goes without saying, just rock on the oregano, garlic, and hot pepper, fold down the middle and enjoy the grease dripping down your arm. Now, if they had some garlic knots and Italian ices I'd be set..
author: Yotam L.

description:
Finally my too long quest to find a decent slice of New York style pizza in San Francisco has come to a conclusion. It's been a long eleven years missing my favorite style of pizza. Arinell is really the closest thing you will find to the classic, greasy NY slice in San Fran. The thinness is perfect (not one of those super doughy monstrosities the rest of this city serves up) The size is perfect, the sauce quite tasty, the cheese wonderfully melted... yes, obviously New York is better, but trust me this is really good for San Francisco. 

The only complaints I have about Arinell are the location being in the mission which is too far from my home =( and the fact they don't accept credit cards forcing me to have to visit an ATM before coming.  Neither of which stop me from making a special trip for a large pie at least once a week. =)
author: Anna M.

description:
you know every time i go there i think this time it would be better. 
the only complaint i have for these guys is.
1- please USE gloves when you handle money and serve Us our food
2- Guys, the hair cut is cool and everything but i really really really don't like your hair on my food.
author: Eddie K.

description: This place has awesome New York style pizza for a great price. Best pizza I've had in SF so far, and I'll definitely come here again.
author: adrian b.

description: Still killer pizza. Great prices. Total dive. Awesome!!!
author: jonny s.

description: Wandering around after a movie at the Roxy, drunk and slightly stoned on the way home, what is this?  Sicilian slices and a boombox blaring Sleep's Dopesmoker?  Twist my fucking arm.
author: Mike A.

description: The BEST slice in the city, THE BEST SLICE IN THE CITY,  pizza so nice ya gotta tell people twice.
author: t h.

description: The crust is thin and the sauce/cheese ratio is good. After that I hate it. You get no old school oven flavor which is a MUST for me. The sauce is really bland. The cheese is fine I suppose. If you want a mushroom slice, they put fresh mushroom slices on it and warm it. Weak! All members of the staff look like they have something against toilet paper and laundry detergent. I think half the New Yorker types that rave about this pizza are just into something that reminds them of their childhood back when everything tasted good. The other half just have bad taste. After reading these reviews, I feel like I could go to New York and say to myself, "Yeah....., there's shitty pizza here too!"
author: Boxxxman J.

description: As close as it gets to NYC pie in the pizza-wasteland that is San Francisco.  Now if they only stayed open past last call.
author: Vernon B.

description:
I've never been to New York so I don't know ding about its comparison to a New York pizza. However, I was surprised at how good it tastes despite their hole-in-the-wall location. The cashier who rang me up and served me the pizza gave me this look when I asked him if I could have it to go. Their solution: dump it into a paper bag.

Nevertheless, Arinell is perfect for a cheap and quick pizza fix.
author: Ricky H.

description: Pay no  attention to the people behind the counter, but behave yourself-no cell phones in the store! If you follow the rules, you are rewarded with the closest NY pizza in this city and county, hands down. You wanna fight about it?
author: Hans H.

description: It is hot, cheap, and a little greasy - sounds like a hooker right? The pizza at Arinell's is not gourmet, but it sure is tasty. Nothing fancy here, just large slices of delicious pizza. The place is tiny and there is always a line. There are no plates and only a few stools to sit on. But you will notice that everyone there is eating there pizza with a smile - because pizza is rad!
author: Dana H.

description: Pretty damn good pizza. If it wasn't so far to go for me I might add a star but by the time I drive up from San Jose to the Mission, I usually end up at Pancho Villas or Ti Couz or Limon. But here you can get a great slice of Za!!!
author: Johnny J.

description: The ONLY pizza joint outside of a small island that Native Americans sold for some wampum that is worth the parking nightmare that accompanies the Mission.  Perfect crust, gooey yummy mozarella, no gourmet pomp and circumstance, and swivel stools while you wait. Dig it.
author: Ben S.

description: I want to give this place one star in honor of the owner that would rather have his place unknown just so that the annoying marina crowd doesnt visit and ask for pesto.  That is an attrocity.  Arinell has ruined me, now I am a closet pizza snob.  Marina peeps, please go to cable car pizza, i hear its really good, trust me.  They like you over there, they really do ^_^.  They can speak pasty-white like you do in the marina.  Trust me, please.  They wont spit in your food if you smell like marina-scum.
author: H C.

description: The best pizza in town, hands down! It's that Jersey Shore style pizza or South Street style. I love it. I miss the days when I used to hump one of the doughboys and I'd get free slices every day. It's worth the $2.50 though to be rid of him, yech.
author: Colleen B.

description: Of course its not NY pizza, we are not in NY.  But its damn close, and that counts for a lot around here.   Maybe they could spend a few bucks so it doesnt look like a crack den in there.   It looks like an abandoned shack when closed.    Damn fine pizza though, damn fine.
author: Dan G.

description: Perhaps it is because I went here before I was wasted instead of after, but I was not impressed.  If this is really close to being just like true NY pizza, as I have been told,  you are much better off sticking to other CA approximations.
author: Amy M.

description: a little grubby, but this place is the real deal and a great call for a late night slice.  After years of "escape from new york" slices on Haight, this place is much better.
author: Jim M.

description: hands down, the best new york-style pizza in the city. skip the toppings and go for the plain cheese. i would usually never say such a thing, but the cheese pie is perfect as-is. eat in or carry out only. what a shame they don't deliver.
author: Brett W.

description: Good, thin crust, NY-style pizza.  Nice surly staff and slices come out of the oven super hot.  My only gripe would be that the pizza sauce is only so-so... not as tangy as I like it.... and they close to early, forcing people to eat at Cable Car (1-2 stars) next door when they're in need of a late night slice.
author: David S.

description:
The 5 stars are for the best quick slice of pizza in town. Don't try to compare this to sit-down places like Pauline's Pizza. That's unfair and you'll be disappointed by the good reviews.

I can't believe that I used to go to Cable Car, which is a few doors down. This place looks a little sketchy from the outside, and probably from the inside too if you're not familiar with the Mission. Give it a chance. Go with the plain cheese slice. Plus, this is the place to go if you must have death metal blaring from the boom box with your 'za. It seriously does add character to the place.

The only bummer is it closes too early to grab a drunken slice after you're stumbling home from the local bars. Ah, thus why I only used to go to Cable Car.
author: Patrick M.

description: As a New Jersey transplant, I have been on a perpetual quest to find good pizza in San Francisco.  After 14 years of searching, I can honestly say that Arinell is my favorite "pizza by the slice" restaurant .  Sure, there are many other high-end pizza places in SF with great pizza, but if you find yourself with only a few dollars in your pocket, Arinell is the place to go.  When I chow down a nice thin slice of pizza, perhaps it is the heavy metal rock and roll playing in the background, or the garlic powder and parmesan shakers on the counter that remind me of my youth in the Garden State.  A happy food flashback without the three thousand mile trip is definitely worth it.
author: Wayne H.

description: The crust is too thin and flimsy for my taste, but the sauce is good as is the sauce-to-cheese ratio.  My OCD side is troubled by the fact that these pizzas are not round, but squareish, resulting in irregularly-shaped (and sized) slices.  I wish they had takeout boxes instead of bags, though, because these slices are super greasy and when I try to take them home (a few blocks away) the bag is practically disintegrated from all the oil.
author: Jen W.

description: The closest one will get to authentic east coast pizza. I have to walk on the other side of the street due my obsession with their cheese slices. Bet on it.
author: Kenny G.

description: I agree with the people who say there is not enough sauce.  The thin crust was very nice and crispy.  2 slices of cheese and a small soda $6 for lunch, taxes included in pricing for simplicity always nice.  Good, but not wowed in anyway beyond the fact that it is thin which you can't find too many places.  When I went for a second slice, I was curious whether most people got 1 or 2 slices and the guy was sort of unfriendly to me saying "I don't know" which I find hard to believe if he works at the place.  Still, worth hitting up if in the area.  Small eating area, which I imagine would be a problem when it gets busy, unless you can bring the slice into a bar.  Other items of note is that they had a sign saying they only added a little salt to the dough, which I like since I hate overly salty pizza, and they won't take your order if you are on your cell phone, which I think is reasonable as I find this practice to be rude myself.
author: Marc S.

description: Great thin crust pizza! Plain cheese. Really greasy. Great! Mean cooks listen to lots of metal.
author: Jeremiah M.

description: A place where both me and my husband can both satisfy our different pizza preferences--he likes deep dish and I like Neapolitan-style pizza. The mushrooms are cooked in a little bit of garlic before being added to the pizza...yum! Note: cash only
author: Dee L.

description:
the pizza i admit was good. nice and thin and chewy. i'm not a new york style pizza critic, so it was good enough for me.

they have a sign that says that they use no sugar and MSG, and only use salt in the leavening process. i find that very respectable.

as of feb 17th or so their prices will rise to 2.75 for a slice of cheese pizza. as opposed to 2.50

the place def has character i must say. rock band types making your pizza, and heavy metal blasting thru the speakers, a spray painting of the city on the counter. a couples of barstools.... but reading some of the yelp reviews going there, i was prepared for the dirty factor.

theres this dude outside smoking, i walk in, order a cheese pizza, the guy picks it up with his spatula, slides it in to the oven to heat it up, i wait a min, he takes it back out and slaps it down on a sheet of wax paper. sprinkle some some cheese on it, and its super hot and toasty, i eat....

in walks in the dude that was smoking outside, he walks behind the counter, and goes right into making pizzas.... AWESOME.... 

other guy wipes his nose on the lower part of his apron. well at least he's not using his hands right???

i know, the real good pizza joints in new york are ghetto and dirty, blahblahblah....

its good. but i just took comfort in the fact that i am hoping the oven just scorched all the germs on my pizza. 

its quite an experience. i'd probably go again. in the day time of course.
author: Irene C.

description: Hands down, my favorite pizza.  I don't even normally go for plain cheese, but here, I don't know what it is--the sauce, the cheese, the crust?  If you've read about the hygiene of their workers, you'll know why I'm afraid to dig too deep into their secret recipe.
author: M A N I K.

description: For your greasy true East Coast Style Pizza Arinell's is the place. Scruffy dirty boys who could care less about serving you but delish pizza.
author: Alyssa C.

description: This place comes highly recommended and I can see why but I wasn't blown away by the pizza.  In fact I was a bit disturbed with the operation in the kitchen and by the oil dripping from the slice on my way to dolores park....but then again those things add character and tastiness.
author: Debbie Y.

description: Forgive me Father for I have sinned! I used to call this joint "Arinelli's" instead of "Arinell's". Delivery:Nope. But great thin (nyc style) pizza.  Prime location at 16th and Valencia. Inexpensive slam dunk when you're in the mood for pizza.
author: Phil M.

description: Don't think this place qualifies as 'cheap', as another reviewer exclaims, but it sure does hit those 'G' spots...grateful and gorged. it's just a perfect balance of crust, zesty sauce, cheese and in my case, mushrooms. I ordered the medium sized pizza, and it's just about as big as a large at most other places.
author: Chris C.

description: I have been going to Arinell's for so long. I don't even remember life without Arinell's. I'm sure it wasn't very good. Anyway, I have had pizza in italy and in New York. Both New York AND Arinell's doesn't compare to italia of course, but Arinell's definitely resembles New York pizza. The sauce is the same consistency (not so thick) and has a  similar taste (not too sweet OR too salty). The crust is thin and crisp and the slices are huge!
author: Josie A.

description: one word YUM!! the pizza is always fresh and best of all the prices are so .
author: Joiera C.

description: Yay! I'm a fan.  I decided to go here when I was surfing on Yelp and had a huge craving for pizza.  I just so happened to be in the neighborhood that I had to check it out.  My first impression was not a real good one...it looked dirty, the staff didn't look all that clean themselves, but hey, I had to give them a try.  I bought two slices of their cheese pizza.  Not bad for $2.75 a slice.  Tasty slices of thin crust pizza.  I would have preferred mine with more cheese and sauce but good otherwise.  My 3 year old son ate a whole slice by himself! Now that's a good pizza!
author: Jerome H.

description: Yes - it's a tiny dingy hole in the wall with 6 stools in an area where you can't blame them for tying down the tip jar. Yes - the personnel doesn't quite look like they have undergone OSHA training. But guess what kids --- once you taste the pizza you really don't care. It is super thin, pleasantly greasy (so that you can rip off the crust and run it along the glistening pockets of happiness), cheap ($2.50 for a HUGE slice of cheese), and magical. So suck it up and reap the benefits.
author: Natalie G.

description: I can't speak to this small joint's New York authenticity, but it works for me -- fast, cheap, and tasty. Too bad parking in the area isn't easier, but that's just the way it is. An ideal place to grab a slice while in between destinations in the Mission, in need of some grub. I always go for the plain-cheese variety.
author: Tara M.

description: New York style = thin crust, slight crunch, plain cheese (no toppings), sold by the (large) slice. The sauce here is great, kind of sweet and tangy but not overdone. The last time I went there, the pizza was kind of cold, though. For New York pizza in San Francisco, it's the best place.
author: John C.

description: Classic NY pizza.  Great stuff.   I once saw a woman bitch and complain because the cashier didn't wash his hands after touching her money.   If you worry about things like that, you really shouldn't eat here.  Oh yeah, the staff there is metal. \m/  If you can't handle it, stay away.
author: Larry A.

description: Being born in NYC and now living in SF I had to try this pizza. This is probably the closest thing to NY Pizza in the Bay Area. The crust is just right but the sauce lacks flavor. If you order any toppings they just slap it on and put it in the oven so it's best to just get a cheese slice. Also the pizza is not round but it's the taste that matters. =)
author: Keoni U.

description:
i never knew what good pizza was until i went to new york: thin crust, baby!  i was deprived and kept in the closet for 19yrs!  and i've always loved me some pizza...

years later, this place is reminscent of that....  the bread should not be the focus of a pizza...  the sauce must be stellar, and the ratio of sauce, cheese, and bread should compliment each other.  i love the slices!  you can fold 'em -- another way i learned how to eat pizza in nyc!
author: Sheri N.

description: The only reason i gave it 4 instead of 5 is because the slice was cut akward but i was hungry and i didn't care! real new york slice, you just fold it over, thin crust, always good.
author: Chris D.

description: Nothing compares to a New York Pizza.  However, this is the best pizza place in the city.  I
author: Carine C.

description: It's a hole in the wall and well frequented.  My kids love the pizza, and we came back 2 nights in a row on a recent visit.  The slices are thin but huge. The dough is thin and crispy.  Plus, it's affordable.
author: N B.

description: This is my favorite pizza in the city, hands down!  They do true NY style no frills thin crust pies that are just the bomb.  I would absolutely go for the full fresh pizza over a simple rebaked slice.  I've got to deduct half a star because they don't deliver. With all the new delivery sites, there's got to be a way to get these guys on the list.
author: Kelly W.

description: Totally legit NY style pizza with no pretensions on being anything but what it is. However, the crust itself is...crunchy? I'm used to a little sloppier crust that can barely hold what's on it from nyc actually. But this is a good thing that it has a crunchy crust, the cheese to sauce ratio is usually perfect, and I usually just get a plain cheese slice. It's the way to go! I like how they cut it different triangular lengths that are larger than normal slices. That way you can fold it  with no problems!  And watch that hot grease drip....mmmm....so good!
author: Gina R.

description: Fantastic NY style pizza, Marcello's is still my favorite by a hair though...
author: Max C.

description: Everything that you read about this joint on this site is true.  I stopped in during a visit from Yuba City, CA.  The pizza was EXCELLENT!  The toppings were many and the crust was crisp.  The place was dirty.  The guy working the register partook of the mary jane.  There really wasn't much of a place to eat.  There was a total of 6 bar stools and two tables hanging off the wall (about 18" deep).  I just wish that this joint wasn't so far away.  This would be my pizza of choice in the local area.  This IS my pizza of choice for San Francisco!
author: Robert A.

description: Pizza is Noo Nork stastic.  Just get there early before all the drunkies get out.  You don't want to eat here, it's pretty small and grimy, but pizza is excellent.
author: ronzilla x.

description:
5 stars, as I can't figure out 4 1/2.  Some trick I'm missing?
Anyway, though I'm from CA, my parents are both from the east (mom NY, dad Boston) so we'd spend every summer there, and y'know what?  I was convinced until last week that we in the land of fruits and nuts were incapable of making real pizza.  On our East Coast travels, we rarely eat anything but pizza.  Even the crappy chain pizzerias back east are better than all the "gourmet" stuff (sorry, but garlic roasted chicken pizza with cheese in the crust and a side of ranch dressing is not edible) our great state offers.  Though I still do not comprehend the reason for this, I have learned over the last 30 years to accept it.  We have better weather, bla bla bla.  Anyway, I had heard about Arinell's, but I'd already been burned twice on my quest for pizza.  But I was stuck in the mission the other day, so I went in for a slice.  It wasn't even that fresh, but it tasted......It tasted like PIZZA!!  Thin, foldable, greasy, not too heavy on anything.  Maybe that's the secret?  It's not smothered in stuff that doesn't belong on pizza?  I don't know, but I'm going back soon, and I'm bringing my parents.
author: Alexander T.

description: All I can say is that I'm happy to have found a place where I can actually eat a slice of pizza and not make a face...it brings light to my pizza-less world. I gave it a 75% in comparision to NY pizza. That's pretty damn high...for pizza in SF. As Robert V. says, I too probably wouldn't indulge in Arinell's pizza in NY...but I'm grateful for it to be in SF. I did find it amusing that to guys behind the counter were drinking tecate while cleaning up and serving the last minute customers.
author: Anita C.

description:
my only qualm is... it is so crispy and thin, you cant fold it! or maybe that's a good thing?

 Delicious pizza served to you by metal-babies.
author: alexis g.

description: Ya, if you dig NY style pizza, this is the place in San Francisco. No frills - get a cheese slice (toppings just kill the mood), roll up and eat. Oh, hope you like death metal, since that seems to be genre of choice for the rotating cast of stoners that work the register. Try not to make things too complex or they just stare at you in confusion. I asked one guy for a slice with no cheese and he started drooling.
author: Jay N.

description: Finding a great slice of pizza in this town is no small feat...however Arinell definitely comes the closest to pulling off the east coast pizza.  I'm still not sure if it can be compared to NY pizza since the slices are not nearly as big, but it reminds me of Roberto's or Ponessa's back in PA.
author: Kelan T.

description: I don't eat pizza much in San Francisco because I usually am disappointed.  Arinell Pizza is the exception.  This is a legitimate New York style pizza slice and my go to place if I want something that comes even close to resembling the taste of a slice of pizza in New York.  I just wish this place was open late night; Arinell's could clean up.
author: Josh K.

description: I love the thick and chunky Sicilian slices, just like home in NY. Probably better to do take out, but the staff were nice when I was there early Friday night.
author: Shannon B.

description: Alright, I love pizza.  Really. I started saying it was my favorite food when the rest of us did around age 11.  So I enjoyed this pizza, but sadly, I didn't love it.  I got a slice of sausage and the re-warmed slice just had the little balls of sausage rolling around on it when they gave it to me. It was good, but I actually expected more from a cool looking, hole in the wall pizza place.
author: Levi B.

description: Want a great slice of cheese pizza for a great price, with a slice of attitude on the side? This is your place.
author: Jeshua B.

description:
of course what i'm about to say is true to most places.......

it's better fresh!

they don't allow cellphone usage. the guys that work there look like they're in a band. they listen to loud rock music which just makes me wanna go home and play GH3!!!! ;)

back to the food....you can't beat the $2.50/slice price! I get cheese only & it is YUM! tried the sicilian too, it's just as yummy. btw, they don't use plates, just a flimsy piece of parchment paper. it's not the cleanest place but it's great for a quick slice or pie.
author: Chris L.

description:
you go in , you order a slice, some grungy dude or dudette cuts a slice, tosses it in the oven takes your money and you are done.

the pizza is thin, crispy, chewy* and delicious.

what else is there to say?  theres this place across the street from me that gives a pizza slice twice as big.. but the pizza is fracking nasty.  arinells is a mile away, but id rather go there, and went like 7 times in the last 3 weeks.

*while being crispy, its still requires a lot of chewing, and my jaw muscles are always fatigued after eating a slice.
author: Irvin S.

description: Hands down my favorite thin crust pizza in SF.  Brings me back to my east coast roots.  Great spot for a slice in between bloody marys at your favorite local watering hole on a weekend morning.  Service isn't very good (I've already been there at night and they've told me they were out of pizza- why are you still open then???) but they really have the recipe right.  I can overlook alot for pizza that good.
author: Zach J.

description: Best NY style pizza in the city by far.  I love all pizza, but this place is seriously one of the best pizza joints I've been to in my whole life.  Crust is awesome, sauce is awesome, cheese is awesome.  Very hole in the wall, cramped and hard to find a seat, but hey, this place wasn't really meant to be a sit down kinda place.  I like how their pizzas aren't perfectly round too -- rustic.  HUGE slices, so good!!  And cheap!
author: Latef X.

description: A great slice.  Just keep in mind that the neighborhood, joint, and employees are crusty too and you're good.
author: Katie E.

description: It's really yummy - thin, chewy crust, good flavor. It's better to go at a busy time, when fresh pies will be coming out of the oven regularly. Or, if the pie's been sitting for a while, make them heat up your slice...otherwise, they will serve you a semi-cold slice.
author: Amanda S.

description: Big, floppy, drippy slices served up straight from the oven.  This New York-style slice joint on the Mission brings authentic New York flavor to San Francisco.  The slice is huge and the service is quick.  There's not much room here, so this is a place to grab some pizza and inhale it while you're standing there.  Mmm.
author: Apollo L.

description: Clearly the wonderful slices at Arinells are no secret,  given the near 300 reviews of the place.  I love it.   IMO the best slice you're gonna find in the Bay Area.  The fact that it's all take-out and you're gauranteed to get hit up by at least five bums on your way in and out (and possibly while you're inside) makes it 4stars instead of five.
author: Raj M.

description: Best new york style pizza i've had so far in SF.  Both sicilian and regular versions......but i'm fron new york so no one will be 5 stars from me...Sf does taquerias...not pizzerias...
author: Francis K.

description: A couple of my friends swear that Arinell's has better pizza than any of the neo-pizza, less-greasy joints like LIttle Star and Pauline's. OK, yes, Arinell's is one of the best places to grab a NY-style slice, load it with parmesan and red pepper flakes, and sit on a creaky stool chewing to the beat of whatever the guys working there happen to be blasting from the speakers.
author: elsa m.

description: Best NY pizza I've had outside of NY, from what I can remember.   Still not perfect or mind blowing but it is pretty darn good.   The crust is ultra-thin and still lightly crisply.  It's easy to go in and grab a couple slices and finish them by the time you walk to the BART.
author: Erick Z.

description: Best NY style street slice in this city.  PERIOD!  Crisp thin crust, tangy sauce and just the right amount of cheese.  The crew may look rough, but they're there to toss pies, and they handle the job with aplomb.  Also, watch out for them to run out of pie around midnight...
author: Don N.

description: The place and the counter help doesn't look appeasing from the outside, but the pizza makes up for it big time.   Nice thin slices that melt in your mouth.  Kinda reminds me when Woolworth's used to sell pizza on Powell St in the 70's with the fruit punch and lemonade.   Sure, it's a grease-bomb, but a good one at that.
author: Richie W.

description: My favorite slice in SF. Not the best slice I have ever had in my life, but good NY style slices in the city!
author: Adrienne G.

description: I'm a New Yorker who loves good pizza. This is the first REAL New York slice of pizza I've had on the west coast. I don't know how they do it but they should sell their recipe to the other million pizza joints who claim to taste like NY pizza.
author: Michelle C.

description: This place is excellent, and being one of two Neal(e)s from Baltimore, I often get confused in conversation with the one who works here. I take off one star for not giving me free pizza when I was DRESSED AS A GIANT SLICE OF PIZZA on Halloween (see user pic). Actually I would gladly have payed for it if I hadn't left my wallet at home.  But, still--where's the pizza solidarity?
author: Neale S.

description: Last time I was here their huge slice of cheese pizza cost me about $2.50. Several years later, on a recent visit, I was shocked and appalled to learn that the same freakin amazing slice of pizza cost me $2.75. I ate the huge slice of deliciousness happily and mozied my way down to some place down the street to grab a beer with someone.
author: joolia f.

description: Among the best NY style in the Bay Area.  No seating, I usually to a to-go "drive by."
author: Narendra R.

description: Long story short, pizza in California sucks. Other than Arinell's, that is. Its one of the only places in the city where you can find true New York style thin crust pizza, and the only place in the city where it is perfect.
author: Ron A.

description: I'm surprised I haven't reviewed this joint yet, it used to be a favorite of mine when I lived in the Mission.  A regular Sunday stop on my stroll of Valencia ... now I stop in when I'm in the neighborhood for a quick slice.
author: Derek D.

description: Oh please, don't tell me that NY style pizza dwells anywhere near this place. It doesn't. All they serve is California style thin crust pizza. Not the same at all. Not at all.
author: Bruce C.

description: This is one off the few pizza places you can go grab a slice at- its thin and delicious (why is that so hard to do in SF?!?) Its perfect for when you are out drinking in the area and need to get some food in the belly asap.  I also really like the sicilian here- its one of the few places that 1) actually serves sicilian and 2) they do it right- the dough is light, lots of cheese & a good amount of sauce- yummm. The only problem is that a full sicilian pie to go $30! yes, $30- ridiculous, yet I find myself paying it when the craving strikes.
