author: Jane K.

description: All you whiners should stop.  This is a fine place for a fine piece of pizza.  And yes I'm from NY.  Of course, this place isn't as good as Lombardi's in Manhattan, or Nick's Pizza in Queens.  But if you can find a better place in SF, message me.  And no, Giorgio's isn't better.
author: Augie C.

description: I must preface my review by saying that I have never been to New York.  But, by my reckoning, this is one of the better New York-style pizza places in the city.
author: Kelvin K.

description: Punk rock pizza, oops, I mean Arinell's is the best I've had so far. The pizza gets 5 stars, the pizza dudes gets three.
author: Andy L.

description: Real New York style pizza, quick, cheap, thin and greasy. Sells by the slice, yum.
author: C D.

description: Being a NYC transplant and spoiled by the NY slice , good pizza by the slice is hard to find anywhere else although while walking along one day I ran in here for a quick bite, to my surprise it was the closet I have had to the NY slice. I will be going back, and suggest that any New Yorker looking for a bit of home go here.
author: Christopher M.

description: the best anytime of day, especially when you have a belly full of beer.
author: Roxana O.

description:
oh well, i burned my mouth again.  it was worth it.

i refer to this spot as rude boy pizza, and would probably be speechless if one of the dudes behind the counter asked me how i was doing.  i like it this way, and it's probably good for turnover, since the pizzeria is the mad tiny one!

it's no di fara's on avenue j, and no carmine street joe's, but we're in SF.  i surely can dig it.
author: Gillian B.

description: As another east coast transplant, I too have searched the city far and wide to find a slice of home. I have since resigned myself to the belief that it is a fool's quest and the closest thing I can find to a 'quick thin-crust slice' is Arinell's. No, it's not the same, but it does at least give you hope that east coast pizza is somehow possible to make on the west coast. They make all their dough the morning of and when they are gone, they are closed.
author: Arash A.

description: Greasy.  Crispy.  Amazing.  It might be among the best pizza that I've ever had, which is all the more remarkable considering that it is practically impossible to find decent pizza (I mean real pizza, not some gourmet thing on a crust that calls itself "pizza" but isn't) in San Francisco.  The fact that the guys who work there remind me of Jay and Silent Bob is a nice bonus.
author: Melanie C.

description: One of the best places in the area to go for a quick, cheap slice. Get it to go (only a few stools in a small cramped space) and get it with the fresh garlic. Yum.
author: SL N.

description: If you want a slice on the go in the Mission then this is the place.  There's not much they do too well and it certainly isn't worth calling ahead for whole pie w/ other, better, choices nearby.
author: don d.

description: I prefer thin crust and this the best pizza I have ever had outside of New York City. But it ain't ny pizza unless NYC water is used in the dough. Its San Francisco pizza and its amazing. Most of the staff are complete slackers, so plan on having to ask them to actually FILL the glass of soda for which you've just paid. That is a small matter, the pie truly is incredible. Mmmmm, I am hungry just thinking about it...
author: Heather G.

description: If I didn't have to watch my figure, I'd probably have arinell's at least once a day.  If you're looking for good New York style thin crust pizza, this is the place to go.  Share a whole pie with a friend (this is probably why I can't eat this everyday) or get a slice late night.  It's goooood stuff.
author: Jen L.

description: I prob eat here once  a week at least. It's funny--the pizza can vary a bit and sometimes isn't as good. But usually it's amazing. I always heard New Yorkers say NY pizza this NY pizza that blah blah blah and never understood what they were talking about. Now I do--not sure what it is--very simple cheese slice but it's sooo delic.
author: Gregory M.

description: By FAR the best thin crust NY-style pizza in all of San Francisco (and one in Berkeley, too)  Too bad they close early, as I always want one of their slices when I'm out at the bars on Valencia.
author: Tom K.

description: classic street corner, nyc style. on a recent trip i was reminded of little italy , carnival cart pizza, mmmm. cheesey, very basic, thin, and piping hot slices served just on wax paper, a bronx tradition, i was told by the owner, Ron Demirdjian. Arinell only hires the surliest grunge/metal/bearded teddy bear pizza makers in California. they may look intimidating, but they are sweet as pizza pie, i swear. ever notice this place does no have any female staff? kinda odd, Ron.
author: casey c.

description: went here late night sat for a slice of pizza. was so unbelievably good, i had three.
author: John D.

description: Great thin crust slices served with heavy metal blaring! Arinell has saved my drunk ass many a night!
author: Gabe L.

description: Thin Crust or deep dish, plain cheese is best or have a party and get a giant pie.  Friendly service by the local Rocker Staff, always good, never lets you down, and check out the old school retro picture of the city below the counter!
author: Zach H.

description:
Arinell's will sell dough balls to interested customers who want to bake their own pies at home.  

I've worked with the dough on several occasions, and it's outstanding.  Just the right balance of firmness and elasticity.  The kind of dough a pizza cook dreams about.  I cannot overstate this.  

The resulting crust has a texture and taste that a friend remarked would make an excellent standalone bread.  

Arinell's other ingredients come up short, however.  I may be wrong, but it looks like they use canned pre-made sauce, and it doesn't have the right chemistry with the cheese they use.  It comes sooo close, though.  Don't bother ordering anything else but a cheese slice because other toppings only get added on before a reheating, so how can you expect that they'll cook fully?  

Otherwise, it has all the accoutrements of a hole-in-the-wall pizza joint.  The atmosphere reeks of authenticity, and the lo-fi hesher rock blaring from the back is the icing on the cake.
author: Daniel M.

description:
take a step back and breathe in the ambiance of Slayer and melting mozzarella upon entry to Arinell's.  Speed Metal and thin crust pie go hand in hand in this Yelper's opinion.

Pie there is absolutely incredible.  Cheesy, sweet, dough is almost non-existent, thin slice pizza does the trick....even sober!

Do not forget the weird pickled peppers near the register.  Alone, the pie is mad at you for forgetting to go down in almost spicy flames.  Not kidding.
author: Karl H.

description: Came across this magnificent find while gallivanting in the Mission. East Coast style thin crust pizza served by guys who look like they're stoned, drunk, just woke up, or all the above. Their friends in dreadlocks came and went. There are less than a half dozen seats in the whole place so be ready to chomp down the slices standing up. One of the few places where when you finish one slice, you want another one even more.
author: Reiko Y.

description:
My husband and I had just eaten a burrito each and walked by Arinell.  The thin crust cheese pizza by the slice caught our attention, so we walked in and ordered a slice to share.  The server, who had just returned change to the customer before us, used his hand (no gloves), picked up our slice, and put it into the oven to warm up.  He then took our money, helped the next customer, and later served us our pizza.  I had already seen him do this a couple of times, but my husband just had that lightbulb go off on his head and whispered, "Did you notice that he touched our pizza with the same hands that touched the money?" to which I answered, "Yeah, but he put our pizza into the oven, so hopefully the heat killed all the germs."  I'm pretty sure he slid the pizza onto the paper for us rather than touch it again with his hands, but I don't know that for sure.  Pretty much what we decided was that if they were closed down, we wouldn't have the best NY style pizza ever!

Pizza is extremely thin, although a little floppy but still crispy.  If I were eating my entire meal there, I would definitely need two slices though.  The place has about 6-8 chairs, so it's really meant for take out. 

The bottom line with the health part is "caveat emptor" - it's up to you whether you'd still go after knowing this.  I would certainly return!
author: Rose C.

description:
I've been looking for a good slice of pizza since I moved to SF from NYC, and Arinell's is the closest so far. While there's some sort of a chemically tang that I just can't put my finger on, I ignore it since the look, feel and taste are the closest to the east village that I've found.  But then again, if Arinell were in NYC I'd never go there and probably say it was crappy. For SF pizza, though, I give it 4 stars. In NYC, think I'd give it a 2.  But then again, it doesn't come with the price tag of a $500 ticket to NYC.  And it satisfies my craving to some extent when I'm dying for NY pizza.
I hope some day they will be delivering, since I'd definitely order more often if it weren't for the trek there. 
The only other negative is the people who work there are kind of douches, but that's fine.  I'm not there for the ambiance and I guess if I had to serve slices to a bunch of hipsters all day I'd probably be the same way.
author: A J.

description: If you want ok/decent slice with a crap attitude, this is your spot. They talk shit about you while they serve you . It is in the neighborhood and I suggest walking a few doors down to what used to be the former Cable Car (open till 3am)  now Thrill of the Grill and get decent pizza served with a decent attitude. We all know how Mission customers can be, obnoxious, drunk, demanding and oblivious, but these guys no matter what, have the irritability and lousy customer service of a bunch of strung-out teenagers coming down from some serious drugs and are super slow from wake-and-all-day-bake. But, hey it is  a quick slice if that's what you are after. The "holier-than-thou, elitist" attitude from a bunch of misanthropes is going to blow you away. Having lived in NYC for 20 years, i can tell you the only thing "east coast" about this pizza is the thin crust, but thats where it ends.
author: lee c.

description: wow! by far the best "new york" pizza ive had outside of new york.  its a hole in the wall and they have a surly vibe  but whatever  great pizza
author: Jake L.

description: So we kept hearing that this place has NY-style pizza. Not from people who are like all, oh yeah, I love Escape from New York pizza, which by the way, is just repulsive -- but that's another review. From former New Yorkers, and Jersey folk, people who would know. Surprisingly, they were right. Thin, no gobs of sauce, no freaking vegetables, really tasty cheese, and death metal on the stereo.
author: Cindy Y.

description: Legit New York Stylee pizzeria pizza. Yes, I am from Chicago but prefer NY style pizza. Get two slices, one on top of another, fold, eat while walking down the street. Or, change it up and get a corner of Sicilian.
author: alistair g.

description: Best pizza in San Francisco bar none. When moving out here from PA approximately 11 years ago the first thing I realized would not ever be the same as it was in Philadelpia is the quality of one slice at a time style pizza. It was either too thick, or too thin, too much sauce or not enough. This stuff is about as close as you could come to the real thing as any place I have been to since moving here. That being said, the place is a bit too small for my taste and the guys look like they just stepped out of a Quiet Riot concert.
author: Salvatore R.

description: This is probably my favorite quick/cheap pizza in the Mission (can't quite live up to Little Star, but it's not that kind of joint).  You can count on a number of things when you walk into this place.  1. You're going to get a really good slice (I personally prefer the Sicilian).  2. Whoever is working behind the counter is going to be loaded on some drug or other.  3. When you walk in, they probably aren't going to care too much.  Customer service not top notch, but I suppose it adds to the charm of the place.
author: doug s.

description: I think Arinell's is one of  the best slices in SF. Thin, crispy from being reheated in the oven a little greasy... simple and pretty damn good. I am not going to say that the sauce is perfect or the dough is right or even that the cheese is good I am just going to say that the total package... a slice coming out of the oven truly satisfies my craving for a real slice of pizza. Of course it has its off days and gruff customer service..but come on your going for a NYC slice. I am  more wary of the take out pizza ... steams in the box.. It can be good but my advice is don't do it... we are talking slices here people totally different animal than a pizza eaten in a restaurant.... why would you bother in the Bay Area anyway?
author: Ben S.

description: Five stars during the night shift, and three during the day... defenitly drops in the day time, but worth it if you are in the neighborhood.
author: Nick D.

description: The pizza is really good here -particularly if you like New York (or NJ if your me) style slices. Served on wax paper only adds to the whole experience. Although it's weird that nobody is representing the guido-italian side of making pizzas. It's straight rockers up in there... playing poorly produced heavy metal tapes (loudly). I suppose its appropriate in the mission, but I wouldn't keep going back for the ambiance or lack there of. I will go back for the f**kin good pizza again, and again, and again.
author: HiFive E.

description:
it would get a higher rating...

...if the pizza were consistently great (sometimes they don't put enough cheese on or it's overcooked)
...if they had, maybe, 5 more toppings to choose from. I'm not asking for a lot!
...if they accepted credit cards or delivered

but mostly if the pizza were consistently great... it's annoying to feel like you're rolling the dice.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Arinells Pizza is a horrific establishment that has literally killed my love for pizza. My boyfriend and I recently stopped by around 10pm on a Saturday night, looking for a couple of hot, low-fi slices to enjoy after a long evening at Dolores Park. 

We were immediately off put by the disgustingly greasy, old, and unattractive slices displayed in the glass pizza cabinet, but tried to remain optimistic that the fresh slices that they make to order would be better. We apprehensively order a slice of cheese pizza with olives, bell peppers, and mushrooms. The attendant informs us that toppings are $.75 each, almost as if to deter us from ordering any toppings whatsoever. 

My boyfriend notes that the price is not an issue, as at this point we had decided against Little Star Pizza after being informed that the wait would be approximately 25minutes for dinner. If only we had stayed at Little Star! But more about that later. . 

Instead  of constructing a fresh slice, our Heroin-addled, greasy, anorexic attendant, whose smile shown of tooth decay and dental neglect, grabbed a slice of thin, greasy cheese pizza and threw a big soggy handful of olives, bell peppers, and pre-cooked mushrooms onto the pizza, and charged us $4.75 for what was the least attractive serving of food I've seen in years. At this point, the eye contact between my boyfriend and I shrieked: "Why didn't we just go to El Farolito's?!?!?" but we stayed and awaited our Arinells slice. 

After about 15 seconds in the oven, we were handed our slice of lukewarm pizza. We both took bites, and soon discovered that this slice was the blandest, soggiest food we'd ever eaten. There were No, I repeat no redeeming factors to this slice. First of all, the toppings looked old and canned. The pizza itself had a millimeter of cheap greasy cheese covering tasteless sauce, and even the crust was soggy! 

Although my boyfriend protested, I brought the slice of pizza up to the front counter, explained that the slice was sub-par, and politely asked for a refund. The other pizza crony, who was apparently quite used to defending the joint's deplorable meals, noted that Arinells pizza slices "aren't designed to handle as many toppings." Not DESIGNED to handle toppings? In this case, wouldn't it be logical to advertise a one-topping max? 

Toothless heroin junkie was highly insistent on NOT giving me back my money, and at that points, we threw their slice of pizza in the trash and left. Although I was tempted to camp outside their restaurant and deter future customers from walking in and wasting their own hard earned American dollars on this joke, I decided to take the high road and walk down to El Farolito's instead. 

This place is a sad sad joke. I recommend Seniore's Pizza on 19th and Taraval instead.
author: julia s.

description:
As far as I know, this is the best NY-style pizza in SF (if you know a better place, let me know!). I noticed, as another reviewer did, that the cook was handling cash with the same hands he was handling the pizzas but I don't really care...we have to keep our immune systems alive :-)
I usually call ahead and order a full pie for pickup ($26 for a large pizza with two toppings).
Parking in that area sucks. There's a reasonably priced parking lot at 16th and Hoffe (on Hoffe) but it is often full on WE nights.
Those are all technicalities. What matters: the pizza tastes  AWESOME!!!
author: Matthieu L.

description: Best NYC style pizza I've ever had outside of NYC!  Marina people stay away!!!
author: Kevin D.

description: Before stuffing the last bit of our bacon wrapped hot dogs down our hungry mouths, Keane and I were already thinking ahead...what is going to satisfy our hunger?  The bacon dog was good, but we wanted variety.  We decided to stop in at Arinell for a slice of NY.  Touted for their NY-style pizza, we were game to try it.  The first thing you notice is that the slices come from super huge pies.  I was a little disappointed that they didn't have some sort of slice specials.  It's basically cheese pizzas to which they add the topping after you order.  I personally prefer my toppings to be cooked together, rather than just warmed up.  To their credit, their crust is thin and crispy.  Much better than some of the other NY-style joints that I've tried.  It almost reminded me of a Neopolitan pie, which is good thing.  It's a small shop with room for maybe 6-8 to sit/stand around.  This is something I'd have anytime of day...whether I'm intoxicated or not.  All in all for the night, it was a satisfying foodie excursion.  Two Mission specialties,  tackled successfully in 20 min...dare we try the Triple Threat (hot dogs, pizza, and taco/burritos) the next time?
author: JeFF T.

description: Wow. I cannot believe how many people give these guys 5 stars. I don't even care about the east vs. west pizza thing. The pizza is good, not great but indeed satisfying at a late hour post Delirium.....wait thats the problem with this place. The people who work there are douche-bags. They do coke in the bathroom (probably just crank and meth as coke is too expensive for a minimum wager) Their breaks are spent dancing and hitting up people for coke at Delirium. Then they show up at your party at 2am with a bunch of taggers and try to explain that "tagging" is an art and thats why you should be proud that it is in the hallway of your house. They tell you repeatedly that they work at Arinells...like you should be impressed by a dipshit rocker who can't wash his hands or get a decent job. Then they puke all over the sidewalk out front. Who the fuck invited these people....oh my dipshit upstairs neighbor. Well she's not invited anymore. Enjoy the free pizza. This doesn't even scratch the surface. Did I get into the cleanliness? I have seen these guys go in and out of the bathroom, then straight to the counter where they touch your slice, then your money, then your slice again. Yes and they have a cockroach problem. Don't believe me? Just go there and spend 3 bucks and think about where said Rocker Douche-bags hands have been as he hands you a slice. This should be a ZERO STAR REVIEW but YELP doesn't allow for ZERO STARS.
author: tex w.

description: Best NY-style thin crusty, oily, floppy slices in the city that my friends and I (east coast natives) have tasted. Served lightning fast by wait staff that looks the part.
author: Frank T.

description: this place sucks.  i once saw one of the dirty hippies drop the pizza slicer on the floor, pick it up, THEN START CUTTING PIZZA WITH IT.  needless to say, i didn't order anything that night and have never gone back.  how the dph continues to let this place stay open i'll never know...
author: Kenji K.

description: i only had a quick slice on the way to the airport, so i didn't think i woudl be able to give the quality my full attention...but one bite was enough for me.  i got a slice of cheese with black olives and was over the moon.  arinell's somehow manages to keep their thin crust from getting too greasy while also not skimping on the cheese.  the sauce was also super-fantastic-- loaded up with spices that gave it a nice kick along with the crunch.  if you're in the mood for a quick bite, i give this place two thumbs way up.
author: Aimee C.

description: hey kid it's okay za.... if you are a NY complainer, you will do fine here.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: Being a native New Yorker, the one thing I truly miss out here (in a culinary sense) is a decent slice of pizza. I'm talking thin, tangy and it droops & drips when you fold it in half to eat it. Well, Arinell's - on a good night - has that and it's a treat. I've been there a few times when the pie was a bit on the overcooked side and the sauce had no 'tang', but overall, it's worth it.
author: Lari B.

description: if youre from new york, think youre from new york, pretend to be from new york, or fantasize about moving to new york, chances are you will claim that this is the best pizza in san francisco, ALMOST as good as real pizza from new york, and and that all pizza is generally crap here. honestly ive never been to new york, dont plan to ever go to new york, and im from san francisco for 4 generations, but i will definately admit, this pizza is absolutely delicious. new york can suck my d***.
author: christopher a.

description: even if I just worked out, brushed my teeth, AND ate pizza all weekend I still have to eat a slice of my fav pizza in sf on the way to the airport as a "so long till next time" bon voyage. huge irregularly sliced, thin crusted, ny style pie served to you by not so smiley indie boys tapping their toes to some craptastic classic metal.  choose your topping of choice and you better be sure you like it cause it's gonna be a HUGE handful of the stuff. they also have a deep dish available but I can never sacrifice a chance to eat the thin to try the thick.
author: Eva L.

description: what a shithole, but what a pizza! thin, greasy and yummy. melts in your mouth. if you're craving for new york pizza, arinell is the real mccoy.
author: frisco j.

description: definetly a 4 stat place , one star off becuz their employees are extremely dry , pizza crust is one of the best in city
author: NAEL K.

description: tried to order some takeout and these guys were assholes.  no idea what the pizza tastes like.
author: Brian C.

description: This is hands down the best pizza in SF -- one of my biggest regrets is that my ex-New Yorker pizza lovin self didn't find it sooner!   Now I go out of my way to get their awesome slices (I can never get just one, and I'm little.)   ALSO, they used no refined sugar in their sauce, how awesome is that?!!  The only down side is some of their gutter punk staff members can sometimes be snarly if you're lookin too yuppie, but great things always come at a price no?   Grunge it up a bit if you want better service.
author: Hida V.

description: finally. pizza like i grew up eating. a crust that is thin and crispy. perfect amount of sauce and cheese. mmm. and it's on the way home. who needs ranch with a crust like this? if you like round table, don't try arinell.
author: Adrienne Y.

description: the longer i live here the more i realize that this is as close as sf gets to ny  slices.  often imitated, never duplicated. arinell's is just the bomb slice of cheesy goodness.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
the pizza is GOOD. i've never tried ny pizza, so don't know if it's a good ny style pizza. but the crust is thin and crispy. they basically have a huge cheese pizza, and if you want toppings, they throw it on, put it in the oven, and serve you.

the guy working at the counter handled both the food AND the money. which to me is quite disgusting. he had super greasy hair down to his belly button, a cracked front tooth, and a row of bullets for his belt. he was nice enough, just wished he had washed his hands in between. come to think of it, he reminds me of the dj guy from zoolander. ew.

the trick is to look away when the guy puts on your toppings. ignorance is bliss!
author: Aiko L.

description: The BEST pizza in the city.  That's it!  The BEST.  You can't get better.  Just get a cheese slice while you're there.  Don't get it with toppings, because they only put it on top and then stick it into the oven and that defies basic pizza chemistry, if you know what I mean.
author: Sophie B.

description: I had been going here on and off for years.  But all it takes now for me to blow a place off forever is being short-changed one time, and not getting an apology.   I'm gonna miss that slice hot out of the oven.  Not going to miss the dirty slacker-stoner that serves the pie, or the guy that makes the pie.  Supposedly, jobs are tough to get these days, but if these guys are employed, obviously anyone can get some type of job with minimal effort.
author: Ex C.

description: delicioso! i'm a huge fan of cheeeesy pizza with little to no sauce and this place definitely delivers! well, they don't deliver per se, but you know what i mean. cheapish and pretty quick, great pizza to eat on a night of drinking. all the greasy cheese makes an excellent sponge!
author: Meredith B.

description: This is NOT as good as NY pizza, folks.  It is better than that painful pizza place a couple doors down, but this is not NY.  Then, there's the the fact that I feel "funny" about 1/2 hour after I eat here-- everytime!  Even though the pizza goes down pretty well, that good feeling doesn't follow through.  SO, here's the good news-- they have a great crust.!  It's close to NY-style, with thinness, crispiness and the right level of char from the oven.  But, there never seems to be enough cheese or sauce on the Neapolitan-style.  And, the sauce (partly because of the lack of it) doesn't hold enough of its own savoury goodness (italian spices and hint of sweet garlic) than even EFNY's formula pies.  So, I have reservations about the thin crust sauce, cheese ratio.  Here's where they get KUDOS-- the Sicilian slice is where it's at.  For those of you ill-informed, that's the square kind where you get to choose whether you want an end or middle piece (if there's any left).  The dough (presumably the same as the thin but just more of it) on the Sicilian pie is the kind of fluffliness reminiscent of those family-style NY places with seemingly enough sauce and a good scatter of cheese- BUT, it's still not NY.  There is a totally logical reason for this being that NY WATER is different than SF water so the pizza dough (and the bagels, and the pretzels, and the street hotdogs) will never been the same.  Arinell gets 3 stars for trying and coming pretty damned close.
author: E L.

description: I am not sure what the allure of this dump is.  The thin crust is crisp but bland, the cheese is greasy and the other toppings are mediocre.  With so many other good places for food -- including pizza -- in the mission, I can't think why anybody who was sober would go here more than once.
author: Peter H.

description: i agree more or less with what michael y says.   3 stars (and im being nice), but i wouldnt mind swinging by a couple times a week bc its quick and cheap for a couple slices.  it's only somewhat vaguely familiar to new york style pizza (in the thin crust sense), but it definitely can't hold a candle to any one of ny's tens of thousands of pizza joints.  the people behind the counter though couldn't care less about being polite to the customers, but im ok with that, as im in and out pretty quickly.
author: Julia B.

description: What the hell?  The stoned dude behind the counter must've knocked half a pound of Kraft cheddar onto my pizza.  It was inedible.
author: Matt F.

description: Growing up in NY, I'm always on the search for a great slice - I heard arinell was the place .  Well, after a couple of visits, I'm done with place- Its so disgusting behind the counter I'm surprised the health dept hasn't close them down yet!  And the guys that work behind the counter have the hygiene of a crackhead.  To top it off, a couple of them were spotted at Dolores park recently, throwing their empty colt45 bottles in the park and then tagging the big green dumpster in the middle of park.  I'll never touch another thing that those hands have been on.
author: J P.

description: Reasonably close to NY style pizza.  And I love that its so dirty in there.  It adds some edge and intrigue to the experience.
author: Brandyn B.

description: really good, cheap, greasy NY style pizza.  perfect for stopping in to get a slice, so you can walk around eating it looking for the next bar to go to.
author: Kate W.

description: best pizza slices in SF.  not where you take your girlfriend on your anniversary or bring a big group from out of town, as the interior consists of six stools and a counter, but if you are craving a huge thin-crust NYC style pizza with tasty sauce and lots of cheese, $2.75 is your ticket to heaven.  also, if you like Corrosion of Conformity you are in luck, because them or something similar seems to be playing on their stereo anytime i come in here.
author: Daryl F.

description:
very good pie.  no bullshit, like the other pizza places in my neighborhood.  the dough is always just right and their sauce is pretty good.  

can't beat $2.50 a slice.
author: Vinyl J.

description: I got totally ripped off.  $29 for a medium pizza and coke?  And to top it off, pizza was mediocre.
author: Susan C.

description: Arinell is a "slice" of heaven in the Mission for two reasons. You can 1.) shut up all of your east coast friends who continually complain "there is no good pizza in San Francisco and 2.) get a kick ass slice!
author: Jeff B.

description: The ultimate Mission pizza experience- you wonder when the guy behind the counter last bathed, and you can play connect-the-dots with the tracks on his arms or the gaps between his teeth, but you can get a great slice of crisp, thin crust pizza in moments to satisfy that cholesterol urge. Theme music is punk or metal blasting from a tinny speaker.
author: Alexander A.

description: hungry. beered up. tired from a hectic work week. stumbled into arinell's for a quick bite and got a plain ol' slice of cheese pizza. delicious, piping hot and just the ticket to stave off hunger pangs. the man behind the counter was nice, courteous and efficient. just what i like in my pizza peeps. and for $2.75 a slice? NICE.
author: ray e.

description: mmmm... pizza... Homer's got his donuts, but I've got my slice of Arinell's. The place is seriously dirty though. I have no idea how they got a perfect score from the health department. Wish list: more drink choices, stay open later, and maybe shirtless worker boys? I mean if you're gonna be that dirty you might as well go all the way!
author: Dan K.

description: punk rock pizza and good to boot! i'd totally hang out there if i were still in high school and think it was the coolest place ever.
author: devildoll d.

description: i love reading the reviews on here about how this place is in the bowels of hipster hell. you know what marina sweet bras, stay in yer own neighbourhood and give us back our mission. i'm sick of running into your untucked armani dress shirt lame arses. oh and go to fugging cable car and leave arinells to me. it's good shite ... and this coming from an east coaster too.
author: James J.

description: i go here when i am just craving a nice slice of cheese pizza.  i walk past two other pizza by the slice places on my way, it's that good.  i forgive them the dirty insides and the slightly sullen/grumpy staff just because i really really like the cheese pizza here.  for fancy pants toppings i go elsewhere, but for just a slice of plain greasy cheese goodness.....this is the place.
author: amanda d.

description: Closest to Jersey pizza I have had so far in SF. They advertise no salt other than whats needed to rise the dough - but I wish they added a little extra. Grab a slice of plain, some tissues for dabbing, toss on a bit of salt, some parm, and a little garlic and I'm a little closer to nirvana.
author: Nors P.

description: this is a hole int he wall if i ever saw one. i love all pizzas. but the reasons why this is one of the best ones i've ever had is the thin crust and the simple but perfect proportion of cheese to sauce. man. i wish i got a second slice. also reading other people's reviews made me expect the people who worked there to be dirty hippies. i did not think so. they just looked like guys who know how to make good pizza. and have long hair and beat up t-shirts and jeans.
author: Tin-Tin E.

description: Nice little place to stop in and get some tasty slices of thin-crust pizza. Nothing fancy, just good pizza!
author: Gregory G.

description: i don't think you'll find a better slice of pizza for $2.25.  not a whole lot of seating though.
author: Zoe L.

description: for SF, this is a pretty good attempt at NY-style pizza. it's fast, pretty cheap, and if you get a fresh pie, it's pretty damn good.
author: Sidney B.

description: The best NY style pizza in SF, imo. Could eat half a pie by myself, yum.
author: Tina K.

description: the pizza here is great!  the closest to new york style i've found in SF (and i'm from NY), but admittedly i haven't gone pizza-tasting all over the city yet.  since they're in an area with lots of bars, I would love it if they stayed open past midnight.    either way, i'm glad they're around.
author: Akshay S.

description: as an east coaster on the west coast, who loves new york style pizza, this place is a godsend.  it's the closest thing i have found in san francisco to the real thing.
author: amanda w.

description: Thinnest of thin crust pizza - new yorkers and all the "other" people in the world can rejoice. For people who normally douse slices w/crushed red peppers, check out the jalapeno peppers instead.
author: J K.

description: of course my favorite thin-crust pizza is a joint called grupo in the east village (ny), but arinell's is what tides me over until my next trip back east for a thin crust.  an honest and simple thin crust slice of pepperoni is all this junkfoodie needs sometimes and this is where i get it.
author: cat c.

description: pretty close to NYC pizza.  dirty and greasy.  great for pre/post evening snack
author: Erika Y.

description: the establishment was crowded, and the pizza was burnt, floppy, and greasy.  after 4 vodka sodas however, i have very low standards when it comes to my pizza or my men (both of which give me problems the morning after).
author: Katherine K.

description: I ate a lot of pizza in my years in new york, and frankly this place didn't measure up in my book.  Maybe this is how they do it in brooklyn, but this pizza can't compete with my top 10 favorites in manhattan.  I decided to seek out this place based on a lot of rave reviews, but I'd say that it was just OK.  Perhaps the pizza is better at night, as one other review says.  I went early in the day and the pizza on the counter looked old, dry and downright unappetizing.
author: D W.

description: For 3$, my garlic quarter-of-a-pizza slice was the perfect stomach-filler before getting obliterated.
author: emilie k.

description: this place is the greasy, cheesy goodness. the cheese is just salted and the slices nice and big. man, if they only delivered! it seems like everyone is a pizza zealot, but this will most likely please all of you and them.
author: matt n.

description: I don't know why you guys say the people that work at Arinell's have "meth-addict teeth" just because they don't have dentists. And I know for a fact they CAN afford cocaine and you can fold the pizzas in half and they don't break. But they do listen to the weirdest music known to man. IT'S PIZZA!!!
author: Lindsay P.

description: This is Great NY Style Solid pizza.  Good toppings, decent sausage, good calzone's.  The dressing on the salads suck, but whatever.  A little expensive but it's rotation worthy
author: Ron B.

description: It is what it claims - NY style.  Coming from a native NY'er, it's a big compliment.  I didn't believe them until I had my first bite.  The dripping orange oil, oozing, chewy mozzarella, and tasty tomato sauce - I felt like I was at the old neighborhood pizzeria.  The crust is thinner and crispier than a typical NY slice, but I like it that way.
author: Lisa F.

description: i thought there was no pizza on the west coast after trying a different place everytime for 3 years. i mean i really was sure that what i was looking for did not exist here. yes, there had been 1 other place but it was on the gourmet/heirloom/organic side and i needed an everyday, by-the-slice,  no bells or whistles place. someone told me about Arinell and i didn't expect that they would be EXACTLY what i mean when i say pizza. but they were and i am so happy to have them! the only place so far that learned how to do it the way it was meant to be done. thin, tasty crust. thin, mild and flavorful sauce. and a perfect amount of cheese.
author: p. w.

description: pretty good for the west coast Arinell...but not quite Ny city grade yet.
author: Andy D.

description: LOVE IT.  the best pizza in SF.  true NY thin crust, big slice style.   and you can't beat the weird punk, we don't care about making money vibe.
author: Dan Y.

description: I don't go out for pizza anymore. I prefer to make it at home but when I do eat pizza I eat Arinell's. It's the best 'NY' slice in SF.
author: Petolo S.

description: Just moved to SF from Boston, where there is an abundance of great pizza..  when escape from NY was opined as the best pizza in town from my very reputable friend who earned is credentials being born and raised on the border of NY and Jersey I was very concerned with my future consumption, until I went to Arinell Pizza.  Where this place falls short is the exorbitant cost for a large pie.  $20 for crust, sauce, and cheese is still too high for me.  Perhaps I need to adjust my cost-of-living to accept this, who knows.
author: Interphace C.

description: Well there good, and there not pretentious, and they don't attract tourist.
author: Tedster H.

description: Pretty classic after reading the other reviews, I too am a Jersey native, this pizza hands down is the best one you will have outside the Tri-State area (NY, NJ and Conn for those of you who don't know that). It's not fancy but it's taste delicious! We once did a taste test, had pizza in NYC, got off the plane and came right to Arinells, very comparable!
author: Nichole G.

description: Piping hot, melty cheese pizza with thin perfectly crispy crust. The whole thing practically melts in your mouth. Cute metalhead/surfer type guys serving it up. Not to mention heavy metal playing most times. Ample toppings. If I'm walking down Valencia and starving, a slice or two at Arinell is the best thing ever. Chowing down on that while listening to "Wanted Dead or Alive" is pretty much heaven. Docked one star because they sometimes serve with bare hands, though it's really just part of the whole seedy ambience.
author: Meg B.

description: got a plain slice: not enough sauce and crust was crispy to the point of being dry, no orange grease, not like NY. also, how do SFers live with $2.50 for a cheese slice?  that's one dollar too much.
author: d p.

description: By SF standards this is the best pizza in town.  Thin NY style that beats any of the California style imposters.  No goat cheeze or artichoke hearts on this pie!  You can add toppings but I recommend going with the slice of cheeze.   Great vibe to the place.  Only bummed out once when the tattooed punk rocker behind the counter had a wet hacking cough.  Also, it's a small place but that's why God gave you legs and the ability to walk and chew at the same time.
author: Ken P.

description: i'm from new york and this is pretty good new york pizza for sf.  it ain't totally legit new york pizza.  but it'll do fine in a pinch.  i have cravings that i cannot deny.  while i try, and do so with mixed emotions and low expectations, occasionally i must indulge myself and try to satiate.
author: Nathan Z.

description: Great new york style pizza.  Very satisfying.  Get a slice or a whole pie.  Too bad they don't deliver.  It's really hard to find parking at times when you pick it up yourself.  But I still think it's worth it.
author: N T.

description: Yeah, this is the shit... relatively.  It's not Fancy Brick Oven Pancetta yadda yadda but it's as close to late-night East Coast slices as you're going to get around here.  Minus two stars for no delivery and closing before a toddler's bedtime.  You're on a big nightlife block, stay the fuck open and make some money after last call!
author: Ludwig S.

description: Overrated. As an East Coast transplant, I can say with reasonable certainty that the only thing the West does not do better is pizza. And this place, which advertises itself as authentic New York style, does not really get it right. Also minus to the unfriendly staff, annoying clientle, and death metal that was blaring in the background. It's like their trying to keep the customers away.
author: Jeremy J.

description: The best slice of pizza in California. If you're looking for "real" New York pizza, this is it. Now if I could just find a New York bagel I'd be set...
author: Justin L.

description: mixed feelings about this place. i used to love it, but the last couple times i came away disappointed.
author: John L.

description: you know something is going on when you see a guy getting a pie and grabbing a cab to take it home, can someone ask these guys to deliver? probably the best pizza in the city
author: Ron F.

description: getting a slice of pizza here and comparing it to NYC is like going to NYC and getting a burrito and comparing it to here. anyways yes this is the closest thing you are gonna get to being a NY slice. it's always  good and worth dealing with those shitheads behind the counter. not all of them are shitheads depending on how many of there hipster friends are in there with them. would give them 5 except for that. so check it out
author: Ausewaldoe J.
